PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) at the request of Senator Kemp, agreed to:

That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974 , the Senate approves the proposal by the National Capital Authority, on behalf of the Department of Communications and the Arts as managers of the Old Parliament House, for minor refurbishment works to Old Parliament House.
Consideration resumed from 1 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering sheet 4, opposition amendments 269, 269A, 270, R271 and R272.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I would suggest that, if there is something else we can move to, it might be appropriate to do so in terms of the amendments before us. I think amendments 269, 269A, 270, R271 and R272 in many respects are technical, and I do not know that they have been fully circulated at this stage. I can probably speak to them while you are trying to find other work.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of 270 in particular, we are trying to ensure there is capacity for a dual stream registration test. Given the fact that Senator Minchin is not here, I think at this particular stage we should defer these amendments. Lots of them are consequential, and I would like to get further advice as to which ones we need to pursue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about 273, 274 and 353?
—I think we can go with those. We have had a debate with respect to them; I do not need to add any more at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I move:
(273) Schedule 2, item 63, page 198 (after line 22), after subsection (2), insert:

PARA.TAB: (2A) In reviewing the decision of the Registrar, the Federal Court:

TAB.TAB: (a) must consider any material that was properly before the Registrar; and

(b) may, if it thinks fit, admit and consider such other material provided to it as could properly have been considered by the Registrar if it had been provided to him or her at the appropriate time, whether or not it was available to the party tendering it at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: (274) Schedule 2, item 63, page 198 (after line 25), at the end of section 190D, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) If the Registrar gives a notice in accordance with paragraph 190A(2A)(c), the applicant may apply to the Federal Court for a review of the decision not to register the claim.

(5) An applicant referred to in subsection (4) may, before the end of the period of 3 months after the notification day specified in the section 29 notice, request the Federal Court to make an order extending that period.
(6) In considering a request referred to in subsection (5), the Federal Court must make an order extending the period unless it is satisfied that:

TAB.TAB: (a) the claimant does not have a reasonably arguable case for the registration of the claim in relation to the area to which the notice under section 29 applies; and
(b) there are reasonable grounds to believe that the Government party or the grantee party would suffer unjustifiable hardship if the period were extended.

PARA.TAB: (7) If the Court makes such an order, the Court:

TAB.TAB: (a) must give directions as to the manner in which consideration is to be given to the registration of the application so as to ensure, as far as reasonably practicable, that that consideration can be done within the extended period; and
(b) may, at any time:
(i) revoke the order if it is satisfied that the applicant has unreasonably failed to comply with any directions given; or
(ii) extend the period further if it is satisfied that it is reasonable to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: (353) Schedule 5, item 11, page 331 (line 16) to page 335 (line 11), omit subitems (3) to (11), substitute:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Application accepted for registration after 27 June 1996

PARA.TAB: (3) If an application was registered after 27 June 1996 in relation to land or waters that have not been the subject of a notice under section 29 of the old Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act or old Act, the relevant Minister of the State or Territory in which the land or waters are situated may request the Registrar to deal with the application or any part of it under the new Act.
(4) If the Registrar agrees to accept the request under subitem (3) or a part of it, the Registrar must:

TAB.TAB: (a) refer the request to the applicant and the representative body for the area concerned; and

(b) advise the applicant and the representative body that the representative body may, within 60 days after the request is referred, certify in accordance with its certification functions (see section 203BE) the application or part identified by the Registrar (subject to any amendment made by the applicant and considered by the representative body); and

(c) if the application or part is not certified by the representative body within that period, or within a further period agreed between the Registrar and the representative body—consider the application under section 190A of the new Act.

PARA.TAB: (5) If, at the commencement of this Act, there is more than one application on the Register in relation to the same area of land or waters, the Registrar must:

TAB.TAB: (a) consider whether the native title rights and interests claimed may consistently be held by different native title groups; and
(b) as soon as reasonably practicable, advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of his or her view and of the reasons for that view; and

(c) request them to provide information and submissions as to whether it is appropriate for the expeditious conduct of the applications and the processes of the Act that the applications be amalgamated in whole or in part; and
(d) consider any information or submissions supplied pursuant to the request, and
(e) determine whether it is appropriate for the applications to be amalgamated, in whole or in part.

PARA.TAB: (6) If the Registrar decides that it is appropriate that the applications be amalgamated, in whole or in part, the Registrar must:

TAB.TAB: (a) advise the applicants and the representative body or bodies for the area of that fact; and
(b) request the applicants to amend their applications so as to ensure that:
(i) rights and interests that are common between the groups are the subject of only one application; and
(ii) separate rights and interests are the subject of other applications;
but only to the extent that the native title group concerned in relation to the separate rights and interests is different from the native title group in relation to the common rights and interests.

PARA.TAB: (7) If the Registrar notifies the applicants and the representative body or bodies referred to in subitem (6):

TAB.TAB: (a) the applicants must, within 60 days after receiving the notification, advise the Registrar whether they have been able to reach agreement as to the identity of the appropriate applicant for those rights and interests and, if they have, advise the Registrar which single application is to remain on the Register in relation to those rights and interests; and

(b) if, within that period or a longer period allowed by the Registrar, the applicants have not reached agreement, the Registrar must advise the representative body for the relevant area of that fact.

PARA.TAB: (8) If the representative body receives an advice under paragraph (7)(b), it must attempt by conciliation to obtain agreement between the applicants as to the identity of the appropriate applicant, and the appropriate description of the native title group on whose behalf the application is made, for the rights and interests.

TAB.TAB: (a) the representative body is not able to achieve a resolution within 6 months of the matter being referred to it by the Registrar; and
(b) either:
(i) it is satisfied that a resolution is not likely to be achieved within a reasonable time; or

(ii) a notice under section 29 of the new Act, or a corresponding provision of a law of a State or Territory covered by a determination under subsection 43(1) of the new Act, is lodged in relation to any part of the land or waters concerned;
the representative body must refer the matter to the arbitral body within 14 days.

PARA.TAB: (10) If the representative body does not refer the matter to the arbitral body, any applicant may do so.
(11) If the matter is referred to the arbitral body, the arbitral body must determine:

TAB.TAB: (a) which applicant is to act for the whole of the area covered by the applications in relation to which common rights and interests are claimed (if that applicant consents to act); and

(b) redefine the native title group so that, to the greatest extent possible, those who were otherwise covered by the overlapping applications are members of the native title group of the remaining application.

PARA.TAB: (11A) If, under this item, a particular applicant and a set of native title rights and interests are defined, the Registrar must amend one application accordingly and remove the other applications from the Register or amend them so that they are limited to rights and interests not the subject of the common application.

(11B) If a notice is given under section 29 before the Register is varied under subitem (11A), except with the consent of the negotiation parties (which for this purpose includes each of the native title parties at the date on which the section 29 notice was given) the negotiations must not commence, and the relevant period specified in section 35 does not commence to run.
(11C) If an application is required to be dealt with under subitems (3) and (4), and subitem (5), it should be dealt with first under subitem (5).

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I suggest that we put the amendments individually. Proposed amendment 273 clarifies the power of the Federal Court regarding material on which the court may base its decision when reviewing a decision of the registrar. Basically, it will allow the court to pick up information and material that may not have been available to the registrar, so it is a minor amendment. In this sense it is an important one in that it makes the court process a bit more comprehensive.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed amendment 274 gives the power to the Federal Court to extend the statutory period for the registration of applications on two conditions: if the court is of the view that the claimant has a reasonably arguable case, and, as importantly, if the court is also of the view that the opposing side will not suffer unjustifiable hardship. We say that is a bit of a balance to ensure protection for both sides. We argue that obviously in some circumstances there is a need for the extension of the statutory period. As I said last night, the period as now proposed is excessively rigid and, through no fault of the claimant, the claimant could find themselves struck out because of the activities of someone else, particularly the tribunal. The transitional application is one that was also canvassed broadly last night.

Proposed amendment 353 is an amendment which deals with the application of the new registration test to applications lodged after 27 June 1996, which, as I said last night, is the date upon which the government announced that the new registration test was to take effect.

The process that we are proposing in amendment 353 provides for the appropriate minister to request that the registrar apply the new registration test to applications lodged after 27 June. In the first instance, the registrar must give representatives of claimants and rep bodies the opportunity to comply with the new test, but only for 60 days when the registrar will then assess the application against the new test, if there is a need for him to do so.

The other point we were making last night was that in respect of the registration test it is important that, if we are to go back past the end of June last year, then we will be constitutionally secure in terms of what we are doing. We claim that the government's proposal is retrospective and discriminatory and is possibly at the end of the day either invalid or compensable.

The proposal we are suggesting is for the registrar to involve the rep bodies and give them six months to try and get a conciliation of all the common rights of interest and make them subject to one application. If that does not happen within that period, then the National Native Title Tribunal or, if there is a state or territory body, that body will arbitrate the amalgamation applications.

We think that is a practical way to go, particularly given the amount of work the tribunal will be doing over the next six months anyway. It is a practical way to go. It involves the parties. Basically, it can get the rep bodies to do a lot of the work of the tribunal. But, if the work is not done in a timely manner—and six months is not a long time given the numbers of applications we might be talking about here—then the tribunal can intervene and ensure a conciliation process. All these proposals are put up in the interests of workability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I did comment on these amendments yesterday, but the government is unable to accept them. Amendment 273 relates to the review by the Federal Court and we have an appropriate review section in 190D where an applicant may apply to the Federal Court for effectively judicial review. The effect of the opposition's amendment would be to allow the court itself to remake the registrar's decision and put itself in the place of registrar in determining whether a claim had met the registration test. We think this would amount to a proposal that would add considerable uncertainty, be inappropriate legally and procedurally and should be unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: Also amendment 274 allows the applicant to apply to the Federal Court for an extension of time for registration after the issue of a section 29 notice. Again, this is nothing more than a recipe for tremendous uncertainty in that it can significantly delay the whole right to negotiate process. If you are talking about multimillion dollar proposals where you want to get the negotiation process under way, see if agreement can be reached and, if not, go to arbitration, this allows an enormous opportunity to stall and delay the whole process.

It is not provided for in the current Native Title Act and there is no such mechanism. It was not thought appropriate then. Why is the ALP now wanting to insert such a proposal which does not go to its professed standard of certainty, but will simply produce enormous uncertainty for those seeking to invest in this country?

We have extended the registration period by our own amendments, which we think will satisfy the obvious desirability of native title parties having appropriate time to have their claims registered. But we do not believe that the Federal Court having the capacity to have a full hearing and then extend the time period is conducive to anybody's interests.

In relation to amendment 353 concerning the application of the registration test, there is no point in the new registration test if most of the claims currently in the system are not tested in some way or another. Already nearly 50 per cent of country has been claimed, so we are whistling in the wind if we talk about a new registration test exempting one way or another most of the current claims from it when a section 29 notice is issued.

Effectively we introduced this new registration test back in June last year and made the statement then that claims made after that date would be subject to the new registration test, so there is no retrospectivity in that sense. That is the way governments operate in many fields of endeavour. Where the legislation is introduced, notice is given and claims or activities made after that date are subject to the new test. In relation to claims made before that date, it is not at all inappropriate that, where a section 29 notice is issued after the commencement of these provisions, an existing claim is then subject to that new registration test in respect of a section 29 notice issued after the commencement of these provisions.

That seems to us again not to entail any retrospectivity. The claim is there and of course the claim can proceed as a claim for determination of native title. But as to the appropriate registration of the claim in response to a section 29 notice, it does not seem at all inappropriate that, when the notice is issued after the commencement of these provisions, the new test is then applied to that claim to determine whether the claimants may be parties to the negotiation in relation to that section 29 notice.

Otherwise the test is not going to be applied to many of the claims already in the system and not solve the problem which we thought the ALP agreed needed to be solved. For those reasons, as I think I said yesterday, we cannot accept those amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a strange response from the minister. It is a curious one, because I do not know whether he actually understands what we are doing or trying to do, or in fact wants to admit that there are some deficiencies in his own proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us take the last point first. We have no problem with the starting date for the test being 27 June 1996. We have said that, but what we say is that our provision to go back before that date is a much broader one than the government's. His does not pick up cross claims. He does not pick up comprehensively the question of overlaps. He picks up some in respect to those where the section 29 process is initiated, but what we say is that our process is there to pick up all cross claims and all overlapping claims prior to 27 June 1996.

I do not know what the problem is in trying to do that. We are trying to do it and we are trying to do it in a way which we think is constitutionally sustainable by involving the rep bodies in the process first. If they cannot get people to sit together and conciliate it, then after 60 days—in this broader category, not just the section 29 overlaps—the tribunal can get into the action and conciliate.

If you are really concerned about overlapping claims, the WA goldfields and so on, the government would be looking at our proposal, because it is broader. It catches more than the government's and, in the way that we propose it, it is constitutionally sustainable.

BREAK.PARA: The other point the minister makes is, why bring in the court process now? In that argument he wants to have it both ways. He says, `They bring in the court process' and fair enough they do, but then he says, `But you cannot bring in the capacity to go to court.' Why not? We are actually saying that the court process should be used for particularly good reasons—for example, where there are allegations of fraud or so on. We think where it is necessary—and we are not suggesting it as a broad measure—it is important to invoke the capacity to go to the court.

The minister says, `Well, it was not in your act, so why are you bringing it in now?' The experience over the last few years, as we all recognise, has been that there have been overlapping claims and cross claims. We think it is important now that we comprehensively try and tackle that.
Senator Minchin interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are doing it much more comprehensively than you do, Senator Minchin, which is why I cannot really understand why you are bucking at these proposals. We say that, because of that experience, let us give a capacity to the system in a more comprehensive way to fix up the overlaps and cross claims, and also give the court a role as well—a very limited role, but one which will be particularly available to the respondents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of comments on this. As Senator Bolkus has said, the government's amendments seek to apply the new more onerous registration test to claims currently on the register of claims.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that is an enormous and largely unnecessary task, and, in promoting the National Indigenous Working Group amendments, we are focusing on those instances where registration via a low threshold test may have caused problems. For example, overlapping claims in response to section 29 notices and we have all recognised that.

The Democrat‐Greens (WA) amendment 328 deals with the retrospective review of overlapping claims and claims which are identified by the appropriate minister as potentially not satisfying the new test. The process provides in the first instance for reconsideration of claims by the applicants and representative bodies. If this does not achieve a result within a specified period, the registrar will be able to assess the claims against the new test.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate that obviously amendment 273 of the opposition and amendment 244 of the Democrats‐Greens (WA) are the same. There are identified conflicts with Democrat‐Greens (WA) amendments 245 and 328. I would have to say that, from the Greens (WA) point of view, none of these amendments represent our ideal position. However, we have been given to understand that the differences between the compromised position of National Indigenous Working Group and Labor amendments 274 and 353 are not such as to cause major problems. If the ALP's amendments 274 and 353 go first, then it will not make any difference to my voting pattern. I will be prepared to support either opposition amendments 274 and 353 or, of course, the amendments we have put up, 245 or 328, along with amendment 273.

—Can I ask one question in relation to section 129D of the bill where the Federal Court may review a decision. I asked this question yesterday and I am not sure if it was made clear. Is that a rehearing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a rehearing of them. That is what we see as the unfortunate effect of the ALP amendment. This is normal judicial review of a decision made by an administrative body. This is an administrative decision as to whether a claim is registered and, as with all administrative decisions, they are subject to judicial review. That is what 190D provides for, but we do not believe you should put the court in the position of actually standing in the place of the registrar and applying the registration test itself, which is what we see as the effect of the opposition amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not quite read that way, does it? Section 190D says:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Registrar does not accept the claim for registration, the Registrar must, as soon as practicable, give the applicant and the Federal Court written notice of his or her decision not to accept the claim, including a statement of the reasons for the decision.

Then it applies for review. That seems to me to be more than simply reviewing it on the law. It seems to be reviewing it on the facts as well. If that is so, it seems that we might be fighting about matters that are already in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Cooney, is right we would not need the opposition amendments. Certainly, it is our policy intent that, as is always the case, administrative decisions can be judicially reviewed by a court and that is what is provided. They may apply to the Federal Court for a review of the registrar's decision according to normal court‐based review mechanisms, which review the legality of the decision and whether it was done in accordance with the law, and do not go to the actual facts or merits of the claim.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is clear on the face of it what is intended there. It clearly does not meet with what the ALP seeks, but we think there is not merit in what the official opposition amendment seeks to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Paragraph 358 of the explanatory memorandum explains the government's point of view and explains the legislation before us. Obviously, in one sense, a substantial amendment is being put forward by the opposition, and by the Democrats. I would like the minister to briefly address the question of overlapping claims and indicate to the committee how a resolution can best be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: You are not going to achieve a resolution ultimately until the claims are determined pursuant to legislation. I know that. The opposition is suggesting that the representative bodies have a role to play at this particular point in time—that is to say, in respect of applications that have been made previous to the date of the operation of this piece of legislation. I would be grateful if the minister could address that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the registration test, at 190C(3) of the bill, we have provided as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) The Registrar must be satisfied that no person included in the native title claim group for the application . . . was a member of the native title claim group for any previous application. . .

The problem of overlapping claims is a serious one. We have sought to address it in the registration test so that the registrar is acting to minimise the extent to which there are overlapping claims, without prejudicing anyone independently making a separate claim, but to avoid the problem whereby people are making multiple claims when they are in the same claim group—they are in one claim group and in another claim group. Clause 190C(3) was designed to prevent that.

In terms of our much upgraded rep body provisions, we have also sought to ensure that rep bodies have a primary role in this. Under 203BE(3) we talk about `overlapping applications for determination of native title' in relation to the rep bodies' responsibilities to minimise that problem. The trouble with the ALP's approach of saying, in relation to claims already lodged before 27 June 1996, `Let's throw that back into the arms of the rep bodies to see if they can work it out,' is that up to this point that clearly has not happened.

For example, the Goldfields Land Council has used its best endeavours to try to seek some resolution of the enormous problem it has there, but it has no legislative backing or capacity because of the current registration test. There is no capacity for them, as a matter of law or direction, to achieve that outcome. It is all based on good faith and goodwill. There are break‐outs on many occasions.

We think it is perfectly proper that if a new registration test has been designed it should apply to claims already in the system, but only when a new section 29 notice is issued. It is not retrospective in that sense. The registration test is for parties wishing to be involved in the right to negotiate process in response to section 29 notices, so the test will only apply in respect of section 29 notices issued after these provisions come into effect. The claimants in the system would then need to satisfy the registrar of the new registration test in order to participate in the right to negotiate in respect of the new section 29 notices.

We think that is the only sensible way to ensure that you minimise the number of frivolous or vexatious claims, or those of less worth, that are involved in the right to negotiate process so that the parties that are involved are those that are able to satisfy the new registration test and, therefore, parties with the greatest likelihood of ultimately succeeding in their native title claims and, therefore, the most appropriate to be parties to the negotiation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin has once again confirmed the problem that we are trying to fix up. Your range is limited to section 29 activated processes. There are a lot more than that that can be fixed up. We recognise that there is no legislative backing for the rep bodies to do anything now, and that is precisely why we have come up with this regime.

SPEECH.PARA: The regime is one which gives the rep bodies very little time, but the compulsion is the fact that if the rep bodies do not work it out within six months, then the tribunal can conciliate and arbitrate. That sort of time‐line compulsion is not in the current legislation. If it were there, it would put pressure on the parties to conciliate under the auspices of the rep bodies, because they would know that if they did not there is a next step under our proposal.

Having that sort of threat down the line—I suppose that is the best way to put it—would put pressure on parties to conciliate before it got to the tribunal. There is an enormous amount of work here. If you left it all to the tribunal, it would take an inordinate amount of time. If parties are forced to confront the issue under the auspices of the rep body—and they are being forced to confront the issue—that would be conducive to reducing overlap. If they do not, then two months later, the tribunal can get into the game and conciliate, and determine an outcome.

We pick up the problem that you see in the existing legislation and try to solve that by putting in a process with very firmly set guidelines which will be the inducement on parties to come together. I ask you to reconsider your position on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Considering that there is a new registration test, can the minister explain, in particular in relation to the extra work associated with the new registration test, what additional funds will be available to the Native Title Tribunal and to the rep bodies—and perhaps he could remind the Senate how many rep bodies there are—in order to deal with the new registration test requirements?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure how many rep bodies there are currently, but new provisions are in place, which we will come to next, in relation to the recognition of rep bodies under the new arrangements. We will discuss that in the next block of amendments. All I can do is remind you that the current annual funding by taxpayers through the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is $40 million. I have told you that before. In anyone's terms, that is a considerable sum of money, and it is an increase from the $25 million that it was in the financial year in which we came to office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Native Title Tribunal is funded through the Attorney‐General's Department. The tribunal has grown significantly in the time it has been operating. It continues to grow, and it continues to receive increased funding. I think it is currently receiving about $20 million a year. Obviously, the government is sensitive to the demands placed upon the tribunal. That is a matter which is considered in the budgetary context in relation to the Attorney‐General's portfolio.

BREAK.PARA: The Native Title Tribunal needs to be funded adequately to meet all its obligations, remembering that now, as a result of the agreed approach to this, its determination function is performed by the Federal Court. The Federal Court is funded through the Attorney‐General's Department, so the tribunal is legally losing a big chunk of its responsibility in that sense. It is responsible for mediation and for administering the right to negotiate, and not for determinations, which is a function which passes to the Federal Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —If any group of people in Australia is good at working through conflicts and working to reach consensus, it is probably Aboriginal Australians, because they do that constantly. However, considering the cultural sensitivities, there will need to be extra time, effort and resources to enable those decisions to be reached in an appropriate way, as far as possible before they reach the Native Title Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, my reading of what you just said is that you believe that what exists with the rep bodies is enough, even though we know that funding for ATSIC has decreased and its contribution has not been able to keep up with demands and necessary expenditure. You have indicated that you are potentially flexible on increasing funds for the Native Title Tribunal. Can you guarantee to the Senate that, given the extra demands we are talking about today, you will be open to providing the extra funding for the Native Title Tribunal which it is likely to need?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter for the Commonwealth government's budgetary processes each year, but each year in his cabinet budget submission the Attorney‐General submits to the cabinet the appropriation which he believes is necessary or desirable for areas of his portfolio. The tribunal is obviously a critical part of his portfolio. That is reviewed annually, and he submits the request for the appropriate appropriation to run the tribunal.

BREAK.PARA: I cannot tell you off the top of my head what has been happening, but I am aware that the funding to the tribunal has been increasing in line with its increasing role and responsibilities. I do not think anybody envisaged that it would have 667 claims before it within four years of its creation and, as I understand it, something in excess of $20 million. All I can tell you is that that is a matter for annual review.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure Senator Bolkus will want to say more about this as well, but I remind you that, under the ALP's amendment, it is allowing six months for Aboriginal people to sort through these issues themselves in a way that they feel is appropriate. That is not what you are providing. You are building in extra unnecessary pressures for the tribunal.

—If Senator Minchin wants to answer that question, he can answer it in the context of my question as well. You talk about 667 existing claims. How long do you calculate it will take the tribunal to handle those existing claims in respect to these provisions alone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I cannot put a time frame on that. I cannot tell you how many days or months it will take. This is all about the issue of section 29 notices in respect of land over which there are claims. Do not ask me to forecast what section 29 notices will be made on what land, whether there are native title claims on it and how difficult it will be to apply the test. We will make sure that it is adequately resourced.

SPEECH.PARA: You are making proposals in relation to the claims that were lodged up until 27 June 1996. Presumably, the rep bodies have had years to try to seek some resolution of those claims and to merge or amalgamate the claims. That has not happened. We hope it will happen in the future to ensure that this process works in relation to any future section 29 notices, rather than apply the rigour of a new registration test when a section 29 notice is issued after these provisions take effect.

BREAK.PARA: We hope they will do what they have not done over the last three or four years and seek some resolution of these overlapping multiple claims. It seems to me to be a wing and a prayer rather than a rigorous application of an appropriate procedure to ensure that bona fide claims are dealt with in the negotiation process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not revisit the whole debate but say that, you know and we know, that up until now the rep bodies have not had any real driving capacity to ensure an outcome. If you adopt our process, they will have that. It will be quite apparent all the way through the process to claimants that, at the end of 60 days, if they do not conciliate under the auspices of the rep body, there will be a process involving the tribunal which will eradicate the overlapping. They have not had that in the past, but I will not go into that again.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, how do you justify saying that 60 days is too long, or having the rep bodies playing a role for 60 days is a delaying tactic, when you yourself do not know how long it is going to take the tribunal to handle the existing 667 claims in respect of overlapping? You have no idea how long it is going to take. You can be sure it is going to take more than a couple of months. Why do you reject out of hand a proposal which would facilitate the work of the tribunal in that period and after it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the minister is seeking advice on that, perhaps I can add another layer to that. It is largely the government which is saying that multiple claims are a problem. It is the Senator Boswell approach of `How dare Aboriginal people have more than one claim on one area' with no real knowledge of the cultural and social basis of multiple claims. There are instances I know of where the company itself has been involved with cowboy practices and has engaged in actions that have encouraged multiple claims because they were not really prepared to sit down and negotiate through the issues. It left it open in that they required people on receipt of a lump of money to sign off their ability to claim.

SPEECH.PARA: If the companies are acting in such a way, as they are, making it sensible for people within an area like the goldfields to engage in multiple claims, then maybe you should be sheeting some of your criticism home to some of the companies involved with their own, sometimes, cowboy approaches to the whole issue—that is, not sitting down and negotiating but just throwing out lumps of money and saying, `Sign away your rights.' That is the kind of issue that should be addressed. There is also the issue of the ability for rep bodies—not just land councils but corporations—to be able to sensibly deal with the issue and get the resources so they can get all the groups together and do their own negotiations.

If you are talking about time and money, which seems to be the main thing you are interested in, not Aboriginal rights, it would seem to me it would make a lot more sense to enable those issues to be dealt with by indigenous people themselves as far as possible. You will save both time and money for the taxpayer if you do. The time involved with a Native Title Tribunal ruling, especially when there is a backlog, is going to be considerable, as will be the money involved.

You are not serving anybody's interests by not providing both the resources and the time for indigenous people to deal as far as is possible with what many people consider is not a particular problem—that is, genuine multiple claims. Aboriginal people have had years and years of dealing with these kinds of issues. They believe they are the best people to sort out those issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you talk to the Goldfields Land Council and Aborigines in Kalgoorlie particularly, where this problem is massive, you will understand that Aboriginal people regard it as a massive problem.
—Yes, because the companies are acting like cowboys.

—Talk to Aboriginal people in Kalgoorlie and ask them what they think of this problem. I am trying to work out the complexity of the ALP's proposition. As I understand it, there is a 60‐day notice period and then the rep body has six months in which to see if it can reach a resolution, then refer it to the registrar. Presumably, the registrar then applies the old test to the claims. It seems to me that that is an enormous delaying mechanism.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that in respect of new section 29 notices issued in respect of claims lodged prior to 27 June 1996, and you might correct me if I am wrong, the existing non-test would apply. In the meantime, the whole right to negotiate process is put on hold. Your proposition will not achieve any resolution of the existing problems or a satisfactory resolution of a sensible right to negotiate a process where section 29 notices are issued in the future on land which already has claims on it.

I am advised that Justice French did give evidence before the parliamentary committee on behalf of the Native Title Tribunal that the tribunal believed that they had the resources and the capacity to deal with claims already in the system in respect of the new registration test. So there was no outcry from the tribunal about the application of these procedures and, of course, we have been very careful to consult with the tribunal in the preparation of all these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal by the ALP provides applicants 60 days after receiving the notification to try to reach an agreement. If it cannot be done within that time, it then goes to the registrar. That provides assistance for a further six months. In fact, what we are dealing with is a proposal that gives a total of eight months. That is not unreasonable considering the delays that may occur if it goes straight to the Native Title Tribunal and the zero time the government has allowed for agreement between bodies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to that, these provisions would set aside at least eight months before the right to negotiate process could commence, and that takes anything up to a year or longer. Correct me if I am wrong, Senator Bolkus, but I understand the effect of 11B is to effectively put the whole right to negotiate process on hold indefinitely. I am not sure that it would even limit it to the eight months if there was no agreement. In relation to section 29 notice proposals issued after these provisions come into effect, you would have the most extraordinary and completely unacceptable delays in the process. That is why we find this set of amendments unacceptable.

—Our 11B puts it back in the hands of the arbitral body. The arbitral body is the tribunal. Essentially, what we are reflecting there is what would happen if it went straight to the tribunal anyway? It would be at the direction of the tribunal as to how quickly the tribunal would be able to handle it, under your proposal and under ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Your 11B says:

SPEECH.PARA: If a notice is given under section 29 before the Register is varied . . . except with the consent of the negotiating parties (which for this purpose includes each of the native title parties at the date on which the section 29 notice was given)—
so they all have to agree—
the negotiations must not commence, and the relevant period specified in section 35 does not commence to run.
What does that really mean? When does the right to negotiate start? When can it start? Is there any sort of deadline or does this thing run on forever?

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, do groups have a right to negotiate upon registration? Is that correct?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Under our amendments, if a party is registered within that four-month period, then they are parties to the right to negotiate.

—Given that we are talking about people who have registered, then what you are saying—that it will take eight months before the groups have the right to negotiate—is incorrect. We are talking about groups who have registered. Therefore, once they have registered they have the right to negotiate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; I was talking about under our proposals and the application of the new registration test to claims already in the system in response to section 29 notices. There is a four‐month period—three months for the registration test to be applied and four months for registration—and then they are parties to the right to negotiate. In respect of the effect of opposition amendment No. 353, described as overlapping applications—and that refers to any claims already in the system that were lodged prior to 27 June 1996—that will set in train almost indefinite delays in seeking to determine which parties shall be parties to the right to negotiate. We think that is completely unacceptable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the points I made earlier in the debate was the question of the constitutionality of what you are proposing. We have not had a chance to address that this morning, but I think it is important that we do. I think the government acknowledges that what they are doing here is taking away an existing right. I would like to put on the record in this part of the debate the comments of Justice McHugh in the Waanyi case. It is important to put this before us because I think there are some real constitutional problems with what the government is proposing. What they are proposing takes away an existing right of any claimant. Mr Justice McHugh said the following on page 52 of that judgement:

SPEECH.PARA: To ignore the procedures of the Act and to determine the extinguishment issue before the Waanyi People had had an opportunity to utilise their rights under the Act would be both a breach of the Act and an injustice to the Waanyi People. To refuse to correct that breach because to do so would serve the social or economic interests of other persons would be a step calculated to undermine the rule of law in our community.
There are some pretty strong words here. He goes on:

BREAK.PARA: The community will quickly lose confidence in the courts of justice if a perception arises that the courts are ready to ignore the legal rights of individuals whenever intervening governments or litigants urge that public or private convenience requires such rights to be by‐passed.

Those comments could be made about the parliament as they could be made about the court. What we draw from those comments is a real concern from the bench about taking away people's property rights. What we are talking about in your reaching‐back provisions is taking away existing rights—the right to negotiate—by reassessing a claim which was lawfully lodged and accepted under the law. People exercise their rights under the law. They start off the process by putting their claims in. What you are saying is let us reach back and let us cut apart their legal capacity to pursue those claims because of the new test that you are proposing that we take back retrospectively to pre 27 June 1996.

That is the real problem you have with your proposal, putting aside time lines and whatever. Justice McHugh was not in the majority in many of these cases, but on this point he reflects probably a seven‐nil position of the court in respect of property rights. You have problems here. Why we say ours is better is because what we involve in the process is a capacity for consent. There is a capacity for the different parties in terms of overlapping claims to be brought together and to consent to an outcome. The aspect of consent is an important aspect when it comes to constitutionality. That has also been made very clear by the court.

Senator Minchin, the easy question to ask you is: have you had advice on the constitutionality of this point? Will you make that advice available? Don't you acknowledge that, by stripping away a pre‐existing property right, you would have constitutional problems?

Before you go to the question of legal advice, in the last couple of months we had the Newcrest case involving Coronation Hill in the Northern Territory where the court on a four to three majority found against the government. We have had the Mewett case—the Voyager case—where the court held seven‐nil that the sorts of rights to action that we are talking about here are property rights and cannot be taken away retrospectively, particularly in a racist manner which this proposal does.

What I say to you is that, on a constitutional basis, you have to look at our proposal because of the capacity to involve the claimants and to get consent through the process. If you do not do that, you have some problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I think sometimes we get so caught up with the legal arguments that we fail to acknowledge there are moral questions here as well. Many Aboriginal groups and representatives have spoken to me and have acknowledged that there are some difficulties with the process, but they have also told me it is a question of acknowledging the difficulties and requiring time to sort them out.

SPEECH.PARA: So we are not just dealing here with a legal right. Aboriginal people think the government is stripping back their rights. They see that there are problems in realising their rights under some of the current situations that have been created in the way the 1993 legislation was drafted, but they are asking—and I do not think it is an unreasonable thing—for the ability to sort this out. If we leave anything for indigenous Australians, we should at least acknowledge that right to sort out some of these difficulties so we cannot continue to point to them and blame them for any difficulties and hold-ups within the court system, because that is what has happened so far. There has been the creation of this blame, when in fact there are many people within indigenous Australia who wish to have the opportunity to sort out these difficulties for all concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The right to negotiate is a statutory procedural right, not a per se property right, and that is the government's clear view. What we are saying is that in respect of claims in the system where there is a new notice of an intention for an act that attracts the right to negotiate, then in future the new registration test shall apply. That is not retrospectivity or the denial of a right. The claim is in the system. The right to pursue the property right—that is, the common law right to native title—is not affected in anyway. It is a question of access to the statutory procedural right when a new act is given notice of under section 29. We do not accept this argument at all and, as you know, Senator Bolkus, the Solicitor-General has said that the bill is entirely constitutional—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, he does. You are laughing at Dr Gavan Griffith?
—He said that the outcome is uncertain, you know that.

—He did not say that. You read his advice. His advice is very clear and he says that the bill is constitutional. But even if that argument were sustainable or you were to accept it—that is, that a statutory procedural right could be argued to be an acquisition of property—by providing full, just terms compensation, which we do in the catch‐all provision in the bill, there is no question about any constitutionality. So the argument has no legs whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: What I do not understand is where the ALP is coming from. If you think your process will weed out, so to speak, the frivolous claims, will merge claims or will lead to a minimisation of the number of overlapping claims, then presumably there will be claimants who will, in effect, not be part of the claims process. So by your own argument, you condemn your own provisions. On the other hand, you are saying that all the multiple claims can and should be able to stay there. I think there is a convoluted logic in the argument you are putting in respect of your attempt to seek to rationalise the number of claims in the system.

All we are saying is that the common law right to claim native title remains. There is a statutory procedural right. The application of that in the future shall be subject to the new registration test. There are many instances at law where that would apply and I am just trying to think of equivalent procedures. For example, if you have a right to drive, then the laws relating to the exercise of that right change all the time and in the future that right is affected. That happens in a whole range of legal fields.

If the parliament deems that in future when an act giving rise to the right to negotiate is given notice of, it is quite appropriate for claims already in the system to be subject to a new threshold test. Otherwise, all the claims in the system up until June 1996 will forever be entitled to participate in the right to negotiate on any part of the land claim, and some of these claims cover huge parts of Queensland and other states. So whenever there is any mining development, they automatically participate in the right to negotiate, regardless of whether they are frivolous or otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, Minister, you have not really answered the question. Firstly, I asked you to take note of the fact that, when we talk about the right to negotiate, let us acknowledge that we are talking about a right that was traded and obtained when the Aboriginal communities cashed in some general common law rights in this area—the capacity, I suppose, under the common law to effectively drag out processes for a long time. There is a mixture here of a common law right and a statutory procedural right. If, for instance, people felt they had been unfairly denied a right under your proposal, they would be able to go to court for a claim in terms of a reduction of not only their statutory procedural right but also their common law right.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, you argue that we are convoluted, but I made the point—and for some reason you were not listening—that in these matters, as has been evidenced before both committees, the consent of the communities involved is fairly critical. What we do is put up a process whereby that consent can be obtained in the early parts of the process. That gives it some constitutional security.

In essence, I suppose we go back to the point that you are denying people and denying them retrospectively, whether it is a statutory right or the capacity to pursue their rights under this act. They can go alternatively to the common law. To the extent that it can be compensatable, it may very well be, but there are other questions of just terms compensation which also go to your regime here. As you full know, Justice Deane in the Tasmanian dams case indicated that there needs to be some contemporaneous aspect to the mechanism to provide for just terms compensation.
Another point needs to be made, and I will go back to Justice McHugh in the judgment of Waanyi where, a few paragraphs before the last section I quoted, he said:

No doubt some miners, pastoralists and other persons believe that the procedures of the Act are unfair, that they create uncertainty and delay that can force interested parties to buy off unmeritorious claims, and that they prevent or impede the exploitation of important national resources. But such beliefs are beside the point. Parliament has laid down the law. It has attached valuable rights to an accepted claim, rights that are exercisable by a claimant before the validity of the claim is judicially determined. The Act has given claims of native title an economic as well as a spiritual and physical dimension.

The court acknowledges that what we are talking about here are valuable property rights laid down by law. All we are asking is for you to treat them with the degree of legal and moral respect that you would have others treat any such rights that you might have in any process you may be involved with in respect of your property. Do not turn a blind eye to these constitutional and compensatory provisions. That is what we are asking of you. When you get a message from Justice McHugh saying that there are some real problems involved here, do not turn a blind eye to Justice McHugh because his position is one that is often quite critical in the court and he has made it very clear of what he thinks of the rights here. Once again, you are doing it unilaterally, from the top, taking away property rights and causing constitutional and compensation problems. We are suggesting to you a way through it and a way through it which should form the basis of a solution to this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all fascinated to know what sorts of deals were done back in 1993. You say now that the Aboriginal leaders you dealt with cashed in their common law rights in return for the right to negotiate. That is a quite extraordinary proposition. Are you suggesting that this parliament allowed a veto over the question of whether or not everything done prior to the Native Title Act was to be validated? The parliament had a clear responsibility—as you well know; you stated it many times—to ensure the legal validity of everything done prior to the Native Title Act, and you did it and you needed to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Talking of deals, we understand—and this has been stated many times—that a deal was done in relation to pastoral leases. There was an acknowledgment that native title had been extinguished on pastoral leases so, as part of the deal, you set up the Indigenous Land Fund to enable Aboriginal people to buy $45 million worth of pastoral leases every year forever. On current value, they could buy, as I understand it, every pastoral lease on Cape York in one year out of that deal. The land fund stays, but now we have native title on pastoral leases.

We have to deal with this in terms of the current problems caused by the operation of the Native Title Act—many of the problems which you have acknowledged. One of them is the extraordinary problem of multiple overlapping claims in respect of a whole lot of mining and exploration in this country—a lot of it not involving the BHPs and the Western Minings but the Jack Otways of the world that I mentioned yesterday.

What we are saying is that a statutory procedural right in the future should be accessed by an appropriate registration test—a registration test which, I accept through no fault of your own, was watered-down by a number of interpretations and court decisions about its operation. It is essential that a new registration test be put in place. It is not being applied retrospectively. It is being applied prospectively whenever a future section 29 notice is issued. It is entirely, as Justice McHugh was saying, a matter for the parliament to determine what administrative procedures should be in place to access a statutory right in the future. It does not go to the common law property right of the claimants, which can be pursued through this act in respect of all claims lodged before 27 June 1996. We think this is entirely an appropriate matter for the parliament to legislate on in respect of future access to the right to negotiate to solve many of the problems which are, self-evidently, a consequence of the operation of the act over the last four years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, you know full well what I meant by `traded off'. In fact, it is very much on the public record. We do not have to go through it comprehensively, but we do know that, in the interests of certainty for themselves and for other stakeholders, Aboriginal Australians did trade-off some capacity to pursue common law rights and that was reflected in the legislation. So do not come in here acutely suspicious of what went on at that particular time.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of what went on at that time, we have you well and truly on the record telling people that pastoral leases did not extinguish native title necessarily. That is very clearly on the record as well, despite the fact that you now claim that it was your obligation as a loyal member of the team to argue that particular point. You knew then. In terms of those trade‐offs, we do not have to revisit that comprehensively this morning.

The one point that we do need to address this morning is the constitutionality of your provision. I think you gave the game away when you said that indigenous Australians can in respect of those pre-1996 rights pursue their claims under common law. Wouldn't it make a lot more sense to actually encourage them to pursue them under the Native Title Act? Isn't that what this act is all about?

If you are saying to those who feel unfairly handled by the process, `You still have your common law rights,' why not take the extra step and process what we are suggesting to try to give them some confidence in the processes of the act? You are not going to give certainty to those people in Kalgoorlie or elsewhere in terms of overlapping claims if you are saying and acknowledging, as you have this morning, that people feeling aggrieved can pursue their common law rights. That is not the certainty they want. You do not give certainty in your proposal. You basically say, `We are going to ride over you. If you feel aggrieved about it, go off to the courts again,' and they will. Why not try to give them some certainty through this process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just briefly in response to that, the claim can be pursued under the act. The native title claim for determination of native title can be pursued under the act. The question is whether, additionally, there is access to the statutory right to negotiate. There is general agreement, as stated by the deputy chair of ATSIC, that there are a lot of frivolous claims participating in the right to negotiate process.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying is that the new test to ensure that only legitimate claims participate in the right to negotiate process in respect of future section 29 notices should be applied. Otherwise, you solve nothing; you do not solve the problem at all. You are still left with claims which cannot meet even the standards of the new registration test as amended by the Senate and therefore are participating in it and therefore, frankly, are acting against the interests of legitimate native title claimants.

Your process is a wing and a prayer to try to rationalise them. As I said, you have not answered this question: if your intention is to rationalise the claims, what about their rights? You are saying that you want to try to minimise and reduce the number of claims involved in the right to negotiate. As I say, you are hoisted on your own petard of your own argument if what you are saying you will achieve is achieved. We think it much better simply to put in place the application of the new test. Whenever a section 29 notice is issued in future, the claim itself, if it fails to meet that new test, can of course be dealt with as a claim for determination of native title under the Native Title Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to keep on repeating myself. Maybe I need to make this point much clearer with respect to the overlapping claims. We say this: post‐27 June 1996 we are happy with the government's regime; pre that, we think there is a capacity for people to be brought together and to bring claims together. To the extent that there is overlapping, you can bring people into the one claim. To the extent that there is inconsistency, you can weed those problems out. You are doing it with the consent of the parties in the process, where there is an imperative on them to conciliate and to get to an agreed outcome. So I do not think there is any problem with it.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point you make I think is just unsustainable. There are ways of bringing claims together, and those ways do not necessarily involve one claim being bounced in preference to another. You can bundle them together. As I say, to the extent of inconsistency, you can get parties to acknowledge inconsistency and weed that out before the respondent has to handle it. All we are asking for is that sort of process in a fair way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has consistently said that they are not taking rights away from indigenous people. The measure they are proposing in this section of the bill we believe is taking rights from a particular race. If they wish to try to live up to their statements or their promise that they are not taking rights, the agreed position between the opposition parties is the only way that they can, in this particular section of the bill, make sure that they are not in fact discriminating against a particular race of people and taking away the rights that exist.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 273 not agreed to.
Amendments 274 and 353 not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (269) Schedule 2, item 63, page 196 (line 24) to page 197 (line 17), omit subsections (3) and (4), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) If a claim in an application is made in relation to an area of land or waters the whole or a part of which is covered by an earlier registered application, the Registrar must not accept the claim for registration unless the rights and interests claimed for any common area of land or waters are:

TAB.TAB: (a) different from and not inconsistent with the rights and interests claimed in the earlier application; or

(b) if the rights and interests claimed in the later application are common rights and interests—the application asserts that they are held jointly with the native title claim group for the earlier application by another native title claim group identified in the later application.

PARA.TAB: (4) If the Registrar is satisfied that a claim cannot be accepted for registration because of subsection (3), the Registrar must:

TAB.TAB: (a) advise the applicants of that fact; and
(b) allow them 60 days in which to amend the application.

PARA.TAB: (4A) If the Registrar is satisfied that a claim could be accepted for registration apart from subsection (3), the Registrar must advise the applicants of that fact.
(4B) Applicants who are advised under subsection (4A) may apply to the Federal Court for an order amending or replacing the earlier registered application.

(4C) The applicant must be a member of the native title claim group and be authorised to make the application, and deal with matters arising in relation to it, by all the other persons in the native title claim group.

SPEECH.PARA: (270) Schedule 2, item 63, page 197 (lines 20 and 21), omit "paragraph (4)(a)", substitute "subsection 62AA(2)".
(271) Schedule 2, item 63, page 197 (line 22), omit "(4)", substitute "(4C).
(272) Schedule 2, item 63, page 197 (line 24), omit "paragraph (4)(b)", substitute "subsection (4C)".

In short, these amendments will prevent, so far as is appropriate, overlapping native title applications and they will also reflect the general law of joint ownership of property. We propose that we allow the overlapping of applications only in rare situations where the rights claimed in a later application are different to but consistent with those claimed in the former application. I think it would be very unfair to bounce those sorts of rights where the right claimed in a later application is different to but consistent with the earlier one. With respect to overlapping applications claiming common rights, we propose that the later application cannot be registered unless it asserts that the common law rights are held jointly with the earlier applicants.

BREAK.PARA: These proposals provide a degree of fairness. If one were to look at the two situations we are trying to pick up, it would be very hard to argue that people in those two circumstances should not be able to lodge a claim even though to a certain extent it could be recognised as overlapping. They are two very tight circumstances. Where someone is claiming common rights, there has got to be an assertion that they are held jointly. Of course, there is capacity thereafter for the registrar to ensure that they are handled and processed together. With respect to the earlier proviso, we are talking about a very rare situation where the rights claimed are different to but consistent with the overall application. People might in fact be claiming for a different access, different definition of the native title rights from a different application. I think these are very fair proposals. That is a word which I suppose is used very unfairly these days but, looking at it from the perspective of the two groups we are trying to protect, you cannot argue that it is not fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe there is a misunderstanding about what is intended here. There is a problem which has been brought to our attention by Aboriginal people, that you have situations where the same people are parties to different claims and therefore members of a variety of competing claims. That is a fact and one which Aboriginal groups themselves are seeking to prevent. What our 190C(3) merely seeks to do is to say that the registrar must be satisfied that no person included in the native title claim group for the application was a member of a claim group for any previous application—that is, that is already on the books—so that you do not get the situation of the one person being a member of two or more competing claims. We think that is important, and this amendment 269 removes that therefore allows that problem to continue.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, I do not know whether this is an actual misunderstanding, but there is absolutely nothing in our amendments which prevents claims to the same area of land being made by different native title claim groups and there is no limitation on that. It does not matter how many there are, if they are all capable of passing the registration test they can all be registered if they involve different claim groups. All we are trying to do is minimise that overlap of people between groups which has been brought to our attention by indigenous groups as a problem. Our bill will not prevent different groups making applications for registration in respect of exactly the same area. There is no attempt to mathematically limit it in any way. If there are 100 groups that all pass the test, they can all be registered. All we are seeking to do is ensure—in response, frankly, to something that has come from indigenous people—that we are talking about different groups. At the end of the day they may all get native title. If there were, for the purposes of this debate, 100 different groups that exercised traditional law and custom in that area, they will all get native title. I am not sure whether there is a misunderstanding of the effect of what we are proposing.
I think 271 and 272 are consequential on 269 and therefore we could not support them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to explain that the Democrat and Greens (WA) amendments were certainly the position of the National Indigenous Working Group. They are an improvement on what the ALP is proposing, I have got to say. Our amendments would prevent, in so far as that is appropriate, overlapping claims. However, they would permit such claims where different rights and interests are claimed by different groups and where common rights and interests are jointly held by different groups. We believe the ALP amendments do not take sufficient cognisance of that, and certainly the amendments we are putting forward would improve on that. However, to avoid muddying the water, I think the National Indigenous Working Group would be prepared to go with the ALP amendments, and so we would also. I just seek confirmation of that from Senator Margetts as well.
—That is my understanding.
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments by the minister would indicate that he speaks to some of the problems but not necessarily the source of the problems. That is often the problem with coming and saying things like, `I have been told by groups that there are problems with overlapping claims.' As I have mentioned before, the problems are not necessarily the creation of indigenous groups. The problems are often the creation of the way companies have operated and the way pressure has been put on people and the way people have been picked off, marginalised or isolated by the way the process has taken place. It is also often a problem of inadequate resources to rep bodies; not just land councils but those more localised rep bodies for which people have a greater affinity. That could be their corporations. Some of them are just setting up now in order to speak to and liaise with land councils and so on. So those problems are ones in relation to the way the operation has taken place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible within Aboriginal society, depending on the nature of the group and the context in which that group is put together, for a person to be correspondingly a member of a clan, a moiety and a larger group, all at the same time. Those claims will be different in their size and scope, depending on the time of year and so on that those groups get together on a normal basis. So the reality is that it is actually possible for one person to be legitimately on more than one claim. It is a bit like you being a member of society, a member of the parliament and a member of a family. You are actually a member of all of those groups simultaneously. It is a different context, but I would ask the minister to listen a little more carefully. Yes, there are problems with the way claims are operating in some ways, but I believe the problems are associated with the way the law has been drafted, and often the problems are with resources and with the way corporations and companies have acted towards indigenous people.

The issue is whether or not you can have one person on three different claims. It is possible for that to happen legitimately. To suggest that that is an oddity that we cannot cope with is not necessarily showing a great deal of understanding of indigenous culture. There may also be problems that are sorted out in relation to resourcing, and that is the sort of thing that over the last couple of hours we have been asking the minister to take seriously. I think that the opposition's amendments do at least take those kinds of issues into consideration, and I really think the government is going about it the wrong way. I would urge the Senate to support in preference the National Indigenous Working Group amendments, but I am indicating that I could also be prepared to support the opposition amendments in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I also respond to Senator Minchin. We have just adopted your regime in terms of overlapping provisions. What we are trying to do here is to recognise that there are some circumstances where overlapping may very well take place. You say that your legislation already allows for it, but I have got to say to you that your 190C(3) makes it very clear that no person included in the native title claim group for a current application could be so included if he or she were a member of a native title claim group for any previous application.

SPEECH.PARA: What do you do with situations where people have got—as I think Senator Woodley put on the record last night very clearly through Professor Marcia Langton's work—affiliations with more than one clan or more than one group, either through marriage or for some other reason? Those people would not be able to pursue their claim in a subsequent proceeding under your 190C(3). It is very clear there. That is the sort of concern that we have. What we say is: you have got your regime in terms of overlap, put a bit compassion into it and acknowledge that people can in fact be members of two different clans, and as a consequence recognise that your 190C(3) is too rigid, too inflexible and will deliver injustice to quite a few people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not acknowledge that. As I say, the driving force for this was the thing that I found in all my consultations last year, and that was that the greatest complaint from Aboriginal groups—and indeed Mr Pearson himself—was the problem that any individual could go and make a claim, an individual could be a member of a number of claim groups, and that led to the problem of multiple claims. I acknowledge what Senator Margetts is saying about companies. There are, as I understand it, some companies which quite improperly have encouraged this sort of behaviour and I condemn it.

SPEECH.PARA: If you allow a situation where families or clans can each individually make claims and they can be parties to different claims, and then they all participate in the right to negotiate, you end up with the situation we have got now, with 20 or 30 different claimant groups all of whom need to be negotiated with.
