The chances of reaching agreement are absolutely minimal in those circumstances. And that is the complaint coming from Aboriginal groups that are seeking to reach agreement: you get agreement from 20 of the 21 but one holds out—no agreement. Of course, that is a big part of the problem.

So we are saying that we want like‐minded groups to consolidate their claim and make their claim, but if there are genuinely different groups with different native title rights which they seek in different tradition and law and custom, then of course there is nothing in our act which prevents that occurring. If the right to negotiate is all about ultimately trying to reach agreement in relation to the prospective mining development, then that is going to be facilitated by the operation of clauses like 190C(3).

It is not oppressive. It simply says that a claim cannot be registered if a person who is in the claim group is already in another claim group—they are part of the process. It simply means that you make sure there is not that overlap of people across claims. It has no effect on the number of claims that can be made, and if they are all capable of being registered, they will all be registered and all participate. Otherwise, you will end up with a situation where you are not dealing with this current problem of 20 or 30 different claimants and the real difficulty of ever reaching agreement in those circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are doing is purely and simply stopping people from asserting the full range of their common law rights. And you are doing that to individuals. In respect of those people who you are stopping from being able to claim the full range of their common law property rights, what will they do? They get bounced by your 190C(3), they have a common law right, they go to court and they get compensation because their rights have been extinguished. What we are asking for here is a bit of sense and justice. If you want a sensible and a certain outcome, then you try and encourage these people to stay under the umbrella of the act. Under this particular provision, anyone who has their rights denied, under a whole body of existing common law, has a compensatable claim and in the process there is uncertainty for the respondents.

SPEECH.PARA: A bit of justice would not go too far astray here either, when you are talking about stopping a subsequent claim by a native title group because one person may have had an affiliation with a previous group, and as a consequence of that affiliation the subsequent application cannot be proceeded with. Their families are like ours, I suppose. People do have affiliations across clans, across different parts of our community. Why can't we acknowledge that in the multicultural dimension of Aboriginal Australia people can in fact have different clans and affiliations? They do, in the same way that we do. But what you are saying is, if they do, then they cannot pursue and exercise their full range of common law property rights by that very rigid application of 190C(3).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support what Senator Bolkus is saying. Don't think that overlapping rights are simply something that native title claimants dream up. There has been more than one occasion when mining companies themselves have interfered with native title claimants in their own areas and have caused overlapping claims. If we apply a rigid test, what we do is make it impossible to sort out not only the overlapping claims by native title claimants, but also the interference which has occurred on more than one occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I am going to give you one example and it comes from South Australia. Actually, it has been before the Supreme Court of South Australia and, I believe, the High Court, and it was to do with the Pitjantjatjara people. Some years ago, after very extensive, very extended and very long negotiation, the Pitjantjatjara people came to an agreement with a couple of mining companies over what land should be mined and what land should be preserved. However, there was one mining company which was left out of the loop. So what they did was they went to an Aboriginal man who did not belong to the Pitjantjatjara people but who happened to be a pastor. They made him a director of their company and sent him up to the Pitjantjatjara lands, ostensibly to preach the gospel.

However, after he had gathered people together and had had a couple of services, he then gathered them together to press the claim of this other mining company. To cut a long story short, it divided the community very seriously. He claimed, when the Pitjantjatjara council excluded him from that community, that they had excluded him for preaching the gospel, which of course was simply not true. They excluded him because he had represented a rival mining company and divided the community, because the mining companies themselves wanted to get a piece of the action.

That is the kind of complicated interference which can occur and which cannot be solved by a rigid application of the kind of test which the government is trying to apply. But it is not just native title claimants who initiate overlapping claims. You can have that kind of interference in a community. That is one example. It has certainly happened more than once, but that is a classic case of what can happen when communities are interfered with, which cannot be dealt with by the rigid application of the amendment which the government is moving. I appeal to the government to listen to what we are saying and to support the amendments moved in 269.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what the Pitjantjatjara example had to do with this. I personally know Pastor Bob Brown and, from what I know of him, he is a fine man. I am not sure that the slur upon his character which we have just heard is appropriate in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: May I take the opportunity to say that the granting of inalienable freehold land to the Pitjantjatjara people was one of the great initiatives of the Tonkin Liberal government and one which all South Australians are very proud of. But I am not quite sure of its relevance here.

In respect of what Senator Bolkus is saying, what we are talking about here in 190C(3) is the registration test. This is not about an application for determination of native title and the pursuit of common law rights. This does not apply to that question. Of course, those common law rights can be pursued in any way thought appropriate, but we are responding to what has been put to us by all parties to right to negotiate proceedings who are trying to develop a mechanism which will enable agreements to be reached that are fair and sensible to all parties and avoid arbitration and all that that involves; and we are seeking, by 190C(3), to encourage in effect the consolidation of claims merely by saying that you have your claim registered if you are a member of two or more claimant groups.

I can only repeat that it does not prevent the lodgment of any number of claims to participate in the right to negotiate. If you do not have this provision, you are removing a major incentive to ensure that there is a consolidation of claims; you are actively encouraging the current situation of multiple overlapping claims and really removing one of the methods by which we sought to meet the concerns of indigenous leaders in seeking to ensure a workable right to negotiate process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —So as not to let the record stand uncontested, I also have spoken to lots of indigenous leaders. They want workability and they want a reduction of overlap, but what they do not want is a situation where people are unfairly denied a capacity to pursue the claim. None of them would support you on what you are trying to do with this particular provision, and the record should not be allowed to stand with your contention uncontested.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us make this clear. They would not want a situation where their people could be denied access to a claim because of their affinity to two clans. Basically, Senator Minchin, you are being unfair. Also, you are not really appreciating how native title emerges from indigenous culture. It does not emerge from our Western culture. Aboriginal society, biology and genealogy are not the only possible basis for collectively held native title rights: there are skin groups, totem groups and so on. These things have to be recognised as the starting point in respect to native title. I am sure that you will be getting lots of critical representation very soon from those Aboriginal leaders that you have tried to verbal in this place this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I object to the suggestion that this somehow affects the claims themselves. This does not affect the common law right to make claims and the confusion of the process by which claims for determination are pursued with this question of parties to the right to negotiate. It just confuses the debate and unfairly represents what the government is on about. This does not affect the applications for a determination of native title.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about trying to get a workable right to negotiate process so that mining companies, explorers and others can have an opportunity to reach agreement. All we are saying is that, in reaching agreement with different claimant groups, you are not involved with the same people belonging to different claimant groups and turning up for one negotiation in one group and coming along and being party to a negotiation in another group as well, which is one of the real problems.

It is unfair to characterise this as somehow cutting across the common law right; it does not do so. It does not affect the application for determination of native title. We are talking about trying to achieve manageable and effective outcomes from the right to negotiate process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right to negotiate means nothing if you have not got the right to claim. What you are doing here is stopping people from having the right to claim under the act. If you acknowledge they can claim at common law, and if our contention is, as it has been across the parliament, that the importance of the Native Title Act is to give you certainty in terms of process and outcomes, why don't you encourage them to claim under the Native Title Act? You will get no more certainty—in fact you will get less certainty—by telling these people they have no right to process claims under here but that they have to go to common law, which is what you are saying continually this morning. It is an insensible situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is saying that he is not actually looking at the social impact or the cultural impact on Aboriginal people. He is forgetting that when you fly over, for instance, the Goldfields, Laverton or Leonora what you see is a landscape pockmarked with tailings dams and holes in the ground and cleared land where Aboriginal groups, corporations, land councils and so on have to deal with hundreds of different mining interests.

SPEECH.PARA: If you want to treat people fairly and if you think it is reasonable that you can have only one basis for dealing legally with people, perhaps you can put in a law that says, `All mining companies in, say, Laverton have to operate on one claim and one claim only, because that is fairness and that is certainty.' What you are saying is in fact a nonsense. You are dealing with the fact that indigenous people in those particular types of areas—like the Eastern Goldfields areas of Laverton, Leonora, Kalgoorlie and around there—have to deal with hundreds of claims on a daily basis. But you are not saying that is unfair; you are saying it is unfair for corporations and companies to have to deal with anything to do with the nature of indigenous culture. I think what you are saying is patently unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to correct something that Senator Bolkus said. We are saying that claims can be pursued under the act. The procedures set down under the act allow the applications for a determination to be pursued under the act without any effect of 190C(3). The claims can be pursued under the act, regardless of this section. This is about those claimants which then seek to participate in the right to negotiate. All we are saying is, `Yes, you can be a party to a right to negotiate process. You have that right if you are a member of a claim group which gets registered.' But to say that in relation to the right to negotiate in attempting to seek agreement with a mining company, an explorer or whatever, you identify with one claim group for the purposes of the negotiation and not two, or 100, seems eminently sensible, because it does not cut across the right to pursue the claim under the act, but it does seek to achieve a workable mechanism for achieving outcomes by agreement through the right to negotiate process. It does not deny anyone the right to be part of a claim group. It encourages the consolidation of claims so that groups can reach agreement, but if there are, as I say, 100 different claim groups and they are all capable of being registered, they can all be registered. There is nothing to prevent that in any of these provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.
