SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to speak in respect of Senator Margetts's quite legitimate interest in the question of funding of rep bodies. There are currently 26 determined representative bodies. The funds allocated over the last three financial years were: 1994‐95, $20.7 million; 1995‐96, $28.4 million; and 1996‐97—in our first budget—$42.1 million. So there has been a more than doubling in the first two years, and we are maintaining it at that level. So we think the resource allocation to those bodies is quite significant.

In terms of representative bodies, I think this is one area of the bill where there is, broadly speaking, general agreement. We have rejected the assertions put by some in the Aboriginal community that we should not enhance the role and place of representative bodies in the system. We do not agree; we think that the management of the native title process is enhanced by having well‐resourced, professional and accountable representative bodies who are genuinely representative and accountable. Our provisions generally achieve that end in a way which does ensure that accountability and effectiveness—accountability, essentially, to ATSIC on a day to day basis, but ultimately to the minister in the strategic sense. There is an allocation of mandatory and other functions to the rep bodies.

I think the big difference of opinion is over our proposal to re‐examine the status of current rep bodies against the new criteria. We do think that, to ensure the confidence of everybody in the current representative bodies, they should be required to demonstrate that they can meet these new responsibilities. They are given priority in the system. They are given the first opportunity to apply for recognition and a 12‐month period in which to do so, so we do think that, to ensure that level of confidence and appropriate accountability, there is no reason that existing rep bodies should not go through a re‐recognition process, given the completely changed arrangements. So we will not be supporting amendments which would seek to remove that re‐recognition process.

I now turn to the government amendments, which are essentially technical. Amendment 77 provides for a new subsection 203AC(1A), which explains the time frames for the minister to make decisions about recognition applications. Generally, the minister must make decisions as soon as practicable after an invitation period, extension, or further information request period has expired. Where the application is made by an existing rep body during the transition period in response to such an invitation the application must be decided before the end of the transition period. I guess that was the intent, but that will now be given direct effect to by this amendment and it obviously acknowledges that current rep bodies do need to know by the end of that period whether they have been so recognised or not.

Amendment 78 gives the National Native Title Tribunal from the end of the transition period the new functions of assisting or mediating under any provision of the act and of entering into contracts with representative bodies to assist with their dispute resolution functions. Again, I would have thought that should be acceptable.

Amendment 79, which is linked to Labor amendment 81, provides that the tribunal may assist a representative body in its dispute resolution functions if there is an agreement between the body and the tribunal under which the body pays the tribunal for that professional assistance.

Amendment 80, again linked to 81, removes the requirement that grants be made in respect of a financial year or part of a financial year, because under 81 grants may be able to be made for a period of up to three years.

Amendment 81 provides a new subsection 203C(3) which allows ATSIC to make grants for periods of up to three years, consistent with other grant provisions relating to ATSIC. It enables ATSIC to make grants for the same duration as the strategic plan required to be prepared by the rep body.

Amendment 82 simply makes it clear that funding given to rep bodies is to be subject to a condition that, if a rep body loses its recognition, the rep body must return any uncommitted funds to ATSIC. Again, I would have thought this was an unexceptionable amendment. It does not require the rep body to repay any money actually paid out by or to another person, nor does it prevent the rep body from meeting any liabilities already incurred before de‐recognition.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment 83 is the technical amendment that arose out of the parliamentary committee inquiry in relation to the definition of a bank to make sure that it includes credit unions.

Amendment 84 provides protection for certain information disclosed during the audit or investigation of a rep body. New subsections 203DF(6) and (7) restrict the uses that can be made by the auditor or investigator of documents or information subject to legal privilege, and that auditors or investigators are to be regarded as Commonwealth officers for the purposes of certain secrecy provisions under the Crimes Act.

Amendment 85, the final government amendment, makes it clear that a rep body must allow an auditor or investigator full access to all documents relating to the rep body whether or not such documents contain legally privileged information, but a rep body will still be able to claim in other proceedings that such documents are subject to legal professional privilege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some common ground with the government with respect to representative bodies. But there is also one very critical and major area of difference, the one flagged by Senator Minchin—the re‐recognition process. We share a concern to ensure that rep bodies are well resourced. We share that concern with other parties in this place, the Greens and the Democrats. There is no doubt that after this act, one way or another, the rep bodies will have more functions; they will be more accountable and they will be integral to the workability of the legislation in the long term but critically integral to the workability in the short term.

SPEECH.PARA: The bodies need to be well resourced and they need to operate competently and with accountability. Our principles are that accountability is necessary. We support most of the government measures in that respect. But we say that accountability should not be at the whim of the minister, and these bodies should not be essentially there at the whim of whomever the minister may be for a particular period.

There has to be a degree of self‐determination embodied in the legislation that is passed by this parliament this week or next week. That self‐determination has to acknowledge that indigenous Australians have been seeking self‐determination and deserve it and, to the extent that this parliament addresses the issue, we will need to have that as one of the fundamental principles driving us.

Accountability and self‐determination can best come through an involvement of ATSIC in the process of accountability. That is one of the fundamental parts of the amendments that we will be moving. With ATSIC having a core role, there needs to be a role for the minister. That ministerial role should be there, and it should be subject to procedural fairness to organisations involved.

Rep bodies are going to be integral to the workability of the scheme, particularly in this forthcoming immediate period. But what is the government proposing to do with them in that period? It is proposing to put them all through a re‐recognition process, regardless of how good they are, regardless of how professionally they operate, regardless of whatever benefits they are delivering to their organisations and regardless of how much more work they have to perform in the interests not just of their people but also of other stakeholders in the process. The government is saying that each and every one of them has to go through a re‐recognition process at the whim of the minister.

As far as we are concerned, this is not just accountability cleansing. We are concerned that the government's agenda here is political cleansing, and it is something that we are not prepared to give a blank cheque to. Have your accountability, but I ask the committee to give me the name of one organisation or one sector in the Australian community that would accept a government‐imposed regime of control of re‐recognition.

The government is asking for a blank cheque to re‐recognise all the rep bodies at the whim of the minister. That is something that we should not be doing. No migrant group in the country in receipt of government resources or otherwise would cop it; no business group would cop it; the NRMA would not cop it; but you are saying, `Well, let's have a re‐recognition process and, at the absolute discretion of the minister, whomever we want to re‐recognise, we do so.' That should not be on, in any sense of democratic working of this parliament. I am concerned that the government has shown right from the start a propensity to try to silence its critics in this particular area.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all areas.

—In all areas, Senator Woodley. Right from the start, when it came to Aboriginal affairs, the weapons were out and the measures were out. The government lost a couple of court cases; they have been proven to have run a fear campaign with respect to resources that have been improperly accounted for in the Aboriginal sector. We can remember the claims of the minister of hundreds of millions of dollars being wasted—that has not come to fruition. But if any sector has to be concerned about a degree of political cleansing, it is this one. I do not think this parliament should embark upon a proposal of re‐recognition at the whim of the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from those concerns, we have concerns that scarce resources will be diverted to try to meet an unnecessary process in most circumstances. Functions will not be performed, critical new functions will not be able to be addressed and indigenous Australians will not have any certainty as to who their representatives will be. State and territory governments, mining companies and developers will not be assured of who is going to be representing the other side. The uncertainty ensured by Senator Minchin's proposal will last for a good 12 months, if not 24.

We say that there is a better regime. That better regime involves giving the minister the power to deregister at the end of the day and ensuring that accountability takes place. Direct accountability should be through ATSIC, particularly in respect of the ongoing accountability and in respect of a de‐recognition process. What we say is that, instead of putting all representative bodies through a process at the start, within 12 months of the commencement of the act, ATSIC shall determine whether any representative body is not working satisfactorily. It ATSIC so determines, it shall advise the representative body and the minister—the minister is to be informed all the way through—and may specify another 12‐month period for the representative body to get its act into order.

At the end of that probation period—I suppose that that is what we can call it—ATSIC will determine whether the body should be de‐recognised. If ATSIC does, it may recommend to the minister that he exercise his powers of de‐recognition granted by our proposed section 203AH(2). This will ensure that we do not go embarking upon a wasteful exercise of dragging well‐operating representative bodies into a re‐recognition process but that we can focus on where the problems may very well be.

In terms of focusing on those problems, what is really important is putting in place ongoing accountability mechanisms. They exist through, for instance, the minister having the right to seek further information, the minister having discretion to register a representative body, a detailed accountability regime, as in clause 203AH, and the withdrawal of recognition potential. Procedural requirements are very critical in this respect. We are recommending procedural requirements on the minister's exercise of his functions, including ADJR and performance criteria. These measures build on the measures proposed by the government which require representative bodies to have strategic plans, proper accounts records, annual reports, financial statements and so on. We also believe that ATSIC should be the first port of call in respect of appointing auditors and investigators of a representative body.

We think our approach provides a balance. It is a constructive alternative that does not have the downside in terms of resource implications and political silencing that the government's proposal has. In specifics, we have an up‐front cleansing process, as I mentioned a little earlier, in terms of accountability and performance. Amendments Nos 318 and 319 ensure that the minister can consider a reduction of area and the withdrawal of recognition when ATSIC has declined a certified body. Amendment No. 306 ensures the deletion of the re-recognition process.

BREAK.PARA: We think the transfer of documents is important. We also think there needs to be some protection in respect of the transfer of documents. Our amendment No. 312 prevents the transfer of documents from an old representative body to a new body where the documents are the subject of legal professional privilege, copyright or, importantly, are owned by a third person in accordance with traditional law and custom. They cannot be passed on without the consent of that relevant person. I do not think we should underestimate that provision.

Amendments Nos 309, 322 and 334 ensure that representative bodies have to meet certain benchmarks in terms of protecting the interests of native title holders. They must consult with them in respect of on‐the‐ground matters, such as environmental and land management issues and so on. There is a tricky issue in respect of conflicts of interest. This is one that representative bodies often have to contend with. Our amendment essentially allows representative bodies to continue to act except where a representative body is satisfied that it is not able to resolve a dispute or cannot adequately or efficiently provide the assistance required. There has to be a balance here, given the lack of access by individuals to alternative forms of advice.

There is a facilitation and assistance function that we ensure the representative bodies are capable of performing. Basically, it is on‐the‐ground support. There is a certification and notification function in terms of many of the claims lodged by claimants.

Finance and accountability has been an issue of public concern. There needs to be accountability, but we also need to ensure that it is balanced by a degree of self-determination. The public needs to have confidence that the process of accountability is transparent. What we say in that respect is that we demand strategic three-year plans. We need to make sure that funding is provided for the period of the representative bodies' strategic plan; we do that in amendment No. 335. We also ensure that ATSIC determines the period of the strategic plan, not the minister; that is important in terms of self-determination. The strategic plans are to be subject to the approval of ATSIC, not the Commonwealth minister.

In terms of direct accountability under amendment No. 340, we propose that representative bodies inform ATSIC, in the immediate sense, not the minister, of matters which quite significantly affect the achievement of objectives set out in the strategic plan. We have provisions for annual reports and for financial statements to both ATSIC and the minister and to parliament. Amendment No. 344 ensures that representative bodies' annual reports and statements provided to ATSIC must in turn be provided to the minister for tabling in parliament.

The minister is in the picture. Amendments Nos 345 and 347 require ATSIC to inform the minister where there have been serious and repeated irregularities in the financial affairs of the representative bodies. Amendments Nos 348 and 349 ensure that ATSIC must comply with a request by the minister for certain information, except in those circumstances I mentioned earlier.

There has been public concern. Some of it has been unfairly beaten up by politicians wishing to take some advantage in this area. There has been some public concern about accountability. It is a legitimate thing for the public and the parliament to be concerned about. The measures proposed by the government, built upon by us and the indigenous working groups, build very much a basis for engendering public confidence in the process. But you will not have public confidence in the process if you allow, at the whim of a minister, all sorts of interference all the way through the process, starting with re‐recognition.

It is wasteful and laden with dangers. Once again, this is another area where the government is going far in excess of what the Wik decision justifies. Of course, it goes to issues of public concern. Once again, it tilts that balance much more unfairly against indigenous Australians. My plea is to put in place further accountability but also to allow indigenous Australians and their representatives to operate with a degree of self-determination and, most importantly through that, a degree of self-dignity.

No other representative body in this country has had this sort of proposal put to them in terms of controlling their day-to-day operations and, in fact, controlling their existence. There needs to be a degree of self‐determination respected by this parliament. The government is not going to do it. It is up to the Senate to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now debating the topic area 19 `Representative bodies'. Part 11 of the Native Title Act established in 1994 a system of representative Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander bodies. Part 11 of the act contains two rather short sections; namely, sections 202 and 203. The government amendments concerning representative bodies now form an entire schedule in the amendment bill and run for 54 pages. I think what Senator Bolkus has just been saying is supported by that alone.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulties which have occurred concerning the overlapping of claims have, to a great extent, been caused by a legacy of dispossession and the stolen generations. I put on the table a lot of evidence of that in the previous debate. The major defect in these provisions is the attempt by the government to undertake a wholesale review of all indigenous representative bodies in Australia. This is totally unnecessary and will cause extraordinary disruption to those representative bodies.

I have a number of questions for the minister. Firstly, if the government succeeds in what it is trying to do with its amendments, will the minister be providing additional funding to representative bodies for the proposed review process and, if so, how much will be allocated to the representative bodies? Where the minister has particular and legitimate concerns about the performance of a representative body, there are ample powers in the bill which would allow him to take steps to cure the situation. These powers are both desirable and appropriate. Although it appears that the government reconsidered some of its earlier excessive proposals in relation to accountability, there are still layers of so-called accountability which are unnecessary, will impair the proper functioning of representative bodies and are likely to be counterproductive.

I think it is important to look at what generates this notion of making sure these `black fellas' are held accountable. Is it that indigenous institutions or bodies have a higher level of corruption or is it that it serves a particular political agenda to perpetuate the myth that they are corrupt? It is so much easier to treat people differently, particularly people with a different skin colour, if you can perpetuate the myth that they are more prone to criminal activity. I wonder if the minister could answer that. Does he really believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are more prone to criminal activity? If not, then why place a more onerous accountability provision on their representative bodies? The so-called accountability provisions could perhaps be more accurately described as stereotyping provisions, because that is what they are doing.

Why get rid of the existing representative bodies? Does the minister really believe that all of them have failed in their task? It is clear to us that the appropriate accountability principles are: first, representative bodies must be accountable for the use of public moneys; secondly, representative bodies should be accountable internally, actively and directly to their constituents; and, thirdly, representative bodies are already subject to adequate accountability arrangements.

On the other hand, the proposed financial and accountability amendments should not duplicate ATSIC and other financial and accountability arrangements for representative bodies which are already in place, be oppressive and so detract from accountability and performance, and place significant control and involvement in relation to representative bodies in the hands of the minister, which is highly inappropriate given the Commonwealth's interests and participation in native title matters. Clearly, a conflict of interest is apparent.

Currently there are representative bodies for most areas of Australia. It is appropriate that there is one representative body for each area. Of all the amendments in this bill—and, let's face it, many of them are paternalistic—this approach regarding representative bodies is perhaps the most paternalistic of them all. We should never forget that it was the underpinning paternalism that created the environment whereby indigenous children were stolen from their families because `it was seen to be good for them'. We should be ever vigilant not to repeat those mistakes.

Of particular concern to the Australian Democrats is the growing trend of governments in this country to establish self-fulfilling prophecies with regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander bodies. The scenario goes something like this: `Okay, you want self-determination. We—and by that I mean non-indigenous Australia—will establish bodies such as ATSIC. But then we will defund them. Of course, we'll blame you when the mess that we created, such as the still appalling health standards, is not given an instant solution.' It is called responsibility shifting. We believe that the government's amendments not only are reflective of responsibility shifting but also are intrinsically paternalistic.

There is consensus that representative bodies need to play a more active and integral role in the native title claim process, and that is rightly so. They will, however, be undercut and set up to fail if they are not appropriately resourced. Then we will be faced with another government in the not too distant future saying, `Look, native title is unworkable. Native title representative bodies are not doing their job. What we need is certainty.' And thrown in for good measure will be a couple of furphies about people's backyards.

Minister, are you really serious about assisting indigenous people in making native title claims? We trust that somehow or other we can get support for the amendments which have been proposed by the opposition parties. We certainly are committed to accountability. That is absolutely essential. We certainly are committed to having representative bodies that are the appropriate auspices for sorting out many of the disputes. They know their own people and they are on the ground and can hear the different sides of the argument.

We do know that there have been problems with the way in which representative bodies are operated. We would say that most of those problems originate from the lack of resources and the lack of clarity in the legislation. Let us make sure that representative bodies are accountable. Let us make sure that they can operate. Let us make sure that they are resourced. Above all, let us make sure that they can bring to this whole divisive debate a sense of unity and a sense in which, in representing and understanding the people that they do represent, we can move forward and not backwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond to Senator Woodley. For a Christian man he is very quick to attribute ill motive to everything the government does, which I find offensive. He is basically accusing me and the government of holding the view that Aboriginal people are more prone to criminal activity. It is really an outrageous proposition and utterly offensive and, I would have thought, should play no part in this sort of debate. You would think from what you have been saying that we are abolishing all representative bodies and taking away all their funding.

SPEECH.PARA: We are effectively implementing the Keating government's 1995 review of representative bodies—a review largely conducted by Aboriginal people—which called for higher standards and one body per area. You have described us as being paternalistic for implementing what Aboriginal people on the 1995 review conducted by the Keating government recommended we do. This is where you become so warped in your views about the coalition government. You think that everything we do is racist and everything else. Let us have some clear thinking here and treat our propositions on their merits. Sure, you can disagree with those that you think are wrong, but please can we be spared the accusations that everything we do is based on some view that all Aboriginals are criminals, for God's sake!

In terms of the resources, the current funding is some $40 million. That will continue. If ATSIC believes additional funding is required then that is a matter for ATSIC either out of its own budget or to seek additional funding through the normal processes.

This issue of re‐recognition, we think on balance, is the proper way to go. If you are going to have a mechanism by which you can establish designated rep body areas and one rep body per area then the way we are approaching it will facilitate that. You will be able to determine the appropriate rep body for the area designated, operate such a system accordingly and ensure that the rep bodies meet the new standards which we are putting in place as a result of that 1995 review.

It seems entirely appropriate to require existing rep bodies to satisfy everybody they can to meet those standards. If they can then they will have no difficulty being re‐recognised. They are given full priority in the re‐recognition process. If they are performing their functions appropriately then there will be no difficulty in re‐recognition.

We think to make this system work you do need this transition period to enable the identification of rep body areas and to enable existing rep bodies to apply for representative body status in respect of the area for which they wish to be a rep body. If they meet the standards then they will be recognised. The minister's decision is not on a whim and a prayer. He has to comply with or make his decision in accordance with the criteria laid down in the act and any decision is a disallowable instrument. It is governed by quite strict criteria. It is not just a whim.

We continue to assert that re-recognition is appropriate. These bodies have the status of a representative body and, therefore, receive Commonwealth funding and exercise powers and functions under a Commonwealth act of parliament and should be required to demonstrate that they can meet those appropriate standards laid down in the act. That is quite proper procedure in respect of any body that is exercising powers and functions under an act and receiving Commonwealth funding.

It does not affect their other status. Most of these bodies are the land councils. It is their additional recognition as a representative body for the purposes of the Native Title Act we are talking about. They will continue to exercise all their functions. I am sure all the land councils that are current rep bodies that can meet these standards will be re‐recognised. We think there is somewhat unduly dramatic condemnation of this process which does not meet with the reality of the need to ensure that we have properly accountable rep bodies operating in all these areas. Priority is given to the existing rep bodies. We think it is sensible to have a 12‐month transition process to enable the determination of areas and appropriate bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You say there is some control over the minister's exercise of discretion. It seems to me that on page 227 at 203AI(3) the Commonwealth minister may consider anything that he or she may want to take into account in making a decision in respect of re-recognition. I do not know what sort of control that is. Can you explain that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, there are set criteria, but it would be silly if the minister could not take into account other matters or was arbitrarily restricted in the sort of information which he or she could take into account in making a decision. 203AI(1) sets out the matters to which the Commonwealth minister must have regard to such as fairness of organisational structures and administrative processes. Criteria for assessing fairness is laid down there. It seems quite appropriate that he should be able to take into account in reaching a decision other matters if there are matters brought to his attention that fall outside these criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: My understanding is the decisions are disallowable if it is believed that an inappropriate decision has been made. It is quite normal to give a discretion to a minister in relation to any decision of this kind in any field of Commonwealth endeavour to enable the minister to have regard to other matters. That is not unusual at all, but the primary criteria to which he must have regard are laid down in the act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond to a couple of things that the minister said. The question I have, and it still remains, is: if this is not paternalistic, why is it that the government wants to deregister all of the representative bodies? If it is not paternalistic, why is it that the current accountability, the very onerous accountability, regime which Aboriginal and Islander bodies have is still seen to be not strict enough, that a more onerous accountability provision, even more onerous than is presently in place, has to be placed on representative bodies? That is the question.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no use saying, `Good God, do you think we are accusing Aboriginal people of criminal activity?' What you do not seem to understand, Minister, is that that is the implication that, admittedly, I have drawn from the whole thrust of your amendments at this point. I honestly accept your assurance that that is not your starting point. I can understand why you reacted, but you have to understand how people who feel that they are being made more accountable than anybody else in the community have to wonder why that is so. So that is the problem.

The other reference you made to my being a Christian—so somehow or other that means that I, therefore, should not point out to the government when I believe it is stereotyping and stigmatising people—just does not hold up. I do not want to go back over the church and state debate, but let me underline that one of the fundamental obligations laid upon Christians is that they speak the word to the governments of the day, a contemporary word. Where that word must be a prophetic word, then it has to be. That is the absolute tradition of the prophetic stream in both the Jewish and the Christian scriptures. So I reject that implication, but I guess that is a debate that we can have at another time. I simply respond to the minister in that way, but I do accept and understand his reaction. I do accept that his motivation in this is other than perhaps what I might have inferred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Woodley for that clarification. Can I just say that we are not about deregistering existing bodies. All we are seeking to do is ensure that rep bodies have the benefit of having received the tick that they would receive through the re‐recognition process. Given that we all agree that we should provide in the act something that is not currently there—that is, a proper set of standards that rep bodies must comply with if they are to perform these functions and to be given the quite significant and considerable powers that they have under the act—they should be properly accountable both for the performance of those functions and for the $40 million a year they receive from the taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that all existing rep bodies are able to meet these standards. If they do, I would welcome that and welcome their continued operation. I am sure many of them will. All we want is to ensure that they have that clear recognition and status, that they can and do comply with the new standards and that they can then perform these functions which are significant and which will involve their making some pretty tough decisions in relation to the areas for which they are responsible. Their capacity to do so will be enhanced by the fact that they have met the new criteria and been formally recognised under the new regime. It can only add to their capacity to perform their functions with the proper authority and respect which that will require.

TALK.START.PARA: —This procedure, division 2, throws a fairly heavy onus on the Commonwealth minister. Do you have any idea of the actual process he will use? Who will in fact gather the evidence that the minister must take into account? It seems to me that the minister is going to have a lot of work. As I read this, it is all something that he is obliged to do personally, which I think would put him under a fair deal of strain and subject him to all sorts of applications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The EM sets out on page 306 the process for recognition of representative bodies. Of course, like many other legislative instruments, it talks about the Commonwealth minister having to be satisfied about the following: the body will satisfactorily represent persons who hold or may hold native title, will be able to consult effectively and, if the body already is a rep body, that the body satisfactorily performs its existing functions, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, like all Commonwealth issues of this kind, the minister will rely upon the appropriate departmental or other advice. In this case, of course, ATSIC would primarily be the adviser to the minister. While it is ultimately a matter for Commonwealth ministerial decision, he acts on advice, and in this case that advice under current administrative arrangements would essentially come through ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —ATSIC is not the body that will be in the firing line; it will be the minister. It seems to me that, having been quite prescriptive here, you are going to throw a fairly heavy onus on the minister which he must take personal responsibility for and subject himself to court proceedings. I remember that in the migration area some ministers have been in the box giving evidence. I do not know whether you want that sort of thing happening here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the essence of the Westminster system: that ministers are responsible for, and accountable to, the parliament and the people for the decisions they make as members of the executive. That is how it works. Ultimately, that can involve ministers in court proceedings—and has done so for as long as there has been representative government. That is why we believe that, ultimately, the minister should take responsibility in this matter on behalf of the Australian people and should be accountable to the people's representatives in the parliament. It is entirely in line with what you would regard as normal procedure in a representative government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reminded of the replayed program on the SBS a couple of nights ago called Blue Eyed . It was about people in a workshop who found what it was like to be required to live down to other people's expectations. That is what we are seeing here. It has been a process since the 1980s when there were talks of treaties, sovereignty and self‐determination.

SPEECH.PARA: To me, whether it is ATSIC or the rep bodies, the most important area of accountability is to the people they represent. Unfortunately, over time and in particular with this government, it has forgotten that ATSIC and the rep bodies are in fact primarily required to be responsible to their constituents. Instead of concentrating on that, what the government has done is insist that their primary responsibility is to take direction from the government. It will require extra duties of the rep bodies if this legislation goes through.

I was trying to work out how many dollars per claimant will be available to establish claims. Considering the cost of lodging claims, it is not going to be very much. It would be far less than $100. I would have thought it would be roughly about $50 per person.

With all these extra requirements of the rep bodies, as Senator Bolkus has mentioned, I am concerned that you also have the situation of rep bodies having to fight for their very existence. The issues are about accountability to the people that rep bodies represent. I believe that government over time has helped to create some of those problems. It is well overdue that governments and the Australian government should ask the members, those people who are served or represented by rep bodies in Australia, to find out how best the rep bodies themselves can meet their needs.

I recall that a little while back the Central Land Council put forward some potential models for decentralisation: methods of using resources or making resources available and allowing the local groups and local clans who were running claims to be in control. Those kinds of models could be discussed widely. I believe the government has a role to enable that level of accountability—that level of response to the members and constituents which both ATSIC and the rep bodies are serving—to flourish. Instead, the government is insisting that more and more onerous conditions be imposed and, as I have mentioned, that the bodies themselves fight for their sheer existence instead of being able to concentrate on the many different jobs, roles and responsibilities that they have been loaded with as a result of these kinds of changes.

It puts the onus on the minister. I have seen examples, for instance, with ATSIC where there is a very small amount of decision making left with the representatives. When a decision is finally made between all the members of the groups represented by ATSIC, the minister says, `No,' and they wonder what it was all about. Those kinds of things are very disheartening, very disempowering and constantly wear down the ability of people to have confidence in the bodies that represent them because they have been given no ability to make decisions on their behalf. I think that is what we and the government should be concentrating on: real self‐determination, sovereignty issues and enabling those changes which will enable those rep bodies to be thoroughly accountable to their constituents, not to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the mathematical assertion made by Senator Margetts, which was I think either $60 or $600 per claim, if you round the number of claims up to 700 and there is $42 million a year, that is $60,000 per year per claim in the current system. The total expenditure on rep bodies over the four years 1994‐95 to 1997‐98 is $133 million. I am not sure what point she was attempting to make, but $60,000 per year per claim does seem a reasonable allocation of resources.

SPEECH.PARA: The rep bodies are there to service native title claimants. We are on about native title claimants getting the best possible service to facilitate their claims and to facilitate recognition of their common law native title. The rep bodies are not the end in themselves; they are the means to the end. The parliament has a right to ensure that those rep bodies meet the appropriate standards in servicing native title claimants and holders. I think there is general agreement round the chamber that that is appropriate and is a deficiency of the current act.

BREAK.PARA: We are responding to the Keating government's review of native title bodies, which recommended much of the procedures we are putting place. This was a review initiated under the Keating government and done under the auspices of ATSIC itself, because it recognised the problem. We have adopted them.

We think recognition of current bodies is an appropriate procedure to go through, particularly when you are agreeing to the proposition that there be only one rep body per area—a very sensible suggestion, I would have thought. But, given that the rep body then has a monopoly in that area, you must be seen to be ensuring that that representative body is a properly accountable body—accountable for the funds it receives from the Australian taxpayers and accountable to its clients, the native title holders. Given the quite significant powers and functions which the bill gives to rep bodies, they must be seen to be able to perform those functions according to higher standards. As I say, their authority and their capacity to perform their functions can only be enhanced if they go through this re-recognition process and, at the end of the 12 months, are recognised under the new scheme. That can only enhance their authority and their capacity to perform the quite considerable powers and functions which are given to them under the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just checking the minister's maths. At $600,000 per claim that means—
—Sorry, $60,000 per claim means basically that the entire money from the $40 million is going into the 670 claims, I would have thought. There is nothing left for administration or anything else.
—He doesn't reckon they do anything else.

—That is right. With all the other functions you have required them to do and expect them to do, there is nothing left. I just did the maths on the back of an envelope; I need to do more. What I was talking about was the actual assistance per person to establish their claims, their rights, and in Australia at the moment it is not looking too special.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds reasonable, Senator Minchin, but we all know that the provisions have heaps of poison in them, and that is what I would like to focus on. You try to argue that the empowering provision of the minister is a normal one in terms of the minister's capacity to deregister or not to re‐recognise. But it is so broad that the minister can take anything into account. Where you have two competing bodies, a new one and an old one, there is no real recognition given in those criteria for an exercise of discretion relating to the ongoing work done by a particular body. You might say that there is indirectly but, as I say, the breadth of the power is something which really gives the minister a blank cheque.

SPEECH.PARA: There are lots of provisions that are of concern but one in particular is your last‐minute amendment No. 85, which is on page 15 of your amendments. This is the provision relating to `access to information'. It is an extraordinary provision. We all agree that there should be strong provisions to ensure financial accountability; that is, capacity to inspect accounts, records and so on. This particular provision—I raise this as a matter of grave concern—is such that it allows a person to be appointed by the minister. It then allows that person to have full and free access to documents relating to a rep body and to make copies of, or take extracts from, any such document. That person may also require a rep body to answer questions, to produce documents in a rep body's possession, and so on. The amendment goes on to say:

(2) A representative body must produce a document or record or disclose information as required under paragraph 1(c), whether or not the document, record or information is the subject of legal professional privilege.

Let us take into account that rep bodies quite often find themselves in legal proceedings with government, particularly with the Commonwealth government. We often have an adversarial situation. This power is so broad that it would demand the production of documents, regardless of legal professional privilege. The amendment then goes on to say:
(3) A document, record or information does not cease to be the subject of legal professional privilege merely because it is produced under paragraph 1(c).

That is a great saving grace if one is in court against the government, and the government has access to all the documentation of the other side in the legal proceedings. If the rep body does not comply, it is guilty `of an offence punishable upon conviction by a fine not exceeding 20 penalty units'. Then there is a subsection about self-incrimination which states:
. . . it is not a reasonable excuse for a representative body to refuse or fail:
(a) to give information; or
(b) to produce a record or document;

. . . on the ground that the information or the production of the document or record, as the case may be, might tend to incriminate the representative body or make the representative body liable to a penalty.

Then you have the provision that the information is not available in criminal proceedings unless it is in respect of proceedings under subsection (4), which is failure to comply, or subsection (7), which relates to producing false or misleading material.

Here we are embarking on very dangerous ground, because those two provisions do not really give the protection that most Australians expect and deserve under our general criminal law or under our legal principles. We basically have a situation where a rep body, quite often in dispute with government, is going to have its legal professional privilege stripped away from it and has to produce documentation. This amendment also makes inroads on the self-incrimination provisions. That in itself is bad enough. But what protection do rep bodies have if they are in legal proceedings as against the Crown? As I say, this is a last-minute amendment which was sold as an olive branch to indigenous Australians. But it is more like a crown of thorns, isn't it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —What is being proposed here is the application of the existing ATSIC Act arrangements regarding audits but with an additional protection—not currently there—in relation to access to legally privileged documents. Our amendment No. 85 makes it clear that, although a rep body must allow an auditor or investigator full access to all documents relating to the rep body, whether or not such documents contain legally privileged information a rep body will still be able to claim that such documents are subject to legal professional privilege.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a protection mechanism which, as I am advised, is not there in the current ATSIC Act auditing arrangements. So it is taking the ATSIC Act provisions and applying them in respect of an audit ordered by the minister, but it is making sure that there is proper protection of legally privileged documents. So yes, as is currently the case in relation to ATSIC audits, the auditors can have access to those documents, but that is the end of it. They cannot report on them or provide those documents or allow those documents to be used in any other respect which, as I understand it, is not a limitation placed there in relation to existing ATSIC Act audits. We are putting that there to provide some protection for such documents, without preventing the auditors themselves having access to them in respect of their obligations to conduct such an audit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could say that, with friends like you, Senator Minchin, who needs protection? My understanding is that the ATSIC Act operates in respect of the relationship between ATSIC and the rep bodies. Our concern is that the rep body could find itself in dispute with the government, and it quite often does. In those cases, there is capacity here for an agent of the Crown, as is termed in the legislation. The agent of the Crown can basically do all these dastardly things that are listed in 203DG. The importance is: what protection do you have in court proceedings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The auditors cannot pass on those documents. They can have access to them but they would be in breach of the law if they passed them on. So they could not be available. I recognise your point: sure, a rep body may be in dispute with the government, but legal professional privilege attaches to the documents in respect of any other proceedings. It is simply saying that we believe access to them for the purpose of the audit should be allowed, but privilege remains and privilege attaches to them. They cannot be passed on or used in any other proceedings.

—The point is, Senator Minchin, you are talking here not just of an auditor; you are talking here of a person appointed under section 203DF(1). That person could very well be a member of the Attorney-General's Department or another agent of some description. What protection is there in the law to ensure that this does not happen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a worry that someone as low as an officer of the Attorney-General's Department could be included here! It says this in 203DF:

SPEECH.PARA: Appointment of person to conduct inspection and audit or investigation
(1) The Commonwealth Minister may appoint a person who, in the Commonwealth Minister's opinion, has skills or knowledge . . .

They are bound by the secrecy provisions that attach to Commonwealth officers, as I understand it. It would be in breach of the law if they were to breach the privilege which attaches and—by our amendments, ensures—will continue to attach to such documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is: the minister has the discretion to appoint an agent in a circumstance where there could be litigation going on between the parties. What I find most objectionable is that there is this power to drag out this information in cases where there is no protection in the circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of a person appointed, you could even appoint Hugh Morgan if you wanted to. What would be the fairness in that? The point I am making is that it is just so broad, discretionary and does have some real intended or unintended consequences in respect of ongoing proceedings, but there is no qualification as to who could be appointed on behalf of the government. We say that it is better that this power be left with ATSIC and ATSIC's relationship with the rep bodies. Then ATSIC can report to the minister whether or not there are serious and ongoing irregularities of accounts. It is better to do it that way rather than to have a situation where the government can intervene directly with a person of their whim in situations where there might be consequences such as those I have just mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess there is a major philosophical difference here. We think that the minister acting on behalf of the parliament and the people should have that ultimate responsibility. We would assume that it may never need to be enacted, but we do think it appropriate that the power be there. I draw your attention to amendment No. 84, which adds subclause (8), which states:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Auditor or investigator taken to be a Commonwealth officer

PARA.TAB: (8) To avoid doubt, a person appointed under subsection (1) of this section is taken, for the purposes of sections 70, 72, 73, 74 and 75 of the Crimes Act 1914 , to be a Commonwealth officer.

SPEECH.PARA: That will ensure that they operate accordingly. So we do think the requisite safeguards are put in place. We do think that the Commonwealth minister, acting on behalf of the taxpayers and the executive, should have the ultimate authority. We would hope that there would never be circumstances in which it should be used, but that power should be provided for in the act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am saying to the Senate is: what you may hope is something that really cannot be reflected in law and cannot play a role in any legal proceedings in those circumstances where there is an unfair situation created because the Commonwealth is in dispute with a rep body and in a situation where the minister can appoint anyone. As I say, even Hugh Morgan could be deemed to be a Commonwealth officer for these pur poses. You have a situation where the rep body is fighting with its arms held behind its back in many senses.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not good enough to say, `We hope it won't happen.' What is good enough is to say, `Let's set up a structure where we can protect legitimate interests and get the balance right.' You are not getting the balance right here. We are saying to you, `Okay, financial accountability is something that we agree with. We have moved amendments to even strengthen some of your provisions. Let's put it under the domain of ATSIC in the first instance, create that structure and make sure that the information flows through ATSIC.' It is the only way you are really going to get the protection that is necessary here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is under ATSIC in the first instance; that is the appropriate regime. The Commonwealth minister, under 203DF(2), must not appoint a person in these circumstances:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to conduct such an inspection and audit . . . of a representative body unless the Commonwealth Minister is of the opinion that there is, or may be:
(a) serious or repeated irregularities in the financial affairs of the representative body; or
(b) a serious failure, or repeated failure, to perform its functions.

I hope the circumstances would never arise. I would hope that the circumstances set out in subclause (2) would never arise. But, if they do, we believe it is appropriate for the Commonwealth minister to have this ultimate reserve authority to act in those circumstances.

It is highly constrained. There is appropriate protection of legally privileged documents. The officers are bound by the Crimes Act and, as I say, I would hope the circumstances set out in (2) never do arise but, if they do, we think it is appropriate that this power be there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get this straight. Government provides resources to a whole range of organisations, and I mentioned some of them earlier: industry groups, community groups, women's groups, migrant groups. You are saying that in this particular circumstance there is going to be an exception. When you are in dispute with all the other organisations, whether it is ACCI or whatever, with respect to government funding, then they have the protection of legal immunity. When you provide resources to other community based organisations, they have protection as well. When you send in audits in respect of some of those, more often than not you will find that somewhere in the process there will be capacity for the person who is being audited to have a look at the draft report and to provide advice and comment.

SPEECH.PARA: That happens normally. It happens with the Auditor‐General, for instance—that capacity for government departments to have a say in the final product. With all those bodies we respect legal professional immunity, but when it comes to indigenous Australian organisations you are saying, `We are not going to respect it at law. We just hope it is going to be respected along the way.'

No wonder we say there is discrimination in this legislation. This is one area where it is pernicious. And your response is, `Let's just pray and hope it does not happen.' I do not think the parliament should trust government to that extent. Parliaments should not trust the executive to that extent because, no matter what the goodwill or otherwise of the minister, there are a range of people with different interests in executives.

One of my concerns which has developed over the last 15 to 18 months is that the executive is becoming more and more isolated from public accountability through different ways. We have not, as yet, seen the government's reforms to the structure of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but, in so many ways, whether it is migration legislation, administration review legislation, funding to organisations such as environmental defenders offices or Aboriginal Australians, you are cutting off the capacity for review and accountability. In those circumstances—in fact, even without those circumstances—I would be saying that giving a capacity to the executive to override legal professional immunity is something that we should not be in the business of. But when you are doing it in a discriminatory manner and not even applying basic benchmarks of accountability to indigenous Australians, when you accommodate the concerns of other parts of the community more generously, then I do not think we can support this measure and I am sure the parliament should not as well.

The doctrine of legal professional privilege recognises the great importance of allowing litigants to prepare their cases in private. You want to make an exception at law for native title litigants to what is otherwise a blanket rule. You say, `It is there at law but we hope it will not be exercised,' but your hope is worth nothing in the court process. Not even in the explanatory memorandum would you hope that, for instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The legal professional privilege is maintained; it is not breached. We respect it and this amendment clarifies that there can be no breach of that legal professional privilege, except for the purposes of the audit or investigation. They are bound by the Crimes Act and the appropriate secrecy provisions attaching to the privilege, and the privilege continues to attach to the documents. It seems unexceptional to us. It is something that is there in our provisions but is not there in relation to ATSIC audits. It would be fallacious to suggest that ATSIC itself is not in dispute with representative bodies from time to time. This is an additional protection of legally privileged documents that may be caught up in the audit process that is not there in relation to the ATSIC Act itself.

SPEECH.PARA: We think that in expenditure of public moneys there should be ultimate accountability to the representative of the people in the form of the minister who is himself, in this case, accountable to the parliament. We do not think this is exceptional at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There should be accountability, but you should not be treating these people as second‐class citizens with a second level of rights. With respect to ATSIC, we acknowledge that, but ATSIC is rarely, if ever, in dispute with rep bodies in legal proceedings; governments frequently are. You say legal professional immunity is protected. How is it protected when an agent of the Crown can get access to the information? The horse has bolted once they have access to that information. Then you say, `Hopefully, it will not be used.' That hope that they will not do it is just not good enough. How many cases have been brought before this parliament of the executive overstepping the mark, doing things they should not be doing? It happens time and time again, no matter what the colour of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: The sort of legal professional immunity which you are providing for indigenous Australians and the rep bodies here is basically meaningless. You are saying it applies but it applies once the Crown has direct access to all information and once the Crown has demanded answers and production of documents. There is no Chinese wall here. There are provisions in the act, but in legal proceedings the capacity for someone to have a look at your case really makes a huge advantage in those proceedings. You are ensuring here, at law, that the Crown has a capacity to look at the other side's case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of hope. The provisions provide that they cannot use those documents in the way suggested and it would be a breach of law to do so. They can only have access to those documents for the purposes of the audit and legal professional privilege attaches to them in all other respects. Turning to amendment No. 84, it says:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report not to contain matters subject to legal professional privilege

SPEECH.PARA: (6) A report under subsection (4) must not contain any information, or include or document or record, that is subject to legal professional privilege or that is derived from information that is subject to legal professional privilege.
So we are ensuring the protection of such documents and it would be in breach of the law for that not to be observed.

It is not a matter of hope. What I said—please do not distort my words—was that it was my hope that the initiation of an inspection under 203DF would never be initiated under the circumstances set out in subclause (2). That does constrain the minister. He must not appoint such a person unless those circumstances are there. My expression of hope was that the only circumstances that can give rise to such an inspection would never arise. Where they do, there is considerable constraint and protection in relation to legally privileged documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin, I think you should understand this: the Crown will have access to that documentation. You say that once it has got access it cannot use it otherwise in accordance with the Crimes Act, but what do you do with someone who is in the AG's Department and has an involvement in pursuing a representative body who also may be involved in indigenous related cases? Do you say to them, `Close off one side of your brain,' or, `You can't go to the other side of the office where people have got access to this information,' or, `You cannot go downstairs'? The Crown will have access to the information and, although the law says they may not able to do certain things with it, in practice it is impossible for anyone to ensure that that does not happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to Senator Bolkus. He does, I think, bring out very lucidly the whole problem of the minister, in effect, being the quality controller of the representative groups. Irrespective of whether the information that is obtained can be used in a court case or a dispute with the representative bodies and the government, it is quite clear that a minister of the government, in dispute with a representative body, has the power to withdraw its recognition at any stage—whether he does it properly or not, there is an appearance that there will be bias on behalf of the Crown or that the parties are not on an equal footing when a minister in one of the parties can withdraw the recognition of the other party.

SPEECH.PARA: To follow on from what Senator Bolkus was saying, 203DF(1) does not apply simply to accounts and records; it also goes to a much more vague concept to:
(b) investigate the body's performance of its functions and exercise of its powers.
In 203DF(2), the minister can look at:
(b) a serious failure, or repeated failure, to perform its functions.
That is really a matter of judgment and is quite different from looking at financial controls.

It seems to me that, when the fate of a representative body is entirely in the hands of a minister of the Crown against which the representative bodies will be in dispute, the appearance of that, if nothing else, is very poor. I do not think the points raised by Senator Bolkus have been answered in that respect yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is ultimately responsible for ensuring that representative bodies created under the act and in receipt of, as I say, $133 million over the last four years are adequately performing their functions. It is his responsibility to the parliament and the people of Australia to ensure adequate performance of the functions and the exercise of the considerable statutory powers granted to rep bodies under this act. We are not talking about community groups here; we are talking about bodies which have considerable authority and power granted to them under this act and ultimately should be accountable to the representative of the parliament and the people, that is, the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, it is only a fail‐safe; the primary accountability mechanism is through ATSIC, as it should be. But we do believe, as a matter of serious public policy, that at the end of the day there should be ultimate accountability to the minister, and the minister, in exercising his responsibilities on behalf of us all in relation to ensuring adequate performance on the part of rep bodies, should have this ultimate authority. It is constrained. It can only be exercised in the circumstances set down in (2). In those circumstances, we continue to insist that it is an appropriate mechanism to install in this act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Question time will be at 2 o'clock. Let us say that Senator Bolkus is asking you questions at 10 past 2 and you are in a position to say, `Look, I don't think that you're performing your task very well any more, Senator Bolkus. We're going to withdraw your capacity to do so'? Whether or not you do withdraw his capacity to do so, he is hardly in a strong position in any dispute with you, is he? Aren't you putting the representative bodies in the same position with the government when the government can withdraw their ability to act or, indeed, withdraw their recognition on the minister's say‐so?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, I would love to have that kind of authority in relation to Senator Bolkus's performance, but unfortunately the parliament is unlikely to grant it. I do find that a most peculiar analogy between a member of parliament duly elected by the people of South Australia in the form of Senator Bolkus and a body which is granted the considerable authority and status of a representative body for the purposes of the Native Title Act. We are talking about its status as a representative body. The body itself, of course, is not affected by this. It is whether, under the Native Title Act, it maintains the authority, the powers and the functions vested in representative bodies by this act and its right to receive considerable funding from the taxpayer to perform those functions.

SPEECH.PARA: All we are saying is that ultimately there should be that capacity to exercise the responsibility of the minister in an appropriate way. Unless the minister can ultimately have such an investigation done in the circumstances set out in paragraph (2), then ultimately it constrains the minister's capacity to properly exercise his responsibility in respect of representative bodies who again, as I say, by this act are granted considerable authority, powers and of course funds under the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The regime the government is adopting, and that in fact the opposition is building on, is one where the minister does have power to seek further information under one of our provisions, and is being supplied by ATSIC with accounting information, with a whole raft of information. There is an obligation on ATSIC to ensure the minister is kept informed of serious and regular breaches.

SPEECH.PARA: But what this debate is really about is an example of the conflict situation you fall into when you do not give ATSIC a meaningful role in this accountability regime. This is just one example, and we could probably spend the rest of the week going through example after example of the sorts of things that will happen if you do not have a distance between the minister and the rep bodies—some third arm that is in there.

Self‐determination principles are important, but this conflict of interest principle is also important—and it raises its head continually in terms of some of the powers the minister will have over rep bodies. Senator Cooney mentioned one, and we have mentioned this particular legal professional privilege, but there are many.

The structure that we are suggesting is one that I think really overcomes these problems in that the first port of call, in terms of the ongoing responsibility to deregister, to make it accountable and to ensure that the minister is informed, is ATSIC—although the minister does have overriding power to deregister and to demand information. Basically, we are saying that when you start moving from a degree of self‐determination these conflict issues will always continue to arise.

As I think we have proved over the last hour or so, people are being treated in a way different from any other representative group in our community. It is completely appropriate to have rigid accountability mechanisms in place; it is completely inappropriate for government to have inspectors to inspect the legal files of rep bodies amongst so many other similar conflict situations that arise in the government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can add any more to what I have said. I think we should carry these amendments forward to a vote. Might I just indicate, in relation to the ALP amendments, that the government will not oppose opposition amendments 332, 341, 342, 344 and 322.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if you could put government amendments 77 to 79 and amendment 85 separately? The opposition will oppose 77 to 79, and also 85, but we will not oppose 80, 81, 82, 83 and 84, so you might want to put them separately.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments Nos 77 to 79 and No. 85 agreed to.
Amendments Nos 80 to 84 agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 18), omit "Part 1 of".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (line 1), omit "Part 1 of".
(3) Clause 2, page 2 (lines 5 to 9), omit subclause (4).
We have had the debate about the rerecognition process and the starting period for that. We have canvassed this at length.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments coincide exactly with the National Indigenous Working Group amendments under the names of the Australian Democrats and the Greens. We will be supporting the ALP position on this.
—Aren't we dealing with opposition amendments 1, 2 and 3 and 303. But 303 is not an amendment. Isn't it a vote as to whether the clause stands as printed?
—It is, but I will have to deal with them separately—amendments (1), (2) and (3) in the first instance, and then that schedule 3, part 3 stand as printed.
—The question now is that schedule 3, items 2 to 10 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (301) Schedule 3, item 1, page 216 (lines 5 to 7), omit the definition of transition period .
(302) Schedule 3, item 1, page 216 (lines 25 and 26) omit the heading.
(304) Schedule 3, item 11, page 220 (line 11), omit "Subject to section 203AA, the", substitute "The".
(314) Schedule 3, Part 2, page 232 (line 1), omit "Later", substitute "Other".
All these amendments are consequential to the transition period for the rerecognition process, so they can be put formally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, these amendments are identical to the position taken by the National Indigenous Working Group.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that schedule 3, items 22, 24 and 29 stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (346) Schedule 3, item 31, page 262 (after line 24), at the end of section 203F, add:

PARA.TAB: (2) If, at the commencement of this section or within 9 months of that commencement, ATSIC is of the opinion referred to in subsection (1) in relation to a representative body, ATSIC must:

TAB.TAB: (a) inform the representative body of that opinion; and

(b) within 3 months of so advising it, consider whether or not the body is likely to take steps to ensure that, within a reasonable period, none of paragraphs (1)(a) to (d) will apply in relation to it.

PARA.TAB: (3) If, at the end of that period of 3 months, ATSIC is of the opinion that the representative body is unlikely to take those steps within a reasonable period, ATSIC must give written notice of its opinion and the reasons for holding the opinion to the Commonwealth Minister.

(4) If, at the end of that period of 3 months, ATSIC is of the opinion that the representative body is likely to take those steps within a reasonable period, ATSIC must advise the representative body of its opinion and specify a period of not more than 12 months after which ATSIC will reconsider whether it is of the opinion that any of paragraphs (1)(a) to (d) applies in relation to the body.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make a brief explanation on this one. I mentioned earlier in the debate that this amendment prevents the transfer of documents from an old representative body to a new one where the documents are subject to legal professional privilege, copyright or, more importantly, where they are owned by a third person in accordance with traditional law and custom, without the consent of that relevant person. This, of course, is a critical issue: the transfer of documents of traditional law and custom without the consent of the relevant people involved. We think this amendment should be treated much differently from most of the others, and we would hope the Senate would show a degree of cultural sensitivity in supporting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is identical to the position of the Greens‐Democrats amendments so, of course, we will be supporting it.
