SPEECH.PARA: However, the body must not allow access to or transfer documents or records that are the subject of legal professional privilege or copyright, or of knowledge owned, according to traditional law and custom, by a third person, without:
(a) for privilege, copyright or knowledge of a third person—the consent of the third person; or
(b) for privilege or copyright of the body—the consent of the body.

I would like Senator Bolkus, and then Senator Minchin, to elaborate a little. The amendment contains the words `knowledge owned, according to traditional law and custom'. I ask Senator Bolkus: are these the specifics which we are dealing with? The amendment says:

However, the body must not allow access to or transfer documents or records that are the subject of legal professional privilege or copyright, or of knowledge owned, according to traditional law and custom . . .
We are talking about the transfer of documents or records that involve knowledge according to traditional law and custom—is that what we are doing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are talking here of a Commonwealth minister being able to issue directions with respect to certain documentation. The documentation we believe should be protected is primarily documentation as to knowledge related to traditional law and custom. I think you are right there, Senator Harradine. As I have said, that is an important part of this, if not the most important.

SPEECH.PARA: There are provisions also with respect to legal professional privilege and copyright, but the core concern here is multifaceted. It is not just concern about Western law's sacred documentation—they call it professional privilege—but also concern about the documentation which goes to the substantiation. It goes to any aspect of the development of a particular traditional law and custom so, yes, you are right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —If it had the words, `However, the body must not allow access to or transfer documents or records that are the subject of knowledge owned, according to traditional law and custom, by a third person, ` I could understand that. But you are throwing in the words `documents that are the subject of legal professional privilege or copyright'. I thought we had that argument just a while ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the minister: what is the government's response to the provision of an addendum to (3), where the body to which the directions apply must comply with those directions? What about if there were this addition: `However, the body must not allow access to or transfer documents or records that are the subject of knowledge owned, according to traditional law and custom, by a third person,' without, in other words, the consent of that third person or the consent of the body?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to this issue, we have provided in 203FC(1)(c)(i) that documents can only be transferred with the consent of the owners of the documents and records. We specifically tried to cater for this issue by requiring consent before they can be given over. We would have thought that was adequate, but I would have no objection to the suggestion made by Senator Harradine for additional wording in 203FC(3) if it was felt that that would ensure that protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Harradine that the reason why the opposition has proposed this amendment is that it is different from the previous debate we had. Here we are talking about the transfer of documentation from one representative body to another—one organisation to another—as opposed to the transfer from a representative body to the Crown. In those circumstances, we felt the need for an amendment, further to the previous one that we discussed, to ensure protection of copyright.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us face it: copyright is a fairly critical issue in indigenous communities—the knowledge as to custom, traditional law and also privilege. The situation is somewhat different from transferring information from a representative body to the Crown—the point we made earlier. There are many circumstances where there may be disputes as to the ownership of a particular copyright. Those disputes may in fact be at law, and they may involve different individual indigenous Australians, for instance.

That is just one case that comes to mind very quickly as to why we should have the three legs of this particular exemption or protection clause. We acknowledge that the consent of a third person can be given, but that third person should not be a victim, for instance, of a lack of protection with respect to privilege or copyright.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this is a very important issue. I believe these safeguards are essential with regard to issues of cultural sensitivity. The Greens (WA) and Democrat amendment is identical to the Labor amendment, so there is no conflict there. But certainly these kinds of safeguards are absolutely critical.

SPEECH.PARA: I feel rather committed to this amendment. In my own state the problem is slightly different where we have governments that shred things. Here we are trying to preserve records. I believe it is critical that we have these safeguards in place, so I make the appeal that this amendment be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to get it clear from the government. In amendment 203FC(1)(c)(i), the words are `but only with the consent of the owners of the documents and records'. Is the minister saying that those words qualify sufficiently the ability of the Commonwealth to direct such that the former representative body need not provide documents, as covered by Senator Bolkus's amendment? In other words, are you saying that those words, particularly in respect of documents or knowledge owned according to traditional law and custom by a third person, cover the proposition that has been put forward by Senator Bolkus? What is really the problem with Senator Bolkus's amendment? Is there some problem with regard to documents of legal professional privilege or copyright? Are those documents also covered by that catch‐all? Need not they be transferred to the new representative body, except with the consent of the owners of the documents and records?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The intent and, we believe, effect of the words `only with the consent of the owners of the documents and records' is as they are written. Those documents can only be given over if the consent of the owners of the documents and records is given. It is a plain and clear intent. I submit that the purpose of the words was to achieve that effect. I note the potentially foreshadowed amendment that Senator Harradine suggested to subsection (3), to which I express no objection. I do not want to quibble. We are all seeking to achieve the same purpose. We believe that our wording does achieve that purpose and that additional amendments are not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We are expecting the representative bodies to do a great deal. Recall the strike‐out provisions of the bill. If the representative bodies are not able to do that with the resources they have, it is possible that claims can be struck out. If the information held by representative bodies does not have the confidence of those people involved, it can be that they must be advised, if it is sensitive material, that it will be transferred from one representative body to another. People may well then take the step of withdrawing the material currently held by representative bodies. It may make it more difficult for representative bodies to put together a claim. Once again, it would be struck out because they have not reached the information that is required under the onerous conditions of this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This is another way of making it more difficult for people to have confidence in the system. I do not think it is unreasonable for people to know that there is a requirement that their material be treated with sensitivity. If the government did not recognise that, one might be suspicious that they think they would rather have claims struck out than have people have confidence in the ability of their material to be treated sensitively.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are concerned that the clause does not cover what we are concerned to cover. For instance, we do not think the owner of the copyright is covered by it. The clause goes to documents and records relating to the performance of functions and the exercise of powers in respect of a former area. Copyright documents are not covered by that and neither are documents that go to customary rights, laws and traditions. The clause does not really cover that. If Senator Minchin has no real problem with it, I suggest that, in order to finish this before lunch, he accept our amendment as an addendum to subclause (3).

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Electronic Smart Cards: Code of Conduct

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Minister, I refer you to the government's launch last week of a code of conduct for government departments wishing to use electronic smart cards. Given that Centrelink has indicated that it is actively looking at smart card applications in the social security area, why is the code of conduct only voluntary? What guarantees can you offer Centrelink clients that personal information acquired by smart card operators will not be misused? What sanctions will exist to deter and punish the misuse of smart card data?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to Senator Collins, this is an issue which the government takes very seriously. The Asia-Pacific Smart Card Forum's smart card code of conduct was launched by the Attorney-General on 27 November and that is for adherence by the private sector organisation signatories. Any smart card schemes which are developed by the government will be covered by the Privacy Act 1988 and any specific legislative and confidentiality requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: Centrelink is applying a wide consultative approach in the development of its smart card schemes. A request for information issued recently to industry was also forwarded to privacy advocates for comments and a privacy advocates' workshop is planned for January. Discussions by Centrelink with the Privacy Commissioner and the community groups are in process and a privacy framework is to be developed after these consultations to alleviate concerns that government advocates and the Australian public may have about the utilisation of the new technology.

It is certainly not the government's intention that smart cards will become a de facto Australia Card, as has been suggested by at least one commentator, and safeguarding individual privacy will be a vitally important element in Centrelink's development of proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, the Ernest Henry mine, a $310 million mine near Cloncurry in my electorate, was officially opened by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Borbidge, on 22 October this year. Could you explain how an Aboriginal group that was formed in mid‐1996 can now seek a Federal Court injunction to stop an operating mine? Does this precedent mean that there is no certainty associated with any project involving native title claims even after they have been approved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator MacGibbon for that question. If any further example were needed of the legal and practical unworkability of the previous Labor government's failed native title legislation, then this would be it. The Federal Court application of the Mitakoodi Juhnjlar people seeks to have the Ernest Henry mine leases declared invalid; it seeks to restrain the Ernest Henry mine from continuing to operate; and it seeks unspecified compensation and damages. The Ernest Henry mine is a $310 million project opened, as Senator MacGibbon said, only six weeks ago. The operation covers 14 separate mining leases, some of which were granted or renewed prior to the Wik decision or to the Mitakoodi native title claim, and some of which were renewed after the Wik decision on the basis they were legally enforceable rights.

ANSWER.PARA: The Ernest Henry joint venturers have had a positive and rewarding relationship with the local Aboriginal community through their peak body, the Koutha Aboriginal Development Corporation. Over 100 Aborigines worked on the mine construction. The permanent work force includes a significant number of Aborigines, and Koutha itself is a joint venturer in the mine trucking contract worth $3 million a year. It is an example of the type of amicable, freely negotiated agreements between miners and Aboriginal communities of which I informed the Senate last week.

The Mitakoodi group was unheard of when these arrangements were initiated and it has since refused to join the Koutha group. Instead, it has attempted to extract $120 million from the mine owners in return for ensuring no native title interference with the mine site, its power or water supply.

Senators will recall the involvement of Mr `15 per cent' Charlie Perkins in that little $120 million extortion attempt. This latest court action is yet another ridiculous demand made possible by the Labor Party's legacy of confusion and uncertainty which invites litigation by unproven and unrepresentative native title claimants. It is a legacy which the ALP still refuses to acknowledge, and it still refuses to support the Howard government's plan to restore a system which is fair and equitable to all parties.

Why won't the Labor Party support the validation of mining titles entered into in good faith before the Wik decision? Do they want not just the Ernest Henry leases but thousands of other mining leases, pastoral leases and other tenements to be thrown into further doubt and confusion? Why won't the Labor Party not support the government in implementing the agreement with the Koutha corporation and the business opportunities, the employment and training for local Aborigines which the Ernest Henry mine provides?

The only answer is that the ALP continues to put politics before good policy. They stick their heads in the sand and they refuse to acknowledge the mess which they created. They do not care about lost investment. They do not care about lost opportunities. They do not care about regional Australia and lost jobs. It is, as I said the other day, a shameful Labor legacy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Finance and Administration: Workplace Agreement

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance and Administration. I refer the minister to the enterprise agreement being finalised at the Department of Finance and Administration that includes annual performance bonuses of up to 15 per cent on top of a six per cent salary rise. Minister, are you aware that this agreement will deliver salary rises in excess of the target band established by the Reserve Bank? Given the Reserve Bank's enthusiasm to interfere in the recent TWU wage claim, does the minister anticipate Reserve Bank opposition to the enterprise agreement, or are the RBA's inflation targets for wage outcomes selective and discriminatory?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Mackay for that question. I have got some advice here from the Minister for Finance and Administration. The certified agreement package that the Secretary to the Department of Finance and Administration has offered to all staff below the Senior Executive Service provides two three per cent per annum pay rises and access to performance pay of between two and 15 per cent. A one-off 1.25 per cent bonus has been included to compensate for the late commencement of the agreement in the current year. The agreement has been cleared by the department.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.
—Thank you, Madam President. You get asked a question by Senator Mackay and you try to answer it and Senator Faulkner is sledging the whole time. It makes it very difficult for people.

ANSWER.PARA: A key element of the package is the new performance management framework which provides access to performance pay for all staff. The Minister for Finance and Administration is advised by the secretary to the department that this framework provides a strong foundation for the new Department of Finance and Administration to establish itself as a professional, high performing organisation. The package also provides for cashing out of overtime, higher duties allowance, meal allowance and streamlining of administration in areas such as working hours and leave arrangements. Savings in these areas provide a significant offset to the cost of the package.

Supplementation available to this department is no different to any other APS department and is but one source of funding for the package. Re‐engineering of other departmental processes will also deliver significant efficiencies and provide better outcomes and increased productivity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now will you answer the question? What does the Reserve Bank say?
—Senator Cook gets very excited. If Senator Cook could keep quiet for a brief moment, I could answer the question. You hit a six the other night, Senator Cook, which no-one will ever forget.
—Senator Kemp, I draw your attention to the question.

—As I was trying to say during this relentless sledging from the other side, re‐engineering of other departmental processes will also deliver significant efficiencies and provide better outcomes and increased productivity. The overall cost of the package—

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —this is relevant, I would have thought, if you could all fall silent for the briefest moment—can be funded within the existing departmental running cost allocation. The Minister for Finance and Administration concludes—and I am sure all senators would agree with this—that he is sure taxpayers would appreciate the emphasis the department is putting on high performance and the provision of quality services and value for taxpayers' money.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I reiterate the question. Are you aware that this agreement will deliver salary rises in excess of the target band established by the Reserve Bank. Given the Reserve Bank's enthusiasm to interfere in the recent TWU wage claim, does the minister anticipate Reserve Bank opposition to the enterprise agreement or are the RBA's inflation targets for wage outcomes—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. A supplementary question cannot be a repeat of the first question. If she has something that arises out of the answer that she wishes to raise, then she has the opportunity to ask a supplementary question. You cannot simply get up and repeat the first question.
—I think the Senator is suggesting that she did not get the answer to the question the first time.

—I will repeat the last paragraph. Given the Reserve Bank's enthusiasm to interfere in the recent TWU wage claim, does the minister anticipate Reserve Bank opposition to the enterprise agreement or are the RBA's inflation targets for wage outcomes selective and discriminatory?

—It is a real problem that there is constant chatter on the other side. The consequence is that Senator Mackay did not listen to the answer. Senator Mackay, listen this time. The certified agreement package that the Secretary to the Department of Finance and Administration has offered to all staff below the Senior Executive Service provides two three per cent per annum pay rises and access to performance pay of between two and 15 per cent. Did you understand that? The final thing is that the overall cost of the package can be funded within the existing departmental running costs. Two three per annum pay rises plus performance pay, Senator Mackay. I do not think you know what you are talking about.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. My question relates to the government's successful economic strategy. In the last fortnight, as a result of coalition government policies, we have seen a major pick‐up in business expectations, a 24 per cent rise in new motor vehicle registrations over the year to October, skilled job vacancies rising to their highest level in nearly two years, strong increases in capital investment, and small business confidence at its highest level in over 2½ years. Minister, will you outline the implications of these excellent results for Australian families and small businesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —With pleasure. Certainly, benefits are starting to flow to the Australian community from good economic management. They always do. That is why we adopted sound economic policies in contrast to our predecessors, the previous Labor government.

ANSWER.PARA: You may have noticed the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry comments yesterday in its survey of business expectations which confirm that the Howard government's economic strategy is on track with significant improvements in business conditions, sales, exports, employment and business investment. In fact, ACCI said:

These results provide confirmation that the actions taken by the Government to lower the deficit through cuts to expenditure are paying dividends. The structural changes have improved our economic fundamentals and restored competitiveness. They have given the economy an underlying strength it has not had for many years.

Not surprisingly, therefore, today we have building approvals rising by 3.7 per cent in October to be 4.6 per cent higher over the year, and retail sales are 5.1 per cent higher over the year as well. That is good news not only for those industries but for all the community that benefits from the flow down of those benefits.

This is, as we have said before, the government of record low interest rates, record low inflation, rising consumer confidence and strong business investment. Perhaps there is no better example than the car industry. We announced on 5 June a package for the car industry which would protect jobs and grow the industry. I am pleased to say that the car industry has responded positively. There has been a commitment of massive investment.

For example, Toyota decided in August to invest $1 billion with the creation of hundreds of jobs and expected tripling of exports by the year 2005. Mitsubishi from my own state has confirmed a marked increase in employment this year following the release of its new model and strong growth in exports. Ford has confirmed that it will slash new car prices next year for the first time in memory because of increased competition in the Australian market and the expected slow‐down of the Asian economy. So we are able to meet the competition.

There is further good news today: South Australian car component maker Britax Rainsfords has won a $115 million, five-year contract to supply rear vision mirrors to the United States, lifting company exports by 30 per cent and creating another 30 direct jobs and a similar number in the supplier, transport and packaging industries. This is good news for all Australians and a demonstration of industry responding to the positive policies and sound economic management of the Howard government.

Furthermore, the benefits are now being seen in employment. Employment has risen 70,000 since May, the ANZ job vacancy measures have risen by a strong seven per cent in the three months to October, and the DEETYA skilled job vacancy survey is at its highest level for two years. All Australians can benefit from the sound economic management of the Howard government, and all Australians are starting to so benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Further, could the minister tell the Senate how the coalition's economic strategy differs from alternative proposals that have been put around in recent times?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Labor today? Labor has abandoned Keating and it has gone back to Whitlam, apparently. The Whitlam model of double digit inflation is now the goal of this Labor Party.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Robert Ray interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —This Labor Party, Senator Ray, that was not even prepared to amend its basic principles document. Its basic principles document says that its basic objective is:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the democratic socialisation of industry, production, distribution and exchange.

How tired! How out of date! They say they are trying to model themselves on Blair. Blair had the courage to change the old dogma, but not the Beazley Labor Party. They could not face up to that change—too radical by far.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is too much noise on my right.

—There is not much noise on the other side at the moment, Madam President. It is not surprising that the other day Mr Brereton broke out and talked about the foreign policy fatigue of the Labor Party—(Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Minister, you told the Senate on 20 November that the Port Hinchinbrook acid sulfate soil management plan was a thorough plan designed to ensure world heritage values are properly protected. Why then did the Australian Society of Soil Science put out a press release on 27 November expressing concern about the management of acid sulfate soil at the Port Hinchinbrook development, pointing out that the independent site monitor, Professor Peter Saenger, is not accredited and that Professor Ian White, who pronounced the management plan inadequate, is accredited? Aren't you being hoodwinked by the Queensland government and Keith Williams? When are you going to listen to the real experts and intervene in this shabby, shonky process before serious damage is done to the Hinchinbrook Channel when the wet season sets in?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I am surprised that you would take a slash at the independent monitor, Professor Saenger, who is very able and a fine professional. It is true that he is not a member of the professional organisation to which you refer. That is correct. But, of course, the acid sulfate plan was approved by QASSIT, the body that had the responsibility in relation to approving the plan for acid sulfate monitoring. I think you will come clean and tell the Senate that QASSIT is made up of professionals who are members of that association. Isn't that correct, Senator? If you do so, that will put that little one to rest.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, the site is subject to testing by a site supervisor as well. So, in fact, we have three levels of supervision here on acid sulfate: the site monitor, who I understand is the site supervisor, who takes daily readings; QASSIT, who had to approve the plan and who have the professional qualifications to which you specifically refer; and the overall independent monitor, Professor Saenger, whom I had never heard criticised by anyone until I read that press release by that particular professional organisation.

The distinction we make between this project and so many others that have occurred in the last decade up the Queensland coast is that this project does have an acid sulfate plan that not only had to be approved by QASSIT, properly qualified people, but also went out for examination by two independent authori ties. After approval it then has to be subject to the overall independent monitoring of Professor Saenger. So what you have is an elaborate acid sulfate plan being implemented to protect against any run‐off of acid sulfate soils. That is in contrast to so many other projects that have occurred up the Queensland coast in the last 10 years.

Whatever the honourable senator might think of Mr Williams or this particular project, he ought to acknowledge that greater efforts are being taken in relation to this project to protect against acid sulfate run‐off than practically any project in the history of the Queensland coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. To satisfy me, Minister, will you table all the results of the tests that have been undertaken?
—I will see what is available.

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, I remember the coalition's election debt truck. Yet, since your government took office, net foreign debt has risen by $24 billion and the amount of Australian assets owned by foreigners has risen by $30 billion. Does this trend of more and more of Australia being owned or in hock to foreigners worry the government? Do you concede that your budget policy and industry policy have so far had the effect of accelerating rather than reducing the build‐up of Australia's foreign liabilities? Will you, in the lead‐up to Monday's new industry policy announcement, be reviewing your entire approach to approval of foreign investment and encouragement of our export sector to make sure that investment and debt bring a net economic benefit to Australia and that more support is provided to our value adding exporters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murray for that question. Senator Murray referred to the foreign debt truck. The debt truck drew attention to the fact that net foreign debt increased under the previous government from $23.4 billion in March 1983 to $186 billion in March 1996, at which time Labor was thrown out of office.

ANSWER.PARA: The key to addressing the issue of foreign debt is the need for Australians to lift their own savings performance. Everyone will know that national savings under Labor collapsed. No‐one would argue with that. The imbalance between saving and investment meant that Australians had to rely more heavily on the savings of foreigners.

It is a central feature of this government's policy that we are trying to lift national savings. One of the ways we have done this is to tackle the issue of the massive deficits which Labor left us—$70 billion from their last five years in office. Senator Cook shakes his head, but he was a senior minister in that government. Senator Cook should know particularly well that the previous government collapsed national savings essentially through running up major deficits.

The first thing we have done for national savings is to tackle the issue of the deficit. It is well known that the forward estimates show that this budget will be running into a surplus by the time we finish this term of government. We have made a major attack on the problem of national savings. Equally, we are giving quite a degree of emphasis to things like the savings rebate to encourage private savings, as you will be aware, Senator Murray.

I have had an occasion before in this parliament to mention that, in the last year to 30 June, it was a super year for super. I do not think anyone would argue with that. Senator Cook and his colleagues constantly argued that confidence was collapsing in superannuation. That is not the case.

There is no doubt that the policies we have put in place will help address the problem of national savings and help to build a savings culture, to the extent that we can do that—and I have mentioned a number of examples. The signs are encouraging and that will make us less dependent on the savings of foreigners. That is one of the reasons why we are giving such particular emphasis to national savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you would share our concern, I hope, that 10 years ago foreigners owned $75 billion worth of Australian assets, or about 25 per cent of GDP; they now own over $220 billion, or 43 per cent of GDP, and the figure is still rising. Are you concerned that our rising levels of foreign investment and foreign debt are the single biggest causes of our rising current account deficit? How are you going to end that deficit in addition to the matters you have outlined already and, in particular, do you have a time frame as to when the deficits will end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things we would like to do is enlist the help of the Democrats in tackling this major problem. Senator Murray, each time we have tried to get budgets through in this parliament which tackle the deficit problem, you and some of your colleagues go missing in action. One of the ways that we are going to rely proportionately less on the savings of foreigners is for us to increase our level of national savings. The Democrats, of course, do have a role in that particular matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Murray, I note your interest in this matter; you have asked me a number of questions on this issue. I welcome that interest and hope that you will join with the government in this great task of lifting the level of national savings in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. Is the minister aware of criticism by a senior technical analyst at RetireInvest that the DSS waiting period for over 55s is administratively flawed? Can you confirm that, in calculating the 39 weeks of income support for over 55s before they have their superannuation or rollover assets means tested, periods of nil entitlement are not supposed to count? Is it a fact that the DSS computer system is not subtracting periods when no entitlements are received? Can you confirm that the inclusion of these non-entitlement periods, including waiting periods or times when casual earnings preclude entitlements, will result in people having their super and rollovers means tested prematurely? What action is the government taking to correct this development?

—Yes, I am aware of those reports, Senator Crowley, and I did call for a report on that. I do not seem to have it with me today. But some of the response that is due to you is that Centrelink, not DSS these days, has assessed only a relative handful of people—I am not sure of the exact quantum—in the manner that you have described. That was incorrect; it should not have done so. That was done through the system I understand that it is now being manually corrected case by case but that there are not many people involved. For those people who have had the worry of that, I apologise on behalf of Centrelink. But I understand that it has now been rectified.

—My question is to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. Given the close relationship between the government and the mining industry, especially on the issue of native title, is the minister aware that the Minerals Council of Australia has been conducting shameless push polling with regard to the current native title debate? In addition, was the minister or the government consulted about the decision by the Minerals Council of Australia to conduct push polling on the issue of native title; and, if so, what was the government's advice? Is it the case that the government's desperate efforts to turn the debate their way is causing panic amongst their industry advisers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I know nothing of any polling being done by the Minerals Council of Australia. It is an entirely independent body which has its own interests to protect and advocate. It is the advocate of one of the greatest industries in this country, an industry that provides huge export income for this country, employs thousands upon thousands of hard-working Australians—many of whom vote Labor as well as Liberal. It provides jobs, investment and security for people in outback Australia. It is the bedrock of your state of Western Australia and of the state of Queensland.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is an outrageous slur on the Minerals Council of Australia, which has among its members some of the greatest, strongest companies in Australia. To cast a slur upon that organisation by accusing it in this chamber of conducting push polling, a practice which we all condemn, really is outrageous. That organisation is perfectly entitled to conduct legitimate opinion polling to find out what the opinion of the Australian people is in relation to the mining industry, native title matters or any other issues it likes. It is a free country. Of course it can do polling and, if it does so, that is entirely its business. I would ask you to withdraw that slur upon the Minerals Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the minister has indicated that he does not know of the poll, it is a bit outrageous of him to suggest that I should withdraw the slur. Given that the push polling conducted by the Minerals Council of Australia contained 25 questions which effectively linked jobs to the extinguishment of native title, and given that the same sector can already claim 93 per cent of Australia's landmass and up to hundreds of kilometres out to sea, will the minister guarantee to disavow any so-called survey findings that emanate from the Minerals Council of Australia in relation to native title?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an idiotic question. I am not going to disavow anything done by the Minerals Council of Australia as a properly independent body, which I am sure conducts its own polling by using reputable organisations. Push polling, for your information, is the practice whereby you seek to influence public opinion by making thousands upon thousands of telephone calls and putting a particular opinion in the form of a question. You try to turn around public opinion by conducting thousands and thousands of calls within a particular electorate. That is not surveying public opinion.

ANSWER.PARA: There is a complete difference between doing a survey of 1,000 people nation wide to find out what the public thinks—it is a fact, as anyone who has done opinion polling knows, that you can, if you want to, get the answer you want—and push polling, which is where you canvass a whole electorate and seek to influence it to vote one way or the other by making thousands of calls putting a particular point of view in the form of a question. That is not a practice I endorse. But I entirely endorse the practice of organisations as reputable as the Minerals Council of Australia conducting polls. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, has your attention been drawn to the comments of Mr Murray Wyatt, the Chairman of the Superannuation Centre of Excellence, Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants, that the 12-page form for the super tax contains wrong instructions? Is it a fact that it would take a professional accountant up to three hours to complete the 188 questions on this form? Can you confirm that this will cost all who must complete the form several hundred dollars, even if they are not liable for the tax? Finally, will you guarantee that no taxpayers will pay the tax inadvertently as a consequence of this form's complexity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor attack on the fair and equitable superannuation surcharge continues. We will never forget that, when the Labor Party was asked to address the issue of a superannuation surcharge on the superannuation contributions of high income earners, the Labor Party went missing in action.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you did. We can go over the history of this. Your leader, Mr Kim Beazley, said in the lower House that the Labor Party would support the superannuation surcharge, if my memory serves me correctly. But when it came up to the Senate—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Kemp has been asked a question, not on the principle of the surcharge but on the administration of it. We cannot object to him distorting our position on it, but at least you could direct his attention to the question. This was a question on the administration, not the principles.
—During the remaining three minutes, Senator Kemp will have the opportunity to deal with that.

—As a consequence, the Labor Party failed, I think, in a fundamental value of the Labor Party history. It failed to support a surcharge, which was an equitable surcharge and was directed at the higher income earners. The collection of this is, as you know, well known. We have debated this in the Senate. Many people will be filling out forms. Others will be required to put that information into the tax office through electronic transfer. Many people will take that particular option.

ANSWER.PARA: The essential information that is required is not particularly complex or difficult for excluded funds, which is what I think you are referring to. It is not particularly difficult or complex. We would expect that the vast proportion of people would be able to complete those forms and complete them on time.

A lot of wild figures have been thrown around about the cost of compliance. Of course, everything that we can do to reduce the cost of compliance is what the government has been pursuing. So I think it is time that the Labor Party stopped attacking the surcharge. If this surcharge had not got through, the cost to the budget, Senator Quirke, would have been in the order of $500 million—a very big cost. That cost, of course, is being paid for by higher income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I refer to the government's plans to introduce the common youth allowance on 1 July next year. I ask: does the minister now have any idea of the numbers of young people who will be forced to return to schools and TAFE colleges? Does the minister have any idea of what the curriculum and support needs of these returning students might be? If the government is still taking no responsibility whatever for the impact of this measure on school resources, does the government at least agree that an influx of returning students halfway through the school year and without advance notice to the schools con cerned will be hugely disruptive? Finally, what is the government doing to assess and provide schools with the resources they need to ensure that these returning students are not just shifted off the unemployment queues and dumped in schools which are already stretched to the limit?

—I thank Senator Allison for that question. I have been consulting with a number of groups in relation to the effect that the youth allowance will have in relation to schools next year. The government conducted these consultations in October this year, prior to my appointment to this position. These consultations are ongoing. We have indicated that we will provide additional resources to the states and territories, should it prove to be necessary. There have been figures bandied around in the order of some 32,000 students that will be flooding back into the system.
—Is that what the cabinet submission said?

—Senator Carr, that figure is by no means certain. Can I say to you that at this stage it is still too early to say what that effect will be. I can assure Senator Allison that the government is monitoring this position closely. We are consulting closely with the principals, teachers, states and territories.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer, and I am relieved to know that the government is going to look at the question of the cost. Once again, I think it is unacceptable that schools are facing this influx of returning students halfway through the school year next year. They have no idea what the numbers will be and are uncertain about whether their schools can cope in terms of curriculum and other measures.

—I will take that as a supplementary comment, Madam President. Senator Allison, in relation to the situation, the government is looking closely at the facilities that are available. This could well be based on demographics. It is not going to be uniform across the country. We realise that some areas will be affected more than others. That is precisely what we are doing at the moment: looking at what is needed when that youth allowance comes into play.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. Minister, are you aware that less than 10 per cent of the money spent world wide combating AIDS is actually spent in the developing world, where 90 per cent of AIDS infections occur? Are you aware that the United Nations AIDS program estimates that, by the year 2010, 40 million children will have been orphaned by AIDS? What action is the Australian government taking to ensure that its foreign aid resources are being constructively targeted to assist in the fight against this pandemic?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised to hear the assertion—therefore, I suspect it is correct—that more money is spent on combating AIDS in the developed world than the developing world. Although I am horrified to hear that 40 million children will lose their parents, it is a stark reminder to us of the devastation that has been caused by HIV-AIDS. It demonstrates why we as a community should not only be sensitive to the issue but also be taking practical efforts to educate and combat the illness and to assist those who are suffering.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's foreign aid program is very much directed towards those most in need and is structured as a program to alleviate poverty, and poverty is associated with these disproportionate figures to which the honourable senator refers. A significant part of our foreign aid program is directed to primary health and to education.

I am not sure how much directly is being spent on this particular issue, but I know from the structure of our aid program that a significant number would be either directly or indirectly benefiting in terms of a better education for those less well off as to primary health care methods, and also in assisting directly in relation to better primary health care. With respect to specific figures, I will take that on notice and see whether I can get some detail for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Education: Indigenous education strategic initiatives program

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Senator Ellison. Labor had 13 years to address indigenous educational disadvantage, yet their record was appalling. For example, the indigenous retention rate for year 12 students was well under that of the general student population. Will the minister inform the Senate of the considerable efforts undertaken in the first 20 months of the Howard government to address this situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to remember, in the atmosphere of the native title debate, the initiatives that this Howard government has introduced in relation to indigenous education in the first 20 months of its term.
—Tell us how you cut the heart out of TAFE.

—In the fiscally difficult 1996 budget, Senator Carr—difficulty caused by your government's deficit—this government committed an additional $80 million over four years to the indigenous education strategic initiatives program. IESIP provides per capita funding to educational providers from pre‐school to TAFE and it is aimed at improving indigenous educational outcomes, which, in turn, will help to narrow the gap between indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1996‐97, $110 million of Commonwealth funding was set aside for that purpose. This is in addition to funding which the Commonwealth provides for all students through the states grants arrangements. Not only did the government provide additional funding, it also restructured the way that that funding was to be provided. It is no longer good enough just to pay money on historical patterns such as Labor did. For the first time in the history of education in Australia, the Commonwealth's funding to education providers is linked to agreed performance targets that aim to improve educational outcomes for students. There is a real incentive for schools to increase their indigenous enrolments and retentions as they will get more money for these increases.

Over 160 contracts are now in place with providers from tiny indigenous pre‐schools in remote areas through to the largest state education systems. Each contract identifies targets against eight key national priorities agreed to by all state, territory and Commonwealth ministers. These include, among other things: literacy and numeracy targets, increasing indigenous employment in the schools themselves, improving the outcome levels, such as year 12 completions, and expanding culturally inclusive curricula. We will await the first report of performance achieved in 1997 under these new arrangements.

IESIP also provides a strategic results element to fund schools to make capital purchases to address barriers as well as to invest in innovative programs which will have the capacity to rapidly improve indigenous educational progress. The government will soon be announcing successful applicants for strategic results funding. Around $27 million will be available in 1997 and 1998.

There is also the initiative of English as a second language for indigenous students. In the 1997 budget, the government announced funding for intensive English as a second language assistance for indigenous language speaking students from non‐English speaking communities who are commencing school for the first time. From 1998, each eligible student will attract a once‐only payment of $3,079 to the relevant state or territory education authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about Abstudy.

—This payment will enable the provision of intensive tuition to assist students to reach a basic level of English communication so that they can function effectively in classrooms using English as the language of instruction. The total cost to the Commonwealth is expected to be in the order of some $6.2 million annually, depending on level of demand in 1998 and 1999. There are also higher education initiatives, Senator Carr. A significant contribution was also made to the indigenous higher education sector. In the 1996 budget, a funding package of $72 million over three years was announced. This included about $21 million per annum for the continuation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander support funding and $6.5 million for the establishment of a number of specialist indigenous higher education centres. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The emphasis on education these days is on job skill education. Will the minister acquaint the Senate with what the Howard government has done in terms of providing traineeships to Aboriginals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I know the opposition does not want to hear this answer because it will not like it because it knows that it never did do what we are doing now. It just wants to use the native title debate against this government and say that we do not care. In the first financial year of this government there was a record number of indigenous traineeship commencements. Close to 5,000 indigenous people commenced traineeships in 1996‐97. In Labor's last full financial year—1994‐95—there were only 817 such traineeships. This government stands on a proud record in its first 20 months for what it is doing for indigenous education and training. This government is committed to improving the lot of indigenous Australians in relation to education and job opportunities.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja does not like the answer either. They do not like hearing the positives; they only want to harp on the negatives. But we are committed to the positives. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Electoral Commission: Appointment of Deputy Commissioner

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Minchin, Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister. Minister, will you confirm evidence given to a Senate estimates committee earlier this year that the successful candidate for Deputy Electoral Commissioner of the Australian Electoral Commission was on the short list of candidates? Will you take this oppor tunity to deny that this appointee was added to the short list through political intervention? Minister, can you guarantee the Senate that the successful candidate was rated either `highly recommended' or `recommended' by the evaluation panel?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —This was, of course, a cabinet decision made well before my appointment as the minister responsible for the Electoral Commission or the Electoral Act. It was an appointment made when my predecessor, David Jull, was the responsible minister, an appointment made by the cabinet. I had no part in the decision whatsoever. I have no knowledge of the decision making process used by cabinet. You would need to ask someone other than me for the information you seek. I cannot assist you. It was a cabinet appointment made by the proper and appropriate procedures. If there is any additional information that I can supply you with, I will see what I can do, but this appointment was made well before my appointment as the responsible minister.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think, given the answer that you have made, Senator Minchin, and the specifics of my question, you might care in that circumstance to take my question on notice and provide the Senate with an early reply. I would ask you to confirm that you will take that course of action. I also think that, from your answer, you might be able then to assure the Senate that you yourself played no role in the appointment of the Deputy Electoral Commissioner for Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already advised the Leader of the Opposition that I will see if there is any additional information which I can supply.

—My question is addressed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. There are half a million young Australians currently receiving some form of income support. Given the government's achievements so far in simplifying the social security system and improving service delivery, how will the introduction of the youth allowance in July 1998 benefit these young people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lightfoot for the question. This is an important initiative of the government which will be coming into effect next year. It is one which has been called for for a number of years by the major welfare organisations, but of course the Labor government was not prepared to listen. It is an important social policy reform which affects young Australians. The income support arrangements for young people that we inherited from Labor was another good example of how Labor says one thing but does another. For all its talk about the importance of education and training, we inherited a system from Labor which promoted the opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: Under Labor, young people got more on the dole than for education or training. We are going to change that. Statistics show why it is so important that we do that. Currently, some 560,000 young people receive some form of income support. Four hundred and sixteen thousand are students aged between 16 and 25 and 144,000 are unemployed young people aged between 16 and 21. The youth allowance will bring significant benefits to the vast majority of young Australians. Three hundred and sixty‐eight thousand will receive the same money as they currently do; 153,000 will receive more money than they currently do; 33,250 will receive a reduced amount; and 12,800 young people who are unemployed will no longer be eligible for payment because their parents are well off. Sixteen hundred youth training allowance recipients will not be eligible as they will not choose to return to educational training. Around two‐thirds of young unemployed people will not have their payments affected by the introduction of a parental means test.

Youth allowance is important because it treats all young people in similar circumstances more fairly. It removes the illogical disincentives for young people to go on to further education or training. Despite Labor's rhetoric in their platform, they left us with a system which encouraged young people to choose the dole over education or training. Young people getting Austudy were means tested; people of the same age on the dole were not. Surely that is unacceptable?

What will be some of the immediate benefits of the youth allowance? For starters, young people will benefit from having a system of income support which is easier to understand and from not having to change between payments as their circumstances or activities change because of sickness, full‐time or part‐time study or jobsearch. One payment will cover all circumstances, making it easier for young people to understand their entitlements and helping them make better decisions about their future.

Seventy thousand students will qualify for rent assistance for the first time if they have to live away from home; 17,000 students will benefit from more lenient criteria for the assessment of whether they are independent than currently apply under Austudy; and 41,000 young people will gain from the abolition of the requirement for a minimum Austudy entitlement of $1,000 a year. Young people under 18 who are living away from home will receive a higher rate of payment than at present. Rent assistance will also be available, including for young people exempted from the requirement to be studying or be in training. All students will now have access to the $500 loan advance currently available under newstart, and the pharmaceutical allowance. They will also be eligible for remote area allowance. There are exemptions for young people in particularly difficult situations such as homelessness.
I draw to the Senate's attention that this is inevitably going to be a better and fairer system for young people and all Australians. It is one which all political parties should endorse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What is the government doing to reduce the complexity and inconsistencies with respect to some payments to young people which the government inherited after 13 years of hard Labor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for the opportunity to elaborate on that because, of course, the system we inherited meant that two departments were paying five different payments at 13 different rates. The inevitable result was that young people and their families, particularly those who were functionally illiterate, were confused as to their entitlements. People who were entitled to help were not getting it or they were not getting the appropriate level of help.

ANSWER.PARA: By simplifying the system as we have just recently done with the parenting payment—that is, the parenting allowance and sole parent pension have been rolled into one parenting payment—we have recognised the role of parents caring for children. That was a simplification measure which was endorsed by the public and by the parliament, I am glad to say. So we now find that the multitude of payments—which, under Labor, were confusing for young people and their families—are now to be one payment, and that is a great improvement. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On Wednesday 26 November 1997, Senator Cook asked me:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . how is a tax revenue loss calculated from the tainting of a company's share capital account?
I now seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

The tainting of a company's share capital account with profits does not in itself create a tax revenue loss. It is the subsequent distribution from the company's tainted share capital account that could create a tax revenue loss.

Companies may have an incentive to disguise a return of profits as a return of capital because of the fact that distributions of capital are generally taxed more favourably in a shareholder's hands than profits distributed as unfranked dividends.

This is especially true for shareholders holding shares acquired before the introduction of capital gains tax, for whom capital distributions are tax-free. Even where shareholders hold shares that are subject to capital gains tax, the tax on the distribution can be deferred and the shareholders may have advantages associated with indexation and averaging.

Therefore, if a company taints its share capital account by transferring profits into that account, the potential maximum revenue loss from subsequent distributions from that account is the difference between tax paid on a distribution as a return of capital (which could be zero) and tax payable on a dividend of the same amount received by a shareholder on the top marginal tax rate.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, we are seeking to build upon that.
