DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Finance and Administration: Workplace Agreement Superannuation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Mackay today, relating to the Department of Finance and Administration Certified Agreement, and to a question without notice asked by Senator Quirke today, relating to the superannuation surcharge.

Senator Mackay asked Senator Kemp to speak to the proposition that the Reserve Bank had seen cause to intervene in a Transport Workers Union claim because it offended against a band of inflation increases that the Reserve Bank had promulgated, but did not interfere in the salary package negotiated by senior officers of the Department of Finance and Public Administration for pay rises well outside that band. It was a question that pointed to the hypocrisy of this government.

Of course, Senator Kemp did not answer that question. He just described the salary package without going to the point of the question. Once again, in a way which avoided the nub of the serious issues, he then tried to attack the Labor opposition on that point. This is not the first nor the last time that we harry the government on its inconsistencies about industrial relations, and, in particular, about the perfidy of this particular minister in dealing so loosely and superficially with his brief.

BREAK.PARA: The question I particularly want to pay attention to today is the question that Senator Quirke asked Senator Kemp. Senator Kemp has direct responsibilities as Assistant Treasurer and Minister representing the Treasurer in this place on superannuation. This government imposed a 15 per cent tax on superannuation recipients who earn more than $70,000 a year—that is, on high income earners. However, the way in which they have gone about imposing this new tax—a tax, I point out, that is in direct breach of the election undertaking by the Treasurer when he was seeking election to the Treasury benches as part of a new government in 1996. He promised not to increase taxes or to extend the existing tax regime at all—this new tax is a breach of that undertaking.

This tax hits low and middle income earners who are superannuation contributors if they are not able to or do not provide their superannuation funds with their tax file numbers. That is to say, people who are not targets of this tax are having imposed on them an obligation to report their tax file numbers to their superannuation funds in order to escape this tax net. If they do not, through inadvertence or ignorance or through not knowing what their new obligations are, then they will be taxed 15 per cent whether they like it or not.

Senator Quirke referred to the fact that Mr Murray Wyatt, Chairman of the Certified Practising Accountants Superannuation Centre of Excellence, said that the questionnaire that the government has issued will take an accountant three hours to complete and will impose on ordinary people several hundreds of dollars of cost simply to claim they are tax free. To prove you do not have to pay this tax, it will cost you several hundred dollars for a professional accountant, or you will incur that type of cost yourself because you cannot complete the form in time.

This iniquitous tax will, according to the Taxation Office's own figures, collect from low and middle income earners who average earnings of $35,000 a year—that is 700,000 people in Australia who the tax office estimates will pay this tax unnecessarily—$220 million of revenue. Low and middle income earners who do not have to pay this tax, because they cannot escape their liabilities or do not know about them, will contribute an income to the government of $220 million.

This minister, the Assistant Treasurer of Australia, cannot answer the question as to what he is going to do to bring tax justice to those individuals. This is a tax on the wealthy but this tax hits at ordinary Australians: the so-called battlers under John Howard's plan. This tax imposes massive red tape when the government at the election promised to cut red tape. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has just said to the Senate that this is an iniquitous tax; yet this 15 per cent tax that was imposed had the support of the Labor Party at the time it was announced. It had the full support of the opposition because, at the time that the superannuation surcharge was announced in the budget in 1996, the Labor Party knew that when they applied taxes to superannuation they did it in a most unfair manner. When the Labor Party wanted to impose a tax on superannuation—and you ought to remember they are the first people that actually imposed a tax on contributions—their idea was that the wealthier you were, the greater advantage you got in putting money into superannuation because you were able to claim a tax deduction at your marginal rate.

SPEECH.PARA: So who was responsible for the iniquitous taxing of superannuation? None other than those people who are now criticising this government for trying to put some equity back into the taxation of superannuation arrangements by making sure that those people on higher incomes actually contribute to a larger degree and that it is not possible for them to be able to claim the huge tax breaks that they got as high income earners and high marginal tax rate payers. I am sure that Senator Conroy would even agree—a man well versed in superannuation—that at the time of the introduction they supported that those people who were on higher incomes pay a higher rate than those who were on lower incomes.

It is very easy to quote quite selectively—which Senator Quirke did. He made a selec tive quote about somebody who had written in and said how much it would cost to fill out a return in order to make sure that somebody did not have to pay the 15 per cent surcharge. I am sure that Senator Cook would also agree that the figures he quoted during his response, in taking note of the question, were hypothetical figures based on low and middle income earners. The scare tactics that were put out by the opposition in regard to the number of people who would supply their tax file numbers, as we found out in estimates, have not proved to be as true as they first thought. They were talking about a 20 and 25 per cent return of tax file numbers from people in superannuation funds and yet we find out that so far the return to this stage is 65 per cent. Sixty‐five per cent was the figure quoted to us by the department.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that is rubbish.

—We will check it out, Senator Conroy. We will go back through the Hansard . They also said that, through their other matching data, 65 per cent of the remainder would also not have to pay this surcharge because they had not supplied their tax file number. So for the opposition to get up and talk about an iniquitous tax when in fact they were responsible for the most iniquitous taxation of the superannuation contributions of Australians that has been introduced ever since superannuation became the norm for most Australians is the height of hypocrisy. If you remember, they were the first people to ever charge a contributions tax on people making contributions to superannuation. They were the people who said, `If you are a worker and you want to contribute to superannuation we will take away your initial $3,000 tax deduction and replace it with a $100 rebate.' That is how well they have looked after the workers of Australia, those who want to make a personal contribution to their own financial income in retirement, when in fact they know and have always known that for those people who got into superannuation at a later stage of life there would have to be some supplementation for them ever to be able to be self-sufficient in retirement.

BREAK.PARA: So the last thing that the Labor Party, this current opposition, ought to talk about when it comes to the taxation of superannuation contributions is inequity. They were the inventors of the inequitable situation that we found ourselves in when we came into government, where they had taken away all the rights of workers to claim a deduction, they had had a 15 per cent tax on contributions, and it was not until this government was elected that something was done to put some equity back into the superannuation system by making sure that people on high incomes paid an extra amount above those who were on low marginal tax rates and were low income earners. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —We saw Senator Kemp yet again today repeat something that he knows is simply not true. When he made the assertion that the Labor Party did not support a 15 per cent tax with regard to well-off people on superannuation, he knew it to be not true. He knows that the Labor Party voted for the second reading of this bill. Our criticism throughout has not been of the 15 per cent tax; it has been of the complexity of it and the fact that it is going to have a manifestly unfair application to many middle and lower income groups. Therein lies our criticism.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp got up today in that sort of `Boys Own Annual', blustering, anti‐intellectual, almost submoronic way he answers questions and asserted that the Labor Party did not support this in principle when he knows it to be untrue. He is not going to get away with that sort of crude bluff and distortion of the historical record of what happened in this chamber.

The Labor Party, then and today, remains willing to support a 15 per cent tax on higher income earners with regard to superannuation. We do not want to see a lot of lower income and middle income earners—up to 220,000—get caught in this particular bind. We do not want to see them have to pay $220 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —All they have to do is provide their TFNs.

—Senator Ferguson says they do not have to. Senator Ferguson, go back to why we got into this situa tion—it was the collection method. Why did you adopt this form of collection method that could capture them? Because you just could not confront the fact that this was a tax and not a surcharge. If it was a surcharge, it would have only lasted one or two years. If it is permanent, it is a tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Because you said certain weasel words before the election—that you would not increase taxes—you had to invent the mirage of a surcharge. Once you made it a surcharge, tax and constitutionality meant that you had to go for a very clumsy collection method which in turn has entrapped all these people. You are right, Senator Ferguson—not one of them has to pay this. I understand that. But it is so complex, and human nature being what it is, we anticipated beforehand a whole range of people would be caught unfairly in this. We have been proven right.

What we have also been proven right about—the main thrust of the question today, not even bothered to be answered by Senator Kemp—is that the forms to be filled out are, firstly, complex; secondly, contain errors; and, thirdly, for a lot of people, will require the use of accountants. It will require, by our estimation, up to three hours work. In other words, a lot of people who do not have to pay any of these things may be out of pocket by $200, $300 or $400. That is not particularly fair; that was not the intention.

What we have got is a principle we all support and an application that very few people in the community support. Guess why they are paying that price? So that the Liberal and National coalition can be politically pure and not be seen to have broken their word. Of course, that scam was done over when the surcharge in legislation became a tax by way of a majority in this chamber.

But it does highlight a very serious problem in question time. I have seen good ministers and bad ministers come and go but I have never seen a minister so weak and failing to get across his portfolio as Senator Kemp. I have never seen one. I have some sympathy if the questions tend to be highly technical—this is a tough area—but clearly, issues on superannuation or wages policy and the Reserve Bank's relationship to it deserve some answer, not just the `Boys Own Annual' bluster.

It is not just that Senator Kemp is getting an extra $50,000 a year to seat‐warm over there, but the overall cost of supporting him as a minister is close to $1 million. If the same productivity principles which Dr Boxall has developed for the new Department of Finance and Administration were applied to Senator Kemp, he would never get a pay rise. I am going to make a big statement: I think he is the worst one I have ever seen, in 16½ years in this chamber, occupy a berth on the front bench.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal in particular with the question asked by Senator Mackay. I am very surprised that she asked this question in this place without having done her homework. I am particularly surprised that such a question was asked by the other side when this relates to an enterprise agreement, which I thought was the policy of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I am even more surprised that they would be in the position of criticising a pay increase based on productivity; in other words, better pay for better work. It is absolutely true—there is no question about it, as I understand it—that the Department of Finance and Administration has recently released a draft agency agreement to its staff for consideration. But I point out there is no breach whatsoever of the RBA's inflation target.

There are some very good reasons for this. One is called productivity. Have you heard of it over there? Do you understand it? There is no breach of the RBA's inflation target. The draft agreement involves an up‐front lump sum equivalent to 1½ per cent of salary and two pay increases of three per cent phased in over the 18‐month life of the agreement.

The department has developed a comprehensive performance management scheme to accompany the introduction of a new broad‐banded classification structure. This replaces the old semiautomatic pay increment system of salary advancement with a performance based system. Do you understand that? That is what this does. It will enable competent employees to access annual performance bonuses starting at two per cent of salary, and those with superior performance will be able to access a bonus of up to 15 per cent of salary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Explain what the productivity system is.
—You were criticising the agreement in the Public Service. Reward for enterprise, that is what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: All agency agreements must be funded from within an agency's appropriation. This applies to the finance department's proposals, which are based on a range of initiatives that will increase productivity and realise savings in the department.

Aside from its new performance management systems, these will include a rationalisation or removal of various allowances and the streamlining of leave provisions; and more flexible working hours and working arrangements, with more flexible deployment of staff—something I would imagine the people in the Department of Finance and Administration would welcome with open arms.

The draft agreement is consistent with the government's policy parameters for agreement making in the APS which allow for better pay for better work—something that is pretty foreign to those on the other side of the chamber. The improvements in remuneration are linked to achieved improvements in productivity and performance and therefore are consistent with maintaining low inflation.

Once again, we have heard a question from the other side which endeavoured to criticise advancement in the workplace for workers in this country. I often ask the question of those on the other side of the chamber: why do you pretend to represent workers in this country while you so often work to bring them down? Why do you so often endeavour to create a situation where they cannot, by their own endeavour, by their own achievements, by their own initiative, advance their own particular position while at the same time improving the productivity of this country?

One of the most crucial things we need in this nation is an improvement in productivity. Here we have a department going about that with a proposal before it which does that. But the other side does not like it, for some funny, unknown reason. It is something that I do not understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —That wasn't the issue.

—It is the exact issue. It was the basis of it. They are saying that the RBA should have intervened. But they did not breach the RBA guidelines. They did not breach what was required, so why should the RBA intervene? That is the question that requires an answer. There is no reason whatsoever why it should intervene.

SPEECH.PARA: I will make the point once again that I am quite certain that, had there been a necessity or reason for the RBA to intervene, or if there had been a breach of its guidelines, it would have done just that and intervened. But it is quite clear from what I have put down here today that there was no breach. Therefore, there is no necessity whatsoever for the RBA to interfere in this agreement. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —This superannuation surcharge continues to be one of the most damning pieces of legislation that this government has brought before the chamber. It is a laughing stock in the superannuation industry, it is a laughing stock in the broader community and it is a laughing stock among its own members of the back bench. They know that it is hopeless, inequitable and inefficient. The Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) continues not to listen to anybody, including Senator Ferguson, Senator Watson and Senator McGauran, his government members on the superannuation committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the chamber's attention to the report of the superannuation committee on the recent amendments. I particularly urge members to take the time to read, complex and detailed as it is, the Hansard of the Select Committee on Superannuation hearings on these bills, because it really exposes what a hopeless shambles this legislation is.
I draw to the attention of senators a couple of comments by Sydney lawyer Noel Davis of Clayton Utz. He calculated how much this is going to cost to administer. Here are his sums:

for the 150,000 small funds, it will cost a minimum of $500 to produce the required information for the tax office. That is a total of $175 million. For the large funds, he estimates costs of at least $1 million per fund, or about $100 million, which is just for the 100 largest funds. That is $275 million that members of superannuation funds—ordinary working people in this country—are going to have to pay to collect the tax because this government wanted to pull the wool over people's eyes that it was not really a tax but just a surcharge.

They are only projecting, on their best estimates, $500 million this year. It will cost a minimum of $275 million to collect, paid for by ordinary workers in superannuation funds, and it is only going to raise, at best, $500 million. We have already seen all the accountants in this country write to everybody who earns more than $70,000 and say, `If you don't change how you structure your salary package at the moment, you will be hit by this.' So what are they all doing? They are packaging themselves out of the $70,000 limit and avoiding the surcharge tax. So they are not even going to raise the $500 million.

Mr Davis predicts that there will be less money raised than it actually costs to implement this bill. Why is this not just unfair and administratively a nightmare but also inequitable? Hundreds of thousands of ordinary workers will pay the extra amount because they will not have supplied their tax file number. The government could not have just implemented it through the group certificate system, the simplest and easiest way to have done it, because that would have been an admission that it was a tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Slugged again.

—Senator Campbell is right; they slugged ordinary workers again. Jacques Martin told the committee that, in its administration of two large industry funds, of its 600,000 members, it has written three letters to every member to try to round up the tax file numbers, and it has only collected 23 per cent of them. That works out at 462,000 ordinary working Australians with incomes less than $70,000 paying the surcharge for the rich. Every one of them will pay it.

SPEECH.PARA: This government is so stingy that—this has been revealed in this chamber in the last few days—if the tax office collects the money from these people, it is not even prepared to pay the money back with interest if the money has to be given back. It is not even prepared to pay interest. Can you imagine what would happen if you were late paying your tax bill. You would have to pay interest. But if the tax office incorrectly collects money from you, this government is so stingy that it will not give you interest on the money that the tax office has been holding which it should never have collected in the first place. That is how stingy this government is.

There is a further administrative debacle; Senator Ferguson knows about it. The Institute of Actuaries wrote to the government and the committee and said that there is no actuarial practice. It is not possible to work it out. This is such a debacle. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook took note of a question asked of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, by Senator Mackay as well as a question asked by Senator Quirke. I want to concentrate on the answer given by Senator Kemp to Senator Mackay. Before I do, I cannot let this opportunity pass without asking—rhetorically what on earth Labor is going on about concerning the superannuation tax. On the one hand, Senator Ray is standing up here saying that Labor supports the tax in principle. It appears that the only real criticism of the superannuation tax is the manner in which it is collected. If that is the case, which it certainly seems to be if Senator Ray is to be believed, and who are we to think that he does not have the definitive say for the opposition, what can be fairer than a tax imposed on those who can afford it—that is, high income earners paying a higher rate of tax than those who do not earn a high income?

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party has certainly speculated widely on problems that have really not materialised. We have heard Senator Ferguson, who has been a member of the committee, say that the only thing that is needed to solve the problem, if one exists, is for all lower income recipients to supply their tax file numbers. It ought not to be beyond the wit, quite frankly, of any taxpayer who gets into the bracket of otherwise being liable to pay this tax not only to be able to fill out a necessary form, but also to understand the imperative that in some instances in taxation law they have to supply their tax file number.

This is not reinventing the wheel. This is not something unheard of. This is not something that taxpayers have not heard of. It is really a simple procedure. It is not as if it is something which is so beyond the capacity of most taxpayers to comply with that it really deserves criticism. So here we have unequivocal support in principle for the 15 per cent tax on higher income earners. I think that is game, set and match, quite frankly, on this topic.

Getting back to what Senator Mackay said in relation to Senator Kemp, it seems to me that if the opposition cannot mount a credible criticism of a policy for which Senator Kemp is responsible, all they can do is attack the manner in which he answers questions. How childish! How churlish! How totally unsophisticated for a group of people to attack the manner in which somebody answers questions rather than policy espoused by Senator Kemp.

You only have to look at the certified agreement that has been offered by the Australian Public Service to see that not only does it actually set out to recognise that productivity is an important part of the work force, but also provides encouragement that as part of getting this work force to understand that productivity is a critical part of the sort of policy this government wants to encourage.

What are the elements of this offer? A one-off 1.25 per cent bonus has been included to compensate for the late commencement of the agreement in the current financial year. The agreement has been cleared by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business as being within the policy parameters for certified agreements for APS departments.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self‐determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need to continue to allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who wish to claim native title, the right to access legal aid outside of the Representative Bodies established under the Native Title Act.
To force Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander claimants to seek funding from so‐called representative bodies is oppressive and may result in breach of their human rights.

Your petitioners request the Senate to refuse to pass the amendment 183(4)(a) which would remove the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander claimants to seek legal aid for their native title claims from the Attorney‐General's department independently of and without interference from representative bodies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 400 citizens), and Senator Lees(from 1,100 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows:
That the Federal Government take full account of the recent Wik decision of the High Court of Australia which accepts that Native Title can co‐exist with pastoral and mining leases.

We strongly encourage the government to initiate a process of negotiation between Aboriginal title holders and other leaseholders to resolve the practical use and management of those lands subject to joint title.

We strongly disagree with any approach which proposes that Native Title be extinguished on land subject to such joint title, or which alters the Racial Discrimination Act, or the Native Title Act (Mabo), to facilitate the possibility of such extinguishment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament Assembled.

We the undersigned residents of Australia draw the attention of the House to the fact that incidents of racial discrimination in the period between February 1996 and February 1997 doubled during the same period for the previous year.

We would further like to draw your attention to the 1997‐1998 Federal Budget, which foreshadows a cut to the budget of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by more than 40% over the next two years.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House resolve to reverse the decision to cut the budget of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, so that it can carry out its role effectively, that is, defending the human rights of all people in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Children
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled
The humble petition of the Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That we:

PARA.TAB: affirm the pre‐eminence of parents' rights to give wise guidance and direction to their children
affirm the primary and inalienable right of parents to nurture, educate, control and discipline their children

oppose the autonomous rights given to children by Articles 12 to 16 of the Convention, which may allow them access to morally harmful material and people (with no adequate protection) and which undermine parental rights and disrupt proper family life.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate advise the Government to withdraw their support for the Convention on the Rights of the Child by denouncing the Convention and by indicating that the Government will not enact any laws which invade the primary and inalienable rights of parents in Australia.
And your petitioners as duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Cassini Space Probe
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government take all measures possible to bring about the halt to the launch on 14 October 1997 of the Cassini Space Probe from Cape Canaveral containing 72.3 pounds of plutonium‐238 because:
(a) it is irresponsible to undertake experiments with significant dangers to the world's population; and
(b) there are no guarantees that an accident will not happen; and
(c) if there is an accident:

PARA.TAB: (i) millions of lives on earth will be endangered through exposure to plutonium; and
(ii) the nuclear material will impact on the entire planet for thousands of years.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
(a) a proposal has been made by the Department of Transport to build a major no‐curfew international airport in Sydney's western suburbs;
(b) airports and attendant infrastructure are a major source of air and noise pollution;
(c) Western Sydney already suffers from the worst air pollution in Australia;
(d) an additional airport in the Sydney airshed will only serve to greatly increase such pollution; and
(e) an airport in Sydney's west will harm the lifestyle and wellbeing of citizens living and working within the Sydney airshed.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate not pass any bill which would lead to the construction of any new airport within the Sydney airshed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a statement and an associated document by the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) entitled Australia's strategic policy . I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Today, I am releasing the unclassified version of a Strategic Review endorsed by the Government, entitled Australia's Strategic Policy .
In light of the review's findings, I am also announcing initiatives to develop or enhance key military capabilities.

Soon after coming to office, I asked the Defence Organisation to conduct a classified review of our strategic circumstances and the military capability decisions arising from that assessment to shape the Australian Defence Force (ADF) to 2020 and beyond.
Australian governments have regularly conducted such high level reviews—the most recent one being in 1993, which contributed to the previous government's 1994 Defence White Paper.

As would be expected in the Defence policy area, this review is an evolutionary document, both in the way it assesses regional trends and in the proposals put forward for force development. I expect this evolution of strategic thinking will continue.
That said, Australia's Strategic Policy details a number of highly important policy differences.
Unlike previous strategic reviews, this document takes a crucial step beyond simply describing our strategic environment to detailing a rigorous set of priorities for force development.
The review details a maritime focus for the defence of Australia and its vital interests, and a logical, structured approach to defence equipment acquisition.

It moves defence policy away from a narrow focus on responding to low‐level contingency scenarios. It stresses instead our capacity to defend Australia in a wide range of circumstances by focussing on our maritime approaches.
Further, the document outlines a policy supporting an enhanced level of strategic co‐operation with Asia‐Pacific countries.
It recognises more clearly than past reviews, the inextricable link between Australia's security and the security of our region.
Finally, the Review places a heavy emphasis on the Defence Force's technological skills.
This document directs the ADF to the forefront of the revolution in military affairs.
This is essential given the general increase in military capabilities in the Asia‐Pacific.
The Strategic Review was not an exercise in hunting for threats. It identifies no immediate threat to Australia. It confirms that Australia is one of the more secure countries in the world.
But, defence planning is about the long term. The review analyses the potential for developments to cause security problems in the future, unlike our largely benign environment today.
In the past Australia benefited from being the most developed economy in our region, holding the most advanced military equipment and weapons.
In some defence areas, that is no longer the case.
To stay confident in our ability to defend Australia, we must be more efficient and smarter in using resources.
Developments in technology are working to our advantage. They are giving a greater capacity to watch our maritime approaches and offer high precision in the way we apply force in those approaches.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A Secure country in a secure region

SPEECH.PARA: The focus of our policy remains on our ability to defend Australia.

Australia's strategic interests do not begin and end at our shoreline. It would be a serious mistake to think we could adopt a `fortress Australia' strategy in the event of a deterioration of regional stability.
We cannot be secure in an insecure region.
In the 1980s our predecessors argued that forces developed for the defence of Australia might also be called upon to operate beyond our shores to protect regional and global strategic interests
Indeed, the Labor Government, with Coalition backing, authorised a number of these deployments—to the Gulf War as well as peacekeeping in Somalia and Cambodia.
But Labor's 1994 Defence White Paper did not recognise how changing strategic circumstances were changing the levels of demand which could be put on our forces in such operations.
We can no longer assume that forces able to meet low‐level contingencies in the defence of Australia will be sufficient to handle conflict beyond our territory.
We must make sure that the forces we develop for our own defence do indeed give options for handling crises in which vital interests may be threatened.
Wherever they are called to operate, our forces must have the capacity to survive against—and defeat—modern weapons.
Such weapons are being acquired in our region and will become standard capabilities for regional armed forces.
The Government, therefore, rejects the argument that we must choose between a defence force to defend Australia and one able—within realistic limitations—to operate overseas.
The defence force must be able to do both.
The issue Australia faces is how to build a defence force able to ensure the security of the country and able to contribute to the security of our region.
So the review concludes that, while the core of our planning will be on the capabilities needed to defeat attacks on Australia, we will choose capabilities suited to a wider range of tasks.
Our aim is to promote a secure country in a secure region.
We will not deploy forces ill‐equipped for the task. We want to avoid last minute scrambles to bring our forces up to scratch.

This review sets Defence on a path exploiting our national strengths—our high education standards, scientific and research base, our access to technology through the US alliance, and our proven ability to perform in tough military situations.
Let me address in detail some of the issues covered in the Strategic Review.

Two key factors are shaping Australia's strategic environment: East Asian economic growth and its implications for arms modernisation programs; and the changing strategic relativities between the region's major powers.

To quote the foreign and trade policy paper, In the National Interest , changing `relativities of power and influence which flow from the economic rise of East Asia will profoundly influence Australia's foreign and trade policy over the next fifteen years'.
Notwithstanding the recent currency crisis in some regional countries, that long‐term judgment holds.
Even if there is only moderate economic growth, if defence spending is constant as a proportion of GDP some regional countries could have doubled defence spending by 2010.
Regional defence spending is not a threat to Australia. Countries have a legitimate right to modernise their forces.
However, that military modernisation—in the event of conflict—could have an impact on its scale and intensity.
That leads me to the second key factor shaping our security environment—changing strategic relativities.
In the 1970s and 1980s, we defined our region of primary strategic interest as South‐East Asia, the Southwest Pacific and the eastern reaches of the Indian Ocean.
Today, tensions in North‐East Asia—for example on the Korean peninsula—have flow‐on effects in South‐East Asia much more directly than was the case in the 1970s and 1980s.
We cannot allow our thinking to be influenced by artificial boundaries. This strategic review re‐emphasises the importance of North‐East Asia to our own security.
A key issue is the prospect of increased strategic competition between the region's major powers. The end of the Cold War and economic growth has changed the strategic balance in Asia.
Underlying any consideration of changing relativities is the role of the United States. A continuing US strategic engagement and presence in East Asia is vital to regional security.
China is emerging as a powerful economic force in our region, with a desire to play a more influential role.
We do not see China as a threat to Australia. We and the region want China to be outward‐looking, prosperous and cohesive—helping to build a stable and co‐operative Asia‐Pacific.
The relationship between the United States and China will be fundamental to stability in the future. The good management of that relationship is essential.
We welcome the recent commitment to developing a strategic partnership by President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin.

The strategic review does not attempt to predict future military conflicts. Rather, it assesses the enduring features of our strategic environment and the long‐term trends likely to affect that environment.
The review articulates our key strategic interests as follows:
. avoiding destabilising strategic competition between the region's major powers,
. preventing the emergence of a region dominated by any power or powers who might wish to damage Australia's interests,
. keeping South‐East Asia—especially maritime South‐East Asia—free from destabilising disputes,
. working with neighbours to strengthen their security, thereby preventing the intrusion of foreign military forces which might attack Australia, and
. preventing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in our region.
Naturally, these priorities must be kept under constant scrutiny, and be re‐evaluated in the light of strategic developments.
We consider that there are three basic tasks which the ADF could be required to perform:
. defeating attacks on Australia,
. defending our regional interests, and
. supporting a global security environment which discourages interstate aggression.
Our highest priority remains defeating attacks on Australia.
Possessing the forces we need to defeat any realistic scale of attack on our territory is the basis of our wider defence posture.
Maintaining this level of military capability is very relevant to how we are perceived by our neighbours and allies.
We aim to be self‐reliant in defending our territory, without relying on the combat forces of other countries.
But there will be continued close contact with allies for non‐combat support, including intelligence and resupply in a crisis.
A potential aggressor would have to cross our air and sea approaches, and—having launched an attack—sustain their forces across this gap.
Our strategic geography dictates that we should plan to defeat attackers in those approaches, before they reach our territory.
In recent years, Australian defence planning placed too much emphasis on reactive operations—especially what have been called `low‐level contingencies'.

Relying on reactive options runs the risk that any crisis would be prolonged. They place little pressure on an adversary to cease attacking or threatening Australia, and concede the initiative to an adversary over the pace and duration of the crisis.

Pro‐active operations in the defence of Australia could enable us to take the military initiative, putting pressure on an adversary to cease hostilities and providing confidence that Australian lives and property would be protected.

In defending Australia, pro‐active military operations targeted against an aggressor's forces in our maritime approaches, would seek to pressure those forces before they were able to lodge on our territory.
This approach recognises the fact that Australia would have already suffered a major strategic blow if it ever became necessary to fight an attacker on our own soil.

In reviewing our military strategy for defeating attacks on Australia, the Government will, therefore, give higher priority to maritime forces—that is, air and naval forces able to operate in our northern sea approaches.

Moreover, the key future technologies for maritime operations involve enhanced surveillance and information‐gathering capabilities, as well as the ability to command and control military forces engaged in operations.
These technologies are elements of `knowledge warfare', an area where Australia has significant national potential, which we will seek to maximise as a national strategic priority.
We have also reviewed our priorities for our international security and defence relationships.
Our alliance with the United States is our most important strategic relationship.
Longstanding defence links with most of the countries in South‐East Asia and the Southwest Pacific also lay the foundation for further co‐operation.
We are working to develop a shared commitment to regional peace and stability among as many Asia‐Pacific states as possible.
But while our ties with our neighbours in South‐East Asia and the Southwest Pacific are of enormous strategic importance, the fact is that the region's strategic centre of gravity is North‐East Asia.
So, we are increasing our links with North‐East Asia, particularly with Japan and China.
We share many strategic interests with Japan and have already instituted regular political‐military talks, complemented by modest military‐to‐military links, such as intelligence exchanges.
We have also an increasing dialogue with China and evolving Defence contacts.
Multilateral structures such as APEC and the ASEAN Regional Forum (ARF) are a useful complement to bilateral ties, providing a very valuable forum for security dialogue.
In terms of military capability implications, a key issue is the benchmark against which we measure our own capabilities.
The acquisition of high‐technology defence capabilities throughout the Asia‐Pacific means we cannot take for granted that our forces will keep their technological edge.
To maintain our relative strategic position, our forces must measure up to two key benchmarks:
. First, we must have the capability to deny our air and sea approaches to any credible force, and
. Second, we must maintain a very strong regional presence as a maritime power.
The discipline this imposes on how we shape our forces leads to some tough policy choices.

These involve making decisions on the balance of resource allocations between land, air and naval forces; between current preparedness and future capability; between the scale of forces immediately deployable and the time they can be kept in the field.
Few countries, however, have as clear‐cut a strategic focus as Australia when it comes to making these choices.
Our geography dictates a maritime focus for defence.
One of the most important outcomes of this review is that we have followed through the logic of our own strategic analysis.
I said earlier that this review puts the Defence Force at the forefront of the Revolution in Military Affairs.
That is because our highest capability priority is the `knowledge edge'—exploiting information technology so we can use our relatively small forces to maximum effect.
We are giving priority to investments in three elements of the knowledge edge‐intelligence, command systems, and surveillance.

It is a major challenge to integrate these elements into a unified system giving commanders a complete picture of the battlefield, and enhancing their control of our forces—and doing that in real time, 24 hours a day.
The knowledge edge is the area which, more than any other capability, can be the decisive factor in combat, especially when it is combined with the high capabilities of our Defence personnel.
The government has approved a number of projects to enhance ADF knowledge edge capabilities, including:
. airborne early warning and control aircraft,
. enhanced satellite communications,
. an advanced secure military messaging system,
. an Army battlefield command support system, and
. an automated command support system for joint operations.
Our second priority relates to developing military capabilities to defeat threats in our maritime approaches.
. We are developing a mix of air, surface and sub‐surface forces to create a formidable barrier to any hostile ships and aircraft in our maritime approaches.
. Air superiority is a decisive capability.
Australia faces a difficult set of choices over the next decade, about our future fighter aircraft capabilities.
My Department is examining options on the balance of emphasis we should put between upgrading the sensors and combat systems of the F/A‐18 and acquiring new aircraft.
It is likely that a major upgrade of the F/A‐18 will be required—what ever the outcome of these studies—as an interim step in modernising our air capabilities.
These decisions are for a later day—and I might add, a later budget context.
. We are also looking at upgrading our air‐to‐air refuelling capability.
. As foreshadowed in the last budget, we will upgrade the survivability, maintenance and habitability of our guided missile frigates (FFGs).
. That includes upgrading their radar systems, communications equipment, anti‐submarine and mine avoidance sonars and an improved defensive missile system.
. We will enhance the surface strike and underwater defence capabilities of our ANZAC ships, including the acquisition of anti‐ship missiles for the ANZAC's new helicopters.
. We plan to expand and enhance our submarine capabilities, including by the acquisition of more capable torpedoes and a mining capability.

And we will begin work on enhancing the current Collins class design to provide data to guide decision making on future enhancements of the class, or the possible acquisition of additional submarines should that be deemed necessary.
This process will build on the strengths of the Collins, taking full advantage of new technological developments.
We have a continuing requirement to conduct patrol and enforcement operations now carried out by the Fremantle class patrol boats.

The Offshore Patrol Vessel (OPV) had originally been designated for these tasks. Following Malaysia's decision not to award its OPV contract to Tenix, our judgement is that the scale of investment required for an Australian‐only OPV is not appropriate for the performance of primarily peacetime patrol tasks.
. We will extend the life of the Fremantle class boats for as long as economical, followed by replacement with a boat for similar purposes.
Our third priority is strike, that is, the ability to operate pro‐actively against enemy forces in the defence of Australia and our interests.

. Our plan is to maintain the F‐111 in service until 2015 to 2020; to expand the operational fleet by upgrading our existing F‐111Gs; and to acquire long‐range stand‐off weapons as well as improving the electronic warfare and air‐defence suppression capabilities of the F‐111s.
. By stand‐off weapons we mean something with greater range than the short‐range weapons already being acquired.
. But we are not proposing very long‐range weapons, such as the Tomahawk land‐attack cruise missile. We do not require this weapon to meet current strategic circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Priority Four: Defeating threats on Australian territory

SPEECH.PARA: Our fourth priority is land capabilities to defeat threats on Australian territory.
Our priorities are to develop:
. highly‐mobile joint task forces;
. a limited amphibious capability;
. improved land surveillance equipment;
. aerial fire support and reconnaissance helicopters
. additional light armoured vehicles for reconnaissance and troop lift, and;
. Special Force elements will receive added attention to improve counter‐terrorist and other capabilities.
Land forces remain an essential part of our military capability.
Indeed, this Government has given a great deal of attention to the restructuring of the Army following the critical Defence self‐assessment of capabilities in the Army 21 review.
Army capabilities will therefore increase as a result of these initiatives, with the land force taking a larger share of the capital equipment budget than in recent years.

Together, the enhanced military capabilities I have outlined—and the rigorous set of priorities against which they have been developed—will give us the most modern, capable force in our immediate region.

This force relies on highly‐skilled personnel using high technology and modern equipment to achieve mobility, hitting power and flexibility, exploiting information technology to attain maximum effect from relatively small forces.
These initiatives will bring a comprehensive enhancement of the military capabilities of the ADF over the coming decade, enabling the force to meet the key benchmarks I mentioned earlier.
We will upgrade all our major combat ships and aircraft, restructure and re‐equip the land force and invest heavily in technology to promote the knowledge edge.
Of course, such capabilities don't come cheaply. Over recent years, we have spent some $2.2 billion annually on investment in new equipment.
The Defence Reform Program will, over the next three years, realise a one‐off saving of $500 million and mature annual savings of between $900 and $1000 million.

Current defence spending levels will allow us—with the savings from the Reform Program—to substantially modernise our existing defence platforms like the surface fleet, to acquire airborne early‐warning aircraft and to give the Army greater mobility.

However, the current budget does not make it possible for us in the medium term to contemplate developing major new capabilities in the form of new fighter aircraft, or a new surface combatant should government decide that such acquisitions were needed.

In determining the need for future equipment capabilities and levels of spending, the Government will monitor developments in Australia's strategic circumstances as well as the Defence Organisation's progress in implementing the Reform Program.

Australia is one of the more secure countries in the world. But that has not always been the case. Circumstances could arise which would reduce our security from armed attack. While we do not expect those circumstances to occur, strategic policy—in developing assessments of our future environment—needs to take a long view.
In taking this long view, we recognise that the ADF is the guarantor of Australia's sovereignty.
We have a natural advantage in the strengths and abilities of the young people who join the ADF. This review ensures that these people will be equipped and trained in the best way possible.
Australia's Strategic Policy provides the planning, ensuring that the Defence Force is capable of meeting this most fundamental of challenges.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond briefly to the ministerial statement. This is the statement of a government which for defence has a champagne appetite on a beer income. It wants to secure a champagne income as well, and that is really what this statement is all about—just watch the next budget or the budget afterwards.

SPEECH.PARA: The extra focus on regional engagements stretching as far as North‐East Asia where Australia has not fought since the Korean War is designed to support the substantial extra funding for defence which the defence efficiency review foreshadowed but did not justify. It also explains why the government has persistently placed the cart before the horse in its approach to defence. More than halfway through its term, the government has finally produced its strategic paper, yet it produced its defence efficiency review with great promptitude. Surely the strategy could have come first, the detailed management structures later. We know that the government wanted to create the impression of defence efficiency so it could justify the excessive financial demands generated by its warped strategic perspectives.

The government talks about efficiency, even in defence, but, by protecting the defence vote, it has encouraged inefficiency in defence. Any organisation with a protected budget will become inefficient. Defence has done just that. The inshore minehunters, the delays in the new submarine, the hundreds of millions of dollars lost in the over‐the‐horizon project are evidence enough of that. Let the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) guarantee an end to these inefficiencies before he comes to the parliament asking for yet more money for defence—$10 billion a year is more than enough.

The government admits, as has every government for the last 25 years, that Austral ia is one of the more secure countries in the world, but is this the strategic statement of a secure country? Does this secure country need to substantially increase defence spending? In fact, this statement bears the characteristic hallmarks of Australian conservative strategic thinking—if there is no threat, invent one. If you cannot credibly invent one, talk about uncertainty. Do whatever you need to do to support increased defence spending and increased Australian military involvement beyond Australia. Redefine security so that we are not secure, even though we are unless every nasty dictatorship that the government wants to cuddle up to is also secure.

All that is missing to complete the classical conservative picture is a regional dictatorship in trouble which we can offer to help out with Australian forces, Australian treasury and Australian lives. But the government should remember the outcome of the last such adventure by its predecessors—Australia, Vietnam, the United States and Cambodia, in different ways, are still paying the price of that piece of adventurism.

It is worthwhile noting in passing the admission in the minister's statement about the US alliance. He says that we will not be depending on allied combat forces, but he freely admits our utter dependence on Washington for resupply and intelligence. So much for self-reliance! With all of these regional pushes further north I wonder how many of those kinds of forays will come out of the defence dollar.

Let me turn to the government's extensive and expensive shopping list. I should congratulate the minister for ruling out acquisition of the Tomahawk land‐attack cruise missile. Other decisions make it clear that this decision is based solely on cost and not founded on any flash of strategic good sense. This is clear because the minister's grandiose conceptions are all too clear in the rest of his list.

He wants us to be a very strong regional maritime power. It might be news to him, but I think we already are. Our naval forces easily outmatch all those in our region. How strong does he propose we get? How much money does he want the taxpayer to pay to fund it? How much does he want the rest of the region to feel they need to catch up?

Incredibly, he wants to increase the number of operational long‐range F111 bombers. The previous government brought some F111G aircraft in the post‐Cold War fire sale, but intended to keep them for attrition reserves, not to add them to the operational fleet. This government wants to add them. How many, Minister? At what cost to the fleet? At a stroke this will increase our ability to threaten regional neighbours with military force. Remember how the then Indonesian ambassador reacted when the F111G purchase was first announced. What do you expect them to do now?

The minister wants to expand our air‐to‐air refuelling capability in unspecified ways, but this capability will only increase the range at which we threaten other countries. What would the minister have to say if China introduced substantial air‐to‐air refuelling into its air force? What would our response be?

He wants to expand the capabilities of our FA18 force. This force is already air‐to‐air refuelable and can reach deep into South-East Asia. What target would the minister like to reach—Beijing or Pyongyang? The essence of this statement is expansion of the military power of a country which admits itself to be secure, a country which, by the way, concentrates on budget black holes. It seems that this is a black hole with a black hole. How can Australia justify all this military power when he says it is secure? Of what relative value is this power in the face of the very real non-military threats which Australia faces, threats this government ignores or even helps worsen, such as climate change?

This is a depressing document. It shows that the conservative parties in Australia are like the old Bourbons of France restored to power after the defeat of Napoleon. It was said of them that they had learnt nothing and forgotten nothing. They have been waiting for this: this statement shows that, since their ill‐starred intervention in Vietnam all those years ago, Australian conservatism has learnt little and forgotten less.

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present government responses to the following committee reports: Joint Select Committee on Certainly Family Law Issues report entitled Child support scheme: an examination of the operation and effectiveness of the scheme ; Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities report on the Annual Reports of the Australian Securities Commission and other bodies 1995‐96; Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the implications of the Australia's services exports to Indonesia and Hong Kong; and the 25th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the parliamentary contributory superannuation scheme and the judges pension scheme. In accordance with usual practice, I seek leave to incorporate the documents in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: An examination of the operation and effectiveness of the CHILD SUPPORT SCHEME
Government Response to the Report by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues

SPEECH.PARA: FOREWORD

The Joint Select Committee's report on its inquiry into the operation and effectiveness of the Child Support Scheme was tabled in December 1994. The former Government tabled an interim response in March 1995 which addressed 53 of the 163 recommendations (Appendix 1). The recommendations addressed in the interim response were mainly concerned with the Child Support Agency's administration of the Scheme. Following extensive examination, this Government has agreed responses to the remaining Joint Committee's recommendations.

In light of the Joint Committee's recommendations, the Government considers its responses provide a framework in which a more equitable balance can be achieved between the interests of separated and intact families, children of first and subsequent families, and both parents and taxpayers. However, in any changes made to the Child Support Scheme, the Government remains committed to protecting the interests of the children affected by the Scheme and reinforcing the principles of the Scheme, particularly that parents share in the support of their children according to their capacity.

In fact, the Government commends the already growing awareness within the community of the ongoing responsibilities of parents after separation. The change in community attitudes in relation to child support is clearly evident in the large and growing number of separated parents who are making adequate private collection arrangements. Wherever possible, the Government encourages parents to make suitable private arrangements for the ongoing support of their children. At the same time, the Scheme provides a means to ensure that responsibility for financial support is shared fairly when parents cannot reach agreement.

It is the Government's intention that, as the Child Support Scheme continues to mature, it will be increasingly accepted as part of a much wider system of support which encourages separated parents to accept joint ongoing responsibility for their children's wellbeing in all ways, not just financially.

Finally, the Government would like to take this opportunity to thank the Joint Committee for the extensive work involved in their examination of numerous policy, administrative and management issues and for the recommended ways in which to improve the Child Support Scheme. The Government believes that the changes made in response to the Joint Committee's report will enhance the fairness and simplicity of the Child Support Scheme, ensuring its continued durability and acceptance both by those directly affected and by the wider community.
JOCELYN NEWMAN, Minister for Social Security
DARYL WILLIAMS, Attorney‐General
ROD KEMP, Assistant Treasurer
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The responses to the Joint Committee's recommendations contained within this report are aimed at fine tuning the Child Support Scheme by making the Scheme easier to access, improving the certainty and speed of payments and facilitating private arrangements where possible. The changes lay the foundation for a greater range of circumstances to be addressed and to enhance a Scheme that is a world leader.

In line with the Joint Committee's recommendations, the Government acknowledges that some changes are necessary to redress the perceived imbalance in the formula and as a result, a number of adjustments have been agreed. While the changes will give some financial relief to payers, the Government has ensured they will not significantly disadvantage children or payees, nor have a detrimental impact on taxpayers. Also, the fundamental principle of the Child Support Scheme, that both parents are responsible for the support of their children, has been reinforced.

With regard to service delivery and administration, the responses to the Joint Committee's report propose ways to simplify legislation and streamline registration, information provision and payment services between the Department of Social Security, Centrelink and the Child Support Agency. These changes are expected to lead to significant improvements in service to parents and a reduction in Government outlays.

The Government is also committed to ongoing monitoring and refinement of the Child Support Scheme and fully supports the Joint Committee's view that the Scheme should be regularly evaluated. As part of this process, the views of interested parties will continue to be actively sought.

Furthermore, while the Joint Committee did not make any recommendations to vary the child support formula percentages, they did recommend that an independent study into the cost of children be undertaken to enable the percentages to be critically evaluated. This research is underway and will be completed by the end of 1997.

As a whole, the response to the Joint Committee signifies the Government's ongoing commitment to refining the complex balance between the interests of the taxpayer on the one hand and equity between separated parents on the other, while ultimately protecting the interests of the children.

PARA.EMPHASIS: BACKGROUND TO THE CHILD SUPPORT SCHEME

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) redrafted in a more simplified and understandable form; and
(b) combined into one piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned about the complexity of the child support legislation and the difficulties experienced by legal practitioners and the courts in applying it.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government agrees there is a need to both simplify the child support legislation and to combine it into the one Act. Priority has been assigned to this redrafting process, with emphasis upon ensuring the amended legislation accords with the following principles:
. promoting the responsibility of both parents to make suitable arrangements with minimal Commonwealth involvement;
. allowing both parents to have maximum input into decisions affecting their children in the development of future child support policy and legislation; and
. ensuring that the child support legislation is accessible and comprehensible to child support practitioners and lobby groups.

It is expected that the legislation could be improved through the use of plain English; the development of a more logical structure; the use of diagrams to explain the legislation and its relationships with family law and social security legislation; and making greater use of regulations to provide some of the detail. As a result, the legislation would be consistent, provide for appropriate flexibility and be more easily understood.

PARA.EMPHASIS: THE PERFORMANCE OF THE CHILD SUPPORT SCHEME
The Joint Committee recommends that a survey be undertaken to determine why a significant proportion of custodial parents are receiving no child support and/or have no child support arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: An important objective of the Child Support Scheme is that parents share in the costs of supporting their children according to their capacity. Consequently, it is important to determine why a significant proportion of payees are receiving no child support or have no child support arrangements.
The Child Support Agency has undertaken, and will continue to undertake, qualitative and quantitative research to better understand this issue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Government adopts the following order of priorities in respect of the objectives of the Child Support Scheme:
Priority 1. adequate support is available to all children not living with both parents
Priority 2. non custodial parents share in the cost of child support according to their capacity to pay
Priority 3. Commonwealth expenditure is limited to the minimum necessary to ensure the adequacy of child support to all children not living with both parents.

The Joint Committee recommends that the objective of the Child Support Scheme that non custodial parents share in the cost of supporting their children according to their capacity to pay be redrafted so that it reads as follows:
‐ parents share in the cost of supporting their children according to their respective capacities to pay.
The Joint Committee recommends that the objective of the Child Support Scheme that work incentives to participate in the labour force are not impaired, be redrafted so that it reads as follows:
‐ work incentives for both parents to participate in the labour force are not impaired.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned with what they believed was an underlying conflict between the Child Support Scheme's objectives and suggested this could be addressed by prioritising these objectives. The Joint Committee was also concerned by the perceived bias of the Scheme against the payer, believing that this warranted a reconsideration of the Scheme's objectives.

The Government agrees that the objectives of the Child Support Scheme should reflect a better balance between the rights and responsibilities of both parents. The objectives will be amended as follows:
. parents share in the cost of supporting their children according to their capacity;
. adequate support is available to all children not living with both parents;
. Commonwealth involvement and expenditure is limited to the minimum necessary for ensuring children's needs are met;
. work incentives for both parents to participate in the labour force are not impaired; and
. the overall arrangements are non intrusive to personal privacy and are simple, flexible and efficient.

These objectives are complementary and not competing as suggested by the Joint Committee. The intention is that a balance exist between the circumstances where the general taxpaying community would take some responsibility for the support of children and the circumstances where both parents have to take shared financial responsibility for their children. The Government therefore does not believe there is a need to prioritise the objectives.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended so that the definition of the basic child support formula includes the custodial parent disregarded income level.

At present, the payee's income is only considered as a modification to the basic formula rather than as an integral component of it. The legislative change recommended by the Joint Committee would not change the amount of child support to be paid. The change would simply recognise the fact that receiving parents are already sharing their income with the children.

The Government agrees that the presentation of the formula could be improved. As part of the process of legislation simplification the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 will be amended to include the payee's `disregarded income' amount as part of the basic formula.

PARA.EMPHASIS: MANAGEMENT AND ADMINISTRATION OF THE CHILD SUPPORT AGENCY
MANAGEMENT OF THE CHILD SUPPORT AGENCY

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes, as a matter of priority, national policies and develops the necessary guidelines and manuals to ensure uniform practices are observed in all areas of Child Support Agency administration and in accordance with the child support legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts due under default assessments be included in the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts paid pursuant to private collection cases registered with the Child Support Agency be excluded from the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes a nationally co‐ordinated approach to identify, assess and introduce as revised national practice, administrative improvements from local branch office initiatives and from best practice in the public and private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:
a) ensures that training has an appropriate focus on client service;
b) evaluates the effectiveness of the training provided by measuring the transference of skills learnt by staff into the workplace;
c) introduces a national program for validating and accrediting all training material and training received by staff of the Agency;
d) adopts progressive and innovative approaches to training and abandons the Child Support Agency's reliance upon `in house' and `on the job' training; and
(e) recruits more staff with experience and qualifications in client service oriented disciplines to assist in changing the current predominantly tax and finance oriented staff culture.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Government establishes a review of the location of the Child Support Agency to be conducted at the end of the 1996‐97 financial year to test the benefits of the Agency's continued location within the Australian Taxation Office.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that the intended benefits of locating the Child Support Agency within the Australian Taxation Office have not been realised to date. Potential benefits of this location include the facilitation of access to taxable income details which are necessary for child support assessment and also, the provision of wider benefits in allowing the Child Support Agency access to other tax information and Australian Taxation Office resources for collection and compliance purposes.

The Government notes that the operation of the Australian Child Support system is very successful, including collection rate (81 per cent in 1996‐97), compliance rates (nearly 70 per cent in 1996‐97) and cost effectiveness (net saving to outlays $148 million, and cost per dollar collected at 16 cents in the dollar in 1996‐97). The success of the system stems in large part from the Child Support Agency's location in the Australian Taxation Office which provides significant savings in tax return intercepts, employer withholding of child support payments and access to data about income.

No change to current arrangements is indicated at this time. The Government notes, however, that the Child Support Agency is actively improving its performance, including seamless integration with Centrelink services.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces dedicated case officers, with assigned responsibility and accountability for individual clients.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces a reference number system to ensure accountability for the advice given to clients and to enable follow up on commitments and the provision of feedback to clients.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces administrative measures to ensure it is advised of clients who are subject to, or at risk of, abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee felt that appropriate measures should be implemented to ensure the protection of child support clients against domestic violence wherever possible. The identification of those who are subject to, or at risk of, domestic violence is an important aspect of this process.

The Child Support Agency, Department of Social Security and Centrelink have made arrangements for the exchange of information and consultation about cases involving family violence or abuse. As this information is sensitive the Child Support Agency has introduced administrative measures to provide an appropriate level of protection to ensure client privacy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency, as a matter of urgency, develops national guidelines for the identification and administration of cases where there is a history or risk of domestic violence and/or child abuse.
