SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to provide the Child Support Registrar with the discretion to suspend enforcement action where the continuance of this action would result in the likely abuse of a child or parent.

The Joint Committee emphasised that protection for parents and children who are at risk of domestic violence is essential. The Social Security Act 1991 requires parents who receive a sole parent pension and/or the higher rate of family payment to take reasonable maintenance action. In many cases this involves registration with and collection of child support by the Child Support Agency. The delegate of the Secretary of the Department of Social Security can exempt parents from taking reasonable maintenance action where there is a fear of violence or abuse within the family. However, where exemption is not obtained prior to the parent taking reasonable maintenance action through the Child Support Agency, there is currently no mechanism to allow that exemption to be given and the Child Support Agency is required to collect child support. This action can place parents and their children at risk and is not acceptable.

The Government agrees that appropriate arrangements need to be made to prevent parents and children from being put at risk as a result of taking action to obtain child support. However, an alternative solution to that recommended will be undertaken to ensure that the protection afforded to parents and their children is consistent, irrespective of whether abuse or family violence is identified before, or after, reasonable maintenance action is commenced.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 will be amended to allow payees who receive a sole parent pension and/or the higher rate of family payment to elect not to have the Child Support Agency continue to collect payment on their behalf when the delegate of the Secretary of the Department of Social Security determines that the criteria for providing an exemption from taking reasonable maintenance action are met.

However, the Government is concerned that violent payers should not be seen to be rewarded for their behaviour. The Government is aware that allowing parents to avoid their child support liability is not a suitable long term solution. Exemptions will be reviewed after a period of twelve months to enable Child Support Agency collection to occur in appropriate cases, however, the safety of parents will remain the key focus of the review. This will be complemented by the Child Support Agency's use of a case management approach for identified violence cases.

In conjunction with other Departments and Agencies, the Child Support Agency will continue to identify more satisfactory long term solutions which protect the safety of parents and their children but also ensure that parents meet their responsibilities to provide financial support for their children.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that within 6 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency conducts a study of the information needs of its clients and identifies shortfalls in current representation.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that within 12 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency reports to the Assistant Treasurer on the costs and benefits, including savings to community organisations, of introducing an advisory function to meet the information needs of its clients. This is to include:
(a) a nationally co‐ordinated `outreach' program targeted to the information needs of Child Support Agency clients, especially those clients in remote locations;
(b) making greater use of the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network by establishing full time Child Support Agency advisory staff in these offices; and
(c) making advisory staff available on a short term, permanent or rostered basis in remote locations in community legal aid, the Department of Social Security or other offices.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops in consultation with its clients, a code of conduct and service standards for Child Support Agency staff and ensures all Child Support Agency clients are aware of the standards of conduct and service which have been set.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces administrative procedures to ensure that clients not receiving the set standard of service have redress to higher levels of management and informs all clients of the process and procedures required to pursue complaints about conduct and service delivery.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops administrative mechanisms to monitor client complaints and solve the deficiencies in conduct and service delivery.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops communication strategies, targeted at the various groups of Child Support Agency clients, to inform them of their rights and obligations under child support legislation and Child Support Agency administrative practices which may materially affect each group of clients.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency in consultation with the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education develop a resource package on child support and other legal responsibilities to be used by the Child Support Agency, marriage education bodies and other relationship programs.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency's public education strategy be aimed to make the population aware of the Child Support Scheme and its impact on families.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of evidence indicating the level of awareness of the Child Support Agency within the general community, the Joint Committee believed that the Child Support Agency public education strategy should raise levels of awareness of the Child Support Scheme and its impacts on families.
The Government agrees that it needs to extend community awareness of the Child Support Scheme. The Child Support Agency is developing and implementing numerous strategies to achieve this, including:
. undertaking initiatives to target specific audiences;
. enlisting and utilising the support of existing community groups; and
. working with the community through broader "family" initiatives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that an independent consultant be engaged to work with the Child Support Agency to realign management and service to the needs of clients and develop strategies aimed at achieving best practice.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Auditor‐General conducts a supplementary audit of the Child Support Agency to evaluate the effectiveness of the implementation of the recommendations of:
(a) the Auditor‐General in the report entitled, Management of the Child Support Agency; and
(b) this report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1996‐97 financial year the Auditor‐General commenced an investigation to follow up its efficiency audit of the Child Support Agency.

PARA.EMPHASIS: COMMUNICATION WITH THE CHILD SUPPORT AGENCY

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency examines the management practices and operational standards applied to telephone communications in leading commercial operations in order to improve the management of the Child Support Agency's telephone enquiry service to clients.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency sets up a separate general inquiry number so that simple and routine telephone enquiries can be handled promptly and effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces on a national basis the voice messaging telephone service.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency requires staff to identify themselves to clients unless staff believe their safety to be at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency re‐writes computer generated correspondence to provide clients with the information they require in a clear, concise and user friendly fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that where clients raise specific issues the Child Support Agency responds on an individual basis and avoids the use of a computer generated response.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Australian Taxation Office advertises in Tax Pack and on individual income tax return forms that information provided in tax returns may be used by the Child Support Agency to assess liability for child support.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews and amends procedures for contacting clients and responding to client enquiries to prevent the unauthorised disclosure of personal information.
The Joint Committee recommends that Child Support Agency staff be trained in the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency and the Department of Social Security jointly examine ways of training their staff in the roles of each organisation and the interaction of child support and social security legislation.

The Joint Committee recommends that staff of the Department of Social Security and the Child Support Agency be encouraged to undertake an exchange between the offices of the Department of Social Security and the Child Support Agency to improve working co‐operation between the two organisations and the results be reported in the respective Annual Reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that there is a great deal of confusion about the roles and responsibilities of the Child Support Agency and the Department of Social Security in the Scheme, resulting in conflicting advice being provided to clients. The Joint Committee considered that the Department of Social Security and Child Support Agency staff needed to be made more aware of how child support and social security legislation and procedures interact.

The Government agrees that the Department of Social Security and Child Support Agency staff need to be more aware of how the legislation and procedures of their departments interact. The Child Support Agency, Department of Social Security and more recently, Centrelink, have adopted closer working arrangements to facilitate this. These arrangements have involved training, exchange of expert speakers, joint projects and regular meetings to identify and address ongoing issues.

Centrelink Family Services, which have been established in some Customer Service Centres and major shopping centres, provide information about a range of Commonwealth services available for families. In order to improve the existing level of service provided to child support clients, representatives from the Child Support Agency are available through a visiting service to selected Family Services. Pilots for physical integration of Child Support Agency and Centrelink activities will commence soon in Gosford and Albury.

The Child Support Agency, in consultation with the Department of Social Security and Centrelink, is continuing to explore options for alternative provision of services. Centrelink is designed as a convenient, personalised `one‐stop‐shop' which provides the opportunity to rationalise, streamline, and re‐engineer Government service delivery. The Child Support Agency recognises a common client base with Centrelink and is currently exploring opportunities to provide a seamless integration of service to clients at first point of contact.
Electronic transfer of data between the agencies and enhanced administrative arrangements will also improve co‐operation and service to mutual clients.

PARA.EMPHASIS: APPLICATION, REGISTRATION AND COLLECTION OF CHILD SUPPORT

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews its registration procedures to ensure that it registers court orders and court registered agreements correctly and does not register applications for court orders.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency revises its training programs in order to improve the ability of staff to interpret correctly court orders.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Family Court of Australia issues a practice direction containing precedents for the wording of court orders to provide guidance to magistrates exercising family law jurisdiction.

SPEECH.PARA: The recommendation was intended to address concerns about difficulties experienced by Child Support Agency staff when interpreting court orders, where the orders contain imprecise terms or are unclear about the effects of particular events. The Family Court and the Child Support Agency have continued working together on the preparation of standard wording for court orders, and the meaning to be given by the Child Support Agency to particular terms and expressions.

The issue of a Practice Direction is a matter for the Chief Justice of the Family Court of Australia. However, the Government believes the solution is largely a matter of informing Magistrates and the legal profession about how to frame orders that may be effectively registered with the Child Support Agency. The Child Support Agency will continue to work with the Family Court of Australia and the legal profession to achieve greater uniformity in the wording of orders.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency complies with the statutory requirements of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and allows prospective liable parents the statutory time to exercise their rights under the Acts.
This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that section 31 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended so that the liability to pay child support under Stage 2 of the Child Support Scheme arises on the day after the day upon which the appeal period under section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 expires.
In making this recommendation, the Joint Committee was concerned to remove start‐up arrears and to protect paying parents' appeal rights.

The Government agrees with the intention of reducing the amount of start‐up arrears as research indicates that payers will be more likely to pay regularly if they do not begin their liabilities with a large start‐up arrears component. However, if the recommendation were implemented, the start date of liability would be at least two months later than it is currently. The Government, following consultation with external stakeholders, views this as an excessive delay in children receiving financial support from the paying parent and hence does not support the recommendation.

Improvements in processing applications together with improved registration procedures for client contact have substantially reduced start‐up arrears in many cases. However, some arrears continue to accrue because the start date of the liability can still be backdated up to 28 days prior to an application being made. To address this, the Government announced on 30 September 1997 that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 will be amended to provide that the start date of liability for an assessment is the date the appropriately completed assessment application is lodged with the Registrar or an authorised representative (including Centrelink).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security immediately forwards all applications for child support to the Child Support Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended to require the Child Support Registrar to accept automatically applications for child support.

The Joint Committee cited the delay in the Department of Social Security forwarding applications to the Child Support Agency as leading to significant start‐up arrears. The Joint Committee also stated that this led to prospective paying parents being unaware of their accruing child support arrears. In addition, the requirement that payees provide proof of parentage was also identified as a major cause of delays in the Registrar's acceptance of child support applications.

In December 1996, the Department of Social Security and the Child Support Agency introduced new registration procedures, which have reduced the length of time between an application for registration and the first payment to the payee. This has had the effect of reducing `start‐up' arrears for new payers, thereby encouraging good compliance behaviour and contributing to an overall improvement in the effectiveness of the Child Support Scheme.

As announced on 30 September 1997, further improvements will be achieved through the electronic transfer of registration details. In addition, amendments to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 on 29 May 1995 and 27 June 1996 inserted several grounds for presumption of parentage which removed the need for many applicants to provide evidence of parentage. In the small number of cases where difficulty in providing evidence remains, the Government believes the Family Court represents the most appropriate arena for determining parentage.

The Joint Committee recommends that section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended to require a prospective liable parent to notify the Child Support Registrar when he or she intends to appeal to a court under this section.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to require the Child Support Registrar to hold in trust monies collected from a prospective liable parent when notified that an appeal is to be made to a court under section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to disburse these monies to the custodial parent if the Child Support Registrar is satisfied that no such appeal has been made.

Section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 allows a person who is liable to pay child support to challenge the Registrar's decision to accept an application for administrative assessment. One of the grounds for such a challenge may be that the person is not a parent of the child covered by the assessment. There are currently a very small number of applications under section 107.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government agreed that child support legislation will be amended to allow the Registrar to hold child support payments in trust where an application under section 107 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 is actually made. This will not include cases where the parent has not actually made the application to the Court. If the application is successful, the Registrar will refund the money to the person who paid. If the application is unsuccessful or is withdrawn, the Registrar will disburse the money to the receiving parent.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Family Court of Australia and other relevant courts hear disputed parentage cases as a matter of priority.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to expedite the collection of child support, the Joint Committee suggested that priority should be given to the hearing of disputed parentage cases.

The priority to be given to the hearing of particular matters must be determined by the Family Court. The Government considers that, as with all family law matters, disputed parentage cases should be dealt with as expeditiously as possible. The Government believes, however, that matters relating to the safety of individuals should in general have priority in court listings over disputed parentage issues.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Family Court of Australia considers delegating to Family Court Registrars powers to resolve child support related paternity disputes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government understands that the bulk of child support related paternity disputes are currently dealt with by Magistrates. The Joint Committee considered that the delays caused by disputed parentage cases may be expedited by the delegation of power from the Family Court to the Family Court Registrars. The Family Court has indicated that in most cases the carrying out of a DNA test will resolve the dispute.

The delegation of power to Registrars by the Family Court is a matter for the Family Court. The power to order DNA and blood testing is currently delegated to Judicial Registrars. The power has not, at this stage, been delegated to Family Court Registrars. However, the Family Court is considering this matter.

The Joint Committee recommends that section 140 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 , allowing a prospective liable parent to apply to a court for a stay of a child support formula assessment, be repealed.

The Joint Committee was concerned, with the recommended arrangements for holding child support payments in trust where an application has been made to the court under section 107 (see recommendations 46‐48), that section 140 would become redundant and only serve as tool to obstruct these new arrangements.

The Government does not believe section 140 should be repealed as it is not limited to circumstances where application has been made under section 107. It applies where a proceeding has been instituted in a court having jurisdiction under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 , or before the Registrar under Part 6A of that Act. To remove the ability to seek a stay of formula assessment in any circumstances could cause undue hardship to payers.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency includes the following information in the notice issued under section 34 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989:
(a) advice on what further correspondence parties will receive; and
(b) advice on making acceptable private child support collection arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that notices of formula assessment issued under section 76 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 must clearly advise both parents that the Child Support Registrar has powers under section 75 of the Act to correct factual errors and false or misleading statements in a formula assessment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops a national guideline on the use of the Child Support Registrar's power under section 75 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that section 43 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to require the Child Support Agency to give non custodial parents the option of voluntarily paying their child support liabilities, rather than being automatically placed on autowithholding.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to remove non custodial parents from the automatic withholding provisions and allow them to elect to pay direct to the Child Support Agency where the Child Support Registrar is satisfied that the child support liabilities will continue to be paid by the due date.

The Joint Committee recommends that where a non custodial parent defaults on direct payment to the Child Support Agency, the Child Support Registrar can request the non custodial parent's employer to commence automatic withholding of child support from that non custodial parent's wages.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that auto withholding is undertaken irrespective of the circumstances, such as past payment records. The Joint Committee acknowledged the value of auto withholding as a compliance tool but felt its use should be selective to encourage voluntary compliance, minimise intrusiveness and encourage parents to take responsibility for facilitating the transfer of child support.

The Government agrees that parents should be encouraged to take responsibility for child support. Amendments contained in the Child Support Legislation Amendment Act (No 1) 1997 allow paying parents to apply to the Registrar to make payments directly to the Child Support Agency. The Registrar is able to authorise direct payments where he is satisfied that the payer will make payments on a regular and timely basis. Where the payer defaults on making direct payments and the Child Support Agency is satisfied that direct payments cannot be re‐established, the Registrar has the discretion to authorise deductions from salary or wages.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended so that, in the first month of liability, the following payment dates apply to new child support applications registered under the Child Support Scheme:

(a) where the child support liability starting date falls after the seventh day of a month but on or before the twenty‐first day of a month, the child support debt is due for payment on or before the twenty‐first day of that month; and
(b) where the child support liability starting date falls after the twenty‐first day of a month, the child support debt is due for payment on or before the seventh day of the next month.

The Joint Committee recommends that section 66 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection ) Act 1988 be amended so that, after the first month of liability, an amount that becomes a child support debt in any month is due and payable on the seventh day of that month.

Recommendations 58 and 59 are limited to new Child Support Agency clients. Recommendation 58 is designed to reduce the time between the application for a child support assessment and receipt of the first payment. Recommendation 58 could not be implemented without recommendation 59 otherwise it would delay the second payment to a payee from one month to six weeks. Recommendation 59 would counteract this and bring the second payment back to one month, but its implications are that all new payers would be paying child support in advance and all existing payers would continue to pay in arrears.

The problems identified by the Joint Committee are being addressed by the recent and planned improvements to the processing of registration of child support applications which are seeing a reduction in the time taken for the first payment to reach the payee. However, the Government believes the Child Support Scheme should provide for due dates which are in line with the receipt of income of the payer. The legislation will be amended to provide this flexibility.
The Joint Committee recommends that section 76 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to give statutory force to Child Support Agency practice.
This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops its own payment system and no longer relies on the Department of Social Security.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency gives custodial parents the option to obtain child support payments as soon as practicable after collection by the Child Support Agency or to receive the payments on a fixed day of the month following collection.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency makes arrangements for child support payments to be credited directly into the bank accounts of custodial parents with:
(a) the Child Support Agency to advise custodial parents when funds for child support have been electronically credited to their accounts; and

(b) the Child Support Agency to advise the Department of Social Security of the amount of child support which has been transferred to a custodial parent's account when the custodial parent is a Department of Social Security client.

SPEECH.PARA: All child support payments received by the Child Support Agency must be paid into the Child Support Trust Account. Section 76 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 requires the Child Support Registrar to transfer to the payees, by the first Wednesday of each month, all payments received in settlement of child support obligations up to the seventh day of the previous month. In practice, the transfer of child support from the Child Support Trust Account to payees is currently performed by Centrelink.

The Joint Committee stated that the current double handling of payments and highly structured arrangements for transferring payments to payees seem anachronistic at a time when the vast majority of payments are through the electronic transfer of funds into a payee's bank account. The Joint Committee considered that the existing administrative delays could be reduced and the Child Support Agency's service to clients improved if the Child Support Agency introduced an independent child support payment system which paid child support received by the Child Support Agency directly into the payees' bank accounts.

The Government agrees that these recommendations are likely to result in clients receiving payments sooner. It would also allow for greater flexibility in how payments can be made by payers and transferred to payees, for example through the use of electronic commerce or direct transfers.

An improved payment system will be incorporated into the redevelopment of the Child Support Agency computer system. The new system will create greater flexibility in the timing of disbursement and make payments directly to receiving parents which may remove the requirement to separately advise payees when funds for child support have been electronically credited to their accounts.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:
(a) develops national guidelines on the recovery of overpayments from custodial parents and repayment to non custodial parents;

(b) gives effect to its commitment to the Ombudsman that, prior to seeking to recover overpayments from custodial parents, the Child Support Agency informs both parties of the overpayment and provides the opportunity to negotiate the period over which an amount should be repaid; and
(c) informs parents of the content of the national guidelines and the potential collection problems created by not advising the Child Support Agency promptly of any change in circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces procedures to ensure that:
(a) amounts remitted by employers are promptly and accurately recorded against the correct non custodial parent's account and that amounts are credited for the correct contribution period; and

(b) amounts credited to non custodial parents' accounts which represent direct payments to custodial parents, accurately reflect the timing and amount of each transaction to assist clients and staff to understand the account with the Child Support Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar to make a payment from Consolidated Revenue where the Child Support Registrar is satisfied that a payment from a non custodial parent has been received by the Child Support Agency but has not been credited against the child support liability.
The Joint Committee was concerned that there was inequity between payments made through employer withholding and those made directly by the payer.

The Government agrees with the recommendation that the Registrar make a payment from Consolidated Revenue where satisfied that the payment from a paying parent has been made, but not credited by the Child Support Agency in time to be disbursed. The Child Support Agency is implementing administrative arrangements which will enable payments to be made in these circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to credit non agency payments as child support when, in the Child Support Registrar's opinion, these payments are in the interests of the child, subject to the following circumstances:

(a) limit the Child Support Registrar's discretion to accept non agency payments as child support to 25 per cent of the liable parent's child support payment for any given month without requiring the consent of the custodial parent;
(b) allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to accept a further 35 per cent of the child support payment as non agency payments but only where the custodial parent's consent is forthcoming;

(c) allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to accept 100 per cent of the child support payment as non agency payments where the non agency payment is made in an emergency with the consent of the custodial parent; and

(d) allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to remove a liable parent's option to select the form in which he or she will provide child support when, in the opinion of the Child Support Registrar, continued provision of non cash support will result in intractable disputes between the parents.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that parents liable to pay child support were not allowed greater choice in respect of the form in which child support is provided. The Joint Committee felt that greater choice would provide parents with a more realistic opportunity to participate in bringing up their children.

Non agency payments have become an important method for parents to deal with situations where immediate, direct payment is needed by the payee. Their frequency has been much greater than was initially anticipated. For this reason, the maintenance income test will now be applied to all non agency payments, ensuring consistent treatment between those people who collect privately and those using the Child Support Agency.
The Government will continue to review non agency payments in the light of ongoing experience.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency takes immediate steps to inform parents in Child Support Agency correspondence of its policy on the crediting of non agency payments.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to give the Child Support Registrar the discretion to substitute private collection for Child Support Agency collection where a liable parent has established a reliable voluntary payment record of 6 months.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar's discretion to substitute private collection for Child Support Agency collection be ordinarily exercised in favour of private collection except where the special circumstances of the case require otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that a large proportion of those parents who voluntarily pay child support to the Child Support Agency on time could be safely moved off Child Support Agency collection. The Joint Committee believed this could be achieved by giving the Child Support Registrar the discretion to substitute private collection for Child Support Agency collection where the payer has displayed a reliable payment record.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government agrees there should be greater flexibility in shifting to private collection, both to encourage parents to take responsibility for facilitating the transfer of child support and to limit Government intrusion. The legislation will be amended so there are no restrictions upon parents entering private collection where both the payer and payee agree to do so.

Where there is no agreement between the parents, the legislation will be amended so that parents will be required to undertake private collection, except in exceptional cases such as those involving family violence or a history of non‐payment, once a good payment record has been established for a period of six months. The six month monitoring period will help encourage parents to establish reliable payment practices.
This process will be underpinned by an effective and timely safety net to ensure that failure in private collection arrangements is promptly responded to in an appropriate manner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes a national guideline on acceptable private child support collection arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee emphasised the need to implement guidelines for private collection to ensure visible audit trails exist whereby the Registrar may track payments if necessary.

The Government agrees that the Child Support Agency should provide parents with appropriate information and guidelines to help develop private collection arrangements. The information provided to clients will include information about the range of methods for making payments and advice concerning the records that should be kept to ensure any disputes can be quickly and satisfactorily resolved.

In addition, the Child Support Agency is encouraging parents to take responsibility for their own child support arrangements through the use of private collection and formal agreements. Strategies aimed at achieving this include a pilot mediation program for new applicants, and the development of a `self‐help kit'. The Child Support Agency will provide appropriate information to clients about their obligations and entitlements backed up by an efficient collection process where private arrangements fail.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Family Law Act 1975 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 have compatible provisions to ensure that parenting plans, which include child support liability, and child support agreements are capable of acceptance by the Child Support Registrar pursuant to section 88 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

The Family Law Act 1975 now provides for the making of parenting plans dealing with any aspect of parental responsibility. A parenting plan may be registered with a court having jurisdiction under Part VII of the Act, and if so, has effect as if it were an order of the court. The provisions of a registered parenting plan can be enforced using the enforcement procedures under the Family Law Act 1975.

The Government has implemented this recommendation. Amendments to both the Family Law Act 1975 and the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 now make it clear that one document can constitute both a parenting plan and a child support agreement. A parenting plan that contains provisions dealing with child support is capable of being accepted by the Child Support Registrar as a child support agreement.

In order to prevent parties using a parenting plan to circumvent the requirements of the Child Sup port (Assessment) Act 1989, the Family Law Act 1975 provides that provisions of a plan that deals with maintenance are not enforceable under that Act where an application could be made for administrative assessment under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 . The effect of this is that parents cannot make an enforceable agreement about child support simply by registering a parenting plan with the Family Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to vary future child support agreements on application from either parent where, in the Child Support Registrar's opinion, the actions of either party render the child support agreement, or clauses in the child support agreement, inequitable.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to vary future child support agreements on application from either parent where, in the Child Support Registrar's opinion, the circumstances of either party have changed sufficiently to make the child support agreement, or clauses in the child support agreement, inequitable.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned about the difficulties involved in varying an agreement where the parties were unable to agree to change it themselves. The only avenue currently available to these parties is to apply to a court.

The Government does not believe that it would be appropriate for the Registrar to intervene to vary agreements where the parties no longer agree to the terms of their agreement, or because there has been a change in their circumstances that may produce an inequitable result for one party. It would be inappropriate for an administrative decision maker to interfere with an agreement between two parties in which that decision maker played no part. These proceedings are better dealt with by a court.

To assist the parties in avoiding problems associated with changing agreements, the Child Support Agency will provide better client education on the effect of agreements and the consequences of entering into agreements. The Child Support Agency will seek to identify for clients the issues they should consider when developing an agreement. This will include advice about clauses which may be included to take account of possible changes in circumstances (such as unemployment or changes in residence), clauses to allow for automatic increases in line with inflation and limiting the period of effect of an agreement where the parties believe circumstances may change over time.

Parties will be encouraged by the Child Support Agency to explore non‐litigious methods of resolving any disputes about variations to their agreement, and to seek the assistance of appropriate professionals, such as mediators, so that the need to seek court imposed variations is minimised.

PARA.EMPHASIS: REVIEW OF CHILD SUPPORT AGENCY DECISIONS
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency provides information in multi‐lingual pamphlets explaining the review avenues available and how to apply for a review.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to establish an internal objection procedure for all administrative decisions and applications for a departure from formula assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee believed a proper internal review process would act as a buffer between the initial decision maker and any external review and would reinforce the need for care and accountability at a primary decision making level.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government agreed that the child support legislation will be amended to establish formal internal review of all administrative decisions which may affect the interests of persons involved in the Child Support Scheme.

The review process, which will be undertaken by Child Support Agency staff who were not involved in making the original decision, will provide for greater accountability of the Child Support Agency and allow appropriate input from both parents. Where a parent is aggrieved by the decision following internal review, recourse would be through the Family Court, which is consistent with the current approach to dealing with matters of Family Law.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to establish an external review office, called the Child Support Appeals Office, to determine appeals by custodial parents or non custodial parents.
The Joint Committee recommends that the appeal officers of the Child Support Appeals Office be appointed by the Minister responsible for the Child Support Agency.
The Joint Committee recommends that all review decisions of the Child Support Appeals Office be made by an appeals officer sitting alone.
The Joint Committee recommends that all review decisions made by the Child Support Agency and the Child Support Appeals Office be published without naming the parties.
The Joint Committee recommends that the relevant legislation be amended to establish a Child Support Claims Tribunal within the registry of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Joint Committee recommends that the relevant legislation be amended to enable an application for a review of a Child Support Appeals Office decision to be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and an appeal from the Child Support Appeals Office to be made to the Family Court of Australia on a point of law.
The Joint Committee recommends that no filing fee be charged by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Appeals Office be able to refer a matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Family Court of Australia for determination.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that an internal review process might not be seen to be truly independent of the Child Support Agency, its environment and culture. It considered that an external review mechanism would ensure the independence of the review process. The Joint Committee also believed that there should be appropriate channels of recourse against the decisions of this external review body.

The Government does not believe it is necessary to establish an external review office as suggested by the Joint Committee. However, recommendations arising from the `Reform of Merits Tribunal' review, which might improve the proposed Child Support Agency review process, will be considered.

In regard to Recommendation 80, the Government believes that the identity of parties in child support matters which determine a liability to pay child support should be protected. However, it also believes that information which is relevant to people who may seek internal review should be made available. The Child Support Agency is developing policy guidelines which will be available to clients and their representatives.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes uniform national procedures for determining when enforcement action should commence and the types of enforcement action which are appropriate based upon the following criteria:
(a) sources of income and assets available to the non custodial parent;
(b) the age of the debt; and
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops debt management and enforcement procedures consistent with the philosophy espoused in the Child Support Agency compliance policy.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops an internal reporting system that:
(a) structures debts by appropriate age intervals and size;
(b) provides accurate and timely information on debtors arrears; and
(c) identifies and classifies non custodial parents who have recently defaulted.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops a risk profile of its non custodial parent client base which enables it to assess accurately:
(a) the costs and benefits of each enforcement practice against categories of its non custodial parent population; and
(b) the short falls of existing enforcement approaches and develops alternative approaches to increase the Child Support Agency's enforcement effectiveness.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency analyses outstanding debt and classifies it into various categories to enable the Agency to understand the nature of outstanding debt.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that Child Support Agency enforcement staff be trained, as a matter of priority, in the appropriate use of existing enforcement powers.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar to report defaulting non custodial parents to credit reference bureaus in cases where there are substantial arrears and other collection measures have not been successful.

The Joint Committee examined various enforcement initiatives being developed overseas to determine their applicability to an Australian context. Reporting payers to credit reference bureaus was one of these initiatives the Joint Committee felt worth pursuing.

The Government is concerned that there are considerable sensitivities associated with the reporting of defaulting payers to credit reference bureaus where there are substantial arrears and collection measures have failed.

The Privacy Commissioner is opposed to this recommendation as the current provisions of Part IIIA of the Privacy Act 1988 would prohibit an entry of this kind from being included in an individual's credit information file as defined in the Act. This is because the provisions which permit the listing of payment defaults or serious credit infringements both relate to credit which a credit provider has granted to the individual. Whilst unpaid child support is, or may become, a debt to the Commonwealth, it would not be a loan as defined in the Privacy Act nor would it be credit extended to the individual.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reports to the Assistant Treasurer within 6 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report on the costs and benefits of introducing private process servers.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:

(a) reports to the Assistant Treasurer within 12 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report on any difficulties in enforcement which might be remedied by the granting of further powers; and
(b) reviews its enforcement strategies on a 12 monthly basis to counter changes in client behaviour which leads them to avoid liability.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

The Joint Committee recommends that section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to allow the identity of parties to a child support enforcement proceeding to be published where a court has made an order in respect of those proceedings.

Section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 prohibits the publication of information about parties to Family Court proceedings. The Parliament has on two occasions considered and made significantly different recommendations on section 121. The Family Law Act 1975 was amended in 1983 to reflect the approach of recommendations made in 1979. The 1992 Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act concluded that "no significant evidence had been placed before it to justify the relaxation of the policy behind section 121". Accordingly, no change to section 121 was recommended.

The Government in early 1997 asked the former Chief Justice of the Family Court of Western Australia to review section 121 of the Family Law Act 1975 to see whether any further changes should be made. The former Chief Justice responded at the end of April 1997. The Government is considering further directions in regard to its approach to the reform of section 121.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency makes enforcement a high priority activity and urgently provides dedicated staff to enforcement to remedy the five years of neglect in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Department of Finance calculates baseline and additional staffing for enforcement activity on the costs and benefits to total Child Support Agency collections, rather than on the amount of Department of Social Security benefits saved (clawback).

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency prepares a submission for additional staffing which needs to be treated sympathetically by the Department of Finance if improvements in this area are to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that the resources available to the Child Support Agency for the enforcement of Child Support liabilities may not be adequate.
A revised workload formula resource agreement, based on guidelines applying to all running cost agencies, was developed with the Department of Finance in 1995 and has subsequently been implemented.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar exercises the power under section 120 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to require non custodial parents with more than 3 months of arrears to attend before him to enable the Child Support Agency to reassess these debts and/or to negotiate payment of these debts.
This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the maintenance income test be amended so that any child support debts paid by non custodial parents are notionally applied against each Additional Family Payment paid to the custodial parent over the applicable child support arrears period.

SPEECH.PARA: Regular child support payments (including any arrears payments) are converted into an annual rate before the Family Payment Maintenance Income Test is applied. In the case of arrears payments, a modified formula is used to convert these payments to an annual rate. The total annualised child support amount is then assessed as maintenance and affects the Family Payment pay‐days in the following month (usually two Family Payment pay‐days, but occasionally three).

This facility is already available to customers who have received child support arrears and have had their Family Payment rate reduced as a result. A customer can request a full manual reconciliation of Family Payment entitlement against child support payments where it is believed that the treatment of arrears using the modified formula is not to their advantage. A manual reconciliation involves the application of the child support arrears payment against the Family Payment entitlement over the relevant period as if the child support had been received when it was due. Whichever method of calculation leads to the payee being financially better off is the one used to determine their Family Payment rate.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended to allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to remit a late payment penalty.
This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the late payment penalty be determined by reference to the prevailing medium term Treasury bond rate, compounded from the date on which a payment falls due.
The Joint Committee recommends that the late payment penalty, when received by the Child Support Agency, be disbursed to the custodial parent.

SPEECH.PARA: Under section 67 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 , a late payment penalty is imposed in all cases where a payment is not made by the due date. This penalty currently consists of a flat rate (9.8 per cent per annum) and a penalty interest component (weighted average of Treasury Note yield plus 8 per cent). Penalty payments received are credited to Consolidated Revenue, not transferred to the payee.
The Government believes the current administration of the late payment penalty is appropriate in that it provides a deterrent to non‐compliance and it partially covers the cost of enforcing the debt.

However, the Government sees value in amending the legislation to give the Registrar discretion over imposing the penalty in the first instance. Under these circumstances, the discretion to apply the penalty would serve the purpose of deterring non‐compliance but there would be a reduction in the reworking currently involved in the high number of penalties that are imposed and subsequently remitted to facilitate payment of ongoing liabilities. A less adversarial environment would also be created for the payer.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar informs custodial parents about the reasons why particular enforcement activities have been unsuccessful or why a decision has been made not to proceed further with enforcement action in accordance with section 113(2) of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency as a matter of practice, regularly notifies each custodial parent with arrears of child support owing to them, of current and recent Child Support Agency enforcement activity and the results of the activity.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency advises custodial parents immediately a decision is made not to proceed with enforcement of child support debts and makes them aware of their objection and appeal rights as defined in the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces national compensation guidelines which are independent of the Australian Taxation Office guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency amends its compensation guidelines to require it to advise clients where its action, or lack of action, has caused financial loss and to include instructions in this advice to clients on how to apply for compensation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that the general Child Support Agency practice of not advising clients to apply for compensation is inequitable. The Joint Committee believed the onus should be placed on the Child Support Agency to advise clients, as it is in a better position than the client to know when mistakes have occurred and to determine the impact of these.

The Child Support Clients' Charter came into effect from 1 July 1996. The Charter advises clients that there may be circumstances in which they would be entitled to compensation. A leaflet is available which explains compensation and provides instructions on how to apply for compensation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency informs its clients of the existence of the compensation guidelines, clients' rights to claim for compensation and the situations in which claims can be made.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency pilot the use of private collection agencies to collect child support debts. This pilot should test:
(a) methods of maximising the benefits obtained from the use of private collection agencies while maintaining the Child Support Agency's initial focus on voluntary compliance;
(b) the most appropriate fee structures and the cost effectiveness of private collection agencies;
(c) allowing custodial parents to apply to the Child Support Registrar for private enforcement of child support debts if the Child Support Agency has been unable to collect these debts; and
(d) the conditions and charges which might apply to custodial parents for the collection of child support debts by these agencies.
The Joint Committee recommends that the costs of collecting child support debts during this pilot be borne by the Child Support Agency.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned with the efficiency of Child Support Agency enforcement practices, particularly if future trends see the more compliant cases move into private collection and only the complex, non‐compliant cases remain with the Child Support Agency.

To date, the Child Support Agency has collected over 80 per cent of child support liabilities which have accrued since the introduction of the Child Support Scheme. In line with the Government's approach to contestability, the Child Support Agency is currently working with Centrelink, the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the New Zealand Inland Revenue Service to review their success in using private collection agencies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: INTERNATIONAL ENFORCEMENT OF CHILD SUPPORT LIABILITY

The Joint Committee recommends that Australia, through the Attorney‐General's Department, increases the number of arrangements in the international arena for the reciprocal enforcement of child support responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee expressed concern about the possibility of payers avoiding their child support responsibilities by leaving Australia.

The Attorney‐General's Department is currently negotiating with a number of countries to establish new bilateral arrangements on child maintenance. In particular negotiations are currently occurring with New Zealand with the objective of improving reciprocal enforcement arrangements.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that reciprocal enforcement arrangements be made in preference to the United Nations Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance multi‐lateral approach.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee recommended that the simplest and most effective approach for enforcing overseas child support liabilities would be to expand existing reciprocal arrangements. The Joint Committee considered that the approach adopted by the United Nations Convention on the Recovery Abroad of Maintenance (UNCRAM) to be too cumbersome and costly.

Australia has always preferred to develop bi‐lateral arrangements on child maintenance instead of relying on UNCRAM, although the difficulties associated with concluding new agreements should not be underestimated. Many countries refuse to enter bi‐lateral arrangements either because their child maintenance systems are incompatible with the system in Australia or because they prefer, as a matter of policy, to use multi‐lateral treaties such as UNCRAM. Discussions with European countries suggest that, rather than participate in time‐consuming and complex negotiations for bilateral arrangements, they would prefer it if Australia acceded to the Hague Convention on Recognition and Enforcement of Decisions Relating to Maintenance Obligations 1973, a multi‐lateral arrangement. The Government accepts this recommendation but will also explore the practicalities and benefits of multi‐lateral approaches.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency assumes the functions of the Attorney‐General's Department in the enforcement of overseas maintenance.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, overseas maintenance orders are received by the Attorney‐General's Department and sent to State and Territory courts for registration. Local court officials locate liable parents, conduct negotiations to seek payments and, if necessary, take legal proceedings to enforce payment of arrears and future maintenance payable under the orders. Local court officials also represent overseas parents entitled to maintenance in any court proceedings initiated by payers to vary or reduce amounts of maintenance payable under overseas orders. Payments are sent by local court officials directly to overseas parents. The Attorney‐General's Department provides advice and assists in communication between local courts, overseas maintenance authorities and overseas parents entitled to maintenance. The Child Support Agency is not involved in enforcing overseas maintenance orders, other than in a small number of cases (19 in 1995‐96) in which orders are registered with the Child Support Agency because local court officials are unable to locate liable parents.

State and Territory courts and the Child Support Agency send Australian court orders to the Attorney‐General's Department for registration and enforcement overseas. Overseas authorities enforce court orders and send payments to Australian courts or the Child Support Agency for distribution to receiving parents. At present administrative assessments cannot be sent for registration and enforcement outside Australia.

A number of aspects of Australia's existing overseas maintenance arrangements are not compatible with the current operations of the Child Support Agency. It is not open to Australia to renege on parts of the arrangements which do not fit with the Child Support Agency's operations.

However, the Attorney‐General's Department and the Child Support Agency, in consultation with the State and Territory courts, are exploring ways in which the Child Support Agency might usefully take on a greater role in the overseas maintenance area without prejudicing the overall effectiveness of existing arrangements. In carrying out that consultation, the following issues are being considered:
. information sharing;
. collection of arrears;
. representing overseas parents entitled to maintenance;
. establishing new maintenance liabilities; and
. advising the public on overseas maintenance legislation.

The Joint Committee recommends that section 12(3) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended so that a liable parent moving overseas is not a child support terminating event, thereby allowing child support to continue to be collected from that parent.

The Joint Committee was concerned that a payer wishing to avoid his or her child support liability simply has to leave Australia. The event of a payer ceasing to be a resident of Australia ends any assessment which has been made under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 , but this does not mean that parents are absolved of their responsibility to pay child support. The parent entitled to receive child support can obtain a court order and then seek the assistance of overseas authorities in obtaining maintenance from the payer under the child maintenance legislation in that country. The Government currently provides support to parents entitled to receive child support, through the Attorney‐General's Department, in having court orders registered and enforced overseas.

Child support assessments are based on parents' Australian taxable income. The mere leaving of Australia does not necessarily mean the parent does not have an Australian taxable income, but where a payer does not have such an income the assessment would be nil. Therefore adopting this recommendation would limit a parent's ability to obtain child support.

The Child Support Agency, the Attorney‐General's Department and the Department of Social Security are working with the New Zealand agencies to develop a reciprocal agreement which will simplify and streamline the process between the two countries. Reciprocal agreements of this nature, with relevant countries, will provide a more practical solution than that recommended by the Joint Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to apply for a court order prohibiting the departure of a liable parent where satisfactory arrangements for the payment of child support have not been made.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned about payers leaving Australia permanently without making satisfactory child support arrangements or instances where it is believed the parent is leaving Australia specifically to avoid their child support obligations.
Response

The Registrar can already apply to a court for an order preventing the departure of a person with a child support liability. Time constraints usually prevent the Child Support Agency from doing so. The Government considers that a practical alternative is to grant the Registrar the power to issue a Departure Prohibition Order, similar to those he can issue in his capacity as Commissioner of Taxation. The Government also considers that the departure order should be temporary, lasting for a maximum of 14 days.

This power will enable the Child Support Registrar to prohibit a person's departure until satisfactory arrangements for the payment of arrears of child support are made. Where necessary, the Registrar will be able to apply to the Family Court to have the order extended beyond the 14 day period. If the Registrar is satisfied that the person will return to Australia, the person may be permitted to leave. The person will be able to appeal against the Registrar's decision to issue an order.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Minister for Social Security commissions an independent study into the costs of children to enable a critical evaluation of the current child support formula percentages.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee noted the need for current Australian research into the costs of children in order to ensure that the formula percentages are appropriate.

The Department of Social Security commissioned the Social Policy Research Centre at the University of New South Wales in 1995 to undertake costs of children research as part of a larger research project on indicative `budget standards' for different households. The Social Policy Research Centre is contracted to produce a final report on its research by the end of 1997. It is expected that the report will be publicly available in early 1998.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to substitute the term, `excluded income' for `self support component' wherever it appears.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that the term `self support component' is misleading as it gives the impression that this is the only amount available for the support of the payer and his/her second family. The payer also has available the percentage of income left after child support and taxation have been deducted.

The term `self support component' is not used in the child support legislation, but has appeared in Child Support Agency publications. The Child Support Agency will ensure that the correct terminology is used in all circumstances.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the custodial parent's disregarded income level be reduced to the applicable pension cut off point (the current Department of Social Security cut off point is $19,723.60 which increases by $624 per annum for each additional child).
The Joint Committee recommends that the current withdrawal rate of child support from custodial parents who earn more than the applicable pension cut off point be reduced to 50 cents in the dollar.
The Joint Committee recommends that the child care component of the custodial parent's disregarded income level be abolished.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that:
. the payee's `disregarded income' level of Average Weekly Earnings (AWE) is too high when compared with the payer's `exempt income' level and should be significantly reduced;

. a reduction in the `disregarded income' level should be accompanied by a reduction in the rate at which child support is withdrawn by payee income above that level, to avoid workforce disincentives for payees; and
. increases in Government assistance with child care costs since the introduction of the formula have made the child care component of the `disregarded income' level redundant.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government proposes to reduce the basic payee `disregarded income' level by aligning it with a different measure of AWE: average total weekly earnings for all employees. This would see the current basic `disregarded income' level of $37,424 per annum reduced to $29,598 per annum in 1997‐98, compared with $19,723 per annum suggested by the Committee at recommendation 118 ($21,465 at 1 January 1997).

To reduce payee workforce disincentives from this measure, the Government also proposes to halve the rate at which income above the `disregarded income' level reduces child support: payee income above the `disregarded income' level will reduce the payer income upon which child support is calculated by 50 cents for each dollar rather than the current dollar for dollar.

The Government also proposes to abolish the blanket allowance for child care costs in the `disregarded income' level and instead allow parents to apply to the Child Support Review Office for a departure from the formula where child care costs exceed five per cent of income.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the maximum cap on non custodial parent income be reduced to twice average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that lowering the income cap would reduce the current work disincentives experienced by payers as a result of the high combined marginal rates of taxation and child support which occur at these levels of income.

The highest marginal tax rate commences at a taxable income of $50,000 and the 1997‐98 cap on child support payments takes effect at $93,560 per annum (2.5 times full time adult average weekly earnings as at August 1996). The Joint Committee's proposal would see the 1997‐98 child support cap lowered to $74,848 per annum.

The Government is not convinced that the work incentives of payers with income over $75,000 per annum are markedly affected by the current `cap'. Further, among all payers in the Scheme, those with high incomes generally have the greatest capacity to pay formula‐assessed liabilities. Like other payers, high‐income payers will benefit from the Government's decision to increase `exempt income' levels in the formula by 10 per cent (see recommendation 123).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to:
(a) introduce a minimum child support payment of $260 per annum where the formula results in an assessment less than this amount; and
(b) allow the Child Support Registrar to waive the minimum payment of $260 in special circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered the introduction of a minimum child support payment to be consistent with the principal objective of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 , that children should receive a proper level of financial support from their parents. Also, the Joint Committee believed it would reinforce another fundamental principle of the Child Support Scheme, that parents have the primary duty to maintain their children. The Joint Committee considered that there may be special circumstances where it would be inequitable to apply the minimum payment to a payer. However, the Joint Committee suggested these instances would be rare and should be dealt with by the Child Support Registrar.
As announced on 30 September 1997, from 1 July 1998 the Government will introduce a minimum child support liability of $260 a year for all payers, including those receiving income support.

This will help reinforce the objective of the Child Support Scheme, that parents share in the cost of supporting their children and will also reinforce the principle that the parents of a child have the primary duty to maintain that child.

There will not be any exemptions as suggested by the Joint Committee, except where a parent has no income at all—for example, a full time dependent student living at home or a parent being supported by a new partner.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the non custodial parent's basic formula self support component be increased by 20 per cent, that is from $8,221.00 to $9,865.20 per annum.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that it is not appropriate to tie the payer `exempt income' amount (which, for self support purposes, is set aside from child support formula calculations) to the pension rate as this ignores the costs of employment borne by payers as well as the fringe benefits available to pensioners.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government proposes to increase payer `exempt income' amounts by 10 per cent. In 1997‐98, this would mean the `exempt income' amount would increase from $9,006 per annum to $9,907 per annum for most payers. The effect of the 10 per cent increase on payers with natural or adopted child in their care is discussed at recommendation 139. The Government will continue to monitor the operation of the formula for both payers and payees.

The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended so that a reassessment of child support on the basis of a person's estimated reduction in income under section 60 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 takes effect from the month following the person's application for reassessment.

The Joint Committee was concerned about the effect on both parties where a reassessment as a result of an estimate causes an overpayment to the parent entitled to receive child support. In this situation, the payer is entitled to a refund of the amount overpaid and the payee may not be entitled to ongoing child support until the overpayment is recouped.
