The Child Support Legislation Amendment Act (No 1) 1997 amended the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 to address this concern. The amendment differs slightly from the Joint Committee's proposal, in that the income estimate election will take effect from the date of lodgment of the election.

The measure contained in the Act provides that when an income estimate election is lodged, payment of the new assessment will ordinarily commence on the date the estimate was lodged. Any amounts payable prior to the making of the income estimate election will generally be left undisturbed but will be taken into account in calculating amounts payable for the remaining period. The payer will be entitled to a refund only where the new amount payable for the year is less than the amount already paid. This will mean that in future, payees will be less likely to be asked to repay any of these amounts due to the lodgment of an estimate election.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the existing estimates system be abolished and replaced by an internal administrative variation of assessment within the Child Support Agency triggered by the receipt of appropriate evidence of current monthly taxable income from either parent which shows a reduction in monthly taxable income of 15 per cent or more from that recorded in that parent's child support assessment.

The Joint Committee recommends that in cases where a child support assessment is nil, or a parent has applied to the Child Support Agency for a revised assessment on the basis of current monthly taxable income, and the parent's monthly taxable income has subsequently increased by at least 15 per cent in the current year, that parent be required to notify the Child Support Agency of the increase.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency issues a revised assessment for the remainder of the child support year when notified of a variation in monthly taxable income of at least 15 per cent.

The Joint Committee recommends that a financial penalty be introduced for persons who recklessly or inadvertently provide false or misleading information in respect of their current monthly taxable income to the Child Support Agency.

The Joint Committee recommends that a financial penalty be introduced for persons who knowingly, recklessly or inadvertently fail to notify the Child Support Agency of an increase in their monthly taxable income of 15 per cent or more when required to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned with various aspects of the current assessment process and, in particular, the estimate system. Their underlying concern was the age of the income data being used in the assessment and the capacity of this data to accurately reflect a parent's current capacity to support their child.

More specifically, the Joint Committee felt the estimate system was inadequate in that it allows payers the opportunity to benefit more than once from a low income year, it fails to accommodate increases in income or decreases less than 15 per cent, it is retrospective not prospective and there are inherent difficulties involved in furnishing an accurate assessment.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government acknowledges that the current assessment process may employ tax return data that is two or more years out of date as the basis of an assessment. This can disadvantage all parents if their circumstances have changed in the interim. To alleviate these problems of accuracy and timeliness, the assessment process will be remodelled to use only the most current taxable income, for example, 1997‐98 income would be used for the 1999 child support year. An indexation factor will no longer be required except where parents fail to lodge a tax return.
Allowing for these changes, the Government does not see the need to abolish the existing estimate system and therefore recommendation 129 will not be adopted.

The date of lodgement for a second or subsequent estimate will be extended to 31 July enabling parents to confirm their actual taxable income for the year before lodging their final estimate. The Registrar will also be given the power to reject an estimate where he is not satisfied that it accurately reflects the actual income of the parent. This will eliminate the opportunity for payers to manipulate the timing of their child support payments. There are already penalties for providing false or misleading information and the Government does not consider it necessary to provide additional penalties.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the impact of the indexation factor be continually monitored and regularly compared to other measures of wage fluctuations.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Department of Social Security and the Child Support Agency report annually on the suitability of the indexation factor as a measure of wage fluctuations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered that the current application of the indexation factor, while satisfactory, is by no means ideal.

With the remodelling of the assessment process, basing it on the most current taxable income available, the use of an indexation factor will only be necessary in those cases where parents fail to lodge a tax return.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 be amended so that:

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a) the full time employment of a child less than 18 years of age is a child support terminating event; and
(b) the receipt of Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance or Austudy by a child at the `at home' or `dependent' rate reduces the liable parent's child support liability by 50 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered it inequitable for the payer to continue to pay child support for children who are in full time employment, as this employment should provide children with the financial means to support themselves. The Joint Committee also noted that the `at home' rates of Newstart Allowance and AUSTUDY are about 40 per cent to 45 per cent lower than the independent rates and considered that the child support liability of the payer should reflect a similar degree of dependency.

The recommendation does not take into account the varied income levels of children in full time employment, the payer's capacity to pay, and the fact that Newstart Allowance and AUSTUDY (or similar payments, such as the new Youth Allowance) for under 18 year olds are part of a continuum of Government financial support for children. In fact, the rate of Newstart Allowance or AUSTUDY paid may represent only a modest increase on previous Family Payment received for the child.

As noted by the Committee, the payer can apply for a departure from administrative assessment where the child's income, earning capacity, property and financial resources makes the formula assessment unjust or inequitable. The Review Officer is in the best position to determine, on a case by case basis, the level of income and whether it is just and equitable and otherwise proper for a departure to be made. The Government considers that these arrangements adequately cater for these circumstances.

The Joint Committee recommends that the provisions of section 66H of the Family Law Act 1975 , allowing the court to make an order for maintenance when a child has attained 18 years of age, be incorporated into the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to decide when the continued provision of maintenance is necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: These recommendations were based on submissions and research which showed that children are remaining under the care of their parents longer. The Family Law Act 1975 allows the court to make an order for the maintenance of a child beyond the age of 18 to enable the child to complete his or her education or because of a mental or physical disability of the child.

In many cases the child does not finish full time secondary education until the end of the year in which they turn 18. The Government announced on 30 September 1997 that the Registrar will be able to determine that a child support assessment should continue until the end of the school year in which a child who is undergoing full time secondary education turns 18.

Expenditure in relation to a child undertaking additional secondary or tertiary education or physical or mental disabilities is more discretionary. Accordingly these decisions should remain with the Court.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the regulations of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 be amended so that the protected earnings rate is set at the non custodial parents' applicable self support component.

In making this recommendation, the Joint Committee considered two main issues. These were the concerns raised by the Department of Social Security and payers regarding the disincentive to work when child support deductions accounted for the majority of net income, and the inability of the Child Support Agency to collect the full amount through employer deductions when salary or wages fell below protected earnings.
The Joint Committee believed that by recommending the exempt income amount be increased, and that protected earnings be set at this amount, it would address the problem of work disincentives.

The protected earnings amount relates to the method of collection by employer deductions rather than the amount of the liability. It is a safety net to ensure that, where an employee's wage is reduced because of sick or other leave, the Child Support Agency does not deduct disproportionately from the take home pay for that period. It does not reduce the payer's overall liability.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that in order to overcome the unnecessary complications and difficulties in obtaining a departure order, the child support legislation be amended to repeal section 98F(b) and section 117(1)(b)(ii) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee questioned the number of requirements about which the Registrar or a court needed to be satisfied before departing from the formula assessment. The Joint Committee did not see the need for the requirement specified by paragraph 98F(b) and paragraph 117(1)(b)(ii) of the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 that the Registrar or court be satisfied that a departure would be just and equitable and otherwise proper as regards the children and parties. In determining whether or not a departure would be otherwise proper, the Registrar or court must have regard to the nature of the duty of a parent to maintain a child and the effect that the making of the order would have on any entitlement of the child or the parent entitled to receive child support to an income tested pension, allowance or benefit or the rate of any income tested pension, allowance or benefit payable to that person.

The Joint Committee stated this additional requirement serves little purpose except to make it difficult for a parent to obtain a departure order. The Joint Committee referred to comments made by the Chief Justice of the Family Court regarding the difficulties of the legislative requirements to obtain a departure.

The Family Law Council has suggested that the recommendation appears to be based on a misunderstanding of the Chief Justice's comments, stating that he did not criticise the steps involved in obtaining a departure order but was making a statement about the complexity of the legislation in general. The Council have strongly opposed this recommendation. The Government is also satisfied with the current procedures, which are in line with those of the Family Court, and does not agree to this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to allow a liable parent who has a defacto spouse the same right of departure from the formula assessment as presently exists for married spouses.

The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to require the Child Support Registrar to adopt the social security legislation concept of `marriage‐like relationships' when determining the standing of a defacto parent in a departure application.

SPEECH.PARA: The current formula is not adjusted to take into account the fact that either parent is supporting a spouse, either de facto or de jure. It is adjusted if the payer has a relevant dependent child, irrespective of the marital status of the parents. However, a departure from the formula may be available where the payer's capacity to pay is significantly reduced because the parent has a legal duty to maintain another person.

Under the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 , a departure from the formula may be available where the payer's capacity to pay is significantly reduced because the parent has a duty to maintain another person.

The Full Court of the Family Court in Vick and Hartcher (1991) FLC 92‐262 held that this duty must be a legal duty. Under section 72 of the Family Law Act 1975 , a person has a duty to maintain a de jure spouse in certain circumstances, but a person is not, at law, financially responsible for a de facto partner unless a court order is obtained.

A person may accept a moral duty to maintain one or more of a range of people including a de facto partner. The Government believes that it would be inappropriate to allow these moral obligations to detract from the parent's primary duty to maintain a child.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the non custodial parents' subsequent family formula self support component be increased so that the relativity between the single and married rate of pension is reflected in the basic and subsequent family self support component.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was effectively recommending a 20 per cent increase to the `exempt income' of payers with a subsequent family. Its rationale for this recommendation is the same as that for increasing the `exempt income' in the basic child support formula; that is, the Joint Committee considered that it is not appropriate to tie the payer `exempt income' amount to the pension rate as this ignores the costs of employment borne by payers as well as the fringe benefits available to pensioners.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government proposes to increase payer `exempt income' amounts by 10 per cent. Where payers have natural or adopted children in their care, the 10 per cent increase will only apply to the component of `exempt income' that is tied to pension. In 1997‐98, this would mean the `exempt income' would increase from $15,023 per annum to $16,525 per annum (plus the current additional amounts which apply for each natural or adopted child in the payer's care).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the self support component for each parent with shared custody be increased to the subsequent family formula self support component.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that the formula which applies to parents with `shared care' children does not take adequate account of the parenting costs of payers.

The Government agrees with the general argument that parents who are subject to the `shared care' formula need a higher level of `exempt income' before being required to pay child support. However, the Government does not agree that a parent who shares the care of a child should be given the whole `exempt income' level which applies to a payer who has the full care of a natural or adopted child in a `subsequent family'.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government proposes to increase the `exempt income' levels of shared care parents by the age related additional amounts in the `subsequent family' exempt income level. For 1997‐98, this would mean the `exempt income' of parents subject to the `shared care' formula would increase by $1888 per annum for each shared care child aged under 13, $2639 per annum for each shared care child aged 13‐15 and $3756 per annum for each shared care child aged 16 or over.
Parents subject to the `shared care' formula will also receive the 10 per cent increase which is to apply to the `exempt income' of all payers (detailed at recommendations 123 and 139).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the social security legislation be amended so that the child support paid by a family is deducted from the income amount used to determine that family's eligibility for Additional Family Payment.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation would ensure that family income assessed for Family Payment purposes more closely reflects income actually available. Currently, any child support received by a parent in receipt of more than the minimum family payment rate is counted under the Maintenance Income Test and may reduce Family Payment. However, child support paid out by a Family Payment recipient is not deducted from income before the rate of Family Payment is determined. This means that payers in this situation perceive an element of `double counting' by the Commonwealth—their taxable income is used to assess their new family's eligibility for Family Payment and the child support paid out is also assessed under the Maintenance Income Test.

As announced on 30 September 1997, the Government has agreed that in line with the treatment of child support under the Maintenance Income Test, the Social Security Act 199 1 will be amended to provide for the deduction of child support paid by a family from that family's income when calculating the entitlement to Family Payment. Where a payer forms a new family and there are dependent children of either of the adults in the household, 50 per cent of any child support paid by the payer is to be disregarded by Centrelink when determining the family's entitlement to Family Payment. Although this does not fully meet the Joint Committee's recommendation that 100 per cent of child support paid be deducted from family income when calculating entitlement to Family Payment at more than the minimum rate, the Government has decided to extend the deduction to the minimum rate of Family Payment.

This favourable treatment will also be extended to Childcare Assistance because this form of child care fee relief is calculated using income test limits similar to Family Payment. As a result, deducting child support paid from income for Family Payment and Childcare Assistance purposes will ensure that the same (or similar) provisions for assessing entitlement are maintained.

PARA.EMPHASIS: REPAIRING THE CHILD SUPPORT INCOME BASE

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency undertakes research to identify the number of parents under the Child Support Scheme who receive business or investment income and the extent to which these parents minimise their child support liabilities.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation was responded to by the former Government in March 1995 (see Appendix 1).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that fringe benefits be added to the existing child support income base for both parents.
The Joint Committee recommends that both parents be required, within a set period, to provide the Child Support Agency with full details of all fringe benefits received from an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that parents may be purposefully or inadvertently avoiding their child support obligations through salary packaging that realises a proportion of their income as fringe benefits.

The Joint Committee felt that this problem could be overcome simply by adding back any fringe benefits into the child support base. Nevertheless, it was acknowledged that the process of identifying fringe benefits is not straightforward, and that the most practical response would be to require parents to provide full particulars of their fringe benefits.

The Government recognises the importance of accounting for all elements of income that may impact on a parent's capacity to support their child(ren). However, identifying and quantifying this income may be problematic, as is the case with fringe benefits. Fringe benefits cannot be identified from Income Tax Returns and this information would need to be sought from all clients, thereby increasing levels of Government intrusion and costs of administration. For these reasons, further investigation is being undertaken to test the efficacy of including fringe benefits as a component in the formula.

Currently, where the income or earning capacity of a parent is not adequately reflected in the formula a parent can apply for a departure from the assessment to take this into account. This can include fringe benefits.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that employer financed superannuation contributions in excess of 9 per cent of a parent's taxable income be added back to that parent's child support income base in any review of that parent's child support liability by the Child Support Registrar.

The Joint Committee recommends that any superannuation contributions by a parent, who is either an employee without any employer superannuation support, substantially self employed or self employed, which exceed 9 per cent of that parent's taxable income be added back to that parent's child support income base in any review of that parent's child support liability by the Child Support Registrar.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Select Committee was concerned that potential exists for parents to minimise their child support liability by making excessive superannuation contributions.

As with fringe benefits, this information is not readily available. Currently, where the income or earning capacity of a parent is not adequately reflected in the formula, a parent can apply for a departure from the assessment to take this into account. The Government will continue to examine cost‐effective measures to ensure child support is not avoided through income minimisation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to make a determination varying a formula assessment for child support upon request of either parent, or of the Child Support Registrar's own initiative, where the Child Support Registrar considers that either parent:
(a) obtains financial benefits from his or her employment, business and investment, or other activities which are not reflected in that parent's taxable income; or
(b) organises his or her employment, business and investment, or personal affairs to minimise taxable income, in order to minimise their child support liability.
The Joint Committee recommends that the child support legislation be amended to:

(a) allow the Child Support Registrar to issue a determination varying the child support assessment to reflect the capacity to pay of a parent in receipt of business or investment income upon the application of that parent;

(b) allow the Child Support Registrar to issue a determination varying previous child support assessments for a period of up to 4 years prior to the current assessment, or up to the date on which the assessment first became enforceable, whichever is the most recent, to reflect the capacity to pay of a parent in receipt of business or investment income;

(c) allow the Child Support Registrar to issue a determination varying previous child support assessments for a period of up to 7 years prior to the current assessment, or the date on which the assessment first became enforceable, whichever is the most recent, in circumstances where a parent fails to disclose accurately all income, expenditure and assets in which he or she has an interest;
(d) avoid retrospectivity, limit the backdating of any determination by the Child Support Registrar to the date of effect of the proposed amendments to the child support legislation;

(e) allow the Child Support Registrar to charge interest on the difference between the original, or last amended, child support assessment and the assessment varied pursuant to a determination of the Child Support Registrar for each year, or part year, at a rate equal to the prevailing medium term rate for Treasury bonds; and
(f) require the Child Support Registrar to pay any interest charged under (e) above to the other parent.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency implements:
(a) a targeted audit program in respect of parents who receive business or investment income;
(b) a random system of auditing parents who receive business or investment income; and
(c) a system of public ruling and other appropriate measures to inform parents and their advisers of the Child Support Registrar's practice in the assessment of a parent's capacity to pay.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar, when making an initial formula assessment or a determination to vary an existing formula assessment for child support shall:
(a) disregard the value of the non income producing assets of each parent where the value of these assets is equal to or less than a threshold amount;
(b) where the non income producing assets of the parent exceed a threshold amount, deem the income on the excess at a rate equivalent to the prevailing medium term Treasury bond rate; and
(c) add back the deemed income to that parent's child support income base.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Registrar be given the power to deem an asset assessable for child support purposes where the transfer of ownership or control of that asset has the effect of avoiding or minimising a parent's child support liability.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was concerned that parents in receipt of business income had a greater capacity to minimise their child support liability (either purposefully or inadvertently) and that the Registrar should be given the power to separately assess these cases.

The Government agrees that greater flexibility should be provided to the Registrar in these cases. Although the existing process to depart from an administrative assessment can effectively deal with these cases, it requires an application for departure to be made by one of the parties to the assessment. On 30 September 1997, the Government announced that the legislation will be amended to enable the Registrar to initiate the departure process where he has information that the assessment does not adequately reflect the income or earning capacity of the parent.

To complement the Government decision to give the Registrar the discretion to initiate a departure, a targeted audit approach will be implemented. The results of these audits will be evaluated to determine whether random audits would also be beneficial.

Existing legislation allows for child support assessments to be amended where there is an increase in taxable income for a prior year as a result of incomplete or incorrect information. It is not proposed to amend this function. It is considered that existing penalty provisions are adequate and that it would further complicate an already complex system if additional penalties were to be introduced and if those penalties were paid to the other parent. As indicated in recommendation 102, the amounts collected in penalty payments would be relatively low and, in turn, the level of recompense received by payees would be significantly outweighed by the high administrative costs that would be involved in implementing this recommendation.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to allow a maintenance order to be amended by an agreement of the parties which is in writing and registered in a court.

The Joint Committee was mindful of concerns placed before it about inequities between Stage 1 and Stage 2 of the Scheme. The Joint Committee, in its analysis of the issue, has significantly overstated the difficulties in obtaining a consent order. In particular, where parties have reached agreement and are seeking a consent order, there will be no requirement to attend a directions hearing, there will be no compulsory conference under Order 24, nor pre‐hearing conference. A consent order is usually obtained by filing an application together with the terms of a draft consent order. The Family Court has delegated to its registrars the power to make orders by consent.

The Government accepts the recommendation and agrees that parties who are able to reach agreement should not be required to enter into litigation in order to give effect to that agreement, provided that it is proper. The Family Law Act 1975 will be amended so that an agreement providing for child support which is registered in accordance with the provisions of the Act will, as a matter of law, prevail over any previous entitlements otherwise resulting from the Act (which would include prior court orders made pursuant to the Act).

PARA.EMPHASIS: CHILD SUPPORT LIABILITY AND PROPERTY SETTLEMENTS

SPEECH.PARA: RECOMMENDATION 153 :

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that where a court makes an allowance for child support liability by capitalising child support in a property order it must clearly specify the effect the order may have on future liability for child support consistent with the decision of Borg v Borg.
The Joint Committee recommends that where a court makes a property order and no allowance is made for liability for future child support the court must specify no allowance has been made.

The Joint Committee recommends that where a court specifies in a property order that there is an allowance for future child support liability, the Child Support Agency calculates on a pro rata basis the amount by which child support is to be reduced until the child turns 18 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's election commitment was to review matrimonial property reforms to ensure greater certainty and clarity in the allocation of matrimonial property, and to protect the interests of all parties. The commitment did not address the issues covered by these recommendations but they could be addressed in the course of the property review.
The Attorney‐General is currently considering the options for reform of matrimonial property, including superannuation and prenuptial agreements, but no final decision has been reached.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the non custodial parent be given the right to apply to the Child Support Agency for an assessment.

SPEECH.PARA: This recommendation provides one solution to the problem highlighted by the Joint Committee that in some circumstances, where proceedings are before the Family Court and the parent entitled to receive child support has not obtained a child support assessment, the Court cannot take into account potential child support liabilities for the purposes of property proceedings under section 79 of the Family Law Act 1975 or spousal maintenance proceedings under section 75 of the Family Law Act 1975.

The Child Support Legislation Amendment Act (No 1) 1997 amended the Family Law Act 1975 to ensure the Family Court is able to take into account a person's future child support liability, even where an assessment had not yet come into existence.
In addition, the Government announced on 30 September 1997 that the legislation will be amended to enable a liable parent to apply for a child support assessment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Attorney‐General consults with the Law Council of Australia to examine the issue of accreditation of legal practitioners practising in family law to ensure the best and most accurate advice is available to the public.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee recognised that formal accreditation of legal practitioners is a matter for the States and Territories and is not directly under the Commonwealth's control. The Government notes that a number of States and Territories already have accreditation schemes for lawyers.

The Commonwealth, States and Territories are, through the Council of Australian Governments, examining reform of the legal profession in Australia. This has involved consideration of the role of specialist and accreditation schemes. The Commonwealth, in consultation with the States and Territories, has issued advertising guidelines to ensure that consumers have adequate information about the services, including specialist services, provided in the legal services market. The Government supports measures to ensure the highest possible standard of representation is available to people in family law matters.

PARA.EMPHASIS: FUTURE EVALUATIONS OF THE CHILD SUPPORT SCHEME

The Joint Committee recommends that the Government, as a matter of priority, commissions the next evaluation of the Child Support Scheme to be carried out by an independent research organisation under the guidance of a three person supervisory committee.

The Joint Committee recommends that the next evaluation of the Child Support Scheme comprehensively examines the Child Support Scheme's financial impact on its clients including an analysis of relative household income, debt and asset levels.

The Joint Committee recommends that the next evaluation of the Child Support Scheme incorporates a comprehensive analytical study and empirical evaluation of the combined effect of the social security, child support, family law and taxation legislation on:
(a) work disincentives for both custodial and non custodial parents;
(b) incentives for the separation of existing families; and
(c) disincentives for the formation of subsequent families.
The Joint Committee recommends that the impact of the Child Support Scheme be regularly evaluated over time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee considered it vital that a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of the scheme on payers, payees and their families be carried out, preferably by an independent organisation.
In addition, Government guidelines require that effectiveness, including relevance and priority, of all program elements are evaluated at least once every three to five years.

The Government agrees that the impact of the Scheme on parents and their families should continue to be evaluated. However, the nature and extent of a formal future evaluation will need to be determined in the context of the environment at the time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that any future modelling of the impact of the Child Support Scheme on the relative disposable incomes of custodial and non custodial parents includes an estimate of the value of fringe benefits provided by all levels of government to those parents who are social security recipients.

SPEECH.PARA: The modelling undertaken by the Department of Social Security for the Joint Committee did not incorporate estimates for fringe benefits to assess the impact of the Child Support Scheme on the disposable incomes of those parents who are income support recipients because of the practical difficulties involved in doing this.

While the Government accepts this recommendation, the range of fringe benefits available to income support recipients varies according to State and often local government area. In addition, the value of fringe benefits depends on the actual use made of them by individuals (for example, the purchase of a hearing aid or the need for dental work). There is no comprehensive data currently available on the average value of benefits.

Despite the complex issues raised by this recommendation, the Department of Social Security and the Child Support Agency will examine the feasibility of including estimates of these benefits in future modelling as suggested by the Joint Committee.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that all future modelling of the impact of the Child Support Scheme be conducted by an independent party.

SPEECH.PARA: The modelling undertaken by the Department of Social Security, like other modelling that could be undertaken by another agency, demonstrates the effect of the formula on the disposable incomes of parents in different circumstances. The modelling is used to show the effects of the current formula as well as the potential impact of proposed changes to the formula. This is important to the provision of policy advice to Government.

While the Government does not accept this recommendation as it stands, it is acknowledged that modelling could be carried out on current available data by any organisation that has a detailed understanding of the interrelationships between the social security and taxation systems and the Child Support Scheme.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE
Matters for the Child Support Registrar

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes, as a matter of priority, national policies and develops the necessary guidelines and manuals to ensure uniform practices are observed in all areas of Child Support Agency administration and in accordance with the child support legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and had, prior to the report being tabled, set up a number of mechanisms to develop and implement consistent policies and procedures.

The Agency recognises that it must be consistent and fair in its dealings with all clients if it is to administer the Scheme in an effective and equitable manner. The Agency's Policy Development Unit was established in January 1993 to tackle this issue. This Unit promotes consistency in understanding and application of national policies and procedures by issuing discussion papers, policy guidelines, Child Support Determinations and Child Support Rulings. Matters requiring policy development are identified and prioritised by conducting regular surveys of Agency staff and external stakeholders. The process for developing policy documents is a consultative one involving the same internal and external stakeholders.

The Agency is monitoring the implementation of national policies and procedures to ensure they are applied consistently. To support this process, the Agency has established regional structures to identify inconsistencies in practices. A Deputy Registrar in each region has responsibility for child support matters in his or her region. A regional executive forum consisting of the regional Deputy Registrar, branch office directors and a staff association representative meets regularly. One of their responsibilities is to ensure that policies and procedures are applied consistently in the region and to take remedial action where this is not happening.
The Agency also holds national conferences involving all branch office directors. One role of these conferences is to contribute to consistency of practice and procedure.

All staff now participate in a legislative training program which is conducted co‐operatively across each region to improve consistency in understanding and applying the legislation. This also promotes consistency in procedures across the Branches.

One factor critical in promoting consistency is the level of staff access to policy and procedural information. To improve the level of support provided to staff, the Agency is currently examining the possibility of using electronic document folders to provide staff with easy and consistent access to Agency policies and procedures.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts due under default assessments be included in the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency has included debts due under default assessments in the calculation of its collection rate since 1 July 1994. No further action is required in relation to this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that child support debts paid pursuant to private collection cases registered with the Child Support Agency be excluded from the calculation of the Child Support Agency's collection rate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency has never included these debts in calculating its collection rate. No further action is required in relation to this recommendation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency establishes a nationally co‐ordinated approach to identify, assess and introduce as revised national practice, administrative improvements from local branch office initiatives and from best practice in the public and private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to implement it.

The Agency has established a Business Improvement Unit to coordinate the Agency's approach to developing best practices for national implementation. As part of an ongoing program, all branch offices of the Agency were asked in December 1994 to share improvement initiatives/best practices by providing details to the Business Improvement Unit. That unit will disseminate information about these best practices to other branch offices. Initially, branch office directors will be regularly contacted to identify best practices.

Improvement initiatives will be assessed as part of a process of continuous improvement within the Agency and the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) as a whole. The outcome of this process will be the development of national best practices.

In relation to public/private sector best practices, the Agency has embarked on a long term, systematic and integrated process of continuous performance improvement consistent with a general move within the ATO. Input to the Agency's continuous improvement process has come from experienced practitioners in the ATO, the ATO Continuous Improvement Team, and from leading organisations in both the public and private sectors.

Employees are often the best source of suggestions for positive change. They are in the best position to know what is going wrong and frequently know how to improve the work system. Through a national health and productivity program, staff are encouraged to identify workplace barriers to administrative efficiency and effective service to clients. An action plan is then implemented to resolve identified issues at national, regional and local levels. The program embodies continuous improvement and Industrial Democracy principles and promotes staff health and productivity.

In addition to this national approach, a regional Deputy Registrar has been appointed in each administrative region to work with the branch office directors in these regions to identify best practices regionally. These best practices are then presented to the CSA Executive and consideration is given to national implementation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency:
(a) ensures that training has an appropriate focus on client service;
(b) evaluates the effectiveness of the training provided by measuring the transference of skills learnt bystaff into the workplace;
(c) introduces a national program for validating and accrediting all training material and training received by staff of the Agency;
(d) adopts progressive and innovative approaches to training and abandons the Child Support Agency's reliance upon `in house' and `on the job' training; and

SPEECH.PARA: (e) recruits more staff with experience and qualifications in client service oriented disciplines to assist in changing the current predominantly tax and finance oriented staff culture.
The Agency has acted to implement parts of this recommendation.

The Agency's National Training Unit is responsible for identifying training needs, setting priorities, developing appropriate training strategies and coordinating the development and presentation of training. This Unit has undertaken an extensive planning process to identify immediate training needs and priorities and, as a result, is concentrating on training in the following areas:

1. Technical training—the CSA Tech 1‐2‐3‐ program is a comprehensive program covering all aspects of the child support legislation and related legislation. Child Support Agency Tech 1‐2‐3 is aimed to ensure the provision of accurate and consistent technical advice.

2. Client service training (incorporating the Client Contact Skills program)—all Agency training should focus on being sensitive to clients' needs and staff will have access to training and resources capable of providing the interpersonal skills to confidently impart technical advice.

3. Arrears and compliance training—is focussed on constructive client contact through improved understanding of the law. This will enable a consistent approach to assessments and provides technical skills for debt collection. This training will be incorporated into CSA Tech 1‐2‐3.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (a)—ensure that training has an appropriate focus on client service

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency's National Training Strategy, released on 15 August 1994, contains the following statement in relation to the client service focus in all areas of training:

'Agency National Training will initially focus on front‐line staff, to achieve the earliest and best responsiveness to client needs. Front‐line staff have the most direct contact with our community. Their performance strongly influences the quality of service delivered. Staff interactions with clients should leave a lasting perception of ease and competence with which the Agency can act on their behalf and resolve their difficulties.'
The principle in this statement is built into the design of all training products produced and cleared by the National Training Unit.

The Client Contact Skills program is a specific program aimed at improving the client contact skills of Agency staff. The pilot of the program was completed in February 1995 and all Agency staff who have direct contact with clients will undertake the program by 31 December 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (b)—evaluate the effectiveness of the training provided by measuring the transference of skills learnt by staff into the workplace

SPEECH.PARA: The effectiveness of all national training is tested before national implementation. The National Training Unit also provides support to branch offices to allow for evaluation of training provided locally.
The effectiveness of all national training in transferring skills into the workplace will be evaluated. For example, the effectiveness of the CSA Tech 1‐2‐3 program will be evaluated in three phases:
. participant knowledge will be assessed at the end of each module
. an evaluation of Trainer Training and the design principles will take place when all modules are released
. evaluation of the transfer of learning and changed behaviour will be conducted when all branches have delivered the training and there has been time for changes to happen.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (c)—introduce a national program for validating and accrediting all training material and training received by staff of the Agency

SPEECH.PARA: All national training programs are piloted and tested before being formally introduced. This allows the Agency to detect any deficiencies in the package and make sure that the best possible product is ultimately presented.

As Agency staff are also employed by the ATO, they have the opportunity to participate in the Taxation Officer Development (TOD) program. Steps have been taken to integrate child support specific topics into the TOD program. For example, Agency staff who complete certain CSA training courses can gain credit towards completion of the TOD program. The TOD program has been formally accredited.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (d)—adopt progressive and innovative approaches to training and abandon the Agency's reliance upon "in house" and "on the job" training

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency's training strategy recognises that it is necessary to have a mixture of in‐house and external resources. The Agency does not rely exclusively on in‐house training but will use its own expertise where appropriate. It is important to use the best source of information, knowledge and skills in developing training materials. The Agency will strive to use the best available resource wherever that may be located.

For example, in developing materials specifically dealing with child support legislation or procedures, the Agency is confident that the most appropriate source of information is available internally. However, if the required knowledge or skills are not available within the organisation, the Agency will engage external consultants. For example, a consultant was engaged to develop the Client Contact Skills package which is currently being piloted. The Agency may also choose to use subject matter experts from other areas of the ATO where they can provide the best available resource.

The Agency has also developed source materials which can be used in a variety of ways. This allows for the same material to be used for self‐paced learning, in workshops involving small groups of people or in more formal classroom training sessions depending upon the needs of particular staff members.

On the job training can be a valuable way of reinforcing knowledge and skills first learnt in more formal training. In some cases, on the job training is the most effective way in which a particular training need can be met.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (e)—recruit more staff with experience and qualifications in client service oriented disciplines to assist in changing the current predominantly tax and finance

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency has, as part of an industrial agreement under enterprise bargaining, undergone a Blueprint process, in which it has examined its current branch office structures to standardise those structures and work practices. Following on from this process, the Agency is currently working on an extensive work and job design process. All jobs in the Agency will be examined to define the duties to be performed and a general description of the job. In that process, the Agency is looking at the skills required as well as the skills that can be developed by working in the Agency. There will be an enhanced emphasis on client contact skills. This will allow the Agency to attract people with these skills, or who have the potential to develop those skills, to work in the Agency. The criteria used for selection for positions within the Agency will then be redeveloped around these duty statements and job descriptions. This will ensure an appropriate emphasis on client service skills in selection processes.

The Agency is committed to recruiting staff with the skills identified through the Blueprint process. As a major part of the Agency's work involves debt collection, it is important to have staff with an appropriate mix of client service and debt collection skills.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces dedicated case officers, with assigned responsibility and accountability for individual clients.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency is moving towards client based multi‐function teams each with their own identifiable group of clients, with a combined team client ownership and individual case management approach. The Agency does not intend to introduce dedicated case officers with assigned responsibility and accountability for the bulk of its individual clients as this would not be an efficient use of its limited resources. Members of the Registrar's Advisory Panel and regional advisory groups recognised this and supported the Agency's approach.
As part of the Blueprint process, the Agency considered a number of models for case management and came to the following conclusions:
1. Case ownership will provide clients with better service and will improve compliance only if targeted correctly and supported by an appropriate infrastructure.
2. This arrangement should be team based with provision for client ownership to rest with individual staff within each team for specific and current issue management.

3. The introduction of individual case ownership should be seen as an enhancement rather than a solution. It should be a longer term goal for consideration after more systemic issues have been addressed and a period of consolidation has occurred.

The proposed approach will provide responsive and robust client service where all members of the team are available to attend to their clients' needs as they arise. The service will not be dependant on the availability of an individual case officer. The team will have a richer pool of knowledge and experience with greater capacity to deal with a range of issues than one individual may have, and the capacity for individual case management is available as problems or issues arise.

As the needs of individual clients can be diverse, each multi‐function team will be able to provide most of the services their clients require from within the team. The remainder will be undertaken within a specialist team whose functions need to be performed separately for reasons of specialisation and accountability. The Agency has recognised the need to address issues of quality service and clear lines of responsibility and accountability. These issues have been given high priority throughout the Blueprint process.

A team based approach also offers the Agency the flexibility to adjust staffing arrangements as the need arises without significantly disrupting client/staff relationships, as would be the case with individual client ownership.
The team based approach to case management will be developed further and implemented consistently in all branches during 1995 through a process of work and job design.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces a reference number system to ensure accountability for the advice given to clients and to enable follow up on commitments and the provision of feedback to clients.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency agrees that it needs to ensure that its staff are accountable for advice given to clients. The Agency believes that this recommendation would not be necessary if the current procedures for recording advice and commitments are followed.

The Agency has an internal system for recording details of advice and commitments given to clients by telephone, in person or in writing. Under the ATO's Agency Agreement, Agency staff have agreed to identify themselves to clients. These two measures will ensure that staff are accountable for advice and commitments they give. The Agency acknowledges that advice and commitments are not always properly recorded. In light of the concerns raised by the Committee, the Agency undertakes to improve the consistency of recording advice and commitments.
This commitment will be supported by the Client Contact Skills program, the Child Support Charter and the move towards team based case management.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency, as a matter of urgency, develops national guidelines for the identification and administration of cases where there is a history or risk of domestic violence and/or child abuse.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and has commenced work on these guidelines.

The Agency's Policy Development Unit is preparing guidelines for the administration of cases involving domestic violence or child abuse. The Agency is consulting a wide range of external stakeholders including client representatives, community groups, legal services and other agencies such as the Department of Social Security, the Attorney‐General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner in preparing these guidelines. A draft guideline is expected by 30 April, with a final guideline in place by 31 July 1995.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that within 6 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency conducts a study of the information needs of its clients and identifies shortfalls in current representation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency agrees that the identification of its clients' information needs is a priority. In order to be able to identify these needs, the Agency will need a specifically designed process to explore the most effective way of providing information to a diverse client population. In preparation, the Agency has started collecting and analysing data from a number of sources.

In March 1995, the Agency commenced a client survey aimed at establishing the level of satisfaction with services currently provided by the Agency. An integral part of this survey is the establishment of some base data for age, education levels, ethnicity and socio economic backgrounds of the Agency's clients. Information is also being drawn from the Agency's Client Relations Officers in each branch through their work with diverse client groups and a range of community organisations. A client profiling project, which is currently underway, will provide information on sources of income of clients.

In conjunction with the above research, the Agency will also commence a research project looking at the specific information needs of some of the key client groups. Research undertaken to date has indicated that specific client groups have a poor understanding of their rights and obligations. Advice from the external advisory panels has also supported this view.

As a first step in this research program, the Agency will be looking at the information needs of clients from non‐English speaking backgrounds and the non custodial parent groups. Part of this research program will include research undertaken in the 1994‐95 year on current and potential clients from non‐English speaking backgrounds or who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that within 12 months of the tabling of the Joint Committee's report, the Child Support Agency reports to the Assistant Treasurer on the costs and benefits, including savings to community organisations, of introducing an advisory function to meet the information needs of its clients. This is to include:
(a) a nationally co‐ordinated `outreach' program targeted to the information needs of Child Support Agency clients, especially those clients in remote locations;
(b) making greater use of the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network by establishing full time Child Support Agency advisory staff in these offices; and
(c) making advisory staff available on a short term, permanent or rostered basis in remote locations in community legal aid, the Department of Social Security or other offices.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports paragraph (a) of this recommendation and has begun to implement it. There are some difficulties with implementing paragraph (b) as recommended and the Agency plans to consider these difficulties. Recommendation 19(c) requires further consultation with the Department of Social Security and other relevant government and non‐government agencies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (a)—a nationally coordinated "outreach" program targeted to the information needs of Agency clients, especially those clients in remote locations

SPEECH.PARA: A Client Relations Officer has been appointed in each branch office. These officers are working under national direction to develop and conduct a nationally coordinated outreach program targeted to the information needs of Agency clients through community based organisations.

Local outreach programs are currently being implemented by branch offices. These programs focus on general information about the Agency which the broader community may need and frequently takes the form of public information sessions.
Some branches of the Agency have very recently set up local arrangements with community organisations in their area. For example
. the Dandenong branch has been working with the Springvale Legal Service/Springvale Community Aid and Advice Bureau
. the Brisbane branch has, in conjunction with staff placements in the Toowoomba regional office of the ATO, been working with community and professional groups in the Toowoomba region
. the Pulteney branch has begun investigating the possibility of working with community groups around the cities of the Spencer Gulf

. the Northbridge branch has commenced liaison with the Aboriginal Legal Services of Western Australia and associated community groups to identify specific needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients in Western Australia, in particular those in remote areas.

The Agency will be evaluating these initiatives as they develop within the national program. This evaluation will start in June 1996. As these initiatives are new it is necessary for a reasonable period to elapse to enable an effective evaluation.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (b)—making greater use of the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network by establishing full time Agency advisory staff in these offices

SPEECH.PARA: Where there is an identified need, a number of branches have been sending staff to regional offices in their areas. The experience in these offices will be evaluated in 1995 to assess the extent to which a nationally coordinated approach to using ATO regional offices is appropriate.

There are some concerns about placing full time Agency staff within the Australian Taxation Office's regional office network. Some concerns relate to security, as staff in remote locations would be isolated and identified within that community as Agency staff, at potential personal risk. The Agency believes that the objective of providing a more accessible client service in remote locations can be achieved through the wider use of well planned and well publicised short term and rostered staff placements.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Paragraph (c)—making advisory staff available on a short term, permanent or rostered basis in remote locations in community legal aid, the Department of Social Security or other offices

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency will need to consult further with the Department of Social Security (DSS) and other relevant agencies before providing advice on this recommendation. The Agency will also have to consider in which offices other than the DSS it would be appropriate to place Agency staff and the practicalities of those placements. For example, the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia has advised the Agency that it may be appropriate to involve Migrant Resource Centres.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops in consultation with its clients, a code of conduct and service standards for Child Support Agency staff and ensures all Child Support Agency clients are aware of the standards of conduct and service which have been set.

The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces administrative procedures to ensure that clients not receiving the set standard of service have redress to higher levels of management and informs all clients of the process and procedures required to pursue complaints about conduct and service delivery.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops administrative mechanisms to monitor client complaints and solve the deficiencies in conduct and service delivery.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports recommendations 20, 21 and 22 and has begun to implement them.

On 5 December 1994, the Child Support Registrar announced his commitment to the development of a Child Support Charter. The Child Support Charter will incorporate standards of conduct and service and will set out the rights and responsibilities of the Agency's clients. The Agency, as part of the ATO, is bound by the ATO's Agency Agreement. That Agreement establishes a number of client contact principles which will also be embodied in the Child Support Charter.

The Child Support Charter will clearly set out the standards of service to which the Agency's clients are entitled and explain rights of redress where those standards are not met. To complement the Child Support Charter, the Agency will put in place an appropriate problem resolution mechanism. Principles embodied in the Child Support Charter will be included in training material and policy documents.

The Child Support Charter is being developed with wide community consultation. Submissions have been sought externally through all major national and regional newspapers as well as through the members of the Agency's Advisory Panels. Agency and other ATO staff have also been encouraged to have input into the development of the Child Support Charter. A draft Child Support Charter will be developed using this input through a workshop process and will then be refined further with additional consultation.
The Agency expects the final draft of the Child Support Charter to be presented to Government for approval early in the 1995/96 financial year.

The Agency expects that delivery of the Client Contact Skills program to all staff will reduce the number of complaints about service conduct and delivery, and the Child Support Charter will provide clients with an enhanced understanding of their rights and responsibilities in their relationship with the Agency.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency develops communication strategies, targeted at the various groups of Child Support Agency clients, to inform them of their rights and obligations under child support legislation and Child Support Agency administrative practices which may materially affect each group of clients.

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure Agency clients are aware of their rights and responsibilities the Agency will commence a client education program targeted to meet the specific needs of all Agency clients.
The Agency will adopt a three‐stage approach to the client education program—research, implementation and evaluation. The research phase has already commenced (see recommendation 18).
The client education program has several key components including
. specific information on the Agency's administrative practices and policies (for example, information on the Agency's policy for crediting non‐agency payments)
. targeted information for key client groups (for example, information targeted to the needs of clients from non‐English speaking backgrounds and liable parents).

These and other strategies for the client education program will be developed in consultation with members of the Agency's advisory panels and staff. The program will link into the Agency's outreach activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency in consultation with the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education develop a resource package on child support and other legal responsibilities to be used by the Child Support Agency, marriage education bodies and other relationship programs.

SPEECH.PARA: While the report recognises the work already done by the Agency to educate potential clients through a number of programs, recommendation 24 focuses on the provision of child support information to people entering new relationships.

The Agency will explore a range of options for developing a resource package for use in relationship programs (including pre‐marriage and counselling programs). The Agency will also discuss these options with a range of interested groups including the Australian Association for Marriage Education and the Catholic Society for Marriage Education.
The Agency has commenced discussions with Legal Aid and Family Service (LAFS) in the Attorney‐General's Department, regarding the inclusion of child support information in their premarriage programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that an independent consultant be engaged to work with the Child Support Agency to realign management and service to the needs of clients and develop strategies aimed at achieving best practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency has already taken action to realign management and service to the needs of clients by opening up its administration to greater community involvement and developing management approaches and work practices designed to meet client needs.

To increase community involvement, the Registrar established the Registrar's Advisory Panel and regional advisory panels. These panels consist of representatives of a range of client groups, other government agencies and community organisations. Their purpose is to provide advice to the Registrar and the regional Deputy Registrars on the administration of the Scheme and to consider proposals to improve that administration. This process assists the Agency to develop practices that meet the needs of its clients and address issues of concern to the community. These groups are involved in the Agency's business planning process and the development of the Child Support Charter.

The Agency is currently undertaking a job and work design process to ensure that work practices are aligned with the needs of clients. This includes the introduction of client based teams as discussed at recommendation 13.
The Agency has put in place substantial mechanisms to deal with the change and improvement programs currently in progress as well as to manage day to day administration issues. These are
. a new senior management team consisting of a Second Commissioner with responsibility for child support and two Assistant Commissioners

. one Deputy Child Support Registrar in each administrative region (New South Wales, Victoria/Tasmania, Queensland and Western Australia/South Australia) has been given responsibility for child support matters within that region

. the CSA Executive consisting of the Second Commissioner, the two Assistant Commissioners, the four Deputy Child Support Registrars with regional responsibility for child support and representatives from the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU)
. the Business Improvement Project Co‐ordination committee which is responsible for coordinating improvements and change projects nationally.

The Agency believes these measures, together with the business planning process currently underway, will better align management and service to client needs. The Agency believes it can benefit from external expertise and has already engaged a number of consultants to assist in developing strategies for a range of activities. For example, the Agency has engaged consultants to assist in
. the business planning process
. planning an information technology improvement program
. developing a Client Contact Skills program
. market testing
. a client satisfaction survey.
Through these approaches, supported by the Agency's nationally coordinated continuous improvement process, the Agency is developing strategies aimed at achieving best practice.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency examines the management practices and operational standards applied to telephone communications in leading commercial operations in order to improve the management of the Child Support Agency's telephone enquiry service to clients.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to improve its telephone performance.

The Agency conducted a national Telephone Project in early 1994 which, as part of its activities, investigated how other organisations managed their telephone enquiry workload. This investigation included the Department of Social Security and research findings from the Incoming Calls Management Institute in Maryland USA.

The Agency has achieved significant improvements in its performance in this area. In May 1994, the Agency decided, as a short term measure, to allocate 10% of all staff to telephone enquiry work in each branch in recognition of the need to provide better service to clients. Since then, the Agency has improved its telephone technology and has made better use of the management information systems which accompany that technology.
The ATO and the Agency are currently working towards having compatible telephone systems to allow calls to be managed on a regional basis from July 1996.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency sets up a separate general inquiry number so that simple and routine telephone enquiries can be handled promptly and effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation in principle.

In an effort to provide a better range of telephone services, the Agency is introducing a voice messaging service called the CSA Info Service. Once this has been fully implemented, there will be two enquiry numbers available to most clients
. the general enquiry number which exists now which includes the facility for transfer to the team handling a particular case
. the CSA Info Service number which will initially handle basic general enquiries relating to payment and account information and provide general information about the Scheme.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency introduces on a national basis the voice messaging telephone service.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and has commenced implementation.

The phased national introduction of a voice messaging service, known as the CSA Info Service, will commence in April 1995. The CSA Info Service will provide specific accounting information to clients using a unique personal identification number.
General information about the Scheme will also be available to those clients who require it.

The CSA Info Service will not replace the Agency's general enquiry service. However, by allowing clients to quickly access basic information, it is expected to free up enquiry officers to provide a better service for these callers who require more detailed information. In time, the CSA Info Service could be further developed to provide a greater range of information.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency requires staff to identify themselves to clients unless staff believe their safety to be at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of the ATO's Agency Agreement, Agency staff have agreed to be covered by a number of client contact principles. The Agency Agreement states:

"55.3 The ATO expects that employees will provide their names when dealing with the public. Where an employee has an honestly held concern for their personal safety which could arise from them identifying themselves, the employee and the manager will jointly determine an alternative form of identification for the employee. Where this occurs, internal systems will be developed to ensure accountability and identification of the employee."

The Agency is committed to implementing this recommendation. The proposed arrangements to give effect to this recommendation will be developed further and implemented as part of the development of the Child Support Charter which will outline some client contact principles including identification.
This issue will also be addressed in the Client Contact Skills program which is currently being piloted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency re‐writes computer generated correspondence to provide clients with the information they require in a clear, concise and user friendly fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports this recommendation and has already acted to implement it.
The Agency has started to review all its computer generated correspondence. It has already reviewed its pre‐acceptance letter and will look next at the most commonly used computer generated letters.

Whilst this review will improve computer generated letters to some extent, a long term solution will require major system changes. To this end, the Agency is developing an Information Technology improvement program.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that where clients raise specific issues the Child Support Agency responds on an individual basis and avoids the use of a computer generated response.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency recognises the need to avoid universal use of computer generated letters but believes they are appropriate in many cases.

The Agency acknowledges that uniquely drafted letters will often be more appropriate than the computer generated letters which are currently available. However, in many cases it will still be appropriate and more efficient to use computer generated letters. Some of the problems associated with using these letters will be reduced as their quality improves (see recommendation 32).
The Agency will examine the training needs of staff in effective business letter writing as part of its national training strategy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Australian Taxation Office advertises in Tax Pack and on individual income tax return forms that information provided in tax returns may be used by the Child Support Agency to assess liability for child support.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports the recommendation. The ATO has agreed to notify clients through Tax Pack 1995/1996 about use of taxation information for child support purposes.

The Agency agrees that it is important that clients and the wider community are aware that the Agency has the authority to access taxation information and that it advises clients of purposes for which information may be used.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews and amends procedures for contacting clients and responding to client enquiries to prevent the unauthorised disclosure of personal information.
The Joint Committee recommends that Child Support Agency staff be trained in the requirements of the Privacy Act 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports these two recommendations and had, before the report was tabled, taken action to implement them.
The Agency acknowledges the Committee's concerns. The Agency treats its clients' privacy seriously and has already taken steps to prevent such breaches recurring.

The Agency issued a guideline to all staff in March 1994 dealing with Proof of Identity, Privacy and Secrecy. This guideline outlines the application of the secrecy provisions in the child support legislation, the Information Privacy Principles contained in the Privacy Act 1988 and establishes a procedure which staff must follow in establishing the identity of a person making an enquiry. It also describes what a client needs to do to authorise someone to act on his or her behalf so that the Agency is satisfied that a person making an enquiry does, in fact, have the authority to do so.

The requirements of the Privacy Act 1988 and its implications for collecting, storing, using and disclosing information are covered in detail in the CSA Tech 1‐2‐3 training program which is currently being implemented (see recommendation 11). The course material includes case studies to make the material relevant to actual Agency experience.
The Agency has accepted an offer from the Privacy Commissioner to provide advice on the content of privacy training developed by the Agency.

In addition, the Agency has introduced enhancements to its computer system to provide additional security measures. The Agency will also review its procedures for contacting employers to minimise the potential for breaches of privacy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency reviews its registration procedures to ensure that it registers court orders and court registered agreements correctly and does not register applications for court orders.
The Joint Committee recommends that the Child Support Agency revises its training programs in order to improve the ability of staff to interpret correctly court orders.

SPEECH.PARA: The Agency supports these two recommendations and has already taken some action to address them.
