The Government will be using IAP consultations and bilateral representations throughout the year to urge Indonesia to improve its commitments to liberalise services markets in its 1997 IAP. The Australian Government will be asking Indonesia to address all service sectors and to make more specific liberalisation commitments in areas of interest to Australian exporters such as professional, financial, telecommunications and maritime services.

The WTO negotiations on telecommunications concluded in February 1997. Indonesia made commitments on its existing policy as a base for future liberalisation. The negotiations on financial services offer further opportunity to pursue Australia's market access issues. The WTO Working Party on Professional Services is due to conclude its work on accountancy services by the end of 1997 and this should also facilitate market access into Indonesia. The next broad‐based round of multilateral services negotiations is due to begin by 2000 and Australia is playing an active role in the lead‐up to that round.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 25. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Austrade and the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism give a high priority to activities designed to open up its markets to foreign commercial presence and service imports.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

The Government is actively engaged in activities to promote Australia to foreign companies as a place in which to invest and to do business, as well as from which they can service the region. The main vehicle for this promotional activity is the Investment Promotion and Facilitation Program (IPFP) which is run in partnership by Austrade and DIST. In the 1996‐97 Budget, the Government extended the IPFP for a further four years with total funding of $33 million. The IPFP funds a component of the Austrade network which includes dedicated investment specialists in twelve overseas locations supported by staff in Sydney and Melbourne.

DFAT Heads of Mission are also involved in the promotion of Australia as an investment destination. The Department more generally has a number of programs including the Special Visits Program (SVPs) and the Media Liaisons Visits Program which help to highlight opportunities available in Australia. The Government will also pay due regard to these issues in developing its response to the Mortimer Report.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 26. The Treasury and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs confirm whether there are significant inequities in allowances for students studying in Australia under World Bank funded projects and if so established, approach the World Bank with a view to redressing this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

DEETYA has established there has been one case of significant underestimation of living allowance requirements for students from Indonesia studying in Australia who were funded by the World Bank. DEETYA has raised the specific issue with the World Bank, and will raise similar issues on a case‐by‐case basis.

The students participating in a Bank‐financed program are sponsored by the borrowing government or a participating public agency. The amount of financial support is based generally on a schedule fixed by the sponsoring agency. The total package of financial assistance provided by an agency to students will depend in part on the nature and duration of the course; the personal situation of the student (including the number of dependants); and the location of the course and related costs for tuition and accommodation. In some instances, the amount may also reflect the seniority and position of the student.

Inevitably, different agencies have different schemes and programs of support. There may, therefore, be instances where different levels of financial support are provided to students from a particular country (who are sponsored by different agencies).

The World Bank's primary concern is that the financial support being provided to students is adequate for them to study and live modestly, including any support needed for dependants. Should the financial assistance being provided under Bank‐financed projects prove to be inadequate and result in hardship for the students concerned, the Bank is able to reassess the provisions and work with the borrowing agency to ensure that adequate levels are provided.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 27. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, in consultation with industry bodies, examine current provision of educational advice to overseas posts with a view to avoiding duplication of effort and simplifying the process for prospective students.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

The AIEF was established to avoid duplication of effort and to simplify the process for prospective students. It has established generic marketing services including the provision of information to students through a number of sources including Australian Education Centres (AEC's), overseas missions, education agents, reference sites (including internet) and various publications.

Each year thousands of students from different countries access information on a variety of Australian education and training courses. The AIEF has established mechanisms to ensure consistent high quality advice and provision of information by the AEC shopfronts, overseas missions and others involved in international education and training. This enables students to make informed decisions on education and training in Australia.
The AIEF mechanism has been recently reviewed and the Government is finalising its response to the review.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 28. Australia offer to assist Indonesia to adopt internationally recognised commercial law standards, business standards and practices that will maintain the confidence of overseas investors.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

Australia has been actively developing and promoting cooperation in law and legal services. Indonesia has been a major focus for the International Legal Services Advisory Committee, which operates under the auspice of the Attorney‐General's Department. These activities will be continued.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 29. Austrade and the Department of Health and Family Services consider ways in which medical services and health education services can focus on the needs of markets like Indonesia to improve the understanding of the high quality of medical services available in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle
Healthcare services (and associated products and services) are among the targeted industry programs executed at Austrade's Indonesian offices.

An Asian health industry team exists, composed of industry specialists in each of Australia's South East Asian offices, to facilitate opportunities in the emerging health care export and investment sector in the region. Major Opportunity Coordinators in Australia work closely with all major companies to bring together what is a very diverse supply side in Australia. A number of major projects are pursued under the health industry strategy in Indonesia and one recent success was identifying and supporting a private hospital project in Surabaya for an Australian healthcare company, the first ever Australian owned and managed private hospital in Indonesia.

Since 1994, the Department of Health and Family Services has given priority to the development of the Indonesian market through, inter alia, the inclusion of health on the bilateral economic agenda for the Australia‐Indonesia Ministerial Forum, the development of a comprehensive action plan under the bilateral Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on health cooperation and the partnering of industry in market promotion and high level liaison at government level.

An important element of the Action Plan is that it will extend collaboration beyond government‐to‐government activity to draw in the private sector, and implementation should draw in wider sources of funding, including from the multilateral banks. This was highlighted in the communique issued after the Ministerial Forum meeting in October 1996 which stated that "Ministers encouraged future private health sector involvement in the development of the ongoing relationship. . . .. Ministers had a view that opportunities offered through the World Bank, Asian Development Bank and other financial institutions should also be examined."

The Indonesian Focus Group, which operates under the auspices of the Australian Health Industry Development Forum with the strong support of the Department of Health and Family Services, provides an important focus for the cementing of bilateral business links in the health sector. The group is working to establish a counterpart group in Indonesia, an initiative which is receiving a strong boost through Ministerial support in both countries. The Department of Health and Family Services has worked to ensure the backing of the Indonesian Ministry of Health for the counterpart group.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 30. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in association with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, take up with Indonesia the issue of easing restrictions for Australian business people travelling and working abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

In addition to bilateral approaches, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will be discussing with the Indonesian Government possible participation by Indonesia in the APEC Business Travel Card (see response to Recommendation 7).

The Government accepts the need to pursue this matter further in the context of strengthening economic links with Indonesia. Recent reforms to the temporary business entry arrangements in Australia provide a basis for progressing this matter, particularly through APEC forums dealing directly with business mobility or with trade and investment.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 31. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Austrade ensure that they have the most up‐to‐date information on Indonesia regulations, their application and enforcement as they affect service exporters, and actively disseminate that information available to service exporters.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

A number of APEC initiatives have contributed to improving the availability and transparency of information on the trade, investment and domestic regulatory regimes of APEC members, including Indonesia. Much of this is relevant to Australian service exporters to Indonesia and is readily available through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade or directly from the APEC Secretariat in Singapore (or via the Internet). Relevant publications include the APEC Investment Guidebook , Deregulation and Liberalisation Initiatives of APEC Member Economies, and the APEC Government Procurement Homepage . A detailed compendium on the arbitration and dispute mediation services available in APEC member economies is being prepared and this might also be of interest to Australian service exporters. Earlier this year, the International Legal Services Advisory Committee (ILSAC), in the Attorney General's Department, published the "Australia Indonesian Contract Management and Dispute Avoidance and Resolution Handbook".

In addition, Austrade provides client specific advice to Australian service companies wishing to enter the Indonesian market, including undertaking market research projects on their behalf. Almost without exception, market research would include advice on regulations, and their application and enforcement as they affect service exporters.

Austrade's Indonesian offices maintain a strong network of alliances with (Australian) services providers in Indonesia (for example, lawyers, banks and accountants) who can help service companies establish operations in Indonesia (for example, obtain licenses and comply with relevant laws).
Austrade's free Business Briefs provide information to companies on market specific issues, including establishing a presence in the market.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 32. Australia encourage the Indonesian government to accept and adopt international standards (ISO).

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed in principle

Australia is working actively through APEC to encourage alignment of members' standards with relevant international standards. Alignment of national standards with international standards is a key element of APEC's work on standards, focusing initially on a number of priority areas to be aligned by 2000/2005. APEC members will contribute to work to develop international standards for building and construction materials as a precursor to aligning their standards with these international standards. This is an area of work that is likely to be of interest to Australian service providers.

Professional standards or qualifications (which are not covered by ISO standards) can also be a significant impediment to trade in services. APEC's Human Resource Development Working Group has begun work on a "Mutual Recognition of Qualifications Project" with a particular focus on engineers. Australia will also encourage the recently established APEC Group on Services to identify ways that it can address the issue of professional qualifications.

Indonesia is an active participant in a number of ISO and IEC activities, including ISO 9000 (quality management systems), ISO 14000 (environmental management systems), wood and particle board, steel, petroleum, rubber, offshore structures, ceramics, agricultural food products and essential oils.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government Response to the 25th Report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation

SPEECH.PARA: Senator John Watson
Senator for Tasmania and Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear John,
I am writing, on behalf of the Government, to provide you with a response to your Committee's 25th Report which was tabled in the Senate on 1 September 1997.

The Government welcomes your Committee's report on its inquiry into the superannuation arrangements for parliamentarians and judges. I note that Committee members were all of the view that the Remuneration Tribunal should be involved in setting parliamentary superannuation.

The Government will be giving further consideration to the findings of the Committee on parliamentary superannuation. Changes to the method of setting parliamentarians' remuneration are contemplated by the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997, namely setting parliamentarians' remuneration by reference to classifications set by the Remuneration Tribunal rather than by direct linkage to public service SES salaries as at present. The Committee's recommendations on parliamentary superannuation will be considered in the context of those changes.

In relation to the judges' pensions scheme, the Government agrees that the scheme should be retained. The Government is consulting with the federal judiciary before finalising its view on the proposed modifications to the scheme. However, the Government is not, at this stage, disposed to support the lowering of the age at which a judicial pension would be available, believing that such a move could encourage early retirement from the Bench.
Yours sincerely
JOHN FAHEY

PARA.EMPHASIS: PRESIDENT'S REPORT TO THE SENATE ON GOVERNMENT RESPONSES OUTSTANDING TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORTS AS AT 2 DECEMBER 1997

INTERJECT.PARA: This document continues the practice of presenting to the Senate twice each year a list of Government responses to Senate and joint committee reports as well as responses which remain outstanding.

The practice of presenting this list to the Senate follows the resolution of the Senate of 14 March 1973 and the undertaking by successive governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in timely fashion. On 26 May 1978 the then Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Withers) informed the Senate that within six months of the tabling of a committee report, the responsible Minister would make a statement in the Parliament outlining the action the Government proposed to take in relation to the report. The period for responses was reduced from six months to three months in 1983 by the then incoming government. The then Leader of the Government in the Senate announced this change on 24 August 1983. The method of response continued to be by way of statement. Subsequently, on 16 October 1991 the former Government advised that responses to committee reports would be made by letter to a committee chairman, with the letter being tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The current Government in June 1996 affirmed its commitment to respond to relevant parliamentary committee reports within three months of their presentation.

The list does not usually include reports of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works or the Senate Standing Committees on Appropriations and Staffing, Selection of Bills, Procedure, Publications, Regulations and Ordinances and Scrutiny of Bills, though such reports will be included if they require a response. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes which are tabled by the committee. Where a response has been made by way of Finance Minute, the date of presentation has been appropriately annotated.

Legislation committees report on bills and on the provisions of bills. Only those reports in this category that make recommendations which cannot readily be implemented through the bill, and therefore require a response, are listed. The list also does not include reports by legislation committees on estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Crane, I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the Sun Fund Bill 1997 , together with submissions received by the committee and transcript of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement in relation to the report.
—Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

BREAK.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown making a statement relating to the report.

The Sun Fund Bill 1997 was presented to the Senate by me some months ago. It then went to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee for review, and today we have the report back from that committee. I am sorry that the government has attempted to prevent me from making some comment on this report, because it is an important matter.

The Sun Fund is a very bright idea. It is a move to extend through a capital grant to farmers and miners the opportunity of installing renewable energy on their properties—solar energy or wind power. I am pleased to say that, while there has been some demur by the committee on the idea of the funding coming from the diesel fuel levy rebate scheme, the idea of the solar power availability to rural areas has been endorsed.

In particular I want to endorse the committee's recommendation that the government investigate the implementation of a scheme to encourage the increased use of renewable energy systems in regional and remote areas of Australia. The committee considered that the scheme had a number of potential benefits for farmers and other people in regional areas. These include the beneficiaries having the ability to use diesel and renewables—solar power or wind power—at the same time and getting up‐front financial assistance from the government to do so.

Therefore, through the boost to solar power and to wind power, it will also be a boost to jobs in regional Australia. It is one small answer to unemployment in the bush. Beyond that, if government gets behind this idea, it is a potential great boost both to the manufacturing and to the research and development of renewable energy forms.

Australia leads the field so far as photovoltaics are concerned—that is, solar panels. But it is a lead that we are rapidly going to lose unless we get government action as countries that are nowhere near as well endowed with solar power as Australia is—countries like Switzerland and Japan—put huge amounts of government investment into this field. They know that next century is the solar century; they know that this is going to be a huge export business as well as a domestic boom; and they know that there are jobs aplenty to follow.

The scheme that I have proposed in this Sun Fund Bill 1997 would create about 1,000 jobs in the bush and would also pour millions of dollars into the alternative energy businesses. Yesterday I spoke at the Australian and New Zealand solar energy conference in this city. I was enormously impressed by the displays from business, often small business, and by the innovative minds at that conference. The willingness, the nous, and the ideas are there in the Australian community. All that is lacking is government action.

In this report, the committee is saying to the government, `For goodness sake, get behind solar power in this country because of the domestic benefits as well as the benefits that will flow on to the rest of the world.' Here on the eve of the Kyoto conference, which is trying to curb the awesomely destructive impact of global warming, is an idea which of itself would create half the benefit that the government's total greenhouse package which was announced a couple of weeks ago sets out to do.

I am pleased that the committee has given encouragement to this idea. I hope the government takes up the challenge issued in this committee report to put a boost into the investment in renewable energy systems, particularly in rural Australia where it has the double boon of replacing fossil fuel in the form of diesel electricity generation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that, on the day that Australia is going into a situation with the rest of the world of pretending that we have no other options and pretending that we have to increase our greenhouse emissions by 18 per cent, we have even a short debate—as was suggested by Senator Brown when he sought leave to speak for, say, three minutes—gagged in this parliament, because the government does not want to hear what the alternatives are.
—Have a look at the standing orders.

—There is the ability, as we all know, to seek to make short statements by leave. In reality, this is what has happened: the government has gagged the debate because it does not want to hear about the alternatives. We know that the Sun Fund Bill 1997 is put in the list for debate today right at the end of everybody else's priorities. It is important that Australia does not go to the rest of the world pretending that there are no alternatives, when we all know that there are alternatives in energy conservation efficiency. Anyone looking into the economics of those know that they are a heck of a lot cheaper—
—Are you speaking to the motion?
—I am indeed. The motion is to take note of the document.
—No, it is not.
—The motion I am speaking to relates to the government's action in trying to gag debate.
—Order! Senator Margetts, the motion before the chair is that there be suspension of standing orders to debate the report.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order—

—I will speak to the point of order first. What has happened here—and it is the reason I am speaking to the point of order—is that there has been an attempt to gag debate. I am speaking to the motion to allow this debate to take place. That is what I am speaking for. The reason why it is important, the reason why it is urgent and the reason why the government does not want to hear this today is why it is necessary to speak. On the point of order, that is what I am speaking to: the reason why we need to have at least a reasonable, not prolonged, debate on this issue.
—There is no point of order. Senator Margetts, continue with your remarks.

—Basically what I am saying is that we do have to have the opportunity. It is urgent because Australia is now, as we speak, in the negotiating stage. Remember that, when questions were asked in Senate estimates about who was even going on Australia's behalf, we could not even find out. It was a secret. A secret delegation has gone to Kyoto to speak to an urgent issue that the rest of the world is talking about. We were not given the list of who was going in advance—and I have not even received it yet—and we have a situation where the government does not want to debate any of those issues in parliament when—
—The minister accepts our report. The minister accepts our recommendations. What's wrong with you?

—Then it would be very nice to be able to respond to that. If the minister accepts the recommendations, it is reasonable for that message to go to those delegates in Kyoto as we speak. But is it? That is the question of urgency. Is that message going to Kyoto? Is that message of the willingness of the Australian community to actually spend the money now to be able to save the money and the greenhouse emissions and the environment in the future going to Kyoto? I very much doubt it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not going to speak for five minutes. I am just disgusted that this is the situation we have in this chamber, where we have a debate on such an important issue and a response from the government gagging debate on such an important issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the need to protect Australian citizens against discrimination and vilification on the grounds of their sexuality or transgender identity, as dealt with by the Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995 [1996], together with submissions and the Hansard record of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Legal and Constitutional References Committee Inquiry into Sexuality Discrimination

SPEECH.PARA: (Report on the Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995)
I am pleased to table the report on this inquiry.

Senators will remember that it was former Senator Sid Spindler who introduced the Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995 into the Senate. The objective of the bill was to ensure that the rights which were available to other Australians were available to gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people.

The bill was referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee in 1996 and the Committee held hearings in all Capital cities and in Canberra between August and October 1996. The Committee was impressed with the quality of the submissions received and the evidence given, and wishes to thank all those people and organisations who contributed.

I appreciate that there has been some concerns about the time taken to report on the reference, and some belief that there was no interest in completing the report or presenting it in a timely fashion. This was not the case—the program of work dealt with by both the Legislation and References Committees has been intensive, both last year and this year. In particular, the inquiry into Euthanasia in January/February this year used substantial resources.

I, on behalf of the Committee, want to place on record our thanks to the Legal and Constitutional Secretariat for their work in arranging witnesses and developing the hearings program; and in drafting the report and in meeting the objective of reporting in this session:
Neil Bessell and Catherine Hawkins deserve special mention for their work in developing a high quality hearings program which resulted in the provision of extensive and very thorough evidence;

Pauline Moore came late to the Inquiry and did a super-human job in analysing the submissions and evidence for the draft report. It was a magnificent effort and a debt of gratitude is owed to Pauline.
Numerous staff in the Committee Office, especially Diane Koepke, Jenny Hill, Jade Ricza and Rachel Kelly who helped with typing and setting up the report.

I would like to acknowledge the contribution by the Deputy Chair of the References Committee, Senator Abetz, during the Committee's inquiry and especially during the hearings program. The issues the Committee was dealing with were ones which aroused considerable emotion and many witnesses expressed their emotions openly. I consider that Committee members demonstrated high quality skills in their effective management of issues and in their commitment to obtaining useful and comprehensive information to illuminate the issues. I thank Senator Abetz in particular for his support and assistance to me and also for his work and his contribution to discussions and questions.

The rights which Senator Spindler was concerned about in developing and introducing this bill, were not special rights. Nonetheless, the Committee heard from some witnesses that homosexual people wanted a range of-special rights and protection.

There was also concern that the proposed vilification sections in the bill would limit free speech; and that religious bodies and organisations would have their principles ignored. Witnesses suggested that vilification provisions were prone to abuse and would give too much power to people to attack those who made any comment about them. Others indicated that the bill would force them to employ people they did not approve of, in contravention of their religious beliefs; or that it would force religious bodies to accept homosexual or transgender members into their churches.

It became apparent during the inquiry that there are many assumptions made about homosexual and transgender people and these assumptions demonstrate how much we try to demonise or mock those who are different. Homosexual people are talked about as if they were concerned only with sex, and not as if they are people with many other roles in life. If they get beaten up, it is argued, they ask for it. It is suggested that transgender people are really only interested in being drag queens or seeking instant fame as sports stars where they have an unfair advantage over `real' women. Why, then, it is asked, should such people have any benefits or any support from society?

Some people suggested that gays and lesbians in fact were not discriminated against, had too much influence already and sought to obtain more. In some cases, while it was agreed that there should not be any verbal or physical assault of people because of their sexuality, it was thought that existing legislation was adequate to deal with any violence or discrimination that did occur.

The Committee does not believe that this is the case. Society has legislation in place which prohibits assault and incitement to hatred, but this does not appear to be sufficient, in part because there is a culture which states:
. it is acceptable to attack some people either physically or in more subtle ways.
. it is acceptable to harass and intimidate in the street, in the school, and in the workplace.
. it is acceptable to exclude people from access to a range of goods and services, or to provide these at a lower level.
. it is not illegal to exclude people from some types of employment or accommodation on the basis of sexuality or gender status.
. in some jurisdictions, the way people dress or the assumption that they might be homosexual, is sufficient to exclude them from some forms of employment.

. definitions of spouse or partner generally exclude same sex couples and transgender couples, often depriving them of the right to provide for partners, a right assumed by heterosexual couples whether legally married or de facto.

That is the form of protection the law offers to homosexual and transgender people. Many witnesses agreed that this was the situation that such people experienced, but they did not think that it required much in the way of legal change. Attitudes change gradually, and, it seems, those who choose to be outside the mainstream can wait until the mainstream is ready to tolerate them.

The Committee does not agree with this approach. It is not concerned with the issues of whether people choose to be homosexual or transgender, or whether people's sexuality or gender identity is determined by factors over which they have little control.

The Committee worked from the premise that there were homosexual people, and transgender people, and that they had rights which weren't acknowledged and responsibilities that they were sometimes prevented from meeting. In such a situation, legislation is often the best way of overcoming discrimination which is so institutionalised that many people are unaware of it and of the limits which it places on the participation of people in everyday life.

The Committee believes that legislation is a means of educating people, and that this education occurs in at least two ways: the existence of the law makes people aware of issues and of the effects these have on others. At the same time legislation helps the disadvantaged to take action, and discourages all forms of abuse by imposing penalties.

Australian society was sufficiently concerned about the status of women, people with disabilities and people of a range of ethnic backgrounds to implement anti-discrimination laws prohibiting different forms of discrimination. The fact that this legislation is still in force does not mean that it is ineffective—in fact, as was stated by anti-discrimination

organisations themselves to the Committee, one of the most important if often unrecognised roles of anti-discrimination legislation is that it can help solve problems before irreconcilable differences occur.

Another argument against Commonwealth legislation was that it would only duplicate existing State and Territory legislation. The Committee was mindful of the need to avoid duplication, especially given the argument that the relevant international covenants did not explicitly talk about sexuality and gender identity. Nonetheless, while there is much that is of benefit in State and Territory anti-discrimination legislation, the fact remains that Sin some states legislation is limited in effect. Further, it cannot address issues which are under Commonwealth control; and, while a number of day to day concerns are matters for States to resolve, it is important for the Commonwealth to demonstrate that it is opposed to systemic discrimination.
The report supports the progression of the Sexuality Discrimination Bill with various amendments. These include:
Changing the title of the bill to acknowledge that it also covers transgender issues;

The report does not make any recommendations about the activities of religious bodies in the operation of their religious activities, and supports the premise of the bill that religious susceptibilities of people be acknowledged. The Committee accepts that religions will determine those who serve them as ministers or priests, and will determine who will or will not be a member of a church.

The report does recommend, however, that where a religious body accepts Commonwealth funding to provide a service, it may not discriminate against people on the basis of their sexuality or their gender status.

The report makes no recommendations about sport—The evidence did not demonstrate that there was much interest in competitive sport by transgender persons and the Committee considers this issue can be dealt with by the relevant sporting organisations on a case by case basis.

The report recommends that couples or partners should be acknowledged regardless of sexuality or gender status. It is believed that such acknowledgment will facilitate access to benefits available to other couples, particularly superannuation and similar benefits.

The report has maintained the bill's proposed vilification provisions, and has also added recommendations prohibiting harassment on the grounds of sexuality or gender status. In supporting the proposal that there be specific vilification provisions the Committee is not inhibiting free speech but believes it is supporting the responsible use of free speech. It has also recommended that the vilification provisions be reviewed, allowing further comment on their effectiveness in limiting physical and verbal violence.

The Committee believes that it is important for society to limit discrimination by limiting segregation of service provisions, and by making all members of a community aware that they have responsibilities and rights. There is provision in the legislation for special measures, and the report endorses this. However, the report has also emphasised that publicly funded services must where possible be available to all. The objective of this is not only cost effectiveness but better communication.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have my remarks on this report incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

BREAK.PARA: The Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995 was an initiative of the Australian Democrats.
When he introduced the bill into the Senate just over two years ago, our then Senator for Victoria, Sid Spindler, set out the reasons for the development of the bill. These included:
. that people receive equal treatment in areas governed by Commonwealth law and are protected against discrimination on the grounds of their sexuality or their transgender identity,
. that no special rights are developed for people of transgender status or non-heterosexuals but that they have rights equal to those available to others;
. that there be protection for people who are going through a gender re-assignment process `or identifying as transsexuals'.

Senator Spindler emphasised fiat the bill did seek to give to the non‐heterosexual community rights more extensive than those available to others. It sought only to ensure that people had equal access to rights, and that they were not discriminated against in a number of areas—areas which included superannuation and insurance, employment, education, industrial relations and the provision of goods and services.

The bill has had a rather tortuous passage to this point, but the Democrats have always been willing to have the bill subject to public scrutiny and debate because we believe it to be a fair, just and sensible piece of legislation. We believe that—when the hysteria and prejudice which often accompanies these issues is separated from the detail of the bill—we have put forward a proposal which gives effect to a very simple and fair proposition: that Australians should not be discriminated against on the basis of their sexuality.
The majority report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee confirms that view.

It reflects evidence presented to the Committee indicating that many of the rights and freedoms that are considered an integral part of Australian society are not readily available to non-heterosexuals or to transgender persons.

The Committee has canvassed the issues and a range of views and the Democrats accept the Committee's recommendations. The majority of the Committee is to be congratulated for having approached the bill with an open mind, with a willingness to explore the issues and with a commitment to giving equal protection from harassment and discrimination to all Australians, irrespective of their sexuality.
Let me repeat: neither the bill nor this Committee report is about giving preferred status to non-heterosexuals.

This is not about giving anyone any special or new rights. It is about giving everyone the same rights. It is a simple recognition that many people are not heterosexual. Now that may be a reality which some don't like—but their dislike or discomfort or fear is not going to change that reality.

The Committee has recognised that reality. Wisely, it has not sought to assess whether sexuality is a given factor or a matter of choice—it has simply considered the best ways of addressing an existing reality regardless of the causal factors.

The Democrats hold the very strong that what consenting adults do in private is their own business—and that business should not form the basis of discrimination. I would have thought that would be a position in line with a true small-l liberal philosophy—although, of course, it's always interesting to see some of those who like to call themselves `liberal' backing the rights of the individual when it comes to economic matters, but throw those same rights out window when it comes to matters of sexuality.
The Democrats can see no reason for discriminating against people living together in committed relationships simply because they are not married or are not heterosexual.

I am particularly pleased with the Committee's recommendation that the Commonwealth should develop a "consistent and gender neutral definition of living in a genuine domestic partnership" for use by all Commonwealth agencies and departments. I think it is well past the time that we formally acknowledged that many heterosexual couples do not want to get married—for a variety of reasons—and that many non-heterosexual couples live in long-term relationship which are every bit as committed and close as traditional marriages.

Australians who choose to live their personal lives in these ways are not second-class citizens. They have a fundamental right to make those personal and individual choices and their decisions should be respected and recognised.

With this majority report, the Senate legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee has formally recognised the need to establish important, basic principles of equality. It has acknowledged that non-heterosexual Australians are discriminated against and have lesser legal rights than heterosexual Australians. It has recognised that the Democrats' proposed bill fills a gap in our human rights and discrimination legislation—and I believe its—recommendations improve and clarify our original bill.

On behalf of the Democrats, I thank the committee for its consideration of the bill. I also thank the Committee secretariat for its work on this reference. I believe the Committee's report represents a mature and sensible approach to these issues.

The Democrats will take the Committee's recommendations on board and we will re-present the new Sexuality and Gender Status Discrimination in the new year—when I hope all parliamentarians will approach it in the same spirit of maturity and tolerance as shown by the majority of the Senate's Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the motion and to welcome this report. The legislation which was brought forward by former Democrat Senator Sid Spindler was aimed at ending discrimination in this country on the basis of sexuality for transgender people.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a major matter. We are talking about one million to two million members of the Australian community. In fact, it affects the whole of the Australian community. How we relate to each other, how we accept diversity and difference and how well we celebrate diversity and difference affects the wellbeing of the whole of the community. This report and the bill on which it was based are milestones in the move towards our becoming a more enlightened and humane society which recognises and celebrates diversity. Not the least, we are dealing with personal matters of sexuality and sexual identification.

The report is a resounding corroboration of the need for legislation nationally to ensure that citizens in this country who are not heterosexual but who identify as homosexual or bisexual or transgender are awarded no less protection under the law from discrimination than are people on any other account. There is a major gap in the law nationally and at many subnational jurisdiction levels, which needs to be addressed. This committee's report is good reading, substantial reading, for people who are concerned that discrimination is a long way from being ended in this country. I might say that there is no way of moving to end that discrimination on the base of sexuality, other than for there to be backup at legal level, at legislative level, to ensure things are put right.

The committee found, in its deliberations, a lot of discrimination. There are a lot of people—not just thousands, but hundreds of thousands of people—in this country who live lesser lives, not because of their own nature or of their own actions but because of subtle, direct or hurtful discrimination practised against them in a wide variety of ways on the basis of their sexuality—because they do not identify as heterosexual. We are a lesser society because of that.

In the strongest possible fashion, this report calls for national action to end this untenable situation and to put it to rights. One way in which this parliament can put it to rights is by following the lead set by the Democrats and former Senator Spindler in enacting national legislation to ensure that discrimination on the basis of sexuality is made illegal, however it might be practised and in whatever form—insidious or overt—it might be used against citizens in this country. Those citizens are contributors to society in every way and should be accorded the right of freedom from discrimination and the tactics of those who believe that they, in some way or other, have a right to discriminate against people on the basis of sexuality.

I point to one particular matter which shows that it is not just the occasional epithet flung at a homosexual or transgender person from a car window, or at a couple or a group, or abuse in a park or at a theatre, or in other unexpected circumstances, which has to be countermanded. With superannuation there is institutionalised discrimination which cannot be allowed to continue and which demands urgent action. It is no less than the confiscation of the funds of those people in the community outside the bounds of heterosexual marriage or de facto status. People who do not fit within those bounds are accorded totally different status as far as taxation and superannuation are concerned and so are unable to pass on to their partners, or to the person they designate, the benefits of the superannuation funds which they have accumulated through a life of contribution to our society. This is wrong. It is an outrage and it requires government action.

It is not just this report that has called this iniquitous situation to the attention of this parliament. As far back as 1995, the relevant committee looking at superannuation recommended to the Senate that legislative action be undertaken to ensure that all citizens were treated equally as far as superannuation is concerned. That includes single people, so that they could designate to whom they wanted their superannuation benefits to flow in the event of their death. Why should that not be? Why should they be treated differently from the people next door who happen to be in a de facto relationship or are married? There is no logical or fair reason for this circumstance, but every day of the week hundreds of thousands of people in this country pay their superannuation benefits knowing that they are going to be defrauded of their rights further down the line, knowing that they are not equal under the law and knowing that this parliament has failed to act on its own advice in the past to put to right this very wrong situation.

I hope the time has come when there are enough people in the Senate with a sense of justice and a fair go to put this situation to right. Sure, money is involved. Sure, those who are advantaged at the expense of the disadvantaged may want to keep that wrongful advantage, but we have now had two major inquiries canvassing opinions right throughout this nation which have said that we should put a stop to this unfair situation.

I make the appeal, on the back of this report, that the government take action to bring justice into the superannuation situation in this country. If it is all right to legislate to make superannuation mandatory, then surely it follows that there is a responsibility to make superannuation payments and benefits fair for all citizens. It is time that this jurisdiction caught up with enlightened countries elsewhere in the world in this important respect. There are many other components to this report which make it valuable reading for all citizens, not just for those who are particularly interested in these matters.

Finally, I would like to talk about the many thousands of transgendered people in our community who are very much overlooked. The committee had quite a tussle with trying to defined transgendered people and, I think, made somewhat of a mistake in trying to define them because to define means to confine. But the matter is at least addressed in this report where transgendered people are recognised as the valuable people in our society that they are. Quite clearly, the call through the report is for a fair go and an end to discrimination against this particular component of our society and citizenry through government action.

The call for government action is there. All that is required now is the commonsense, the goodwill and the sense of responsibility from the Howard government to see that, in the coming 12 months, a response is made to the wider community call in this report to put an end to the discrimination of the past. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bartlett, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate long. I would like to speak briefly to the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. It is a report on a very important issue. I am very pleased as a Democrat to see the committee reporting back on this crucial issue and progressing it further. As Senator Brown outlined, it is an initiative based around the Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995 [1996] by former Senator Sid Spindler. I pay tribute to him for the very important work that he has done in this area over many years, along with many others in the Democrats and in the broader community, to try to get greater attention on this important issue. It is an in‐depth report and it is important that it be read properly. I would like to have the time to do that myself. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this bill was first before the Senate I made the following statement:

INTERJECT.PARA: Government amendments to this bill have been circulated in the form of requests. The amendments confer a power on a minister to make determinations which may be exercised in such a way as to exempt certain superannuation assets from the operation of the assets test and thereby increase expenditure under the bill.

The Senate in the past, by express resolution, has followed the principle that an amendment which confers a power on a minister which may be exercised in such a way as to increase expenditure is not an equivalent of an amendment increasing expenditure and therefore does not require a request.
I also note that the explanatory memorandum accompanying the amendments states that their financial impact is negligible. The amendments will therefore be treated as amendments.
The bill has been returned with most of the Senate's amendments disagreed to on the basis that they should have been requests, but with amendments identical to the Senate's amendments.

Of the non‐government amendments to the bill, three—Nos 5, 6 and 8—perhaps should have been requests in so far as they expand entitlements to payments from the standing appropriation in the principal. TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to revised schedule 6: `8—use of reserved land'; schedule 1, item 9, subdivision J.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are about to embark upon a number of issues which amount, together and individually, to a really pernicious, gratuitous act of dispossession and extinguishment of title that is in no way justified by the Wik decision. The measures involve a racially discriminatory acquisition of property, with insufficient notification, no just terms and no beneficial measure to try to in some way make the measures constitutional.

SPEECH.PARA: In that respect, we talk about reserved land. We talk about the way the government is proposing its measures with respect to facilities for services to the public. We will come to the freehold test later. Renewals and extensions is another of those areas. All these areas together show what we have been saying about the government. When the government says there is no blanket extinguishment, we say in response that they are actually putting together this elaborate little quilt of extinguishment—section by section, it all comes together. We have seen some measures passed by the committee this morning with respect to process. Here we are tackling a number of government measures to take away people's rights with respect to different categories of land. In many ways, this is not one of the high profile debates about validation, extinguishment or right to negotiate, but I do not think anyone with a social conscience can accept what the government is trying to do in this particular area.

BREAK.PARA: As I say, it involves reserve land and three or four other areas that, together, try to do things which are in no way justified by the Wik decision and in no way can be justified because they dispossess people of property rights, with no just terms, no notification and so on.

Let us look, for instance, at the first part of the government's proposal with respect to reserve land. The government wants to extend reservations prior to 23 December 1996 rather than 1 January 1994. In essence, it is trying to say, `Well, for all those reservations in that period, don't worry about the operation of the Native Title Act. Just make believe it wasn't there for the last couple of years and don't worry about the need to have processes in place to ensure justice in the process.' The government says it wants to extend its amendments with respect to reservations for this period. There is absolutely no reason and no justification for this measure in Wik. It is a measure which I find totally offensive in that it is discriminatory. It takes away property rights that people could have been pursuing for that intermediate period.

The amendments also seek to allow different acts to be carried out—that is, not just the acts for which the land was reserved but different acts, so long as the impact of such acts is no greater than the reservation. In terms of certainty in law, what sort of certainty does that provide anyone? It is vague and it is not in accordance with the common law.

Amongst the examples the bill gives is that, if land was reserved for a hospital any time before 23 December 1996, it can be used as a school in the future. Does that presume that the school is not going to be bigger than the hospital? Does it presume any other aspects of impact on surrounding areas, on native title claimants or potential claimants who live around that particular part? It is a vague test, but it is one that, in its vagueness, is intended to have an ambit operation. Another example in the bill is: if there is a reservation for a national park, this would allow the creation of a national park management plan.

We say, with respect to all these: why shouldn't indigenous Australians who may have an interest in the area be part of the process? Why shouldn't they have, in some instances, a full right and, in some other instances, a capacity to really put forward and to have taken into account in a meaningful way their concerns and their rights?

There is no reason for allowing these things. For instance, there is nothing which limits the land from being used as a government facility. The concern also is that it does not just stop there. In the event of the land being provided for the benefit of a third party, then this provision allows a change of the interest and a change of those who could pursue that interest. If the land were to be provided for the benefit of the third party, this could take place without the rights that ordinary Australians would be entitled to. It would happen without compulsory acquisition and it would happen at the expense of a native title holder's possible right to negotiate. This is clearly discriminatory and anyone with a social conscience would come to two conclusions: it is not justified in its discrimination, and it cannot be justified as emanating from the Wik decision.

There was also always substantial argument that reservations and proclamations themselves did not extinguish or affect native title. So native title rights should be able to be continued in full. But they will not in this case.

The provision has a third problem. It also allows acts to be carried out under grants of leases to statutory authorities prior to, once again, 23 December 1996 if the state authority or any person uses it for the purpose of the earlier grant. So you can basically transfer the right to a statutory authority or any other person. If all this does not amount to a land grab without a legitimate factoring in of native title interests, a land grab for which Australian taxpayers will have to pay, a land grab which is in no way justified by Wik and a land grab for which the government has not put up any sustainable case at all to maintain that this should happen, and if the public knew that what they will be asked to do is pay compensation because the Commonwealth has decided that some person may inherit a right or that right may be extended and that Aboriginal Australians were excluded from a fair process, I reckon that they would bucket it.

The provision also states that where the new act is a public work, this extinguishes native title permanently. There are real problems with that. The permanency aspect is a real problem. It takes away future property rights, and it is in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act. The government has gone around the country saying, `We're not extinguishing native title. There is no blanket extinguishment.' The Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer, was right, and this is one of those bucket loads of extinguishment which, in all sense of morality, constitutionality and justice to all involved, including indigenous Australians and taxpayers, you cannot justify. The committee cannot justify passing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Subdivision J, which is what we are talking about at the moment, is intended to implement part of point seven of the government's 10-point plan. As Senator Bolkus has indicated, it intends to present another one of these buckets. Future actions for the management of any existing national park or forest reserve would be allowed. This is misleading, as governments already have sufficient power under the current Native Title Act to manage these areas should negotiations with native titleholders not result in agreement. The subdivision would prematurely stifle any meaningful negotiations about indigenous concerns and the possibilities of joint management of these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: As drafted, subdivision J goes well beyond national parks and forest reserves to apply to any land reserved for a particular purpose before 23 December 1996. As Senator Bolkus says, it is a massive land grab. Where an act is done in accordance with an existing reservation—that is in proposed subparagraph 24JA(1)(e)(i)—and the reservation predates 1 January 1994, the act will be valid. There is no justification for extending this regime to acts not done in accordance with the reservation, especially as the likely effect is extinguishment. If the reservation was done in the intermediate period, there is no reason to validate it.

BREAK.PARA: Governments have full power to compulsorily acquire native title and ordinary title if land is needed for public purposes in the future. This subdivision permits gratuitous extinguishment. Leases to statutory authorities are in no different position from those noted. Such a lease has a similar effect with respect to native title as a reservation. This is the same absence of justification.
I would also like to read from an opinion that has been provided from the Australian Conservation Foundation:

It is clear from Mabo [No. 2] that, before the RDA, the reservation of land alone is not an act which is capable of extinguishing native title. Rather, the subsequent use of reserved land may extinguish native title if the use is inconsistent with the continued existence of native title. It is possible that the reservation of land may have been inconsistent with native title to some extent. Where land is reserved for a public purpose, the reservation may create a public right to use the land . . .
That was from Randwick Corporation v Rutledge. It continues:
However, not all reservations of land were intended for public use. Also, the Wik Case raises the potential re‐emergence of native title rights after the removal of a reservation.

The use of reserves has rarely been scrutinised, there being little opportunity for public challenge for reasons of standing and public administration. However, the uses of reserves is circumscribed by the purpose of the reservation and the legislation under which the reservation is made . . .
That is from Woollahra MC v Minister for the Environment. It continues:
Many uses of reserves in the past may be invalid if they do not conform to this standard (eg. leasing parts of national parks).

After the RDA, surviving native title rights in reserves were protected. Dealings in reserves where native title survived may have been consequently invalid. The NTA validated any dealings in reserved land that may have been invalid. However, dealings otherwise must conform with the future act test. Consequently, while the use of reserves that were dedicated between 31 October 1975 and 1 January 1994 may continue after that time in accordance with the reserve purpose (NTA s.228(9)), the use of reserves that were dedicated before the commencement of the RDA must observe the future act test. Given the sparsity of native title determinations, this mean that the low impact future act test (NTA s.234) has significant implications for the use of reserves. To achieve any management objectives that don't comply with the low impact future act test (eg. the construction of a ranger station in a national park), land managements must negotiate with native title holders. Native title holders are thus given a substantial role in the management of reserves.

It does go on, but I think the issues here are about whether or not existing rights are being taken away. Quite clearly from that opinion—and I am sure a number of others—this is exactly what we are going to see. This is one area where there was, I believe, some negotiation and some assistance from the National Indigenous Working Group, and I am pleased to see there was alteration of the original position taken by the Australian Labor Party. This is an important issue. It is not a small issue. It is another way which state governments can use to simply remove existing rights of indigenous Australians. In that sense, it is in no way acceptable to the Greens (WA).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a remarkable burst of moral outrage on a provision which is very similar in policy intent to provisions in the existing Native Title Act, certainly to the policy intent in subsection 228(9) in respect of reservations and what can be done in future on reservations. We are dealing with land that, in effect, has been alienated in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are proposing here I would have thought was innocuous. What we are talking about is the validity of future acts if the following conditions are met: there must be a valid act that took place on or before 23 December 1996 and that can include validated past acts and the earlier act. The reservation must have been done by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, state or territory or consisted of the making, amendment or repeal of legislation. The earlier act must have contained, made or conferred a reservation to use particular land or waters for a particular purpose. The later act must be a bona fide act done under or in accordance with the reservation or in the area covered by the reservation but only if its impact on native title is no greater than would have been the case for an act done under or in accordance with the reservation.

There was a very strict criterion set down for this provision and for the validity of acts done under it. As I say, it is consistent with the policy intent of subsection 228(9). We are surprised by the vehemence with which this is opposed. We are talking about land which has, in effect, had government action take place in relation to land management. The land is not vacant crown land; it has been reserved for a purpose by properly constituted, democratically elected governments exercising their sovereign power in the past to reserve land for future use. We think seeking to prevent this happening will only cause considerable alienation and difficulty in communities right around Australia and be quite inappropriate.

The argument coming from the ALP and others for the complete removal of it is to suggest that the power exists if necessary but that can be done only by compulsory acquisition. If you wish to use the reserve for the purpose for which it was set aside then the only way you can do it, if this section is removed, is by compulsory acquisition which extinguishes native title altogether. Ours is a much more flexible approach. The non‐extinguishment principle applies except for the construction of a public work, which is already provided for in the Native Title Act.

National parks are a classic example for which national park managers have to make management plans or construct walkways or safety fences for the public and all the other things that are required for managing of parks or reserves of that kind. All you are left with is a compulsory acquisition process if this subdivision is deleted all together.

You get this quite ridiculous situation arising if this subdivision is deleted altogether. If subsection 228(9) of the current act applies, that is, the act has been validated—that is the reservation—then the act can be performed in accordance with the reservation but not if it was always valid. So you get this nonsense distinction between reserves validated by the Native Title Act and those which were always valid. It has been put to me that you will have states and territories arguing that the reservation was made after the Racial Discrimination Act came into effect and therefore is prima facie invalid and therefore validated by the Native Title Act and therefore, under the Native Title Act, can be exercised. Whereas, if that was not the case and it was a valid reservation, you cannot do it.

It is a complete nonsense and we do not think it is acceptable. We are talking about land reserved essentially for national parks, hospitals, schools, et cetera—always reserved by sovereign governments exercising their sovereign powers where they had made that alienation. They wish to give effect to the purpose for which the land was reserved or to a similar purpose where there is no greater impact on native title. We believe that should be allowed under the very strict regime which applies in subdivision J. The non-extinguishment principle applies, as I say, except in relation to public works. There is full right to compensation, et cetera. We propose an amendment to our provision. I move:
(26) Schedule 1, item 9, page 60 (after line 29), at the end of section 24JB, add:

PARA.TAB: (6) If the act consists of the construction or establishment of a public work, then, before the act is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

TAB.TAB: (a) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters covered by the reservation or lease that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done in relation to the land or waters; and
(b) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment is to proposed section 24JB which provides that future acts done in good faith pursuant to certain kinds of reservations and leases will be valid. The amendment inserts a new subsection 6 which requires the person proposing to construct a public work to notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth minister, the persons mentioned in paragraph 6(a) that the act or acts of that class are to be done and to give those persons an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts and that notification must occur before the future act is done. The amendment is to ensure that native title holders are informed beforehand if the public work is to be constructed pursuant to the reservation or lease to which this subdivision applies. Therefore, we are ensuring appropriate notification procedures and, again, full compensation for any impact on native title. These are all in respect of reserves. They are consistent with the policy set down in the current Native Title Act. Therefore, we seek the Senate's support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg to differ with the minister. I will read a little more from the advice provided by the Australian Conservation Foundation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments to the NTA significantly detract from the rights and negotiating position of native title holders in reserves, particularly national parks.
The things the minister was saying prove exactly that. It continues:

In effect, it will be as if the RDA did not apply to reserves. The proposed amendments will allow reserve land to be used for the reserve purpose if the land was reserved before 23 December 1996 . . . This is inconsistent with the operation of the RDA. Also, it ignores the distinction between reservation and subsequent extinguishment made in Mabo [No. 2]. Any reservation of an appropriate date will mean that land managers will be authorised to use land for that purpose despite the existence of native title rights. Extinguishment will be authorised in the case of public works . . .
the minister has mentioned that—

The proposed provision does require the previous reservation to be in place when the subsequent act is done . . . However, allow land to be used for non‐reserve purposes where it would cause `no greater impact' that a use consistent with the reserve purpose. This provision is unworkable and provides no criteria for measuring impact . . . eg. does it include impact upon cultural and spiritual values of native title holders, . . .
There is a reference to Ward.

It is also inconsistent with the law concerning the use of reserves (ie. it purports authorise the use of a reserve for a purpose that is otherwise illegal such as allowing the construction of a commercial facility in a national park, illegal under Woollahra MC , because it would cause no greater impact than the construction of a ranger station—this is the Commonwealth using its race power to undermine the land management systems of States and Territories merely because particular acts affect native title).

The amendments have dramatic consequence for the management of reserve lands. No longer will land managers be required to consider the low impact future act test when undertaking management activities. The characterisation of land use purposes that are related to a reservation will determine the extent to which land managers may disregard subsisting native title rights in reserves established before 23 December 1996. It is telling that, in Woollahra MC supra ., Kirby P described the establishment of a ski resort in a national park as consistent with the dedication of a national park. It remains to be seen if State and Territory provisions which protect native title rights in reserves will continue or will be altered by hostile legislatures.

It is quite clear that we have a number of states and territories that are set to make changes because they think they will benefit from the changes occurring. We know that Queensland is right there ready to make changes that will impact even more on the rights of indigenous people. Quite clearly, any change in this provision will be capitalised on by those states that have no care for either native title rights or the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be interested in Senator Minchin's response to Senator Margetts. I do not have that type of problem, but I do have a problem with this amendment. If you are looking at acts undertaken after Wik and the reservation that was actually placed before Wik, that is one thing, but this bill seems to go a bit further than that in the provisions of 24JA(1)(e)(ii), where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the area covered by the reservation, so long as the act's impact on native title is no greater than the impact that any act that could have been done under or in accordance with the reservation would have had.
There is an example given in the bill where subparagraph (e)(ii) might apply. It states:
. . . subparagraph (e)(ii) might apply if particular land was reserved as a hospital site before 23 December 1996, and instead a school is later built on the land.

That is not an act which is pursuant to the reservation that was in place before Wik. What if land was reserved for a hospital and it was then given by the health department to the education and recreation department of that particular state and a dodgem car track was built instead of a hospital? I suppose you could say, although I do not quite follow this, that that falls into the aspect of the impact being greater. I would like to have that explained to me. I am wondering why the government is pursuing subparagraph (e)(ii) and whether there is an adequate explanation for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the minister, I point out that I have been advised that Parliament House is experiencing some power difficulties as a result of a bushfire in the vicinity of Duntroon. If half of the lights go out at some time it is because of the bushfire and nothing else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mabo was all about separating the acquisition of sovereignty from the exercise of sovereignty. As is indicated in the current Native Title Act, the act of reserving land by a sovereign government is an exercise of the sovereignty and, therefore, takes it within that realm of acts that can take place.

SPEECH.PARA: So, if a state government exercises its sovereignty to reserve land for a hospital, why should the Commonwealth parliament say to the state government, `That's all very well, but you can't use it for a school.' In terms of the provision of facilities of that kind, it just seems something of a nonsense to say to a democratically elected government, which has taken the decision, the sovereign act, to reserve the land accordingly in the past, that they cannot use it for an equivalent purpose against the test that there must be no greater impact on native title. That seems to us an unreasonable intervention in the sovereign right of governments to manage land over which they have exercised their sovereignty for proper purposes.

Obviously, if it is reserved for a national park, it would not meet this test, in the sense that you would not be able to put a school or something else on it. It has to be used for a purpose that can have no greater impact and, if there was any attempt to do so, it would be invalid under this Native Title Act.

We were responding to the reasonable propositions, we thought, put to us by state governments about their use of land that they have reserved for particular purposes. It seems to us that the reasonable test is that there can be no greater impact on native title. If it is a hospital or a school, there is not a lot of difference, and that ought to be allowed. But you could not put a school in where it had been reserved for a national park.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of things that come out of that debate. It is okay for Senator Minchin to focus on governments, but what about individuals? We are concerned about the individual property rights of native title claimants. They are not factored into the equation at all. That is our concern here. If a reservation was made some time ago, we believe that the reservation that was made is the one that should continue to operate. If there is any change to that, any change to the parties to it, it needs to go back to the drawing board.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a couple of things that the government should appreciate about this. Senator Minchin says that this is not much different from what happened in the 1993 legislation. It is substantially different from what happened in the 1993 legislation in that that legislation accepted that there was a trade-off. That trade-off was that indigenous Australians made concessions. Maybe the minister is just discovering the fact that indigenous Australians made concessions.

One of the concessions they made was with respect to reservations, reserve lands. They made that concession, but they got something back in return. The overall package at the time, including the indigenous land fund and so on, was beneficial. Unless you have an overall beneficial package here, you are going to have real problems constitutionally. This is one of the reasons why, for instance, the RDA provisions should apply to this range of activities as well as to others.

BREAK.PARA: You are acting in a way which takes away property rights of the Aboriginal race without compensation, without real notification. You are doing it in a number of ways. It may have been approved as a school some 25 years ago, but they might want to do something totally different with it now. For instance, if the property was yours, Senator Minchin, and the government wanted to do something with it, it would not just be a matter of the federal government and the state government getting together and saying, `If you want to do something else with it, go ahead.' They would consult you and they would have to go through the Lands Acquisition Act processes. You have rights here. Fortunately for you, you are not a black Australian. Fortunately for you, you are not going to be subjected to this legislation.

There are important discrimination aspects to this. For instance, you raised earlier the difference between a reservation that was made before the RDA and one made after the RDA. One thing is different—that is, the RDA came into effect in 1975.
