If a government has not effected the purpose for which that reservation was made in 22 years, it is a bit rich to be saying 22 years later, `We might decide to do something with it now. We might decide to sell it to Joe Bloggs who wants to build a theatre there, or whatever he wants to build there.' It is all third party, so long as the impact is not different. These criteria are not sufficient to satisfy the tests of just compensation.

It is also worth noting in this part of the debate what Justice Brennan said in Mabo. He said that the crown act of making a reserve will not significantly impact upon native title until the reserve is put to its intended purpose. Therefore, when there has been a reservation and, say, 20 years later the reservation has been put to its intended purpose, it may be property characterised as being akin to vacant crown land for native title purposes. So, in these circumstances, any adverse treatment of native title in such an area by the bill will have a significant impact on the native title claimants concerned. As I said, you might be concerned about government to government but, under the constitution, individuals have property rights and rights for just terms compensation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, any impact on native title will be properly compensated. Full compensation provisions are provided for in this subdivision. I repeat: the problem we have with what is being proposed is that there is still this big distinction between validated land and valid land. Where it has been validated by the Native Title Act, the reserve can be implemented but, where it is valid, it cannot. It is a legal nonsense. Working through whether the land is validated or a valid reserve, and whether in fact you can act under the Native Title Act or not, seems to us an absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: We think we have built in enormous protections and restrictions on the way in which this subdivision can be used, with full compensation for any impact on native title, remembering we are talking about land where governments acting on behalf of the people of their states have reserved land for particular purposes. In the circumstances where the reserve happened in the past—we are not talking about future reserves—it is appropriate to allow those reserves to be implemented, but only in accordance with the conditions set down in subdivision J.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that schedule 1, item 9, subdivision J, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to point out that part of what we are being asked to decide here is whether coexistence can exist in areas other than pastoral leases. I would say, `Why not?' Why is coexistence not possible on reserved land, especially when there are no problems about doing so?

SPEECH.PARA: There is a big monster being developed that coexistence is a problem. I do not see why it should be, especially if it simply means that people have a right to negotiate, be consulted and be part of the decision making process about what happens to those kinds of lands. There is no reason why coexistence should not be something that the rest of the community are able to accept and practise as a normal way of operating in our society in 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the committee that we are talking about the non-extinguishment principle here except in relation to public works. If the test applied in the current Native Title Act, public works would be extinguished. But wherever it is not a public work, then the non-extinguishment principle operates.

SPEECH.PARA: So, if it were a national park, it would be on the basis of the non-extinguishment principle. Native title claims can be made. Native title can be found to exist, but, in accordance with Wik, any statutory rights would prevail over any surviving native title rights. Otherwise, you do force state governments that wish to act on behalf of their people to compulsorily acquire to allow these things to occur, which does result in complete extinguishment. We think this is a preferable clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the point I was wanting to get clear. If the committee does not approve of 24JA, then we are left with the situation described by the minister—the state authorities simply make compulsory acquisitions.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I come back again to 24JA(1)(e) (ii). What does (ii) mean if there were a specific purpose reservation made prior to Wik and subsequent to Wik there were an action undertaken which built a facility which was not the specific purpose determined prior to Wik? The example I gave was of the health department handing over land to the education department and recreation department and, instead of building a hospital, they build a dodgem track, which I would have thought would make an impact on the particular area and may not be as desirable to the native title holders as a hospital, for example.

BREAK.PARA: Is (e)(ii) saying that, if there were a greater impact, then that could not occur. Is that what it is saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the test is that there must be no greater impact on native title. If there were, it would be invalid under the act. So that is the test.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the land has been reserved for a purpose. If there is an equivalent exercise of the reservation—that is, that something is done that has no greater impact on native title—it would be valid. But if it did, it would be invalid and therefore not able to be done under the act or challengeable at law if there were any attempt to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you measure the impact?

—As with all citizens of Australia, people would have the right to seek an injunction to prevent the act occurring on the grounds that it had a greater impact on native title than the purpose for which the land was reserved. They would need to establish that that were the case. That is the normal legal recourse available to all citizens whenever they believe there is a breach of the law. What we are talking about here would be a breach of the law if there were a greater impact, and you would need to establish that.

—We have not got an answer as to how one would measure impact—whether it is as to area or whatever other impact we are looking at here. I think it is also worth putting on the record that, if this particular provision were not here, when the state government wanted to acquire it would have to do so in accordance with non-race discrimination principles as embodied by the Racial Discrimination Act. They would also have to do so pursuant to land acquisition processes. Indigenous Australians would have a role in that as well. So I do not think it is fair, clear or comprehensive enough to say that, if this were not here, then there would be no protection for indigenous Australians. In fact, there would be a lot more than is provided under this particular provision.

BREAK.PARA: Minister, in 1993 when this regime was first adopted it was recognised that there were some aspects of it that needed to be compensated to ensure that the legislation was overall beneficial to indigenous Australians. What benefits do you claim would be taken into account by any court in assessing whether your bill or this part of it could amount to a special measure under the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are now diverting to the old constitutional question where you are arguing that beneficial effect is required for the whole bill to meet the Native Title Act. All I can do is refer you to our publicly released legal advice on that score. We have maintained that the Native Title Act as amended will continue to be an act of benefit to Aboriginal people. I can spend the next 20 minutes running through that again, but it is all there in our legal advice and in the answers we have given to these questions over and over again as to the considerable benefits involved in the whole bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind you that this bill preserves the Native Title Act's prohibition on extinguishment in future, except by way of agreement or compulsory acquisition. It also preserves the whole agreements provisions and the whole provisions relating to representative bodies with the considerable benefit they give to native title holders. We can debate it every time this question comes up but we believe the bill as a whole is of benefit to Aboriginal people. The act as amended is of benefit to Aboriginal people because it protects native title from its general defeasibility at common law. We are pleased to present the bill in that light. It is one of benefit to Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I raise this particular point in this particular instance is that we are talking here of impinging on native title property rights in a racist manner. As a consequence, it is important to ensure that people realise that this is exactly what is happening here. We also want to get an understanding as to what you think will be the important consideration when this matter goes to court and is judged by the courts as to whether it is constitutional or whether it is discriminatory under the act. It is important to put that on the record.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also say that, when you talk about the benefits in the legislation, you talk about the embroidery; you do not talk about anything substantial for indigenous Australians. When indigenous Australians speak as one voice in this debate, they say that there is nothing in the legislation for them. That also needs to be recognised. But I do not want to stray too far from the debate other than to stress the point that this particular provision, as with a couple of others coming up soon, has some real problems in terms of constitutionality.

You pick up one line out of the Solicitor-General's advice like `any port in the storm'. The real advice from the Solicitor-General was that he had no idea as to what the outcome would be. I think that probably reflects the best advice available to government, whereas the best advice available outside of government is that you have some real problems with this. You are really proceeding with your head in the sand. I do not think that is the way that legislation should be proceeded through parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an outrageous slur on the Solicitor-General and a complete misrepresentation of his statements. You know perfectly well that, in his advice, he has made it quite clear to the government that he believes this legislation is constitutional. And that advice is backed up by David Jackson QC and Stephen Gageler. That advice is quite clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The misrepresentation of what Dr Griffith said to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund—in relation to the fact that, of course, at the end of the day it is a matter for the High Court—is just a statement of the obvious. He was asked for his professional opinion. You know he is one of the best constitutional lawyers in the country because you appointed him. He acted for you in relation to the Native Title Act case where the act was found to be constitutional. He has made it perfectly clear that, as far as he is concerned, there is nothing in the bill which would so alter the fabric and structure of the Native Title Act as to change the nature of the act for the purposes of any High Court examination of it vis-a-vis the Western Australian case where the act was challenged. So, please, let us not continue that furphy.

TALK.START.PARA: —A lot of us were there at that hearing. He spoke for 40 minutes trying not to speak to the subject and at the last minute said, `If you want my opinion, it's constitutional, but my opinion is not worth much.' That was what he said. If this section of the bill is wiped out, yes, it might be the situation where state governments decide to compulsorily acquire but they would obviously need to pay a compensation regime to do that—and that is the current situation—but it might well be that all they have to do is negotiate with indigenous native title holders in the management of reserves. What is wrong with that? I do not think there is any problem with that. If this section is opposed, then the world as we know it will not end.
—The question is that schedule 1, item 9, subdivision J, as amended, be agreed to.

—Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts, I understand that your amendments 19 and 17 respectively were consequential on the passage of your earlier amendments on this running sheet, so they are now superfluous.
—That's right.
—Sadly.
—We move to running sheet revised No. 7 and opposition amendments Nos 93 and 94.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of the discussion and argument we have had in respect of the previous item is relevant to this item on facilities for services to the public as well. The government amendments provide for validation of future acts that provide services to the general public, such as transport facilities, electricity supply and so on. These future acts the government intends to validate unless they prevent native title holders from gaining physical access to affected areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The form of validation proposed by the government will mean that such future acts do not need to pass through the non-discrimination threshold test. Basically, the bill will enable a raft of future acts to evade the non-discrimination freehold test and to do so without, for instance, having to pay heed to even matters as important as heritage protection. As a result, the government's provisions will, once again, acquire property rights of native title holders in a racially discriminatory manner and in a way which fails to provide heritage protection.

We have some pretty fundamental concerns with this item. We are totally frustrated that we cannot seem to get this message through to a majority of the chamber. We are talking here of a racially discriminatory appropriation of property. At the end of the day, there may be a provision in the legislation to provide just terms in terms of value, but there is absolutely no attempt by the government to meet the test required in respect of meeting the just terms provision in the constitution. As expressed by Justice Deane in the Tasmanian dams case, the compensation needs to be something in relation to which the property holder has to have some awareness of the process and the compensation must be somewhat more contemporaneous than is provided in these circumstances by this legislation. Compensation paid five or 10 years after the event is not just terms compensation.

So we have a raft of amendments again. They are designed to restrict the scope of the subdivision so that it only applies to existing facilities. We need to pursue amendments to improve heritage protection measures and also to implement and clarify adequate procedural rights. What we are about is minimising the impact on native title rights already impaired while ensuring protection of heritage, natural justice and just terms compensation.

We are concerned about the government's proposal, and we are concerned that the notification provisions and the right to negotiate are not adequately protected here. Under our proposal any extinguishment will not be permanent, as opposed to the government's proposal which does provide for permanent extinguishment. There are some pretty heavy fundamental flaws in the government's proposal. It is a proposal that is in no way justified by Wik. The government has not attempted to justify why it is going so far in this particular area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to delay the Senate. The Democrats-Greens amendments fulfil the same purpose as the ALP amendments, with some refinements. It is quite clear that it really will not matter. That is a disaster as far as I am concerned. So we will certainly be voting for those amendments, and we will see what the rest of the Senate does. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (85) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (line 7), omit "construction", substitute "reconstruction".
(86) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (line 11), omit "construction", substitute "reconstruction".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will remind the Senate of what is really being proposed here. It is, in our assessment of the operation of the Native Title Act, an important provision. It is about ensuring that services to the general public can be provided, particularly in remote communities and in remote Aboriginal communities. We are putting very significant constraints on the way in which this can be used.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect on native title must be minimal. There must be legislation in existence in the relevant jurisdiction providing for the protection of significant indigenous sites from the effects of the activities. The non-extinguishment principle applies. Compensation is payable by the relevant government and native title holders shall have the same procedural rights as other comparable interest holders in relation to the act.

We are talking about, effectively, the provision of basic public services where they pass the test of having minimal impact on native title. The conditions are set out in 24KA. It must be an act that permits or requires the construction, operation, use, maintenance or repair of the listed facilities. They are things like roads, jetties, navigation markers, electricity transmission, lighting, gas transmission and things like that. The activities, construction, operation, use, maintenance or repair of a list of facilities are to be for the general public. The act must not prevent native title holders in relation to the land or waters where the listed facility is, or is to be situated, from having reasonable access to such land or waters in the vicinity of this facility. There must be a Commonwealth, state or territory law that makes provision for the preservation and protection of areas or sites of particular significance to Aboriginal people. As I say, the non-extinguishment principle applies. Native title holders must have the same procedural rights as other title holders.

We really do think that some of the exaggerated condemnation of these provisions is unwarranted. It is a very tightly constructed provision which significantly limits the extent to which it can be used but, where these sorts of essential community and public services are proposed, they ought to be able to be done—but only in accordance with the quite strict requirements which we put in place. Therefore, we do believe it should be accepted as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The words sound almost reasonable, until you look at what they mean. I will speak briefly to the Greens‐Democrats amendments Nos 85, 86 and 87, although 87 is mentioned separately.

SPEECH.PARA: What they do is confine the scope of the provisions to the operation, use and maintenance and repair of existing facilities. I do not think it is unreasonable for indigenous communities to be concerned about what is going on currently in relation to states and territories stacking up various sorts of crown to crown grants and also compulsory acquisitions of land and so on for services that are not government services. I would just like clarification. Minister, we are not just talking about government services; we are talking about private developers and so on, aren't we, as long as they can guarantee or state that they are providing some sort of service to the public?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a requirement that they be done for the general public. Obviously, all governments around the world are having public services constructed by private operators, but the facility must be for the general public or it will not be allowed under these provisions.
—So a private railway line in Geraldton, for instance, to be used by a port which is privately constructed for private profit, might be considered under the same section?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If it were a private railway line for moving coal or something like that, it would not even fit into these provisions. It must be for the general public. If it were a railway line for the general public, a general public transport facility, then it might, but it would not otherwise.

—What I am suggesting is not necessarily one that is a company railway line but one that is developed privately for the use of, for instance, a port, which I guess is, to a certain extent, a public facility. It could be a railway line for the use of freight, not just for one company, that is perhaps provided for under some sort of state compulsory acquisition. Would that not slip into that category?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only repeat that the test is that it must be operated `for the general public' and not be for any private port, private freight, private mine or private transport facility. It will only pass this test and cannot proceed unless it is operated for the general public.

—Minister, you can see the thrust of the question. It is of great concern because all around the country we have a real blurring of the line between private and public. Is the government going to define `public purpose' any more carefully? Once upon a time `public purpose' was a very clear definition, but it is not any longer. I am not wanting to argue the case any further, but I am wondering whether the government is going to provide any clearer definition. The problem is that the blurring between those two is now very significant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot be any clearer than the bill which refers to facilities and services `for the general public'. Obviously, at the end of the day that is a matter for a court to interpret, but I would have thought that its meaning is pretty plain. It is a fact that even in places like Bulgaria and other models of capitalism you have services for the general public provided by private operators, but the service can only be enacted or done under these provisions if it passes that test of being for the general public. I would have thought the meaning of that is self‐evident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be self‐evident to the minister. We used to have a public transport system in Western Australia; more and more it is a private transport system. As yet, the trains have not been privatised, but I guess that will come. A person pays to use a train that may originally have been provided by the government. After a while, if that is privatised, a rail line and rail reserve is a public facility but people will still pay to use it. Over time, whether it is a port, public transport or freight transport which people can purchase the use of, it is for profit.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a facility for gas lines which are privately owned and are for profit, and people have to pay those corporations. Is a reserve on each side of a gas pipeline private or public? There is no distinct line at the moment between private and public use. A gas line, supposedly, is for the general public benefit, but it might be that someone is making a profit out of it. Where is the difference and where is the definition?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assist ing the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose relates to access to the service. If the general public can access the service and the service is not restricted to, for example, people in a company town or only to employees—in other words, anyone can access the service, so it is a service to the general public—then it passes the test. The question of the provider in that sense is relevant, as it is increasingly in the whole world, but to pass this test it must be a service which is available to `the general public'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has just indicated that, providing the public pay, it does not matter, as we have just found out, whether they pay the government or a private contractor for the use of that facility. It is basically open for almost anything, and I can think of lots of ways it is already being used in Western Australia in readiness for this act.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (93) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (line 7), omit "construction", substitute "reconstruction (but not so as to increase significantly the area of land used)".
(94) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (line 11), omit "construction," substitute "reconstruction (but not so as to increase significantly the area of land used)".
(95) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (lines 17 to 22), omit paragraph (c), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (c) it does not prevent native title holders in relation to land or waters on which the thing is located or to be located from having reasonable access to the land or waters in the vicinity of the thing, except for reasons of health and safety; and

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments confine the scope of the provision to the operation, use, maintenance or repair of existing facilities. I think that is still an important restriction to place on this, since we have not won the overall substantive debate. These provisions try to limit the extent of the damage by ensuring that they go to repair or reconstruction of existing facilities and I think it is important that they be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am wanting to hear from the minister as to whether these should be restricted to the activities referred to by Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments have the effect of limiting it to existing facilities. The whole point of this provision is to enable the provision of services to the general public in the future where they—
—Don't we know it!
—Well, it is the proper role of governments to provide services to the public, including to Aboriginal people. That is what it is about.
—It won't be the government providing it. You've just admitted it.

—The government authorises others to provide services to the public. Labor governments around the world are doing that. To suggest that we go back to the communist world that you would prefer to inherit is a nonsense. Even Cuba will be privatised one day.

SPEECH.PARA: This is about ensuring that services for the purposes of the general public can be provided in the future. There is no point in proceeding with this if we restrict it to existing services. We want to provide a way in which services can be provided to the general public in the future on the understanding that it is done only in the circumstances where there is minimal impact on native title—and that is provided—where there is the non‐extinguishment principle, where there is relevant legislation protecting sites of significance, et cetera. The whole point is to find a way to facilitate the provision of these services in the future. That is why we cannot accept the amendments which suggest that we freeze it now, and this only relates to existing services. That misses the point. This provision is here entirely for the purpose of ensuring that these sorts of services can be provided to the general public in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —That misses the point. You would miss out on another effective bucket load of extinguishment.

—As I said, we lost the substantive debate in terms of the overall provision. One way of ensuring somewhat of a balance is to allow continuation in terms of existing constructions, facilities and so on. But if you want to build a new one, then why not ensure that native title holders and claimants have a role in the process? Senator Minchin may not like that, but I think it is a fair thing to ask for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, the significant limitation on this is that they must be acts which have a minimal impact on native title, and the non‐extinguishment principle applies. The problem at the moment is that if you go into the real world where people are trying to provide services to the general public, including Aboriginal people in remote communities, you can find yourself in a situation where you have got to compulsorily acquire native title and extinguish it in order for these services to be provided. That is what we are trying to avoid to enable services where powerlines run overhead or there is a gas line under the ground where it will not affect access to the area, where the impact on native title is minimal and there is protection of sites based on non‐extinguishment. It seems to us a sensible approach to coexistence in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As an example of the underlying principle of this legislation we say to Aboriginal Australians, `Heads we win, tails you lose.' In order that the states do not go off and extinguish their native title in these areas we will just render it meaningless at this level. Great!

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments not agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (96) Schedule 1, item 9, page 61 (lines 23 to 29), omit paragraph (d), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (d) the heritage protection requirements (see section 238A) are complied with.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what you have to do to win in this place, but opposition amendment No. 96 is a provision which tries to ensure effective protection of heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that amendment we share that concern but, as I say, for this provision to operate and for services to be able to be constructed under it there must be a Commonwealth, state or territory law that makes provision for the preservation and protection of areas and sites that may be in the area or in relation to which the act is done and of particular significance to Aboriginal peoples in accordance with their traditions. This would include state heritage legislation. We think that is the appropriate protection mechanism and therefore this amendment is unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to point out that this is also the general thrust of the Greens' and Democrats' amendment No. 88 which is to improve the heritage protection provision by requiring effective protection. I think the moving of it is important but, from the look of it, it might be academic.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment not agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, did you want to persist and continue to move amendment No. 88?
—I think the writing in this instance is on the wall. The government is not interested in heritage protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (97) Schedule 1, item 9, page 62 (line 7), after "facility", insert "that is not a water catchment area".
(98) Schedule 1, item 9, page 62 (lines 13 and 14), omit paragraph (m).
(99) Schedule 1, item 9, page 62 (line 16), after "future act", insert "and the procedural rights conferred by subsections (7), (8) and (9) are complied with".
(100) Schedule 1, item 9, page 63 (lines 7 to 17), omit subsection (7), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (7) The native title holders have the same procedural rights as they would have in relation to the act on the assumption that they instead held ordinary title covering any land concerned or covering the land adjoining, or surrounding, any waters concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: (101) Schedule 1, item 9, page 63 (after line 32), at the end of section 24KA, add:

TAB.TAB: and, in addition:
(e) placing notices, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister for the purposes of this paragraph, on any land concerned, advising that the act is to take place; and
(f) notifying the public in the determined way (see section 252) that the act is to take place.

PARA.TAB: (9) The procedural rights referred to in subsection (7) apply to a person referred to in paragraph (8)(c) or (d) who is entitled to be notified as mentioned in subsection (8).

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments Nos 97 to 101 are, once again, important qualifications to what the government is trying to do. We are concerned, for instance, that when we talk about water supply in the government's proposal we are not talking about the whole water catchment area. As a consequence, amendment No. 97 is geared to ensure that the scope of `water supply' is limited to something more local than a whole water catchment area. We think there are problems with the legislation; it is too broad.

Amendment No. 98 is another important provision. The amendment seeks to remove the catch‐all extension of the list of facilities at the end of the list in section 24KA(2). Once again, that catch‐all provision allows the government to put in whatever they like.

Amendment No. 99 ensures that validation of acts covered by this subdivision is subject to compliance with procedural rights specified in subdivision 24KA(3). As we have argued through this particular part of the debate, those procedural rights are important if, of course, you acknowledge that indigenous Australians have got some rights in the system.

Amendment No. 100 refers to the procedural section. Here we remove the distinction between acts on non‐exclusive leases and other tenures to ensure that native title holder procedural rights are quoted with ordinary titleholders in all cases.

Amendment No. 101 is a measure which probably helps the constitutionality of the provision, although it does not guarantee it. But it improves notification provisions by adding `notification determined by the minister and also public notification'. It also permits rep bodies and registered claimants who receive notice to have the other relevant procedural rights. This is in addition to 24KA(8).
In any fair process these sorts of provisions would be taken for granted. I put them to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Democrats‐Greens (WA) amendments are the same as the Labor Party's, so we will support those. It is the same problem that we have been debating. It is not just railway lines. In Queensland we are about to have two gigantic dams built that are going to severely impact on some pastoral properties and very good agricultural land. So there is not only that impact; there is also the impact on very significant Aboriginal sites in the area that is going to be flooded.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that you could say that there is a general benefit to some of the public, but it is one of those situations where you take away the rights of a whole group of people simply to hand them over to somebody else. Once you give state governments the ability to do that, all of the consultation processes that ought to happen in that situation are just academic. We would hope that the Senate might support these amendments, but it is probably a forlorn hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I make it quite clear that there is no way in which a large‐scale dam of the kind mentioned by Senator Woodley could ever possibly be constructed using this subdivision of the act. That is simply not provided for in any way. The only way a dam of the kind he is talking about could be constructed on land on which native title may have survived in the future is either by agreement or by compul sory acquisition, following the compulsory acquisition provisions of the bill, not under these provisions.
—Can the minister tell us what a water supply facility under proposed section 24KA(2)(h) of the bill comprises?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The only things allowed under this are a pipeline or other water supply or reticulation facility, or a drainage facility or levy or other device for management of water flows. We are not talking about dams or anything of that nature.

—Therefore there should be no problem in supporting amendment No. 89, or the equivalent amendment of the Labor Party, to ensure that the whole of the water catchment area is not included in this catch‐all phrase of `water supply facility'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to make the same observation. I did not how that applied. Proposed subsection (2)(h) says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a pipeline or other water supply or reticulation facility . . .

You want the words `that is not a water catchment area'. When I first read that I could not see how it fitted there because a water catchment area, as I read it, is not any of those things. A pipeline is not a water catchment facility and `other water supply' is not a water catchment area or reticulation facility. I am easy, one way or the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about a bore or a set of bores? Does that constitute a water supply facility?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you look at the list in the bill you will see in (g) it says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a well, or a bore, for obtaining water . . .

So that would be allowed. But there is no intent whatsoever, as I think Senator Harradine is saying, for water catchment areas to be allowed under these provisions. Remem ber that we are talking about this falling within the requirement that it is a service to the general public. So if a community wants a bore, that can be done. Again, it must satisfy the condition that the act, if it is a well or a bore, must not prevent native title holders in relation to the land or waters where the listed facility is situated from having reasonable access to the land. So there are a number of tests that have to be met before any act can be validly done under these provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I am accepting your assurances, but I really would prefer that the amendment was supported. This is the problem I was having in (h) where it says, `a pipeline or other water supply'. If you link that to (j) where it says, `an irrigation channel or other irrigation facility,' it is starting to get fairly close to my dam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, I know you have difficulty believing or accepting things that we say, but I can only say that there is just no way a dam could come anywhere within these restrictions. Again, not only must it fit within those guidelines—and a channel is not a dam—but it must not prevent reasonable access for the native title holders. I know you find it difficult, but please accept my assurance that there is no way in which a dam could be constructed using this particular provision.

—In relation to amendment No. 100 that Senator Bolkus is moving, I just want to go through the logic of having (7)(a) there. The bill says that if the native title holders have their rights on a non‐exclusive agricultural lease, they should have the same procedural right as those people on a non‐exclusive agricultural lease. That would seem to join the native title to the non‐exclusive lease. It seems to me that they are quite separate. Why do you not just leave it at (7)(b) so that it is quite clear that the native title is an interest in the land separate from the non‐exclusive agricultural lease, which is another interest in the land? As a matter of logic, Senator Bolkus's amendment No. 100 seems to make more sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —This touches on a debate we will have in the next day or two. We approached the issue of equity from the point of view of the coexisting title holders. If a service of this kind is being provided across, let us say, a pastoral lease or a non-exclusive agricultural lease and therefore native title may have survived and there may be claimants, then we adopt the approach of seeking to ensure that the coexisting title holders have the same procedural rights. We think it is a fundamental matter of equity that if the land has a lease over it and the lessee has whatever procedural rights that pertain in respect of an electricity facility going across that land, then the native title holders must have the same procedural rights. If it is vacant crown land or something like that they will have freehold title rights, but where they have a native title which, under Wik can be a coexisting title that is subject to the rights of the pastoralist et cetera, where you have got people who are sharing that land and therefore have coexisting rights, we believe as a matter of fundamental equity that equivalent procedural rights are the only way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not seem to fit in with the reasoning behind Wik and Mabo which, as I understood it, said, `Look, what you have got is not so much the ownership of the land as a series of rights over a particular piece of property.' Following from the old English law, it is really an issue of relationships between people where each person has a particular right over the land. It might be that of a lessee, a mortgagee, a mortgagor, or they might have an easement, but they all have interests that, although connected, are separate.

SPEECH.PARA: The logic that you seem to be introducing in subsections 24KA(7)(a) and 24KA(7)(b) seems to turn that on its head. You seem to be saying, `Look, if you have got a lessee and a mortgagee, you cannot give one any more procedural rights than the other.' That seems to do violence to the land law under which we have operated. I am trying to think of some other comparison you could make—and perhaps you could help—where the procedural rights of a particular person who has an interest in land are determined by the rights that somebody else has in the same piece of land. Can you think of another example of where that happens?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that I can answer your question satisfactorily except to say that Wik decided that a pastoral lease does not necessarily extinguish the native title; it may do so, but in order to determine that question you have to examine the rights granted under the lease and whatever native title may exist, and then match them up and see whether extinguishment has occurred or not. If it has not, then to the extent that the rights can be exercised consistently the rights of the pastoralist prevail.

SPEECH.PARA: As you would well know, in the function of our ordinary law, statutory rights prevail over common law rights. It is not a matter of race; it is a matter of the nature of the right. To take a devil's advocate position: you could argue that the procedural rights attaching to the statutory rights over the land should be greater than the rights that are attached to the subsidiary common law right. We are not arguing that. We are saying that, in relation to a government wishing to put a public facility across a pastoral lease, the farmer and the native title holder must be treated equally. We do not philosophically see any other way in which you can sensibly manage coexistence and sharing of land. It seems an eminently Australian, fair, sensible and reasonable way to approach the question of what rights attach to the coexisting title holders on land of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just seems extraordinary. If you are going to build a pipeline along here, for example, and Senator Woodley is a pastoralist and somebody else has a different ownership, if you are a native title claimant—
—I would be happy to sit down and talk with you.

—You would, of course. If you are a native title claimant in Senator Woodley's territory, you may have some sort of procedural rights, but when you get to the next area where Senator Margetts is you get a different sort of procedural right under (b). So if you have a pipeline line going across the state, different Aboriginal groups are going to have different procedural rights, depending not upon their title but depending upon the title that other people have in the land. It just seems extraordinary.
—I assume they were referring to Senator Woodley's pastoral care.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney, it is a function of the fact that native title on a pastoral lease is a coexisting title—you are sharing the land with another title holder. A title has been granted over the land—a lease—which may not necessarily extinguish the native title. That would ultimately be a matter for the court to determine, but in the meantime or until a determination is made the pastoralist is an occupier of the land.

SPEECH.PARA: The native title holder—presuming they have had a determination—has rights on the land as well but in a coexisting manner. So that piece of land is being shared and therefore you have two title holders. All we are saying is that for the purposes of the procedural rights that attach to them they should be treated equally. So when the government wants to put in that service it treats those people equally. If it is on vacant crown land, because there is no other coexisting title and, if there has not been a determination, the native title can potentially amount to an exclusive possession title, which it cannot by definition amount to on a pastoral lease, then, adopting as we have essentially the same freehold test that is in the current Native Title Act, the equivalent way to treat the native title in those circumstances is to equate it to freehold and to guarantee that those title holders who by definition can potentially have a much greater bundle of native title rights should be treated as though they held freehold and have the rights of a freeholder. But on a pastoral lease, by definition they cannot have the same bundle of native title rights, because, to the extent they survive the grant of the lease, they are subject to the rights of the pastoralist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —Shared rights over the same piece of land, and rights of co‐existence, are hardly unique in land law. You might have a married couple as joint tenants or tenants‐in‐common in that piece of land. You might have a lessee; you might have easements running all over the place; the person next door has rights to light so that you cannot build as high as you might want to; then there is a common fence and you have to contribute to the fence. Your children come home and take up residence and they have rights, even if they do not pay rent, it seems to me, or the school next door might be creating too much noise so you get an injunction against them. There are all sorts of rights in the one piece of land so people are coexisting—particularly if you live in the city—the whole time.

SPEECH.PARA: They all have access to the law to exercise their rights but the way they exercise their rights and the procedures made available to them are made available to them in terms of their rights that have to be vindicated and not in terms of somebody else's rights. It seems extraordinary and almost unique to me that in this particular case you say, `You have rights but the procedure that you will have to vindicate those rights will be decided not in terms of your rights but in terms of somebody else's rights.' No doubt we will talk about that later on.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to return to the question I asked in relation to the definition of a water supply. Because I was concerned about that, I checked what was in the bill. What is clear to me is that the definition the minister gave represented, in fact, the other items on the list. That does not actually constitute a definition. If you define `other water supply' in terms of the other items on the list—a well, or a bore, for obtaining water or reticulation facility—you have not defined it at all. Unless you can prove to me there is a section which clearly defines `other water supply facility', I would think that, by law, all that someone would have to do is prove that what they were doing constituted a water supply facility, and there is nothing in this bill that would indicate you have the ability to argue back, unless we come back to this chamber and redefine it by way of amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be remembered that this is all subject to the test that the act must not prevent native title holders from having reasonable access to the land. So the minimal impact test is essential to this. Obviously, anyone interpreting this, if anyone sought to challenge what it meant, will read it in its context. It says, `a pipeline or other water supply or reticulation facility,' so it must be read in that context. It must be a water supply facility that equates to, or is the equivalent of, a pipeline. That is how it would be defined and interpreted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —A reticulation facility, arguably, could be part of an irrigation system. It could be part of a major scheme. I also add that paragraph (m) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (m) any other thing that is similar to any one or more of the things mentioned . . .

So anything similar to a water supply facility comes under that. It does not say `pipeline'. I do not think you have defined it at all, Minister. I think you have left it clear that anybody can argue in the court that that is not defined. Quite clearly, that will also restrict the rights and enjoyment of native title because it is not defined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can go on repeating myself. All these things must satisfy the test that they are for the general public and they have minimal impact on native title by ensuring reasonable access. They must be consistent with the nature of the things mentioned in (a) to (l), which are all minimal impact services which do not prevent—and cannot proceed if they do so prevent—native title holders having reasonable access to the land.

BREAK.PARA: This is all about enabling these services to proceed without forcing governments to extinguish native title in order to allow them to proceed. That is why we are doing it. It seems a much more sensible approach to enable this sort of service to be provided without having to compulsorily acquire native title and then extinguish it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like amendment No. 100 to be put separately from the other amendments. I was a little concerned about it. Since Senator Cooney entered the debate, I am even more concerned about the matter. The committee is perhaps being invited to set a precedent on this matter that it may not wish to see established, particularly when other things are coming down the track, including right to negotiate provisions and so forth. This provision in subsection (7) appears to me, for the purposes of procedural rights, to place native title on the same basis as leasehold. I do not accept that. I do not come from that position at all. The fact is that native title rights and interests have a deeper foundation, certainly in common law, than do the rights and interests of leaseholders under statute.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the minister is indicating that this is for procedural rights only in respect of this subdivision. Nevertheless, I feel that it would be a precedent for later matters that will come before the chamber. I am inclined to vote for the amendment being placed before the committee by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The farming families of Australia will be grievously disappointed that the Senate wishes to discriminate against them in the way proposed. We are talking about farming families who have had pastoral leases on this land and who are accorded certain procedural rights by state governments as the sovereign managers of the land in relation to activities that occur on that land. You have to then determine in relation to native title what appropriate procedural right should attach to it, because the common law is effectively silent on that matter.

BREAK.PARA: What Senator Harradine is asking us to do in deleting subsection (7)(a) is to discriminate legally against the farming families of Australia by ensuring that they have lesser rights than native title holders, when the High Court itself has said that the native title rights on a pastoral lease are subject to the rights of the pastoralist, which is a natural corollary of the whole basis of our laws. Statutory rights—that is, rights granted by democratically elected governments—prevail over judge made rights. It is a very sad day when you cannot accept a principle of equality but you prefer a principle of discrimination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what I am suggesting. You are talking about farmers. When you use the word `farmers', I presume you mean pastoral leaseholders. Their lease is subject to the provisions thereof. Let us face it: when we come to the question of the rights of native title holders in respect of negotiations with mining companies on pastoral leases, I do not want it to be said at that stage that I supported a situation whereby the rights of those native title holders should be the equivalent of the rights of the pastoral leaseholders under some mining act. I do not want to have that debate here.

SPEECH.PARA: The government should understand where I am coming from. The pastoral leaseholders in this instance, which is in respect of proposed section 24KA that deals with facilities for services to the public, should, under state laws—if they do not, they should—have substantial procedural rights. In fact, in my view, they should have the same procedural rights in respect of those matters, if it affects their daily living, as ordinary title holders. That is my view of the pastoral leaseholders. In that instance, when it might affect their interests, pastoral leaseholders should have those procedural rights.

When it comes to the question of native title holders, I return to the Wik decision. If the exercise of native title holders' rights are inconsistent with the exercise by the pastoral leaseholders of their rights, the pastoral leaseholders' rights prevail. Nobody is arguing that point; it is fine. We are talking about a situation relating to facilities for service to the public. If you can get away from that sort of precedent, which I fear is there and may interfere or prejudge somewhat a debate that is going to take place on the right to negotiate later this week, I would be happy to listen to it.
Progress reported.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.28 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assist ing the Prime Minister)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering opposition amendments 97 to 101.
—We had agreed to extract from that bundle amendment No. 100. There was an indication that Senator Harradine wanted to have that treated separately.
—I would like to ask the minister what a sovereign land manager is?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what you are referring to is some expression I may have used. Under the constitution of Australia the states have the sovereign right to manage land. The constitution does not provide for the Commonwealth parliament a specific land management function. That is a constitutional prerogative preserved for the states. The states are sovereign governments. They manage land on behalf of all their peoples. Certainly from the coalition's point of view I think that is something that must be borne in mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is forgotten that the Native Title Act is quite a significant development in Australian constitutional law in that, obviously by definition, it represents the most significant intervention in the land management responsibilities of the states since Federation on the basis of the race power. We are not seeking to repeal the act. We are seeking to amend it. It ought to be remembered that the constitutional responsibility for land management is and has always been vested in the states.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a relief. I thought perhaps you meant someone who had the right to run cattle and sheep, as they do in Western Australia—sovereign over all they saw.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No.100 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now move to opposition amendments 97 to 99 and 101.
—We now move to sheet 8, opposition amendment 359.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move amendment 359. This is a new area that has been proposed by the opposition. As I have tried to say consistently through this debate, we have not taken the approach in this process of just resisting what the government is putting up; we have put up an alternative package. Part of that package is the recognition that to have the bill constitutionally sustainable there needs to be some aspects that balance the negative aspects of the government's legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those aspects, and one aspect which is pretty important for indigenous Australians, is this next proposal that goes to fast tracking. These provisions are intended to be of benefit to indigenous people. They are intended to be of benefit because they streamline the procedure for the recognition of native title on Aboriginal lands or other categories of lands where the character of the tenure is such that it was clearly intended to benefit indigenous people.

These provisions will also have the effect of recognising the access rights of people who, despite regular physical contact with the land, are not native title holders. They involve, in essence, an addition of a new schedule, schedule 6—fast track determinations.

I will go through some of these provisions. It is important. What we are talking about here is land which is generally and very clearly intended to benefit indigenous people—Aboriginal reserve lands and other categories of land where the character of the tenure is very clearly for the benefit of Aboriginal people. In respect of these lands, there is a current problem that unfortunately the government has not focused on. There is whole basket of problems that it has focused on but it has not focused on this particular one which is of concern to indigenous people—that is, very few native title claims have been recognised even over these lands where native title claims are so obviously justified. Our proposition is one that streamlines the procedures for the recognition of native title on these Aboriginal lands.

The provisions would also have the effect of recognising, as I say, the access rights of people who are not native title holders. The proposals in detail are through the imposition of a new schedule: first, a provision that inserts a capacity for a representative body to perform fast track functions on Aboriginal lands. The representative body could, for instance, identify native title holders, identify indigenous people with an interest in the area and proceed to prepare a determination. A registrar has a role, as a registrar should, in this particular process. We provide for the representative body to notify the registrar of details of the representative body's findings. The registrar is then to provide public notification, registration and the handling of disputes and compensation as well as act in the interests of protecting non-indigenous interests.

So you have a process on a particular area of land, which is essentially clearly intended to benefit indigenous people, and the rep body and the registrar have a role in that process. It overcomes the existing procedural regime which has proven to be overly cumbersome, has resulted in inordinate delays and really is quite senseless when you look at the fact that what we are trying to establish here is a permanent legal place for native title claims with respect to Aboriginal reserve lands.

We believe that the relevant rep bodies are pretty well placed to do the work that we envisage them doing. We also envisage that the process would be informal and cost effective and should not be burdened by formal legalism and, more importantly, that the registrar would exercise the most contentious functions of the procedure.

The rep bodies have recognition not just in existing legislation but also under the government's proposal. The government is proposing to give them more functions and this particular function sits very comfortably within the roles of the rep bodies. Let us also appreciate when we are talking about rep bodies that we are talking about bodies which, in the vast majority of cases, have an enormous degree of contact with and respect of the people whom are they are representing. We put this proposal up. I think the government, in the spirit of trying to get a workable regime, should pick this proposal up. In any event, we submit it to the Senate and hope the Senate can see the merit of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a Democrats and Greens WA amendment No. 334 which actually includes, I believe, all of the provisions in the Labor Party's amendment, but it is better because it includes national parks and conservation reserves. That is something which has been very strongly emphasised by the National Indigenous Working Group. It is my understanding that the Labor Party has been convinced by the strength of the arguments.

BREAK.PARA: I certainly know that Tracker will be very pleased if he sees that there is support for the improved version. I hope that this can be supported by the majority of the Senate. The fast tracking provisions do need to actually mean something. There have been a number of changes that we have already seen tonight in relation to what is left of reserves. It is important that these fast tracking provisions do actually assist people working out agreements and do not clog up the system unnecessarily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I verify the fact that the opposition has been persuaded by Senator Margetts's arguments in the chamber before and also representations from a number of people in the indigenous community. There is no real reason we should not adopt the extension and we support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (by Senator Margetts) proposed:
(334) Page 347 (after line 10), at the end of the Bill, add:
Add:

TAB.TAB: (c) an entry made in the National Native Title Register following a submission to the Registrar by a representative body in accordance with its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA).

PARA.TAB: Insert:
(1A) This section also applies in relation to land or waters the subject of findings given by a representative body under subsection 191A(1).
Insert:
(1) If a representative body has fulfilled its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA) in relation to an area of land or waters, it must give details of its findings to the Registrar.

(2) The Registrar must notify the public in the determined way of the findings, and stating that the persons referred to in subsection (4) in relation to the area may appeal against the findings within 3 months after the notification.
(3) If there is no appeal within the 3 months, the Registrar must:

(b) include a notification in the determination identifying any indigenous people found to have a regular physical connection with the land or waters and their recognised rights.

PARA.TAB: (4) These people have standing to appeal against the findings:

TAB.TAB: (a) indigenous people who claim that they are the native title holders and that the group identified in the findings is not;
(b) indigenous people who claim that they should be included in the native title group identified in the findings;
(c) indigenous people who claim to have a regular physical connection with the land or waters and who seek to have their recognised rights noted in the determination.

PARA.TAB: (5) an application may be made to the Federal Court for:

TAB.TAB: (a) an order that the person or persons be included in the native title group; or
(b) a declaration that the person or persons has a regular physical connection with the land or waters and is entitled to continue to exercise recognised rights.

PARA.TAB: After "High Court", insert ", or determinations made following the performance by a representative body of its fast tracking functions (see section 203BHA)".
Insert:

TAB.TAB: (ea) the fast tracking functions referred to in section 203BHA;

PARA.TAB: Insert:
(1) The fast tracking functions of a representative body are to be performed in relation to areas of land or waters of a kind referred to in subsection (4).
(2) The fast tracking functions of a representative body are, for such an area:

TAB.TAB: (a) to take all reasonable steps to identify as the native title holders of the area the group of people who, by acknowledgment of traditional law and custom, have a traditional connection with the area; and
(b) to ascertain whether the native title holders wish to have their connection recognised by an approved determination of native title; and
(c) to if they do, ascertain whether the native title holders wish:
(i) that the native title be held on trust by a prescribed body corporate; or
(ii) to hold the native title themselves; and
(d) to consult other indigenous people particularly concerned with the area; and

(e) to identify any such indigenous people who have a regular physical connection with the area and identify the rights or interests (the recognised rights ) they enjoy (such as occupation, access, fishing, hunting or gathering); and

(f) to facilitate the mediation and negotiation of issues relating to the fast track recognition of native title for the area between the native title holders and other indigenous people particularly concerned with the area; and
(g) to satisfy itself that appropriate arrangements have been made to protect the interests of those other people.

PARA.TAB: (3) If such a representative body is satisfied that the native title holders wish to have a determination of native title in relation to such an area, it must:

TAB.TAB: (a) make a finding to that effect; and
(b) make a finding as to the identity of the people (if any) who are not native title holders for the area but who have a regular physical connection with the area and as to their recognised rights.

PARA.TAB: (4) The areas of land or waters to which the fast tracking functions of a representative body apply are:

TAB.TAB: (a) Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander land or waters; and
(b) areas referred to in paragraph 47(1)(b); and
