(d) areas which constitute a national park or reserve for conservation purposes; and
(e) vacant Crown land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —We as a government obviously have some sympathy for the direction from which the ALP comes in proposing this package of amendments. It is about land occupied by a reserve for Aboriginal people. Obviously it is in everyone's interests, where native title is sought on such land, to have determinations to that effect made as soon as is practically possible. That is why the government proposes to move amendment 45 which is aimed at much the same thing, and we will come to that later. It seeks to ensure that, where Aboriginal people are in occupation of land either by a reserve or by vacant crown land, any past extinguishment should be ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a lot of talk about the constitution. I regret to say that it is the government's view, based on our legal advice, that the fast tracking proposals submitted by the ALP in this provision, as attractive in principle as they might be, do run into significant constitutional problems. I will not try to play politics with this or try to belabour it in a political sense, but the whole point about Brandy was that it was unlikely that the Native Title Tribunal would be able to exercise judicial functions as a consequence of the Brandy decision. In other words, it was not able to make determinations of native title because that is a judicial function, a common law right. A determination that someone holds that common law right and what the right consists of is clearly a judicial function and can only be exercised by a judicial body. That was accepted by the previous government in amendments it proposed to take account of the Brandy decision.

Frankly, there is no difference in the constitutional hurdle facing any suggestion that, in effect, a rep body, by and large, is entrusted with the responsibility of effectively making determinations of native title. That is the effect of the opposition amendments in terms of fast tracking determinations. If there is no appeal against what the rep body finds within three months, the registrar must enter the findings on the register as an approved determination of native title. It is subject to appeal, but I regret to say that it is the government's legal advice—and we are not seeking to stymie this in any way—that there would be significant constitutional hurdles to a proposition that a rep body is making determinations as to common law rights, which is what native title obviously is.

So we do think there are constitutional objections to the proposal which we do not see any way of overcoming. We are attempting to do what we can through our amend ments in proposed new sections 47A and 47B in relation to the disregarding of previous extinguishing acts on land occupied by Aboriginal people. In what we are doing to streamline the whole process by which native title claims are heard and mediated, and also by way of the much enhanced agreements provisions, we would hope that native title determinations in respect of land currently occupied by Aboriginal people can be facilitated by those agreements provisions and, ultimately, a Federal Court rubber stamping, in effect, agreements to that effect. We have no sort of philosophical objection to what is being put here, but we do think it runs into a significant constitutional problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have actually had a chance to assess the government's response to this, and we do find it not only disappointing in terms of principle but also disappointing in terms of the law that has been suggested here. If you look at our amendment to add schedule 6, you see the details of the process. We would maintain that the process we are suggesting is constitutionally acceptable. It is one that does satisfy the Brandy requirements.

BREAK.PARA: Subsection (1) in proposed section 191A gives a rep body a role to make some findings in respect to a claim and give the details of those findings to the registrar. The registrar's function is an administrative one. He must notify the public under subsection (2). Under subsection (3), if there is no appeal, the registrar must enter findings and include a notification. We then provide for those categories of people who may have an appeal in subsection (4). Subsection (5) makes it very clear that, if there is anything to be adjudicated upon, it goes to the Federal Court—application may be made to the court for (a), (b), (c), (d) and, on application to the Federal Court, such and such will happen.

We are quite conscious of the Brandy problems but, in this particular case, if anything is to be adjudicated upon, it is done by the court. It is not as if the tribunal is going to make the adjudication, the finding, which was the problem that the High Court focused on in Brandy. In this particular case, the registrar plays a purely administration role, and any adjudicative function is performed by the Federal Court, as the constitution would require and as the Brandy case made quite clear.

If the government have some concern about this, let them consider it in this context. The fast track provision that we are providing for here provides a mechanism similar to the ordinary ex parte application before a court. That is, when there are no parties with a contrary interest who wish to contest the application, the court is entitled to consider the matter and make orders accordingly after satisfying itself of all the necessary matters. It is a process like that but, if there is a matter of dispute, that dispute is quite rightly sent to the Federal Court and no adjudication is made as to people's rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the constitutional obsession of the opposition, I am surprised that they believe they can dance around Brandy in this way. As I am advised, Brandy was a very similar set of circumstances where the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission made a determination—sure, that was appealable—but the determination, as a matter of law decided by the High Court, had no standing. They are providing that there is a determination of native title made by an administrative body.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole point of Brandy and the whole point of all these amendments is that determinations of native title can be made only by a court—either by the Federal Court under this act or by a supreme court if you are bringing a common law action outside the Native Title Act. You cannot have an administrative body making a judicial determination. If you restructure this so that somehow the findings of the rep body are brought before the court for the court to make a determination, you will have what happened in Crescent Head. That is, effectively, the agreement that was reached with the state government was brought before the Federal Court and the Federal Court effectively rubber stamped the agreement, the determination was made and then the native title, effectively, given up. There was no native title, and there cannot constitutionally be native title until a determination is made by a court. Otherwise, you just run into the whole Brandy problem.

You are just saying that the determination stands. Sure, there is an appeal, but that is just a normal appeal right. The determination has insufficient constitutional standing, unless that determination is made by a court in the light of Brandy. I do not see how you can possibly overcome that hurdle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just put this again. Under proposed subsection (1), the rep body has a role with respect to the fast tracking functions. Under subsection (2), the registrar must notify the public. I will read this out fully:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) If there is no appeal within the 3 months, the Registrar must:
(a) enter the findings—
not a final determination—

on the National Native Title Register as an approved determination of native title stating that, subject to any notification under paragraph (b), the native title rights and interests confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment . . .
(b) include a notification in the determination identifying any indigenous people found to have a regular physical connection with the land or waters and their recognised rights.

These are findings. But I must make this clear—I may not have made it clear earlier: whether there is a dispute or not, the application has to go to the Federal Court for such finding, for such determination. I should not confuse the words `finding' and `determination' here. There could be findings as to some range of facts but, in terms of any determination agreed to or in dispute—and I make this clear again—under subsection (5) of proposed section 191A, that determination is made by the Federal Court.

We do have an obsession with constitutionality. Unfortunately, the government has not shown the evidence that it shares that obsession with respect to some real fundamental issues for this legislation. I say again: all findings are to be made by the Federal Court and, as a consequence of the fact of whether it is in dispute or not—and I hope the advisers are picking this up as well—the final determination is made by the Federal Court. That is one particular reason we think this overcomes the constitutional problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must be reading a different amendment. What I read in 191A(3)(a) is that the proposition is that the `register enter the findings as an approved determination'; in other words, the findings are converted into a determination of native title and that the native title rights and interests confer possession, occupation, use and enjoyment of the area concerned. That is conferring legal rights. If that is not judicial, what is?

SPEECH.PARA: You are proposing that this be done an by administrative body. How is that any different to the Brandy situation? All you have got is a right of appeal to the Federal Court if you do not like the determination. But it is a determination against which you are appealing and a determination which must be subject to all the doubts that were created as a result of the Brandy decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have received advice that this does satisfy the Brandy requirements. Senator Heffernan, it is nice of you to drop in and shake your head around a bit. I do not know if it is all that helpful, but keep on doing it. I would like to seek leave to defer this particular amendment until tomorrow. Given the fact that the government agrees with the sentiments, there may be a way of clarifying some of the language to get to an agreed outcome.
—Is it the wish of the committee that consideration of this amendment be postponed? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Schedule 1, item 9, page 18 (line 15), omit the heading to Subdivision A, substitute:
(14) Schedule 1, item 9, page 20 (after line 26), at the end of Subdivision A, add:

TAB.TAB: The regulations may impose requirements to notify persons of acts, or classes of acts, that are to any extent valid under this Division (whether such notice is required to be given before or after the acts are done).

(49) Schedule 1, page 125 (line 4), omit "subparagraph 24GE(1)(f)(i)", substitute "paragraph 24GB(9)(c), subparagraph 24GE(1)(f)(i), paragraph 24HA(7)(a) or 24JB(6)(a)".

This is a sort of grab bag provision. I regret to say there is a whole range of technical government amendments here. I will go through them as quickly as I can. Amendment No. 13 is extremely technical; it just replaces a heading. Amendment No. 14 is to subdivision A of division 3, part 2, which deals generally with the future act regime. The amendment inserts a new section 24AC which will enable regulations to be made that impose notification requirements in relation to acts or classes of acts that are valid under division 3.

As we announced publicly and to the other parties, this is in response to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee report. While we did not accept—and our legal advice substantiates our view—that notification requirements of this kind were necessary to preserve the constitutionality of the just terms provisions in our bill, we are happy to include in the bill appropriate notification arrangements of this kind without conceding the point about whether they are necessarily required. So amendment No. 14 picks that up.

Amendment No. 44 is an amendment to proposed section 44H, which deals with the doing of activities pursuant to requirement or permission contained in a valid lease, licence, permit or authority. This amendment seeks to put beyond doubt that native title rights and interests are not extinguished by the requirement, permission or the doing of any activity in giving effect to the requirement or permission contained in the lease. Again we are simply responding to concerns about our bill that we do not think are well founded, but we want to put those matters beyond doubt. These amendments do not fit into any other block of amendments.

Amendment No. 47 is simply to oppose schedule 1, item 27, which is an unnecessary provision. Amendment No. 49 is a amendment to proposed section 214 and it lists those instruments that are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A. The amendment to paragraph 214(a) adds determinations made under paragraphs 24GB(9)(c), 24HA(7)(a) and 24JB(6)(a) to the list of disallowable instruments. The effect of that is to make determinations made for the purposes of the new notification requirements in the future act regime disallowable instruments.

BREAK.PARA: Amendment No. 70 ensures that the function of holding an inquiry into certain matters can be performed by an equivalent body approved under section 207B. Amendment No. 73 is to oppose an unnecessary provision in the bill. Amendment Nos 74, 75 and 76 correct drafting errors. Those are the miscellaneous government amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —In the spirit of the arrangement we have had, I suggest that we treat this somewhat differently to what has been proposed. The opposition does not have any problem with these government amendments other than government amendment No. 70. Other members might have problems with some of the government amendments. We obviously do not have problems with amendments that tackle typographical issues and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that government amendment No. 70 is one that corrects a technical error by including the function of holding inquiries under section 139 into matters which can be informed by the equivalent state or territory bodies under 207B. We have proposed an amendment to 207B. We are suggesting that we replace 207B by way of our amendment No. 275. We propose that we replace it with a much more beneficial scheme ensuring that state and territory tribunals do afford native title holders the same rights as they have under the Commonwealth scheme. So I am suggesting that we separate government amendment No. 70 from this provision.

Whilst I am on state and territory tribunals, as we know, the government proposes that states and territories may establish equivalent state native title tribunals. This proposal raises the likelihood of the existence of numerous native title systems throughout Australia, each with differing rights of review and differing rights of appeal. That is of concern to us.

We have already indicated one amendment, amendment No. 275, which will provide instead that the laws of any state or territory must provide rights of appeal and review that are at least consistent with Commonwealth laws; thereby native title holders and native title parties in the state and territory tribunals will not be dealt with less favourably than their equivalents under Commonwealth law. And also, you will not have one particular community in one state being handled and treated less beneficially than others may be in other states.

We are also having circulated—at present, I think—another amendment relating to accessibility to the National Native Title Tribunal. Given that it is not on the table now, at the conclusion of my remarks on this topic I will suggest that we also deal with it later on in the evening. In this amendment, we are proposing that an applicant may be able to choose the national body, if that person so desires, and a respondent may have the same right to choose to go to the national body rather than to a state based body. So, in essence, our amendment will give parties to proceedings the option to go to a national body.

We reckon that is the best way to ensure fairness for all in terms of protecting people against having a differential scheme depending on which state they may be in. It is also the best approach to ensure that the law and the practices that are developed are consistent across the nation. They will be opposition amendments Nos 253A, 253B, 253C and 553D. As I said, maybe we should handle these later in the debate, because people might want to have some chance to look at them.

Our other amendments concern the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. We find it quite inappropriate that the government is seeking in this particular legislation to delete references in the Native Title Act to the continuing role of the ATSI Social Justice Commissioner and to provide in their legislation for his replacement by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. That is a decision that has not been taken by the parliament at this stage. It is one that will be subject to substantive debate when it does come up.

We on this side of the parliament have some concerns about doing away with the specialist ATSI Social Justice Commissioner, and I am sure other parties here would have the same sorts of concerns. Whilst that matter is yet to be resolved by the parliament—that matter does require amendment to the HREOC legislation—we say this item should be left until the parliament has decided whether or not that position should be maintained. In the meantime, let us not pre-empt any such decision with this broad ranging legislation.

The other thing we must say at this particular stage is that, as part of our package, we are committed to providing miners with statutory recognition of their existing right to claim tax deductions for reasonable legal mediation and compensation costs that arise out of native title claims. For constitutional reasons, this measure would be proposed in a separate bill to be moved in the House of Representatives. We cannot tack it on to this bill. However, it is important to put that on the record as part of this debate.

I suggest that we handle two of the government's amendments separately. I would also request that our amendments in respect of state and territory native title tribunals be deferred until later this evening so that people can have a chance to look at them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no further explanation that I need to add because the amendments that the ALP has made to these miscellaneous provisions are identical to the provisions of the National Indigenous Working Group taken with the Democrats-Greens (WA) amendments. There is one section which is not covered by the ALP amendments, and that is amendment No. 267. But with all the other decisions that have already been made on this bill, that is probably irrelevant. There is now no need to move amendment No. 267 to oppose item 88.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments Nos 13, 14, 44, 49, 74, 75 and 76 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that schedule 1, item 27, stand as printed.
—The question is now that schedule 2, item 84, stand as printed.
—We now move to government amendment No. 70.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We will be moving an alternative amendment, No. 275, which will remove the proposed new provisions that will accommodate equivalent state and territory bodies. What we are suggesting is that, instead of that, we adopt a provision that will provide that the laws of any state or territory must provide rights of review and appeal that are not less favourable to native title holders and native title parties than those available under Commonwealth law before a Commonwealth minister can make a determination under 207A(1).

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we provide a national benchmark. It is also important, through that national benchmark, that we provide for consistency for rights for native title holders. As well, I think it is fair to say that the Commonwealth law has the best range of admin review when one compares it with state based jurisdictions. It is important that that capacity be available to parties to ensure adequate review. In many states they would have very little capacity to ensure admin review outside of common law rights. We think the Commonwealth law provisions are important enough to ensure that they are replicated in state jurisdictions before any such jurisdiction can make determinations in respect of native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the government believes strongly in the retention of 207B relating to equivalent state and territory bodies. I would point out that the current Native Title Act, passed by this parliament and proposed by the previous government, provides for recognised state or territory bodies to perform functions under the Native Title Act. In my own state of South Australia, that is currently the case. South Australia operates its own native title system under the auspices of the current act.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the very strict criteria we have set down in 207B are more than adequate. 207B says:

BREAK.PARA: (4) In order to ensure that there is a nationally consistent approach to the recognition and protection of native title, the Commonwealth Minister must not make the determination unless the Commonwealth Minister is satisfied that . . .

Basically, these equivalent state bodies are acting as agents under the Native Title Act. They are implementing and performing the functions designated by the Native Title Act, according to the criteria of the Native Title Act under the auspices of the Federal Court. At all times, matters being mediated or dealt with by an equivalent state body are under the auspices of the Federal Court, and any appeals or judicial review or anything else can be done to the Federal Court. The determinations of native title are by the Federal Court, and nothing in any of this affects that.

This is talking about the administrative functions performed by the tribunal being able to be performed by an equivalent state or territory body, according to the strict criteria laid down by the Native Title Act. Given the growth and the scope of native title claims and the fact that they so often involve state law and parties at state level, it seems imminently sensible and clearly consistent with what is already in the Native Title Act to enable the Commonwealth minister to make a determination in relation to equivalent state or territory bodies, governed very tightly and closely by the provisions set down in this part.

They in no way affect the right of claimants who bring claims under this act to have the claims determined by the Federal Court at all times. This is not a determinative function that is being handed to the states. It is the administrative function in relation to working under the auspices of the Federal Court in relation to mediation and other non-judicial functions that will now be performed by the tribunal.

So we do think these are sensible provisions. We are surprised that they will not be supported by the opposition, particularly in light of what the opposition itself provided in the current Native Title Act and what is working more than adequately in my own state of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this section—schedule 2, item 71—the amendments of the Democrats and Greens are the same as the opposition's amendments. We would also be opposing the government's amendments in relation to this section.

—I take Senator Minchin to 207B. He referred to 86B and talked about access to the Federal Court. Can you explain to us how 207B interacts with 86B? I think 207B is the provision which ensures access to state based tribunals.

—I am looking for indications as to the convenience of the committee and whether the committee wants to proceed. It is the Brandy amendment and is to provide that the law of the state or territory requires a member of the National Native Title Tribunal to be a member of the equivalent body. That seems to me to be a matter that stands alone and I would like to propose that now, if that meets the convenience of the committee.
—You can certainly move your amendment now, Senator Harradine.
—I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: (56) Schedule 2, item 71, page 201 (lines 24 to 33), omit paragraph (f), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (f) the law of the State or Territory requires a member of the NNTT to be a member of the equivalent body; and

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment does have a significant purpose. The new native title mediation regime will require that all native title applications be filed in the Federal Court. The Federal Court will then refer registered applications for mediation either to the National Native Title Tribunal or to the equivalent state or territory body. In the interests of national consistency, the mediation process pursued by the state or territory bodies should be uniform. I think that is desirable all round. That has been acknowledged and indeed desired by the government. In its explanatory memorandum on page 266 the government stated that the purpose of the criteria that it has in fact proposed in this bill for the state and territory bodies:
. . . is to ensure that the powers and functions conferred by the determination on the equivalent body are exercised or performed in a `nationally consistent' manner.

One way of assisting with this objective is to provide that the equivalent bodies each have as a member one of the members of the national mediation authority, namely the National Native Title Tribunal, and this is the purpose of this amendment. It may well be that the person concerned, namely the member of the National Native Title Tribunal, will actually be living in the state. There are a number of members of the NNTT and they are spread throughout Australia. It seems to me that it might be appropriate for that particular member to be a member of the equivalent state body as well.

I recall that certain industrial relations legislation many years ago did have similar provisions. Of course, those days are gone now, but it had provisions which enabled an arrangement similar to the one that I am proposing for the very purpose that I am proposing this, namely for the objective that is sought by the government, to assist in that particular objective. I commend the amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment goes to the question of management of water and airspace. The government does have amendment No. 25. While Senator Minchin is trying to find that I could probably spend a few minutes spelling out the opposition's position in respect of the management of water and airspace and why we will move amendments to this particular provision.

SPEECH.PARA: Recognition of native title in the Mabo decision gave rise to the potential for the recognition of native title rights and interests in airspace and in waters, including offshore, onshore and subterranean waters and, of course, the resources within them. Such recognition in accordance with the common law could give native title holders authority to deal with these elements of the environment as owners, and rights to access and use them as resources. To date, according to the Australian common law they have been regarded as natural resources belonging to no‐one, therefore accessible to anyone. The capacity of the Crown to regulate and manage access to water has mostly been unfettered by having to take into account the property rights in it.

The object of regulation and management has been expressed in a number of court cases, including Thorpes v. The Great Pastoral Company of 1955. I think it is probably worth placing on record the view of the court in that particular case:

. . . to enable the Crown in a country in which water is a comparatively scare and important commodity to exercise full dominion over the waters and rivers and lakes and to undertake generally the conservation and distribution of water. For the attainment of that object it was not necessary to destroy anybody's rights but it was necessary to give to the Crown or some statutory authority overriding rights to which private rights must, if need arise, give way.

In order to achieve the required regulatory and management control, in most states the right to the use, flow and control of water in most watercourses, lakes and so on was vested in the Crown. It was held by the High Court in the same case that such vesting:
ensured in the same way native title rights will not be extinguished by management of water resources by the Crown and may be exercised not inconsistently by that management.

Of course, since Mabo we have in recent years had a new development. There has also been the development in recent years of a move to go national towards regulating and managing inland waters by creating tradeable property rights in water. These had not been contemplated before and the interacting of native title rights and such property rights has not been addressed in this context.

We do have pending the Yorta Yorta case. That particular case may very well decide the issue of whether native title exists in onshore waters and the resources in such water. That is a case which has been going for some time—some would say for too long—but it will be a very critical case in this particular area.

In respect of airspace, at common law the principle is that ownership of land extends from the heavens to the centre of the earth and that property rights in airspace are attached to the property rights in land. However, the extent of these property rights at common law is uncertain. So native title in land which amounts to full beneficial ownership of the land possibly carries rights in the airspace above it. Native title applications have been made for determinations of native title on airspace along with the land underneath.

In 1993, we had the Native Title Act. It is worth putting into this debate the importance of the Native Title Act in the development of the law. Under the current provisions of the NTA, sections 23(6) and 211 ensure that the Commonwealth, state or territory laws which require licences or permits before activities can be carried on—for instance, fishing or hunting and permits to do the same—do not prevent the exercise of native title rights and interests such as fishing, hunting, cultural and spiritual activities, where those activities are carried on for personal, domestic or non‐commercial communal needs.

Further, it is worth remembering that they ensure that native title holders' procedural rights are protected to the same extent as the holders of other rights over the same waters. Also, in section 212(1) the act provides that, subject to the act, a law of the Commonwealth or state may confirm:
(a) any existing ownership of natural resources by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth, the state or the Territory, as the case may be; or
(b) any existing right of the Crown in that capacity to use, control and regulate the flow of water.
As well as that, it confirms:
(c) that any existing fishing access rights prevail over any other public or private fishing rights.

Most states and territories have, since that time, taken the opportunity to confirm these matters through their own legislation, but any such confirmation was expressed so as not to extinguish or impair any native title rights and interests. This is in section 212(3).

Thus, the common law position on the survival of native title rights and interests in water has been retained, of course until we come to the government's legislation. The government's bill will validate future acts consisting of legislative acts or acts being the grant of leases, licences, permits or authorities under valid legislation relating to the management or regulation of the use of surface and subterranean water or resources in water or airspace, where water includes water in all its forms.

The impact of these provisions is likely to be broad and it is something that really should concern the committee. For instance, surface and subterranean water in all its forms is likely to include water in rivers, creeks, watercourses, lakes, swamps, marshes, aquifers and bores as well as percolating water. Resources in water may include fish, dugong, crocodiles, other commercially exploitable species with any associated intellectual property, together with minerals in the water. Further regulation and management of airspace may include such things as pollution, that is, tradeable pollution credits, navigation and power to control access to particular airspace.

The validation of management regimes will confirm government's ability to control the commercial exploitation of natural resources in which a native title holder might have a property interest. This is to be distinguished from the confirmation of indigenous rights to hunt, to fish, to gather or to carry out cultural or spiritual activity as is provided in the current section 211.

Section 24HA of the government's proposals also states that a future act being a lease, licence, permit or authority granted under a management or regulatory regime is also valid. There is a comparison between what the government is proposing and what exists in section 212. The government has pretended that this particular scheme is required so as to confirm the meaning of 212. However, the proposed 24HA is far wider than the current law.

BREAK.PARA: You may ask the question at the start: if 212 is there, why do you have to confirm it? The answer is: because the government wants to do much more than just confirm 212. Section 212 enables the confirmation of any existing ownership of natural resources by the Crown or any existing right of the Crown to use, control or regulate the flow of water. We believe this is sufficient to protect existing management regimes from native title uncertainty. We say also that section 212, which provides that any changes to water management regimes should be subject to appropriate negotiation with native title holders as property owners and stakeholders in the resource, is an appropriate provision.

It is also worth noting that 212 is about preserving the status quo as it existed on 1 January 1994 when the Native Title Act came into effect. The new proposal grants validity to future acts. Its focus is on preserving the state and territory governments' ability to adjust that status quo at the expense of indigenous rights. Section 24HA overrides the right to negotiate.

The other concern with the government's proposal is that confirmation of ownership rights or access under the current provision does not extinguish or impair any native title rights and interests. The new provision renders any native title affected by the validated legislation or interests ineffective pursuant to the non‐extinguishment principle.

To sum up, our concern is that section 24HA in effect puts native title in inland waters in the same position as native title in far offshore waters. It gives no protection at all. There will be no limit on what can be done by government or any person in onshore areas, even if native title exists. For instance, there will be no right to negotiate with respect to any grant of property rights in waters. This may enable the effective extinguishment of native title by state and territory management and regulation regimes.

A further concern is that if grants are inconsistent interests of third parties will have been and will continue to be validated. We are concerned that the total impact of all this will render ineffective any title rights that indigenous Australians may have in inland water.

As we have said, since Mabo they have been a stakeholder. There is a balance in the legislation. The legislation takes into account native title interests, but the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 removes from indigenous native title holders all authority to deal with these natural resources and confers that authority on government.

There is no duty imposed on government to take into account the interests of native title property holders to ensure they are protected. There is no mechanism such as the right to negotiate, which now applies to compulsory acquisition of native title rights in water for the benefit of the third parties. That will not be retained. Section 24HA does not treat native title holders as significant stakeholders in water.

For these reasons, we are concerned about the government's proposal. The existing regime is one that has not caused any problems over recent years and does give some justice. Our amendments go very much to retaining that particular regime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the topic of management of water and airspace, I would like to point out that the position taken by the Greens and the Democrats through our amendments in consultation with the National Indigenous Working Group is different from those of the ALP. They are different because they actually clarify the situation which is currently unclear in relation to the management of water and airspace and native title rights. As has been mentioned, there is more than one court case being fought, and the Yorta Yorta case has been mentioned. If that case were to be found positively for the Yorta Yorta, then obviously what we are doing here is very practical. It actually prevents the kind of thing that occurred with pastoral leases under the Native Title Act as a result of the Wik case and all the problems that could occur as a result of those changes from taking place under a future act.

SPEECH.PARA: The government, however, wants to stymie the situation by squashing that ability—or potential. So there is a range of views expressed here. The government says, `Let's not have this and let's make it clear.' The ALP says, `Let's take out the subdivision and leave it to the courts.' The Greens, Democrats and the National Indigenous Working Group are saying, `Let's clarify it now to avoid the situation of future act provisions that we will have to come back to at some stage. Let's clarify it and say that native title is not extinguished over water and airspace.'

I think that almost any indigenous Australians you speak to can tell you why this is so very important—culturally, socially and spiritually. Anywhere in Australia where native title exists there are special places for ceremonies—sacred sites—in relation to places of water. They could be creeks, waterholes, rivers, seasonal rivers and so on. They are meeting places. They are special. They are an absolutely important part of the storylines of indigenous Australians.If you wipe out of contention the possibility for indigenous Australians to have a part in their management, you are basically wiping out a large part of their cultural life and identity.

I think this might be an appropriate time to ask this question for Robert Bropho from the Nyungah community in Western Australia: what kind of studies, Minister, have been done in relation to this act regarding the social, spiritual and even local economic impact of these kinds of changes on indigenous Australia? We have had quotes about the potential impact on mining investment and on pastoral exports, but have studies been done on the impacts on indigenous Australians? If so, can you point me to them and to the kinds of outcomes there were from the studies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government approached this whole business of amending an unworkable Native Title Act by embarking on a series of consultations immediately after we came to office with a mandate to amend it. Those consultations and inquiries took place all around Australia. Leading up to the Wik decision, we introduced amendments which took the form of draft bills and so on. Then of course the Wik decision meant that we had to go back to square one. But the Wik decision meant that the area over which native title could be claimed had doubled. There was a most extraordinary increase in the area of Australia potentially subject to native title claims as a result of the Wik decision. So what we are dealing with here is a situation, quite unlike that in 1993, where Aboriginal people have the benefit of being able to claim native title on more than double the area of land which was thought to be available in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: We engaged again in another exhaustive round of consultations following the Wik decision to seek everybody's views. We put out the 10‐point plan and sought comment. We put out a draft bill and sought comment. We put out the bill itself. We have had rounds of inquiries—parliamentary and otherwise. So there has been every opportunity for people around Australia to have their view on this matter and to indicate it to the government. The Australian farming community does not believe this bill goes far enough, nor does the mining community, nor do state governments. Of course, leaders of the Aboriginal community think it goes too far.

Having been elected last year as their government, we have struck what we believe to be the appropriate balance in the Native Title Act on behalf of the Australian people. As the Prime Minister has said, we take the fact that it attracts criticism from all sides as being evidence of the fact that we have struck the right balance in this act. Senator Margetts, I am not sure that I can give a fuller answer than that to your question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —From the answer from the minister it is quite clear that no actual study has been done, although we have got figures and quotes of what the impact will be on jobs and exports. I think there is a big credibility gap in what has been said in relation to those potentials; however, it does seem clear that there has not been any considered or funded study into the impacts on indigenous Austral ians. This is quite extraordinary considering this is a bill about native title.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the areas that might be considered to be of spiritual significance and that might end up being taken out of the realm of consultation as a result of this action could include: Todd River; Boobara Lagoon; Lake Victoria; Lake Mungo; Crocodile Dreaming in Broome; inland fishing environments such as the Cooper Basin; Murray‐Darling Basin; Snowy River; Macquarie Marshes; socially significant areas of customary obligation; gathering and meeting places; trading places; areas of access to cultural activities; stock routes and reserves; access areas for ceremonial materials such as ochre; burial sites and sandy banks; recreational and leisure activities, especially those for children; education and camping sites; and economically significant areas for reeds, shells and stones, examples of which include the Mitchell River system, Cooper Creek, the Lake Eyre Basin and Dalhousie Springs.

The minister raised the old favourite about how much of Australia is available for claim, and hopefully by now he has a copy of the maps that my office staff member put together using sources from the National Farmers Federation, Auslig and the Offshore Minerals Act 1994. One of the maps shows the areas available for mining claim, areas exempt from mining leases, areas of lease or open to lease and marine lease or open to lease, and the areas open for native title.

The mining leases must show activity for mining. They take precedence over most other property rights. There is often no negotiation required and mining can be very destructive of the environment and is generally incompatible with other uses. In relation to native title, we have 93 per cent of Australia open for mining leases and we have areas—up to several hundred kilometres in some places—offshore. I will mention that point later. It is only areas such as the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and Shark Bay Marine Park which are not claimable at this stage. Of course, we know there are oil rigs off Shark Bay. We also know that areas of national park are not safe because simply putting it through an act of the state parliament means that those bits can be excised. We know this happens on a regular basis. So 93 per cent of Australia is potentially claimable under mining lease.
On the next map, we find that the mining lease area is potentially much greater than the area of native title; there are some explanations at the back. I seek leave to table the maps.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the committee. Water rights are fundamental to the traditional economies of all coastal indigenous people in Australia. Their right to preserve their access to the sea and to protect traditional fishing grounds is even more important following the dispossession of much of their land, and we will deal with that further when we deal with offshore areas. Inland rivers and waterholes are very often the location of the most spiritually significant places for Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.PARA: What the government is seeking to do is to move to the very heart of many of the traditional beliefs and stories of indigenous Australians. I would like to ask the minister whether the government understands native title rights and interests in connection with water and what water provides to native title holders. I move:
(59) Schedule 1, item 9, page 54 (line 4), omit "section", substitute "Subdivision".
(60) Schedule 1, item 9, page 54 (after line 10), after subsection (1), insert:

PARA.TAB: (1A) If the legislation contains a provision that is wholly or partially inconsistent with the continued existence, enjoyment or exercise of native title rights and interests in relation to the water or airspace, the act is valid if:

TAB.TAB: (a) the provision extends equally to the doing of any act in relation to the water or airspace by native title holders and any other person; and

(b) there are circumstances in which any prohibition contained in the provision can be relaxed, and the circumstances include the grant of permission to native title holders to exercise native title rights or interests which would otherwise be subject to the prohibition; and

(c) before the act commences, the relevant Minister has notified any representative body, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to land or water which may be affected by the act and has consulted with them in good faith as to the purposes and effect of the act, including any as to amendments which may protect native title rights and interests or provide for a relaxation of the prohibition in favour of native title rights and interests.

PARA.TAB: (1B) The non-extinguishment principle applies to the act.
(1C) The native title holders concerned are entitled to compensation for the act in accordance with Division 5.
(1D) The compensation is payable by:

TAB.TAB: (a) if the act is attributable to the Commonwealth—the Crown in right of the Commonwealth; or
(b) if the act is attributable to a State or Territory—the Crown in right of the State or Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: (61) Schedule 1, item 9, page 54 (line 11), omit "Leases, licences etc. ", substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 24HB Leases, licences etc relating to water and airspace

TAB.TAB: Note: Renumber subsections 24HA(2) to (6) as subsections (1) to (5) of new section 24HB.

SPEECH.PARA: (62) Schedule 1, item 9, page 54 (line 12), omit "also".
(63) Schedule 1, item 9, page 54 (line 21), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) Subject to compliance with Subdivision P (which deals with the right to negotiate), the act is valid.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I indicate that the opposition opposes schedule 1, item 9, page 54, line 1, to page 55, line 6, subdivision H.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to Senator Margetts that, as I understand it, there has been no determination of native title over water, so I have no idea what native title may amount to in relation to water; that is entirely a matter for the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that our act preserves the fact of common law; who holds native title, what it consists of, is entirely a matter for the courts of Australia. It is a common law right. You would be the first to attack us if there were any suggestion that it should be converted to a statutory right and defined. It is left entirely to the courts to determine whether, how and in what way native title may survive or exist in relation to water, whether onshore or offshore. I look forward to the determination in that respect as much as you do. It may be that the Yorta Yorta case is the first determination of that kind. I await the findings of the court, along with everybody else.

I have absolutely no idea what the purpose of this map is. I understand that you are extraordinarily hostile to the mining industry. Fortunately, most responsible Aboriginal leaders do not share your hostility. They recognise the great potential for self‐sufficiency and empowerment that the mining industry provides to Aboriginal people. It is the one great source of opportunity in terms of jobs and income for Aboriginal people in outback Australia. It is the absolute

bedrock of our standard of living. Without a mining industry, the people of this country would have a much lower standard of living. We would not be able to provide the sort of welfare benefits that you, on your side of the chamber, always seek to ensure that we provide. We would be a much impoverished country without the mining industry.

Let me remind you that mining occupies an infinitesimally tiny part of the continent. Less than half a per cent of the continent is actually occupied by mining. These resources are owned by all of us. The wealth generated by mining is for all of us, for all Australians, and without it we would be much impoverished. Every less developed and poorer country in the world is desperate to attract the sort of mining development and expertise that we have. It is one of Australia's greatest industries. We are world leaders in mining. We should all be applauding the success of workers in the mining industry, many of whom are blue collar workers who would vote Labor, but I applaud them in their commitment to that industry, and I applaud the success, wealth and job opportunities it has generated.

One of the most extraordinary things about the action being brought to shut down Ernest Henry is that it will affect Aboriginal people involved in that mine. I applaud the mining industry for its consistent attempts to ensure the involvement of Aboriginal people in mining projects. I have seen that at first hand around Australia. The mining industry should be encouraged to, and should continue to, pursue that path. I think it is providing tremendous opportunities for Aboriginal people. So I have no idea what that map is all about. I move:
(25) Schedule 1, item 9, page 55 (after line 6), at the end of section 24HA, add:

PARA.TAB: (7) Before an act covered by subsection (2) is done, the person proposing to do the act must:

TAB.TAB: (a) notify, in the way determined in writing by the Commonwealth Minister, any representative Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander bodies, registered native title bodies corporate and registered native title claimants in relation to the land or waters that will be affected by the act, or acts of that class, that the act, or acts of that class, are to be done; and
(b) give them an opportunity to comment on the act or class of acts.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment includes the notification provisions, which we mentioned before, that we are installing into the act. I would have thought, therefore, that it should be supported.

In relation to this whole issue of water, I would have to say that there is no greater responsibility on the governments we elect in this country than the management of our most precious resource in this country, which is water. This is a nation which sustains and supports over 18 million people and is growing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I was under the understanding that Senator Margetts had moved her amendments. The minister has moved his amendment. I would like a direction from the chair as to which amendments we will be dealing with under that circumstance.
—We have amendments from the government and the opposition and Democrat and Green amendments. We will deal with all of them.
—Seriatim or all together?
—We will deal with them separately. I will probably put them in the order of government amendment No. 25 first. Does that clarify the position for you?
—It helps.
—On the point of order: as Senator Brown was saying, I did not know that you could actually move all of them simultaneously. I thought that you had to move them one lot at a time.

—When the minister rose to speak first, he did not move his amendment at that time, and the opposition did not move amendments. I invited you to ultimately move your amendments. I intend to deal with the amendments now that they have been formally moved by all the parties. I intend to deal with the government amendment first.

—There are two questions here. I do not know whether we have finished debate on this issue. Senator Brown has raised a point of order. The answer to it is that we are having a cognate debate. When amendments are put, they are put in a particular sequence. We will get to them later when they are put. The practice in the area of water and airspace, for instance, is that we will discuss all the different aspects of them. I also have a problem with the sequence that is being suggested. For instance, opposition amendment No. 70 goes to deleting the whole of subdivision H. We do not believe that there should be a change to the existing regime. I was going to suggest that we put that first. If it is carried, obviously the government's amendment will become irrelevant. That is the suggested process. Senator Minchin is nodding his head, so I think he is happy with it. I suggest that we continue with our cognate debates.
—Yes, I can do that. I can put them that way.

—I was speaking when Senator Brown made his point of order. I was going to make the same point that Senator Bolkus has. We have been having cognate debates. Everybody moves their amendments and then talks generally to the subject. The chair, when it is appropriate, moves the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I was talking to the government's subdivision dealing with the management of water and air space. We have become conscious in government that there are difficulties and problems in relation to the management of water and the issue of native title, which we wish to rectify by this subdivision. As I say, I do not think there is any greater responsibility on our democratically elected governments than the management of our most precious resource, water, on behalf of us all. As an aside, I am a supporter of Australians for an Ecologically Sustainable Population because I think the water issue in this country is so critical. I do not see how Australia can sustain a big population with the water resources it has.

From the government's point of view and from the point of view of the responsibility of all governments, there is no more important issue. This is about ensuring that, on behalf of every Australian, water can be adequately and properly managed. The existing act made some attempt to recognise that responsibility. However, in our view, it does not go far enough. What section 212 in the current act does is legislate to confirm certain existing rights. It then states—I think this must have been an amendment moved on the run at the time—that native title cannot be impaired. There has been great confusion on the part of governments and others involved in the management of and rights to water issue as to what exactly that means. We clarify it by ensuring the operation of the non-extinguishment principle in relation to water management.

BREAK.PARA: Under these provisions, there is no opportunity or possibility of extinguishment of native title. In no way do we seek to constrain the right to bring common law claims in relation to water. As I say, that right is protected by section 24HA(4). The non-extinguishment principle applies to the act.

Another concern about section 212 in the current act is that it refers to the ownership of resources but is silent on the question of the management of resources. This is causing a great deal of concern and difficulty around the country for the fishing industry. Amateur fishermen are having considerable concerns about it. The professional fishing industry and other users of water as well as state and territory governments need to know exactly what they can and cannot do now that there is the imposition of this Commonwealth legislation. Section 24HA allows the ongoing management and regulation of water. We cannot freeze this as at the time of the current Native Title Act. That is part of the problem with section 212; it does not apply to rights granted after the commencement of the act. There is considerable doubt about how the proper responsibilities of state governments to manage water on behalf of us all are to be adequately performed.

We do think this provision and this section is necessary to ensure an ongoing future act regime in relation to the management of water and airspace according to the quite clear requirements laid down there, most particularly the non-extinguishment principle; the provision that native title holders concerned are entitled to compensation for any acts; provisions in relation to who pays the compensation, et cetera. Given that the ALP are the ones talking about certainty, if the opposition amendment to delete the whole subdivision H were to succeed, we think it will produce and sustain the current situation of considerable uncertainty in relation to the management of water in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition amendment is seeking to continue the existing regime. It is a regime that has worked for a couple of years now. Your proposals go too far. Your proposals take away existing rights and you have in no way justified doing that. As I said, in Mabo there was recognition of native title interests in onshore water and airspace. As a consequence, the Native Title Act was amended in 1993 to apply from 1 January 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had this regime in place now for a couple of years. In fact, we have had this arrangement in place for over three years. For the minister to say that by going back to the regime that has been in existence over the last three or four years we would be falling into the area of uncertainty, unreliability and the end of rights as we know them in respect of water is really an argument with no substance at all. Senator Minchin, in the course of this debate you have not instanced one particular problem that has arisen from the current Native Title Act provisions.

But, in the same way that you comprehensively tackle Aboriginal rights throughout this legislation, this is a sneaky, backdoor way of trying to limit native title interests and trying to render them basically ineffectual and ineffective. There is no justification for this. Section 24HA, your proposal in the bill, does not treat native title holders as significant stakeholders in water. Let's face it: in many instances, their very lives and livelihood depend on the rights to continued access to the waters we are talking about here.

There is no justification. The scare campaign of `we will be falling into a regime of uncertainty' will not work. Let us keep the existing legislation. No-one has argued with any substance at all that the existing legislation has led to any problems. In fact, it has been quite useful. As I say, in terms of common law rights you have the Yorta Yorta case pending. That case is going to be quite critical. Why don't we let the common law develop? Why do you want Australian taxpayers to pay for the extinguishment of rights that are there already?

These questions you have not been able to answer. You cannot justify—it is not a land grab because you cannot grab water—what you are trying to do here. It is unprincipled, unsubstantiated, and it is going to cost taxpayers when it does not need to. It is a discriminatory act which stifles the development of the common law. That is probably why you want to pursue it, because it stifles the development of the common law. But this Senate should not be in that business. We have a regime in place that is currently working. It does allow for common law in a reasonable way. You cannot justify your proposed section 24HA, which basically says to native title holders, `Just don't worry about it.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the Democrats/Green (WA) amendments. They are substantially different from the ALP amendment. We would certainly want to press those amendments and to vote on them. Let me speak then to our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mabo decision left open a number of major issues at common law, including whether traditional rights and interests regarding onshore and areas of sea and seabed may be recognised as Native Title Act title under the common law. The present Native Title Act 1993 leaves these issues, quite rightly, to the courts. The Croker seas and Yorta Yorta cases, which are presently before the Federal Court, are expected to clarify the law.

Indigenous fishing rights to onshore and offshore waters have been recognised. In overseas jurisdictions, in Canada, the United States and New Zealand, this included rights to take fish for subsistence purposes and in some cases the right to trade or operate commercial fishing. As far back as 1905, the Supreme Court of the United States held that the Indian tribes were not much less dependent upon fishing than the air they breathe. That case was United States v. Winans.

In New Zealand the Maoris have successfully negotiated joint ownership of Sealords Products Ltd, which owns 22 per cent of New Zealand's fishing quota. Recognition of these rights have enabled indigenous people to negotiate with government and commercial interests to ensure that they are a stakeholder in the process. This has included commercial fishing quotas that do not detract from subsis tence fishing. The proper mechanisms are in place to protect certain species and that pollution and overfishing are prevented.

BREAK.PARA: In some cases indigenous people have negotiated a significant involvement in the fishing industry, such as a share of the harvest of certain species. If indigenous people are going to make the contribution they want to make to this country—a magnificent contribution which they are already making but which they want to extend—then we have to give them the opportunity to do these things.

There is a significant difference between our amendments and the amendment of the ALP. I noticed in the Labor Party's minority report that, in respect of offshore waters, the minority recommends deletion, in respect of future action, of the right to negotiate. It seems to me that your amendment does not reflect that view of the minority report. I am asking Senator Bolkus: is that so and why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I can answer that question. Senator Woodley, you are right. Since you were a co‐signatory to much of the report it is quite understandable that you would pick on that development in our policy. What we have said all along and what we will continue to say in respect of our response to Wik and to native title is that we have been developing, negotiating, discussing with all stakeholders to get an outcome which we think provides both certainty and a balance.

SPEECH.PARA: We have talked through the question of offshore water. Let us remember that, at the moment, we are talking about essentially inshore water—the management of water and airspace. We have talked through the question of offshore water. In the same way, for instance, that we would like to see the development of the common law in respect of onshore water through the Yorta Yorta case, we have decided after further thought that we should take the same attitude in respect of offshore water. There are obviously cases involved there. The Croker Island case is the one that immediately comes to mind. Those cases will ensure a development of the common law.

We are prepared to wait in respect of offshore water to see how the common law develops. In the meantime, we are recommending, as you quite rightly picked, not a full right to negotiate but a right of notifica tion and consultation as a basic platform level of rights that should apply, depending, of course, on how the High Court develops the common law in respect of offshore water. We believe that is probably the most reasonable and appropriate response given the circumstances involved, but we are not in the business of cutting off the development of the common law in both offshore and onshore cases.

Whilst I am on that point, it is important to recognise in respect of onshore waters—the water and airspace under the proposal we are discussing now—that we argue that the Senate needs to be consistent as well as we apply a benchmark across the spectrum of native title interests. We have acknowledged in this debate time and time again that native title is nothing unless you have a capacity to be able to claim that title or have a capacity to be involved in a decision in respect of the areas and the interests that you may possess.

In this particular instance, we are contemplating a massive deviation from existing rights of native title holders. We can very easily render meaningless, render totally empty any right to particular waterways or access to waterways if we do not ensure that the native title claimants are a party in the process.

If we are to be consistent, the government's 24HA, which overrides the right to negotiate, has to be defeated. It has to be defeated if people in this place recognise the importance of the right to negotiate rights to native title. It is for this particular reason in this case that we are opposing the government's proposal 24HA. As I said earlier, we maintain that the Senate should continue with the current scheme in operation. I think I have answered three or four of your questions, Senator Woodley. I stress the last point I made in respect of this particular matter. If we were to adopt the government's proposal 24HA it would render the right to negotiate in respect of onshore water meaningless.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for that very extensive answer. You understand my puzzlement, as you have acknowledged. What we do ensure is that mining rights onshore are certainly subject to the right to negotiate. I guess what we are saying is that miners on an oil rig offshore should also be subject to the right to negotiate as miners onshore are. That was the point I wanted to make. I thank you for your explanation. It was frank. Even if I do not necessarily still agree with you, at least we got an answer. That was helpful.

—Can I complete the answer. I should also place on record that when we come to the offshore area we will oppose the government's proposal in respect of the intertidal zone and will seek to retain the right to negotiate in respect of that intertidal area, which was also part of the recommendations of the minority report of the joint parliamentary committee on native title and the Wik legislation.

—I have a couple of specific questions to the minister. One relates to the issue that Senator Woodley has just cited of an offshore oil installation. Can you say whether or not your amendment extinguishes the right or potential right of Aboriginal people with an interest in, say, a fishing ground to negotiate or have a say under the law in the enabling of an oil drilling process? Secondly, can you say in regard to, for example, proposed dams on the Fitzroy River in the Kimberley or elsewhere—because there are a stack of these in northern Australia—whether your legislation extinguishes the rights that native title holders may have, at least in so far as their ability to negotiate, not compensation afterwards, the impact that such a proposal would have on them, their culture and their land is concerned?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume Senator Brown is aware that the current act does not provide for a right to negotiate offshore. There is no such thing. The ALP is not proposing to change that nor are we. We do not yet know whether native title can exist offshore. We are dealing with offshore places in block 11. We are not doing anything to prevent native title claims being brought offshore or to allow that matter to be heard. I think the Croker case will be the first one where that question may be determined.

SPEECH.PARA: The current act, as I recall, basically gives native title holders procedural rights that are equivalent to others, and I do not think anybody is quite clear on what that means. There was certainly no attempt by this parliament previously to apply a right to negotiate offshore, nor are we or the opposition proposing that.

A dam would almost inevitably involve a compulsory acquisition of the area of land required. The normal provisions would apply if that was vacant crown land, then it would involve a right to negotiate in relation to the compulsory acquisition of whatever. Obviously, under the current act, compulsory acquisitions for government purposes do not involve a right to negotiate per se. Compulsory acquisitions for third parties involve a right to negotiate, but the current act does not give a statutory right to negotiate the compulsory acquisitions for government owned purposes. You have to think where it is, what land it is on, who is building it and what it is for. I am just giving you a running commentary on the current act in relation to the matters you raised with us.

There is nothing in these provisions which, of themselves, `override the right to negotiate', as was asserted by Senator Bolkus. It is important to remember that these provisions do not extinguish native title. The non‐extinguishment principle applies. Claims can still be brought through all the auspices of the act for native title and native title determinations made. We are simply ensuring that governments elected by us and acting on behalf of all of us can into the future manage that water for all of us under a certain regime.

There is no certainty about the regime currently operating, and you have only to talk to state governments who have that responsibility at the moment and the fishing industry itself to know that there is considerable uncertainty about what can and cannot be done at the moment. All this seeks to do is ensure that a certain regime applies into the future in relation to the management regulation of water, very clearly, on the non- extinguishment principle and with full compensation for any impact on native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, while I understand you to say these provisions of the government's do not extinguish native title—and I do not think anybody has said they would—the concern I have is that they extinguish a potential right, or a real right, to negotiate, not just the compensation after the act but the proposal. For example, on an inland waterway like the Fitzroy River, I understand you to say that these provisions by the government will extinguish the right or the ability of people to negotiate the building of a dam, not the right of people to have a claim.

SPEECH.PARA: That would have very big consequences for native title claimants or holders—their ability to fish in the locality of the dam, their ability to fish downstream of that locality and their access to sites in that area which may be of great significance, and remember their settlement has always concentrated on water. It goes without saying. Minister, I would like you to clearly tell the committee if that is the case—that is, in the building of dams on northern rivers, the native title claimants or holders will have no right to negotiate.

The second point is about potential native title claims or acknowledgment of rights over the seas. As you quite rightly say, this has been perhaps determined in the courts. I am concerned about the situation where the courts find that native title claimants are in fact able to claim the seas, very important to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Is this amendment that you have here then going to tie the hands of those people in being able to, for example, ward off an oil drill being brought into the area which they have successfully claimed, with all the threats that that means for their traditional fishing grounds offshore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat: the current situation with regard to the right to negotiate is that it applies to mining and compulsory acquisitions for third parties. Those are the circumstances or activities that trigger the right to negotiate. That is the current arrangement. So it does not apply when a government compulsorily acquires land for its own purposes. Under the current act, if a government is building a dam, the right to negotiate does not apply. That is simply a statement of what occurs at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of rights over the seas, we are talking here about management, not extinguishment. We would argue strongly that, if native title exists offshore, it can only amount to a coexisting right, given the authority of governments over the seas to manage them on behalf of all of us. We do not believe it is possible to assert a claim for exclusive possession over the seas, but certainly it may be. In relation to the question of whether native title can exist offshore, we do not know yet but, if it can, it could not possibly amount to more than a coexisting right.

So the law in relation to this matter must take that into account. In that sense, we believe it essential that governments can continue their proper responsibility on behalf of all of us to issue statutory rights to fish, whether it is to Aboriginal people or to others, in their management of the resource on behalf of all of us, but it must be in a way that does not amount to the extinguishment of common law rights.

It is quite clear as a matter of common law that governments under Mabo and Wik have the right to issue statutory rights. We are saying that, where they do so, in accordance with Mabo and Wik the statutory rights prevail. But, unlike Mabo and Wik, in the future those statutory rights will not extinguish native title. That is the case with the management of water. You cannot effect an extinguishment except by compulsory acquisition. You cannot do it by the issue of other rights as such.

I simply repeat that this is a critically important issue for us. We do think that the potential for the fishing industry is enormous. It provides enormous opportunities for Aboriginal people themselves and for the nation as a whole. We are setting down here an appropriate regime for the management of those resources and of water itself into the future which we believe is a deficiency in the current act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a little while ago the minister said that the states have said that there is uncertainty, therefore, we need to act. The states have never wanted Mabo; they have never wanted a Native Title Act; they have always claimed there was uncertainty; and they have always wanted to extinguish native title interests. We do not always have to act when the states demand that we act. What we need to do is take a dispassionate overview and see when they are in the right and when they are in the wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: If you were to take a dispassionate national overview in respect of this area of the debate, you would recognise that in current live proceedings in the Federal Court in the Yorta Yorta case there is an argument as to the right to negotiate in respect of inland water resources. That is a very live argument and it is one that the courts will determine in the not too distant future, hopefully.

States have claimed there is uncertainty and whatever. They have always said that. When the law was laid down and made very clear to them, as it was in the Waanyi case, they still did not pursue the certainty of the law, except for Western Australia, which did so after the Waanyi case. Other states should have done so as well because the High Court made it very clear in that case what the law was. We would not have half the problems we have now if the states had followed the certainty of the law as laid down by the High Court.

This argument about the states saying that it is uncertain does not really wash and should not wash in this place. What should wash is the fact that this proposal cannot be substantiated and cannot be justified. According to most evidence to the parliament, section 212 is operating pretty well. Whatever deficiencies there may be in it, they do not justify this overriding of a potential right to negotiate and they do not justify rendering indigenous interests as virtually worthless in this process. The argument has not been put for us to adopt 24HA in the government amendments. We should stick with the current regime.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
