TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Bolkus whether his amendment would remove fishing rights between the high‐water mark and the low‐water mark of the tidal areas. Could he give me an indication of whether this is the case?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we are merging item 6 and item 11, inshore and offshore water. It is an appropriate opportunity to say to Senator Boswell and to anyone else who wants to listen that we are not in the business of taking away anyone's rights. Wik was about coexistence. Our proposals in respect of that intertidal zone is to maintain the currently operating right to negotiate regime. We are not in the business of excluding and taking away the fishing rights of people who may have them at the moment, as you can see later on in terms of our validation proposals, which do not have the support of minor parties in this place. Those proceedings are also geared towards providing certainty for existing operations and existing rights under the law.

SPEECH.PARA: If you are concerned that we are in the business of taking away people's rights in respect of the capacity to fish, we are concerned—we are concerned that this government's measure will take away the legitimate rights of native title holders. That is something that we think the parliament should recognise in the context of your concern.

Senator Boswell is concerned about fishing operations. That is a legitimate concern. We are concerned about that, but we are also concerned about protecting the legitimate rights of native title holders under a broad umbrella of coexistence. If your government were as concerned about indigenous Australians as you are about industry, then they would be sticking with the existing section 212—they would not be adopting 24HA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one area that is so important to rural Australia so I would like to make a small contribution, recognising the time constraints that we are under. The opposition's amendment removes the government's right to regulate water, which is a right that a lot of people depend on. It is fundamental that the water be managed by the Crown. It is the lifeblood of regional Australia, whether for the water supply for major towns, the ability to interfere in irrigation licences, the food processing areas or the horticultural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I sit here I think of people like Senator Margetts, who has a fairly high income by normal standards with a car and so forth. It seems to be a surreal position here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Surreal.
—I said `surreal'—where people with very high incomes are saying, `We want to stop the development of food processing'—

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Boswell! Would spectators in the gallery please maintain silence; otherwise I will have to deal with them.

—I want to say to Senator Margetts and to the chamber that the largest producer of jobs in Australia is the food processing industry. It produces many hundreds of thousands of jobs for blue-collar workers. The mining industry, which also provides many hundreds of thousands of jobs, needs to be able to use the water as well.
—Many hundreds of thousands of jobs.

—Well, downstream jobs. It provides many jobs. Senator Margetts, I just ask you to be considerate to other people who are looking for jobs—whether those jobs be in the mining industry, in the food processing industry or on the farm. You have a very high income. People out there do need to have jobs so they do not have such enormous pressures placed on them.

SPEECH.PARA: I say very sincerely that water is the lifeblood of regional Australia. It is for common use. To give native title on that will allow people—for instance, in the Yorta Yorta case—to seek a veto right over management decisions to do with permits and licences. Well, we can sit and wait for the High Court to come down with a decision and then we will go back and try to sort out the High Court decision as we are at the moment. Surely, it is better for this government to legislate. This is what we are sent here to do: to legislate and remove uncertainty.

We left a decision to the High Court on the Wik decision. We were all here three years ago when we were told that there were no native title rights on pastoral leases. The High Court has changed that, and we are now trying to rearrange the legislation to accommodate the High Court's decision. But when we are seeing the Yorta Yorta people seeking to veto rights over management decisions, then it is surely in the interests of Australia to short circuit that and legislate. We are sent here to legislate; we are sent here to remove the uncertainty; and that is what the government proposal does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are sent here to legislate but we are sent here to legislate for all of us, as the government likes to say. Let me say to you, Senator Boswell: I am concerned about access to water but I would like to think that Aboriginals are entitled to drink it as much as any other white person. I would like to suggest that they should be able to fish it.

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bolkus! Could those people in the gallery please remain silent or I will have to take action against them. I have warned you once; I will warn you no more. Any more outbursts and you will be evicted.

—They should be entitled to fish it as well as of right. Senator Boswell, your proposal is about taking away those particular rights. If you had been here for the start of this debate, you would have been able to listen to me laboriously go through both the common law and the statute law. You would have been able to appreciate that water management regimes are not being affected by what is being proposed here.

BREAK.PARA: Let me put it to you, Senator Boswell: I hope you are not kicking off another fear campaign because it really would demean your position in this place if you were to do so. There is no threat to existing management regimes from this particular legislation. If there is any threat at all, it is from the commercialisation of interests in water rights. That is something that the national interest should take a look at from time to time. But, under this legislation, those existing regimes will in no way be affected. Those tradeable rights and so on are things that maybe you should start worrying about. Management regimes will not be affected. They are protected; they are in place now. Let me make that very clear for you.

In respect of the Yorta Yorta case, go back and look at the proceedings and then come back in here, because you have that wrong as well. Senator Boswell, you said that leaving it to the common law is something that we should not do because you know what happened in Wik. I will tell you what happened in Wik and I will tell you what happened during the 1993 Native Title Bill deliberations which were going on in here at the time the Wik case was going through court. You were in here and you were one of two, if not three, National Party senators who recognised the possibility of Wik determining that native title interests could coexist with pastoral interests. That is precisely why you voted for Senator Kernot's amendment at the time to ensure that leases could be renewed on same terms and conditions in the event that native title was found to apply in respect of pastoral leases.

You knew what was happening then, Senator Boswell, and I hope that you know what is happening now. Any fear campaign based on an impingement on management of water regimes is something that would be below your performance in this place, and I hope that you do not proceed with that. If you are concerned about people's access to water, stick with the existing section 212 otherwise indigenous Australians will be denied the same sort of access that other people have.

We are concerned about management but you should also keep in mind that regional management regimes include many stakehold ers. They are run by local government and they include horticulturists, farmers and whatever. The only people left out of the process to date have been the native title holders. I think that is of some security in the process as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What the government is proposing here is a total overreach in that it allows almost any action over any water to constitute a future act. It does do what I have not heard of native title doing in any part of the world; that is, restrict the right of native title claimants to claim native title and to have access to fishing. It is just almost unbelievable.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed section 24HA(1)(b) and 2(b)(ii) both say `living aquatic resources'. It would be very interesting to see if what this government is suggesting is that, at some stage, they can envisage—and perhaps the minister can please advise me that this is not the case—traditional owners being in breach of some law, arrested or put in prison for accessing traditional fishing rights. If they do not have access to native title over fishing areas, it is going to be difficult for them to fish and hunt, especially fish. If they do not have access to native title, how could they be guaranteed access to those traditional methods of existence?

The proposed government amendments will deny native title holders the right to negotiate. Senator Boswell, it is not the right to veto; it is the right to negotiate. The right to negotiate is not the same as the right to veto. The amendments will provide only the most minimum procedural requirement available to them before the government takes action which may permanently deprive them of their rights to fish or use waters or to prevent desecration of sacred sites in, for example, wetlands, waterholes and rivers.

This is most significant to many native title holders. On the one hand, there are many locations across Australia where the only likely remaining native title rights reside in waters because the greater area has had native title extinguished by the grant of exclusive possession. Therefore, the proposed amendments will effectively provide the final act for dispossession of those people. How can we find anything in this act which distinguishes the Australia of today from our colonial past? Where is the fair and just outcome for these people in this bill? Where can it be seen that their remnant rights are respected?
Under traditional law and custom, there is no differentiation between rights in land and rights in waters. There is no doubt about that, and I would like to quote Senator Harradine. He stated:

If a right to negotiate . . . is to be enjoyed by native title holders whose country is vacant crown land, that right should not be taken away from native title holders who suffer the disadvantage of having their land subject to a pastoral lease without their consent.

I would like to thank Senator Harradine for those words. Under the same principle, this place must ask the question: if a right to negotiate is to be enjoyed by native title holders whose country is vacant crown land, why should that right be taken away from native title holders who suffer the disadvantage of having their only remaining native title rights removed or affected without their consent simply because these rights reside in waters?

Australia is, in the main, a dry continent and, as such, waters are of essential significance to native title holders. Many people traverse the country from waterhole to waterhole or up and down watercourses and rivers. Water was not only essential for survival but provided important places for meetings, ceremonies and trading between different groups. Such waters provide a very important social role for people, which is integrally linked to traditional relationships, law and customs. Waters have been traditionally used for a wide range of activities—from recreational places and harvest plants to traditional medicines and burial places and so on.

Under the current act, any grant of new rights is subject to the future act regime by which native title holders must be accorded the same procedural rights as they would be if they possessed freehold title. The proposed amendments are a significant impairment on existing rights and are likely to be in breach of the Racial Discrimination Act.

BREAK.PARA: There can be no question that water and places around water have traditionally and customarily been of economic, social, recreational, educational, ceremonial and spiritual importance. People are also traditionally responsible for caring for, and looking after, waters and land around them. Waters and land are integrally related in a traditional way. Remember, the land belongs to the people, and the people belong to the land. It is a two-way process. Any attempt to preclude claimants from carrying out their responsibilities in caring for waters is unjustifiable and shows a complete lack of understanding of native title itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come in, Gareth. You did it.
—I guess if we are talking about the people who are probably richest in Australia and have a particular interest in pastoral leases, I suppose we just heard from one of them.

BREAK.PARA: If we are going to be concerned about the impact on indigenous Australians—the government obviously have indicated that they were not because they did not do any studies—this is probably one of the most important issues. They have gone totally over the top, unnecessarily, in their overreach in this process. I would urge the Senate to support the Democrats-Greens amendments to try to establish some level of clarity in relation to this. We cannot simply act in this place to remove the basic rights which exist in every country where there has been native title established. Fishing rights are a basic part of that right just about everywhere in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to respond to Senator Margetts in relation to preservation of native title rights. We are keeping 211, particularly with respect to (2), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the law does not prohibit or restrict the native title holders from carrying on the class of activity . . .

Those classes of activity are set out. They include hunting, fishing, gathering, cultural and spiritual activities. Those activities are specifically provided for in the current Native Title Act, and that is not affected. This is about the future management of water in such a way that does enable coexistence. It is about ensuring that the non-extinguishment principle applies but that governments have the right, elected by us all to govern on behalf of us all, to manage and regulate water on the basis of non-extinguishment and full compensation for any impact on native title.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are discovering here is, as Senator Margetts says, a very critical component of this debate. Senator Boswell has said that the water is the lifeblood of regional Australia. It certainly is the lifeblood of the indigenous people's interests.

SPEECH.PARA: We also know that we are moving into an area where there is going to be enormous pressure on those water resources, particularly in northern Australia. The minister has adverted to that already by saying that the government wants to have a controlling interest in what happens to those waters on behalf of various interests. But we know that will ultimately mean on behalf of developmental interests and against the indigenous interests.

I put it to Senator Minchin that in the event that the courts establish that there are native title rights over offshore waters, this government amendment effectively extinguishes those rights in big degree. For example, if a government were to legislate that a fishing company had the exclusive fishing rights to waters that had been subject to claim and where there had been a native right established, that would cut right across the essential component of that right as far as livelihood is concerned. There would be nothing the indigenous people could do about it because here in this section, if it passes this parliament, is the extinguishment of the right to negotiate about that fishing interest in the future.

The same also applies to onshore waters, to rivers, billabongs and wetlands. Developments affecting these waters will not be ones that indigenous interests can effectively stand up against. They will be hamstrung. Their rights and powers are cut away by this particular government amendment. There is no doubt about that; that is what this amendment says.

Senator Minchin ducked and weaved to a degree about the question on dams, but if legislation comes through for the establishment of private dams, if private developers are able to tweak the ear of governments and say, `We need legislation to enable us to dam these waters,' this section says that their rights prevail and the indigenous rights retreat. Nothing that the minister has said has given me any confidence that it is otherwise than that. As Senator Margetts said, we are down to a crucial issue here for the future; that is, the indigenous interest in the waters, the lifeblood, as Senator Boswell said, right across that area of Australia which Mr Howard has referred to as `potentially available for claim'.

Now add to that the offshore waters, the sea fisheries and the cultural interests that the Aboriginal people have in offshore areas as well. Under this section, all of these interests, as far as indigenous people are concerned, become subsidiary to the developers of the future. There is no doubt that that is what this section is saying. If we allow it to pass, that indigenous interest will be effectively subordinated, if not eliminated by this government amendment. It is pivotal, it is crucial and we all need to think very carefully about this before we allow the government to have sway. That is why we are moving, in this corner of the Senate, to amend this section, to restore the indigenous interest and to make sure that it is not made subsidiary.

I have no doubt that that is why the opposition is moving simply to oppose what the government is doing because it has enormous untoward ramifications for the future as far as the indigenous interests in those lifeblood waters onshore and offshore are concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I gather there is an understanding that we might postpone debate on this until a later stage. Senator Brown just said that this is all about extinguishing the right to negotiate. Of course, these sets of provisions have absolutely nothing to do with the right to negotiate. There is no right to negotiate now in relation to anything except mining or compulsory acquisitions for third parties. To the extent that there is any mining or compulsory acquisition involving water, then that would continue.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no right to negotiate offshore, there is no right to negotiate except on mining or compulsory acquisitions for third parties now. These provisions have nothing to do with the right to negotiate. We should try to keep the debate on what is actually being discussed. I seek leave to postpone this debate and come back to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the committee that that procedure be followed? There being no objection; it is so ordered.

—Under item 21, miscellaneous, we did handle most of the provisions there, but although I introduced amendments with respect to the retention of the title of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner—amendments 276, 277 and 300—those amendments were not formally put. There has not been a decision with respect to them. I do not think we need to go through the debate again because everyone who is here now was here during the earlier stage this evening. I suggest that we put those amendments at this stage, before we move on to the next item.
—Senator Bolkus, as I understand it, your position was to oppose item 72, 73 and 74 in part 3. Do you want to oppose all of those items?

—That is right. They are the items that delete reference to the ATSIC commissioner and replace it with an overriding general term of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. All those amendments go to basically opposing that change of title and reference.
—You are referring to page what?
—To help honourable senators, we are dealing here with sheet 9. The proposal from Senator Bolkus is to oppose schedule 2, items 72, 73 and 74, and also to oppose schedule 2, part 3.
—I had just put that sheet away until a later time. Could you refer me to the page of the bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —Pages 203 and 214, Senator Harradine. On page 203, subsection 209(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner (appointed under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 )", substitute the words "Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission".
There is consequential amendment No. 73 and, I think, 74 as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I recall the discussion we held. I think it was some time this afternoon. On that matter, as I recall what Senator Bolkus said he was indicating that we should not support those provisions. He indicated that because the matter needs to come before us under the relevant act—that is to say the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986—it would be better to have the debate there rather than in this particular measure.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like the minister and Senator Bolkus to address what difference that would make. What actual effect do 72 and 73 have at the moment in respect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner? What effect would these provisions have?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are asking what effect it would have if you deleted reference to the commissioner, the concern that we have is that it would have the effect of deleting this legislation's recognition that there should be an ATSI Commissioner and that that person should be involved in the implementation of different aspects of the legislation. You could argue, for instance, that by putting the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission there you are, in a broad sense, saying that someone in that commission would have to prepare and submit reports in respect of obligations under this act.

SPEECH.PARA: Our concern would be, firstly, as you said earlier, that we would be anticipating debate in the Senate. Secondly, it is premature debate as well because I am sure the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission probably has not made any plans to pick up any work in a general sense—work that Mick Dodson may be performing now. They also may not be ready to adopt this sort of amendment. Basically, it is an inappropriate place to put it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am confused by the ALP amendments, I must say. I am not sure what is being sought here. As I understand it, they are designed to contradict what we are doing in relation to the Social Justice Commissioner in other legislation. You can move them, but it will have to be dealt with in other legislation in any event, so I am not quite sure why you are seeking to do this here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We are saying it is better handled in other legislation, and we are trying to work out why you are seeking to do it here. A number of parties have put their position on the record in terms of whether there should be an ATSI Commissioner. We maintain there should; the role is important enough. That debate can take place once the government's legislation comes before the Senate. I am sure that, when it does come before the Senate, there will be a whole range of issues that will have to be discussed that go to the relevance or the importance of specialist commissioners, including one for ATSIC. We are saying: let us leave it for that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: At that particular stage, if the government is successful you can amend the Native Title Act as it then stands, but it may be some time before that legislation is actually passed by this parliament. It could take—in a reasonable assessment of time frames—up to nine or 10 months. Until that time we would like to see retention of the position of ATSI Commissioner. We would also like to see on obliga tion on the government to fill that position when Mr Dodson's term expires.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to back up that statement by Senator Bolkus. If there is an odd placement it is from the government's point of view in the way they have put this particular area in the legislation: opportunistically, I guess, to try to take a second bite at the Senate in relation to debate that has occurred already. It seems to be rather strange that the government is asking why we think this may not be the best place for the debate and asking why we want to keep to issues in relation to the Native Title Amendment Bill rather than issues that might be somewhat opportunistic on the part of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —In our amendment bill on page 203 we refer to omitting `Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner' and substituting `Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission'. That is consistent with other government policy and, as I am advised, that is what the previous government sought to do in 1995. That is consistent with the previous government and is consistent with current government policy in relation to the question of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. All that we seek to do in our bill is change that heading. What you are seeking to do, I gather, is override that.

—Is there any evidence or material that would suggest that it is a good thing at this point in time to take away the job from the commissioner and give it to an organisation? You are transferring the functions from a particular person to an organisation. I think what has everybody a bit concerned is why. Is there any material that we can look at to show that that would be a good thing rather than leaving the status quo exist and leaving the debate, if there has to be a debate, as to why you should go from a particular person to an organisation to another time? I think that is what has been put, and I was wondering if there was any evidence that you could put forward to show the reason why we ought to do it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think we should spend a lot of time on this. We are doing what, as I am advised, your government sought to do in 1995 and included in your Native Title Bill. It seems that there can be no objection to requiring the commission to prepare and submit its report. That is a matter for the commission as to its preparation and presentation. As I have said, your government thought it appropriate then; we do now.
—The question is that schedule 2, items 72, 73 and 74 and part 3 stand as printed.
—We now move to sheet 11, government amendments 31 to 34—offshore places, schedule 1, item 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —This goes to offshore places and in this particular area there is some division, as has already been evidenced, between the ALP and other minor parties. There is, of course, major division between other minor parties and the government. What the government's bill does is to adversely affect native title claimants' offshore and intertidal zone interests. It does so at a time when the matter is still to be decided by the High Court in the Croker Island case.

SPEECH.PARA: Subdivision N of the government's proposal is one of the nubs of the problem. That subdivision envisages that any native title rights may be recognised by the High Court and that any native title rights that may be recognised by the High Court can be acquired. This means that this happens despite there currently being no means of identifying which acts will extinguish native title. As a consequence, it would be very hard to ensure that the appropriate notification provisions as required by the broad demands of the just terms compensation provision of the constitution are met.

BREAK.PARA: We are talking here of a government moving to stifle the development of the common law in respect to offshore. We are also talking of a government which is trying to remove indigenous people's rights in respect of the intertidal zone by removing the right to negotiate in respect of the intertidal zone. This, of course, is a right currently existing under the Native Title Act. We are concerned that the government's legislation is unnecessary. To the extent that it extinguishes the right to negotiate, it obviously has a similar effect on the rights that are being consequently extinguished by the extinguishment of that right to negotiate.

The government's proposal will have a major impact on indigenous people's traditional fishing and shellfish gatherings in the intertidal zone area and in offshore places, of course, if the High Court rules that native title to some extent does exist offshore. In short, this can be described as a gratuitous attempt to limit the ability of native title holders to assert and pursue their claims. It is that sort of typical government response that says, `Oh, well, let's just buy them off; money will do the job.' But you do not really appreciate that there is more than money involved here. Native title interests emanate from a whole range of reasons.

I have said that this is a gratuitous attempt to limit people's ability to assert their claims. It also raises a number of inconsistencies. You are trying to pre‐empt the common law and you are trying to override the right to negotiate in respect of the intertidal zone. When you look at some of the arrangements along Australia's shoreline already, for instance, at Shoalwater Bay, indigenous people have under agreement with the federal government a right to continue traditional practices in respect of those intertidal waters. I think it is also in respect of waters in excess of the intertidal zone. Basically what you are trying to do here is overturn that sort of practice.

It is worth noting in this debate that what the government is doing here is in contradistinction to the Torres Strait treaty of 1984 whereby the Commonwealth `protected the traditional fishing activities of the inhabitants of Papua New Guinea and created a protected zone in the Torres Strait'. If the government's amendments tonight are passed, then Australia's indigenous citizens will have similar traditional rights extinguished—rights that are recognised by treaty, rights for people from the Torres Strait and Papua New Guinea and rights that are recognised by agreement with indigenous claimants in respect of other parts of Australia. This government is trying to extinguish those rights in a broad general sense.

So what we are doing is seeking to amend subdivision N to ensure that there are minimum standards for notification and consultation with native title claimants about acts carried out offshore. These standards will ensure that, if native title is found to apply offshore, the interests of native title holders are taken into account and they are properly notified, consulted and involved in respect of any acts that may give rise to compensation. We will apply the non-extinguishment principle to the acquisition of native title rights on offshore waters. We will also move amendments to maintain the current regime—that is, the right to negotiate regime—in respect of the intertidal zone waters.

In conclusion, the government is, once again, trying to stop the development of common law rights here. It is something that we should all be concerned about. It has immediate effect on people's rights and practices.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I mentioned before that water rights are fundamental to the traditional economies of all coastal indigenous people in Australia. Their right to preserve their access to the sea and to protect traditional fishing grounds is even more important because of the level of dispossession of so much of their land. For many generations, governments encouraged sole dependence on the sea as a means of facilitating that dispossession. The same situation applies along inland rivers.

SPEECH.PARA: The special importance of the sea to indigenous people has been acknowledged by the Resource Assessment Commission in its 1993 report on the coastal zone. The threats include not only fishing but also oil and mineral activities. So we are talking about the impact of other activities on those rights. Like the seas, inland rivers and waterholes are, as I have mentioned, very often the location of the most spiritually significant places to Aboriginal people.

We see that overuse by other interests may in fact cause environmental disasters and destroy sacred places—and that can be sea as well as inland river overuse. The development that goes with that kind of activity can also restrict access to important areas. The right to negotiate is the minimum protection which can be afforded to indigenous people, giving them some say in how future proposals affect their traditional sea and river country.

Canada, New Zealand and the United States have each afforded their indigenous people a level of protection for their marine estates which go well beyond that currently existing in Australia. The current act does not deal adequately with native title over places beyond the limits of a state or territory—that is, areas not covered as onshore places. The only relevant provisions are those which allow a government to confirm its ownership of natural resources and to confirm public access to coastal water—that is, sections 212(1)(a) and 212(2)(c). Native title fishing and hunting rights are preserved by section 211.

The need to deal with offshore resources which are or may be subject to native title should be addressed. The bill would allow them to be extinguished without any procedural fairness, or to be regulated out of existence. What we are talking about here is the need to allow native title holders to be heard when decisions are made concerning the exploitation of resources and the granting of fishing licences.

If the right to negotiate is not to be provided, the constructive approach should remain and the indigenous land use agreements could provide that relevant mechanism. In any event, this subdivision, at the very least, should be omitted. It is internally inconsistent. It will apply only to land outside states and territories, but it envisages the application of their compulsory acquisition laws and is grossly discriminatory.

BREAK.PARA: I therefore indicate that whilst I would prefer to see the Greens‐Democrat amendment carried, this is so important to so many of the indigenous people—groups and representatives—we have spoken to over the last few days and weeks that, at the very least, we would urge the removal of the section in the bill to not prejudice and to not have negative implications for future common law decisions and to make sure that people know what the situation is in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I am a little surprised by the hyperbole surrounding this provision, because it simply does restate in a separate division the current provisions in the Native Title Act regarding offshore places. We can put to one side the debate we can have later about the right to negotiate in relation to the intertidal zone. That is nothing to do with these provisions. That relates to the right to negotiate—and we are happy to have that debate—but it has absolutely nothing to do with this.

SPEECH.PARA: The current act does not provide a future act regime in relation to offshore waters. That is the current position. That is continued, but what we do is simply restate the proper regime to apply in relation to offshore places. We maintain the procedural rights arrangements that are provided for in the current act in 23(6)(b), exactly the same procedural rights that are currently provided. The same arrangements apply with relation to compensation. The arrangements in relation to extinguishment are the same in the sense that, to the extent that if there would need to be a compulsory acquisition, that can occur. And that is the only basis on which there could be extinguishment, otherwise the non-extinguishment principle applies.

So it is simply regulating in a different way in restructuring the act what is currently the case. Nothing in our scheme at all determines the question of whether or not native title exists offshore. That is left entirely to the courts, as I say, by these provisions. It is simply restating that the statutory arrangements should apply to the extent that native title is found to exist offshore. As I say, that is entirely left to the courts.

We believe this subdivision should stand as printed. We do not believe there is justification for the amendments proposed. We certainly do not believe that the ALP should now go beyond what it did before, so as to say that the validity of offshore acts should be conditional upon the satisfactory implementation of procedural rights. That was never in the original Native Title Act, and we do not believe that should be done now. It would create massive uncertainty.

In terms of opposition amendment 109, we are simply continuing the current law in relation to extinguishment. Where a compulsory acquisition occurs, that is the only way in which extinguishment can take place, but that has to be possible. Again, opposition amendment 110 is inconsistent with the current provisions which we restate, which are contained in 23(6)(b). We therefore believe that subdivision N should stand as printed and do not support any of the opposition amendments. We propose some amendments of our own, which I now move:
(31) Schedule 1, item 9, page 70 (line 30), omit "(whether compulsorily or otherwise)".
(32) Schedule 1, item 9, page 71 (after line 2), after paragraph (b), insert:

TAB.TAB: and (c) the practices and procedures adopted in acquiring the native title rights and interests are not such as to cause the native title holders any greater disadvantage than is caused to the holders of non‐native title rights and interests when their rights and interests are acquired;

SPEECH.PARA: (33) Schedule 1, item 9, page 71 (line 31) to page 72 (line 2), omit subparagraph (7)(a)(i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) if a law of the Commonwealth provides that a person other than the Crown in right of the Commonwealth is liable to pay the compensation—that person; or

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Schedule 1, item 9, page 72 (lines 5 to 8), omit subparagraph (b)(i), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) if a law of the State or Territory provides that a person other than the Crown in any capacity is liable to pay the compensation—that person; or

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 31 is an amendment to proposed subsection 24NA(3), which provides that native title offshore can be extinguished by a non‐discriminatory compulsory acquisition. A requirement of such non‐discriminatory process is that non‐native title interests are also acquired. The amendment removes the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' from this requirement with regard to non‐native title interests. That is in response to concerns expressed by some that the words `whether compulsorily or otherwise' may in some way be discriminatory or permit compulsory acquisitions that are discriminatory. That is not our intention and we want to clarify that so that what applies onshore applies offshore.

Amendment 32 is an amendment to proposed subsection 24NA(3). The amendment requires that the practices and procedures adopted in relation to a non‐discriminatory compulsory acquisition do not cause native title holders to be any more disadvantaged than the holders of other rights and interests where their rights are also acquired.

Amendment 33 adjusts the provision which allows the Commonwealth to pass on native title compensation liabilities to third parties. It will make it clear that if a law of the Commonwealth states that a third party is liable for compensation, then that third party, not the Commonwealth, is liable. Amendment 34 is in similar terms.

What we are seeking to do is simply to restructure the act to accommodate the existing arrangements in relation to offshore in this subdivision for ease of dealing with this often quite difficult act, where particular parts are spread throughout. This pulls the provisions of the current act together in one section. We believe they are the appropriate provisions and should stand. This has nothing to do with the right to negotiate per se in the intertidal zone. We can deal with that under the rights to negotiate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister said there was no difference between what the government does and what the opposition is trying to do here; and that the opposition is trying to retain a clear field for the common law to develop in resp ect of offshore places. Did I hear you correctly, Minister?
—I said there was no difference between what we are doing now and what is in the current act.

—The opposition does not agree with that. There is provision in the current act. The development of the Croker Island case is evidence of the fact that there is capacity for the common law to develop in respect of native title in offshore places, whereas under the government's legislation, in subdivision N, there are provisions that, in respect of an offshore place, ensure that future acts are validated, extinguishment can be achieved by compulsory acquisition and, in respect of other future acts, the non‐extinguishment principle applies.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest, Minister, that the current law does allow for more flexibility than your provision is proposing. It is for that reason that we suggest subdivision N be opposed. If what you are saying is right and there is no difference between what you are proposing and what is in the current legislation, then why do you spend three pages in subdivision N to affect places offshore when, from what you are saying, the principle and the point is already covered?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Permissible future acts are covered under section 23 of the current act and that relates to both onshore and offshore. It specifically refers to offshore in the course of the section, and that has been replaced. That is why you need the new provisions. They are entirely consistent with what you advocate as being the development of the common law. None of these provisions affect that in any way. As I say, they continue the scheme in the current act by replacing what is in the current act with this new subdivision N so that the current act's provisions dealing with offshore places are together in one subdivision.

SPEECH.PARA: There is general agreement that the structure of the current act is a lot more user friendly with these subdivisions in this schedule that we have been working through. All we have done is simply to pull together into this one subdivision the law relating to acts affecting offshore places. You may want to change your own act, but let us get the facts right: what we are doing here is restating what is the current law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to simplify this matter for my own benefit by asking the minister whether he could give some specific examples of the sorts of acts of compulsory acquisition that are envisaged here that state, territory or Commonwealth governments might need to undertake to purchase native rights to offshore places. Is the government looking at the potential, for example, for purchasing areas so that offshore facilities such as mining developments might be able to take place? Is it looking at the potential for purchase of offshore areas to which indigenous people have native title rights in terms of fishing or is it looking at the potential for offshore places which might be affected by dredging, by the building of jetties or by other works that the Commonwealth or state deem to be important enough to require compulsory acquisition—remembering that this is compulsory acquisition without the right of the native title holders to negotiate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —The current act contemplates the possibility of compulsory acquisitions occurring offshore, as does ours. I honestly cannot imagine in what circumstances a state government or the Commonwealth government would need to exercise its compulsory acquisition powers. All we are saying is that if that situation ever arises, it must be non-discriminatory and it must involve the compulsory acquisition of all other rights and interests in the area concerned. Of course, full compensation is payable.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to mining offshore, the same principle would apply as it does onshore; that is, the non-extinguishment principle applies, as it does to all mining leases. In respect of any mining or development offshore, that principle would apply. There is no suggestion of compulsory acquisition for those purposes. I do not think it has been suggested to us by any state government that it has in mind anything that would fit within this category. As I say, it is a restatement of what is currently the case and what is currently allowed under the act, where it simply acknowledges the fact that governments, Commonwealth and state, have compulsory acquisition powers that need to be accommodated by an act of the extraordinary breadth and impact of the Native Title Act. It provides the mechanisms by which those sorts of powers are to be exercised. As I say, they have to be non-discriminatory and acquire all rights and interests concerned. I cannot think—it has not occurred, as I understand it, in the four years since the current act has been operating—where those provisions have existed in relation to anything offshore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That adds a certain element of mystery to the need for changing the current act which ought better be explained to the committee. The government is saying that it cannot envisage a situation in which these provisions would be required. Nevertheless, the provisions have been brought forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the minister that the government is looking at the potential for a court ruling to find that there are offshore native title rights. This is preparation for state and territory governments to be sure that, in the eventuality that native title rights are found to be valid offshore—this, in particular, includes fishing rights—governments will be able to acquire those rights. I find that a matter of some concern because, to me, it simply appears to be covering the potential for taking away, through compulsory acquisition, rights which are potentially to be found for indigenous people offshore.

It looks to me as though the government is preparing for what it would see as an adverse finding by the courts. It is what we here might see as a logical finding for the courts; that is, that there are indeed offshore rights for native title claimants. Indigenous people do not find a line in the sand as far as their territory, culture and interests are concerned. The sea, the shore and the land are all part of a continuum. It is just in our legislation that we find the need for sectioning these things up.

There has been a question mark over native title rights offshore. That again is a fixture of the Western law mentality. It is quite a foreign concept to indigenous people that there is any division between the seas and the lands as far as law is concerned.

It does concern me that this section is strengthening up any government's ability to compulsorily acquire those rights, if they are found to exist, without the ability of indigenous people to negotiate. Tell me if I am wrong, but I believe that there is no right to negotiate to come out of this amendment, as the government puts it. But if the compulsory acquisition goes ahead, the only thing that can be talked out is the monetary compensation at the end of the day. For many indigenous people with whom I have spoken, that is a very secondary consideration to their traditional rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that there is no change to the act in relation to these provisions. This does not involve a change; it is a restructuring of the act. There is an installation of the current provisions relating to offshore areas into their own separate division. The current act contemplates the possibility of compulsory acquisition. This Senate voted for it then, including the Democrats, the Greens and the Labor Party. I appreciate that you personally were not here then; I accept that. However, you voted for this regime to be there. You voted for an act which does not provide for a right to negotiate offshore. That is in the current act.

SPEECH.PARA: If this bill does not get up, the current act will continue to operate. The current act provides for compulsory acquisition. It does not provide a right to negotiate offshore. It provides for procedural rights offshore to be corresponding rights and interests in relation to the offshore place or an equivalent. We are continuing that scheme. I respect your right to come in and argue that the current act is inadequate in that sense. All I ask is that you acknowledge the fact that we are reaffirming the current act's arrangements in relation to offshore acts.
Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferris, Sen Jeannie

TALK.START.PARA: —Scare campaigns are often based on interpretations of the truth and sometimes on a steady diet of misrepresentations. So it is when there is an examination of the issue of whether freehold land may be claimed under the processes set up by the Native Title Act 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned last week in this place, there are currently 27 native title claims in South Australia lodged with the Native Title Tribunal. It is absolutely crucial to understand that less than a dozen of these claimant applications explicitly exclude freehold tenure from the bounds of their claim. The remaining claims, including those by the Eringa, Kuyani, Dieri, Coultard, Yalata, Maralinga and Yankunytjatjara people, do not explicitly exclude any freehold land that is situated within the boundaries of the claim area. In fact, in many cases, these claims instead include an all encompassing statement that says:
. . . the application excludes any areas which may have been the subject of extinguishing events or, to the extent of the impairment, areas the subject of events which may have impaired native title.

In other words, the claimant group has left the door open—they have retained the ability to subsequently claim freehold if the courts give them that opportunity. The language of `impairment' and not `extinguishment' is used—consistent with the view raised by some of the High Court judges that native title may revive after the expiry of a validly granted title including grants of freehold. I repeat: the majority of these native title claims in South Australia therefore leave the door open to the possibility of claiming freehold title.

So, should the common law at some future point in time determine that native title may survive or revive over freehold land, these claims provide for that opportunity. Of course Justice French's statement last week—and Gareth Evans's as well—confirmed that this is an issue that has not yet been specifically resolved by the High Court.

There are also examples of claims in South Australia lodged with the tribunal that currently do include freehold land. However, the town of Ceduna, which I mentioned last week in this place as being the subject of a native title claim over freehold, is in fact excluded in the detail of the claim, while being, to say the least, confusing on the maps that are available. However, the Nukunu peoples' claim does cover extensive areas of freehold. In fact, this particular claim covers the South Australian cities and towns of Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Crystal Brook, Gladstone, Wilmington, Quorn and Jamestown—a fairly large part of the north of South Australia.
This claimant application states that it is subject to the following:

With respect to any validly granted freehold land situated within the area of the land the subject of the application, the applicants do not claim any native title they or their predecessors in native title may have held which—
and this is the important part—
was extinguished by the valid grant of freehold title.

In other words, they claim native title over all the freehold land which may be eventually found not to have been extinguished. It is significant that this wording is quite different from that in the documents lodged by many other native title claimants in South Australia. This carefully drafted legal phrasing deliberately leaves the door open to claiming all of those areas of freehold land should the High Court at some point in the future find, albeit to everybody's surprise, as the case with Wik, that the grant of freehold does not necessarily extinguish all native title rights or, alternatively, that native title may revive on reversion of freehold land to the crown.

Other claims in South Australia are even more explicit in claiming freehold land. The Dieri and Yandruwandha peoples' claim, lodged as recently as August 1997, purports on the surface to exclude freehold in accord ance with the tribunal's guidelines. However, interestingly enough, the claim goes on to state the following caveat:
The applicants reserve their rights to seek to amend in the event of those guidelines being found to be too narrow in their scope.

That is, they explicitly reserve the right to claim freehold should the High Court find that this is possible in a future test case. Yet another group concedes that this is a live issue. The claim by the Wangkangurru and Yarluyandi peoples use precisely the same wording in their claim and—surprise, surprise—the same lawyers are looking after both parties.

This is a far cry from the statements this week claiming that claims on freehold land have been repudiated. These also sound frighteningly familiar to those of us who were here in 1993 when various parties said similar things in relation to native title claims over pastoral leases being categorically ruled out, to quote the words of Mr Noel Pearson. The existence of these claim documents which have been lodged with the tribunal registrar also show that the tribunal is not properly following its own procedures and guidelines. Those procedures are supposed to prevent claims being lodged over freehold land.

Last Friday, the president of the tribunal, Mr Justice French, released a two-page statement on native title and freehold land, strongly asserting that under the Native Title Act 1993 a valid grant of freehold title will always extinguish native title. Aboriginal activists have also been waving around a previous media release from Justice French headed `Tribunal rejects claims over private freehold'. Even overlooking the heading, which implicitly confirms that claims may be made over public freehold land, it cannot simply be reconciled with previous statements made by Justice French which do not measure up with his latest claims.

Justice French told the parliamentary joint committee on native title that `no coherent theory of extinguishment has yet emerged from the various judicial decisions' and that the possibility of native title reviving on freehold land which reverts to the Crown is still a live issue. It strikes me as curious and puzzling, to say the least, for the tribunal's president to, on the one hand, concede that native title claims may have been made over freehold land and to state that the issue is yet to be resolved by the High Court and to, on the other hand, make strong statements asserting that native title claims simply cannot be made over freehold land. It begs the question: how do we resolve this uncertainty?
Justice French went on to say:
If claims have been subsequently registered which do include freehold, it is because that freehold was not apparent on the face of the application.

The Tribunal is not empowered generally to rely upon information provided by governments or others or to search for such information outside the framework of the application before deciding to accept an application . . .

The current procedures set up under Labor's legislation therefore mean that whatever the claimants assert must be accepted as fact, and is being accepted as fact by the tribunal. It is quite an extraordinary situation, I would have thought, and of little comfort to those families in regional Australia when multiple claims arrive in the roadside mail. How are they to know that those claims may simply make an assertion which simply will not eventually be found to be worthy of the paper it is written on? It is absolutely crucial that this issue concerning claims in South Australia and other states in this country is resolved, as soon as possible, beyond any doubt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to discuss the issue of the caller number display option. This week in my home state of South Australia and my home city of Adelaide the residents are being used as guinea pigs as Telstra trials its calling number display option. One person said to me yesterday that this is the service that most people never knew they needed. Indeed, when Leigh McLuskey on 5AA interviewed a Telstra representative she said, `Remind me again exactly why we need this particular service?'

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it clear that the Australian Democrats are not disputing the right of telecommunications carriers or industries to introduce such a service and acknowledge that there may be benefits associated with an option such as calling number display. Obviously, those benefits might include whether or not you choose to take a call based on the knowledge of who is calling. Certainly it has been put forward that parents would be able to have the benefit of knowing if their child was calling and from what location they are calling, et cetera. I state on the record that my party would have preferred if this service had been offered as an opt in as opposed to an opt out service, but it is going ahead regardless.

We are most concerned about—in fact downright scared of—some of the privacy implications as a result of the introduction of calling number display. We are particularly concerned that the target levels of public awareness about calling number display—public awareness as to not only the service but also the blocking options associated with it—have not been achieved. We are also very concerned that the research into whether or not these targets have been met has been made only selectively available publicly—and selectively available to a point where the result given, I think, is potentially misleading in their evidence.

There are dangers associated with the calling number display service. I would argue that these privacy dangers and concerns might outweigh some of those so-called benefits that have been put forward by the government and by the telecommunications industries, especially, of course, if people are unaware of the privacy implications associated with this service. The dangers can be anything from women's shelters, which have expressed their concerns about confidential listings being accessed by people, or more generally the use to which the calling number display option and its associated information can be used by telemarketing companies and other organisational users. The privacy foundation has said:

CND allows organisations such as businesses and government agencies to keep a record of the contact time and call number whenever a person makes a call. They can automatically reverse match the calling number with either their own records or an electronic phone directory, allowing the organisation to record where someone is calling from (and potentially who they are) before they have even had the opportunity to speak to anyone and without the caller knowing. This sort of use of CND has made it one of the more controversial privacy issues in recent years in other countries.

The Democrats first raised this issue with the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) on 30 October. We raised it in question time on 19 November and the minister has acknowledged some of our concerns and responded to them—not normally in question time, I might add, but normally in a belated form in a media release.

In those releases, the minister has assured me and my colleagues that the appropriate consumer safeguards would be in place and that carriers would be expected to conform to those safeguards. That was before calling number display was introduced. The Australian Communications Industry Forum, ACIF, code of practice is not in place. I think the minister thought mistakenly that it might be in place by 1 December, which is when the Telstra service was due to start. I would not be very surprised if we do not see this for at least another six months. The minister claimed that, regardless of whether the codes were in place, there would be interim protection—that is, through the Austel principles and guidelines—and consumer information and consumer privacy would be safeguarded.

This is a far cry from the original belief by some, including the minister, that the draft guidelines for a code would be available prior to the introduction of CND on 1 December. As I mentioned, it looks as if a draft guideline will not be available for at least six months after the introduction of this particular service. It does not really matter what assurances the minister is giving members of the public, me or my party, because there is still a privacy vacuum in Australia, and specifically within the telecommunications industry. We all know that this vacuum would not be there if we had national, consistent, uniform or enforceable privacy laws in this country, just as was promised by the coalition prior to the federal election.

Indeed, honourable senators have heard me discussing this issue many times in this place. We know that in September last year the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) promised legislation would be introduced to extend privacy laws to the private sector. He said, `I intend to be in a position to develop legislation for introduction next year.' However, as many of us know, there was a backflip in March this year by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), no less, when he stated:
I took the opportunity of today's Premiers Conference to raise the Commonwealth's concerns regarding proposals to implement a privacy regime for the private sector.
He then said:
The Commonwealth will not be implementing privacy legislation for the private sector.

Regardless of the reasons for this particular backflip, or backdown—and I might say I have had very few rational arguments put to me by the government as to why this backdown has taken place—it does not take away from the fact that the government has created this crucial privacy vacuum in law in this country in a number of sectors, not the least of which is telecommunications.

I acknowledge the minister's expectations that calling number display options would not be introduced until the requisite levels of public awareness were achieved. The minister in fact and in writing has endorsed the Austel guidelines. I note that in its 1996 January report, Austel recommended that calling number display should not be introduced—that is, it should be allowed on an opt out basis, and we acknowledge that is the case, even though we would prefer it to be an opt in basis—until a public awareness education campaign was conducted and an 80 per cent public awareness of the following three points was achieved. Those three points include the awareness of the introduction of CND—the displaying of phone numbers—the privacy implications of sending a number before the phone is answered and the fact that the number may be captured by organisational users and how consumers manage their personal privacy by opting out of sending their number through call blocking—line and call options—regardless of whether they subscribe to the calling number display services.

As it turns out, Telstra's own figures, released by the minister last week, reveal that these targets have not been achieved. So less than 80 per cent of awareness in those areas has been achieved. It looks as though we are on track to achieve more than an 80 per cent awareness of the actual introduction of the service, but that does not necessarily mean that people understand the privacy implications associated with the introduction of that particular service; hence the delay by at least two weeks by Telstra of calling number display.

There is still a problem. There is some reason to doubt the methodology and the research that has been involved in trying to capture or attain the levels of public awareness, and add to that the fact that the full results have not been made available in their entirety. I should state today that Tim Dixon, the key member of the Privacy Foundation, on behalf of the Telstra reference panel—who, I might add, note in their press release that a gag has been put on them—outlined the fact that not only have these public awareness figures not been met but Telstra has fallen significantly short of the targets of awareness of privacy implications and blocking, which they unanimously conclude. They have urged Telstra to defer the introduction of CND until the awareness of targets are achieved, and they have stated that the awareness targets cannot be achieved until Telstra specifically informs its customers of how organisations will capture and use their telephone number, as explicitly required by the PAC report.

We call on the government to provide to the chamber all the Telstra results, the full methodology of those surveys, including sampling techniques and details of all questions, and the rejection rates of all those surveys. We call on Telstra to delay the introduction of this service. It is not an urgent service, and it has dire and dangerous privacy implications. We call on this government to do something about the privacy vacuum that exists in our law, to do something about ensuring that we have nationally consistent, uniform and enforceable privacy standards so that the introduction of smart cards, genetic testing or, in this case, calling number display is not done in a way that scares the community or leaves consumers vulnerable.
